And they came, both men and women, as many as were willing-hearted, and brought bracelets, earrings, rings, and tablets, all jewels of gold; and every man who offered an offering of gold to the LORD.
And every man with whom was found blue, purple, scarlet, fine linen, goats' hair, red skins of rams, and badgers' skins brought them.
Everyone who offered an offering of silver and bronze brought the LORD's offering; and every man with whom was found acacia wood for any work of the service brought it.
And all the women who were wise-hearted spun with their hands and brought what they had spun, both blue, purple, scarlet, and fine linen.
And all the women whose hearts stirred them up in wisdom spun goats' hair.
And the rulers brought onyx stones and stones to be set for the ephod and for the breastplate,
and spices and oil for the light, for the anointing oil, and for the sweet incense.

The children of Israel brought a willing offering to the LORD, every man and woman whose heart made them willing to bring for all manner of work, which the LORD had commanded to be made by the hand of Moses.
And Moses said to the children of Israel, "See, the LORD has called by name Bezaleel the son of Uri, the son of Hur, of the tribe of Judah;
and He has filled him with the Spirit of God, in wisdom, understanding, knowledge, and in all manner of workmanship;
to devise artistic works, to work in gold, silver, and bronze,
in cutting stones to set them, and in carving wood to make any manner of artistic work.
And He has put in his heart the ability to teach, both he and Aholiab, the son of Ahisamach, of the tribe of Dan.

He has filled them with wisdom of heart to work all manner of work, of the engraver, the skilled craftsman, and the embroiderer, in blue, purple, scarlet, and fine linen, and of the weaver, as well as those who do any work and those who devise artistic designs.

Then Bezaleel and Aholiab, along with every skilled craftsman whom the LORD had endowed with wisdom and understanding, worked on all kinds of tasks for the service of the sanctuary, following all that the LORD had commanded.
Moses summoned Bezaleel and Aholiab, as well as every skilled craftsman whose heart the LORD had inspired, each one whose spirit was stirred to join in the work.

They received from Moses all the offerings that the children of Israel had brought for the service of the sanctuary, to carry out the work. They continued to bring him freewill offerings every morning.
All the skilled craftsmen who were engaged in the work of the sanctuary came, each one from the task they were working on.
They spoke to Moses, saying, "The people are bringing more than enough for the work of the service, which the LORD has commanded us to do."
Moses then commanded that it be proclaimed throughout the camp, saying, "Let neither man nor woman make any more contributions for the sanctuary." So the people were restrained from bringing.
For the materials they had were sufficient for all the work to be done, and there was more than enough.
Every skilled craftsman among them who worked on the tabernacle made ten curtains of finely twisted linen, blue, purple, and scarlet, with cherubim skillfully embroidered into them.
The length of each curtain was twenty-eight cubits, and the width of each curtain was four cubits; all the curtains were of the same size.
He joined five curtains together, and the other five curtains he joined together as well.
He made loops of blue on the edge of one curtain at the end of the joining, and likewise he made loops on the outer edge of another curtain at the joining of the second set.
He made fifty loops in one curtain, and fifty loops on the edge of the curtain that was part of the second set; the loops held one curtain to another.
He made fifty clasps of gold and joined the curtains together with the clasps, so that the tabernacle became one.
He made curtains of goats' hair for the tent over the tabernacle; he made eleven curtains in total.
The length of each curtain was thirty cubits, and the width of each curtain was four cubits; the eleven curtains were all of the same size.
He joined five curtains together by themselves, and six curtains together by themselves.
He made fifty loops on the outer edge of the curtain in the joining, and fifty loops on the edge of the curtain that was part of the second set.
He made fifty clasps of bronze to join the tent together, so that it might be one.
He made a covering for the tent of rams' skins dyed red, and a covering of badgers' skins above that.
He made boards for the tabernacle from acacia wood, standing upright.
The length of each board was ten cubits, and the width of each board was one and a half cubits.
Each board had two tenons, equally spaced; he made this for all the boards of the tabernacle.
He made twenty boards for the south side of the tabernacle.
He made forty silver sockets under the twenty boards; two sockets under one board for its two tenons, and two sockets under another board for its two tenons.
For the other side of the tabernacle, which faces the north, he made twenty boards.
He made forty silver sockets; two sockets under one board, and two sockets under another board.
For the west side of the tabernacle, he made six boards.
He made two boards for the corners of the tabernacle at the two sides.
They were joined at the bottom and connected together at the top with one ring; he did this for both corners.
There were eight boards, and their sixteen silver sockets, with two sockets under each board.
He made bars of acacia wood; five for the boards on one side of the tabernacle,
five bars for the boards on the other side of the tabernacle, and five bars for the boards on the west side of the tabernacle.
He made the middle bar to extend through the boards from one end to the other.
He overlaid the boards with gold, made their rings of gold to hold the bars, and overlaid the bars with gold.
He made a veil of blue, purple, and scarlet, and fine twisted linen, with cherubim skillfully embroidered into it.
He made four pillars of acacia wood and overlaid them with gold; their hooks were of gold, and he cast for them four silver sockets.
He made a hanging for the door of the tabernacle of blue, purple, and scarlet, and fine twisted linen, crafted with needlework.
He made five pillars for it with their hooks, overlaid their capitals and bands with gold, but their five sockets were made of bronze.
And Bezaleel crafted the ark from acacia wood: its length was two and a half cubits, its breadth was one and a half cubits, and its height was also one and a half cubits.
He overlaid it with pure gold, both inside and out, and fashioned a gold crown around it.
He cast four gold rings for it, placing them at the four corners; two rings on one side and two rings on the opposite side.
He made staves from acacia wood and overlaid them with gold.
He inserted the staves into the rings on the sides of the ark to carry it.
He constructed the mercy seat from pure gold: its length was two and a half cubits, and its breadth was one and a half cubits.
He made two cherubim of gold, hammered from a single piece, positioned at the two ends of the mercy seat;
One cherub at one end and another cherub at the other end: the cherubim were made from the mercy seat at its two ends.
The cherubim spread their wings upward, covering the mercy seat with their wings, facing each other; their faces were directed toward the mercy seat.
He made the table from acacia wood: its length was two cubits, its breadth was one cubit, and its height was one and a half cubits.
He overlaid it with pure gold and created a gold crown around it.
He also made a border of a handbreadth around it and fashioned a gold crown for the border.
He cast four gold rings for it and placed the rings on the four corners at its four feet.
The rings were positioned opposite the border, serving as places for the staves to carry the table.
He made the staves from acacia wood and overlaid them with gold to carry the table.
He crafted the vessels for the table: his dishes, spoons, bowls, and covers, all made of pure gold.
He made the candlestick from pure gold: it was crafted from beaten work, including its shaft, branches, bowls, knobs, and flowers, all of the same material.
It had six branches extending from its sides; three branches on one side and three branches on the other side.
Each branch had three bowls shaped like almonds, along with a knop and a flower; this pattern continued throughout the six branches of the candlestick.
The candlestick itself had four bowls shaped like almonds, along with its knobs and flowers.
There was a knop beneath two branches, another knop beneath two branches, and a third knop beneath two branches, corresponding to the six branches extending from it.
All the knobs and branches were of the same design: everything was a single beaten work of pure gold.
He made seven lamps, along with snuffers and snuff dishes, all from pure gold.
He crafted it from a talent of pure gold, including all its vessels.
He made the incense altar from acacia wood: its length was one cubit, its breadth was one cubit; it was square, and its height was two cubits; its horns were of the same material.
He overlaid it with pure gold, covering both the top and the sides all around, including the horns; he also made a gold crown around it.
He fashioned two gold rings for it beneath its crown, at the two corners on its sides, to serve as places for the staves to carry it.
He made the staves from acacia wood and overlaid them with gold.
He prepared the holy anointing oil and the pure incense of sweet spices, crafted according to the work of a perfumer.
He constructed the altar of burnt offering using shittim wood, measuring five cubits in length and five cubits in breadth; it was square and three cubits high.
He fashioned horns for the altar at its four corners, made from the same material, and overlaid it with brass.
He created all the vessels for the altar, including pots, shovels, basins, fleshhooks, and firepans, all made of brass.
He designed a brass grate of network for the altar, positioned beneath it, extending to its middle.
He cast four rings for the four corners of the brass grate, serving as places for the staves.
He made the staves from shittim wood and overlaid them with brass.
He inserted the staves into the rings on the sides of the altar for transport; the altar was constructed hollow with boards.
He crafted a laver of brass, along with its foot, made from the looking glasses of the women who assembled at the entrance of the tabernacle of the congregation.
He built the court: on the south side, the hangings were made of fine twined linen, measuring one hundred cubits.
There were twenty pillars with twenty brass sockets; the hooks of the pillars and their fillets were made of silver.
For the north side, the hangings also measured one hundred cubits, with twenty pillars and twenty brass sockets; the hooks and fillets were silver.
The west side featured hangings of fifty cubits, supported by ten pillars and ten sockets; the hooks and fillets were silver.
The east side measured fifty cubits.
The hangings on one side of the gate were fifteen cubits, with three pillars and three sockets.
On the opposite side of the court gate, there were also hangings of fifteen cubits, with three pillars and three sockets.
All the hangings surrounding the court were made of fine twined linen.
The sockets for the pillars were brass; the hooks and fillets of the pillars were silver, with silver overlay on their chapiters, and all the pillars of the court were filleted with silver.

The hanging for the gate of the court was intricately designed, made of blue, purple, scarlet, and fine twined linen, measuring twenty cubits in length and five cubits in height, matching the hangings of the court.
There were four pillars with four brass sockets; their hooks were silver, and their chapiters and fillets were also silver.
All the pins for the tabernacle and the surrounding court were made of brass.

This is the total for the tabernacle, known as the tabernacle of testimony, as it was accounted for according to Moses' command, for the service of the Levites, by the hand of Ithamar, son of Aaron the priest.
Bezaleel, son of Uri, son of Hur, from the tribe of Judah, made everything the LORD commanded Moses.
Alongside him was Aholiab, son of Ahisamach, from the tribe of Dan, an engraver, skilled craftsman, and embroiderer in blue, purple, scarlet, and fine linen.
The total gold used for the work in the holy place, including the gold from the offerings, amounted to twenty-nine talents and seven hundred thirty shekels, according to the sanctuary's shekel.
The silver from those counted in the congregation totaled one hundred talents and one thousand seven hundred sixty-five shekels, according to the sanctuary's shekel.

Each man contributed a bekah, which is half a shekel, according to the sanctuary's shekel, for every individual counted, from twenty years old and upward, totaling six hundred three thousand five hundred fifty men.
From the one hundred talents of silver, they cast the sockets for the sanctuary and the sockets for the veil; one hundred sockets were made, one talent for each socket.
From the one thousand seven hundred seventy-five shekels, he made hooks for the pillars, overlaid their chapiters, and filleted them.
The brass from the offerings amounted to seventy talents and two thousand four hundred shekels.
With this brass, he made the sockets for the door of the tabernacle of the congregation, the brass altar, the brass grate for it, and all the vessels of the altar.
He also made the sockets for the court surrounding it, the sockets for the court gate, and all the pins for the tabernacle and the court.
And from the blue, purple, and scarlet, they crafted cloths for service in the holy place and made the sacred garments for Aaron, as the LORD instructed Moses.
He constructed the ephod using gold, blue, purple, scarlet, and fine twined linen.
They hammered the gold into thin sheets and cut it into wires to work with the blue, purple, scarlet, and fine linen, employing skilled craftsmanship.
They created shoulder pieces for it to join it together; it was coupled at the two edges.
The intricate girdle of his ephod, which was on it, was made of the same materials, according to its design: gold, blue, purple, scarlet, and fine twined linen, as the LORD commanded Moses.
They fashioned onyx stones set in gold settings, engraved like signets, with the names of the children of Israel.
He placed them on the shoulders of the ephod to serve as memorial stones for the children of Israel, as the LORD commanded Moses.
He made the breastplate with skilled craftsmanship, similar to the ephod, using gold, blue, purple, scarlet, and fine twined linen.
It was square; they made the breastplate double: a span was its length, and a span was its breadth, being doubled.
They set four rows of stones in it: the first row contained a sardius, a topaz, and a carbuncle; this was the first row.
The second row included an emerald, a sapphire, and a diamond.
The third row featured a ligure, an agate, and an amethyst.
The fourth row had a beryl, an onyx, and a jasper; they were set in gold settings.
The stones were named after the children of Israel, twelve in total, each engraved with his name, corresponding to the twelve tribes.
They made chains for the breastplate at its ends, crafted from pure gold.
They created two gold settings and two gold rings, placing the rings at the two ends of the breastplate.
They attached the two gold chains to the rings at the ends of the breastplate.
The ends of the two gold chains were fastened to the two settings and placed on the shoulder pieces of the ephod, in front of it.
They made two gold rings and placed them on the two ends of the breastplate, on the border that was on the side of the ephod inward.
They made two additional gold rings and placed them on the two sides of the ephod underneath, toward the front, opposite the other coupling, above the intricate girdle of the ephod.

They bound the breastplate to the rings of the ephod with a blue lace, ensuring it was above the intricate girdle of the ephod, so the breastplate would not be loosened from the ephod, as the LORD commanded Moses.
He made the robe of the ephod from woven work, entirely blue.
There was an opening in the center of the robe, like the opening of a coat of armor, with a band around the opening to prevent it from tearing.
They made pomegranates of blue, purple, and scarlet, and twined linen on the hems of the robe.
They crafted bells of pure gold and placed them between the pomegranates on the hem of the robe, all around between the pomegranates;
A bell and a pomegranate, a bell and a pomegranate, all around the hem of the robe for ministering, as the LORD commanded Moses.
They made fine linen tunics for Aaron and his sons,
And a mitre of fine linen, along with beautiful bonnets of fine linen, and linen breeches of fine twined linen,
And a girdle of fine twined linen, blue, purple, and scarlet, crafted with needlework, as the LORD commanded Moses.
They made the plate of the holy crown from pure gold and inscribed on it a writing, similar to the engravings of a signet: HOLINESS TO THE LORD.
They attached a blue lace to it, to fasten it high upon the mitre, as the LORD commanded Moses.
Thus, all the work of the tabernacle of the tent of meeting was completed: and the children of Israel did everything the LORD commanded Moses, so they did.
They brought the tabernacle to Moses, the tent, and all its furnishings, including its clasps, boards, bars, pillars, and sockets,
And the covering of rams' skins dyed red, the covering of badger skins, and the veil of the covering,
The ark of the testimony, its staves, and the mercy seat,
The table and all its vessels, and the showbread,
The pure lampstand with its lamps, arranged to be set in order, along with all its vessels and the oil for light,
And the golden altar, the anointing oil, the sweet incense, and the hanging for the tabernacle door,
The bronze altar, its grate of bronze, its staves, and all its vessels, the laver and its base,
The hangings of the court, its pillars, and sockets, the hanging for the court gate, its cords, pins, and all the vessels for the service of the tabernacle, for the tent of meeting,
The cloths for service in the holy place, the holy garments for Aaron the priest, and the garments for his sons to minister in the priest's office.
According to all that the LORD commanded Moses, so the children of Israel completed all the work.
Moses inspected all the work, and behold, they had done it as the LORD commanded; they had completed it, and Moses blessed them.
And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
On the first day of the first month, you shall set up the tabernacle of the tent of meeting.
And you shall place the ark of the testimony inside, and cover the ark with the veil.
You shall bring in the table and arrange the items that are to be placed on it; and you shall bring in the lampstand and light its lamps.
You shall set the golden altar for incense before the ark of the testimony, and hang the door to the tabernacle.
You shall place the altar of burnt offering before the door of the tabernacle of the tent of meeting.
You shall set the laver between the tent of meeting and the altar, and put water in it.
You shall set up the courtyard around it and hang the curtain at the courtyard gate.
You shall take the anointing oil and anoint the tabernacle and everything in it, and consecrate it and all its vessels: it shall be holy.
You shall anoint the altar of burnt offering and all its utensils, and sanctify the altar: it shall be most holy.
You shall anoint the laver and its base, and sanctify it.
You shall bring Aaron and his sons to the entrance of the tabernacle of meeting and wash them with water.
You shall put the holy garments on Aaron, anoint him, and consecrate him; that he may minister to me as a priest.
You shall bring his sons and clothe them with tunics.
You shall anoint them, as you anointed their father, so that they may minister to me as priests: their anointing shall be an everlasting priesthood throughout their generations.
Thus Moses did: according to all that the LORD commanded him, so he did.
And it came to pass in the first month of the second year, on the first day of the month, that the tabernacle was erected.
Moses erected the tabernacle, fastened its sockets, set up its boards, put in its bars, and raised its pillars.
He spread the tent over the tabernacle and placed the covering of the tent above it; as the LORD commanded Moses.
He took the testimony and placed it in the ark, set the poles on the ark, and put the mercy seat on top of the ark.
He brought the ark into the tabernacle, set up the veil of the covering, and covered the ark of the testimony; as the LORD commanded Moses.
He placed the table in the tent of meeting, on the north side of the tabernacle, outside the veil.
He arranged the bread on it before the LORD; as the LORD had commanded Moses.
He placed the lampstand in the tent of meeting, opposite the table, on the south side of the tabernacle.
He lit the lamps before the LORD; as the LORD commanded Moses.
He placed the golden altar in the tent of meeting before the veil.
He burned fragrant incense on it; as the LORD commanded Moses.
He set up the curtain at the door of the tabernacle.
He placed the altar of burnt offering by the door of the tabernacle of the tent of meeting, and offered on it the burnt offering and the grain offering; as the LORD commanded Moses.
He set the laver between the tent of meeting and the altar, and put water in it for washing.
Moses, Aaron, and his sons washed their hands and feet there.
When they went into the tent of meeting, and when they approached the altar, they washed; as the LORD commanded Moses.
He erected the courtyard around the tabernacle and the altar, and set up the curtain at the courtyard gate. So Moses completed the work.
Then a cloud covered the tent of meeting, and the glory of the LORD filled the tabernacle.
Moses was not able to enter the tent of meeting because the cloud rested on it, and the glory of the LORD filled the tabernacle.
When the cloud was taken up from over the tabernacle, the children of Israel set out on all their journeys.
But if the cloud was not taken up, they did not set out until the day it was taken up.
For the cloud of the LORD was upon the tabernacle by day, and fire was on it by night, in the sight of all the house of Israel, throughout all their journeys.
And the LORD called to Moses and spoke to him from the tabernacle of the congregation, saying,
"Speak to the children of Israel and tell them, 'If any man among you brings an offering to the LORD, you shall bring your offering from the cattle, whether from the herd or from the flock.'
If his offering is a burnt sacrifice from the herd, he must offer a male without blemish; he shall present it willingly at the entrance of the tabernacle of the congregation before the LORD.
He shall place his hand on the head of the burnt offering, and it will be accepted on his behalf to make atonement for him.
He shall slaughter the bull before the LORD, and the priests, the sons of Aaron, shall bring the blood and sprinkle it around the altar at the entrance of the tabernacle of the congregation.
He shall skin the burnt offering and cut it into pieces.
The sons of Aaron, the priests, shall put fire on the altar and arrange the wood on the fire.
The priests, the sons of Aaron, shall arrange the parts, including the head and the fat, in order on the wood that is on the fire on the altar.
But he shall wash the innards and the legs with water, and the priest shall burn all of it on the altar as a burnt sacrifice, an offering made by fire, with a pleasing aroma to the LORD.
If his offering is from the flock, specifically from the sheep or the goats, for a burnt sacrifice, he shall bring a male without blemish.
He shall slaughter it on the north side of the altar before the LORD, and the priests, the sons of Aaron, shall sprinkle its blood around the altar.
He shall cut it into pieces, with its head and its fat, and the priest shall arrange them in order on the wood that is on the fire on the altar.

But he shall wash the innards and the legs with water, and the priest shall bring all of it and burn it on the altar; it is a burnt sacrifice, an offering made by fire, with a pleasing aroma to the LORD.
If the burnt sacrifice he offers to the LORD is from the birds, then he shall bring his offering of turtledoves or young pigeons.
The priest shall bring it to the altar, wring off its head, and burn it on the altar; its blood shall be drained out at the side of the altar.
He shall remove its crop along with its feathers and cast them beside the altar on the east side, in the place of the ashes.

He shall split it open with its wings, but shall not divide it completely; and the priest shall burn it on the altar, on the wood that is on the fire; it is a burnt sacrifice, an offering made by fire, with a pleasing aroma to the LORD.
When anyone offers a grain offering to the LORD, it shall consist of fine flour; he shall pour oil on it and place frankincense upon it.

He shall bring it to Aaron's sons, the priests, who will take a handful of the flour and oil, along with all the frankincense, and the priest shall burn this memorial portion on the altar as an offering made by fire, a pleasing aroma to the LORD.
The remainder of the grain offering shall belong to Aaron and his sons; it is most holy among the offerings made by fire to the LORD.
If you bring a grain offering baked in the oven, it shall consist of unleavened cakes made of fine flour mixed with oil, or unleavened wafers anointed with oil.
If your offering is a grain offering baked in a pan, it shall be made of fine flour, unleavened, mixed with oil.
You shall cut it into pieces and pour oil on it; this is a grain offering.
If your offering is a grain offering cooked in a frying pan, it shall be made of fine flour mixed with oil.
You shall bring the grain offering made from these ingredients to the LORD, and when it is presented to the priest, he shall bring it to the altar.
The priest shall take a memorial portion from the grain offering and burn it on the altar; it is an offering made by fire, a pleasing aroma to the LORD.
What remains of the grain offering shall belong to Aaron and his sons; it is most holy among the offerings made by fire to the LORD.
No grain offering that you bring to the LORD shall be made with leaven, for you shall not burn any leaven or honey in any offering made by fire to the LORD.
As for the offering of the firstfruits, you shall present them to the LORD, but they shall not be burned on the altar as a pleasing aroma.

Every grain offering you present shall be seasoned with salt; you must not allow the salt of the covenant of your God to be missing from your grain offering; you shall offer salt with all your offerings.
If you offer a grain offering of your firstfruits to the LORD, you shall offer green ears of corn dried by fire, even corn beaten from full ears.
You shall put oil on it and lay frankincense upon it; this is a grain offering.
The priest shall burn the memorial portion, part of the beaten corn and part of the oil, along with all the frankincense; it is an offering made by fire to the LORD.
If his offering is a sacrifice of peace offering and he offers it from the herd, whether male or female, it must be without blemish before the LORD.
He shall lay his hand on the head of the offering and kill it at the entrance of the tabernacle of the congregation; Aaron's sons, the priests, will sprinkle the blood around the altar.
He shall present a portion of the peace offering as a fire offering to the LORD, including the fat that covers the innards and all the fat on the innards.
He shall remove the two kidneys and the fat on them, located by the flanks, along with the caul above the liver, together with the kidneys.
Aaron's sons will burn it on the altar, on top of the burnt sacrifice, which is on the wood in the fire; it is a fire offering, a pleasing aroma to the LORD.
If his offering for a peace offering to the LORD is from the flock, whether male or female, it must be without blemish.
If he offers a lamb, he shall present it before the LORD.
He shall lay his hand on the head of the offering and kill it before the tabernacle of the congregation; Aaron's sons will sprinkle its blood around the altar.

He shall present a portion of the peace offering as a fire offering to the LORD, including the fat and the whole rump, which he shall remove near the backbone, along with the fat that covers the innards and all the fat on the innards.
He shall also remove the two kidneys and the fat on them, located by the flanks, along with the caul above the liver, together with the kidneys.
The priest shall burn these on the altar; it is the food of the fire offering to the LORD.
If his offering is a goat, he shall present it before the LORD.
He shall lay his hand on its head and kill it before the tabernacle of the congregation; Aaron's sons will sprinkle its blood around the altar.
He shall present a portion of it as a fire offering to the LORD, including the fat that covers the innards and all the fat on the innards.
He shall also remove the two kidneys and the fat on them, located by the flanks, along with the caul above the liver, together with the kidneys.
The priest shall burn these on the altar; it is the food of the fire offering, a pleasing aroma; all the fat belongs to the LORD.
This shall be a lasting statute for your generations in all your dwellings: you must not eat fat or blood.
And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
Speak to the children of Israel, saying, If a person sins through ignorance against any of the commandments of the LORD regarding things that should not be done, and acts against any of them:
If the anointed priest sins in accordance with the sin of the people, then let him bring for his sin, which he has committed, a young bull without blemish to the LORD for a sin offering.
He shall bring the bull to the entrance of the tabernacle of the congregation before the LORD; and he shall lay his hand on the bull's head and kill the bull before the LORD.
The anointed priest shall take some of the bull's blood and bring it to the tabernacle of the congregation:
The priest shall dip his finger in the blood and sprinkle it seven times before the LORD, in front of the veil of the sanctuary.

The priest shall put some of the blood on the horns of the altar of sweet incense before the LORD, which is in the tabernacle of the congregation, and shall pour all the blood of the bull at the base of the altar of burnt offering, which is at the entrance of the tabernacle of the congregation.
He shall remove all the fat from the bull for the sin offering; the fat that covers the innards, and all the fat that is on the innards,
And the two kidneys, and the fat that is on them, which is by the flanks, and the caul above the liver, with the kidneys, he shall remove,
As it is removed from the bull of the peace offerings: and the priest shall burn them on the altar of burnt offering.
The skin of the bull, and all its flesh, with its head, and its legs, and its innards, and its dung,
The entire bull shall be carried outside the camp to a clean place, where the ashes are poured out, and it shall be burned on the wood with fire: where the ashes are poured out, it shall be burned.

If the whole congregation of Israel sins through ignorance, and the matter is hidden from the eyes of the assembly, and they have acted against any of the commandments of the LORD regarding things that should not be done, and are guilty;
When the sin, which they have committed, is known, then the congregation shall offer a young bull for the sin and bring it before the tabernacle of the congregation.
The elders of the congregation shall lay their hands on the head of the bull before the LORD, and the bull shall be killed before the LORD.
The anointed priest shall bring some of the bull's blood to the tabernacle of the congregation:
The priest shall dip his finger in some of the blood and sprinkle it seven times before the LORD, even before the veil.

He shall put some of the blood on the horns of the altar that is before the LORD, which is in the tabernacle of the congregation, and shall pour out all the blood at the base of the altar of burnt offering, which is at the entrance of the tabernacle of the congregation.
He shall take all the fat from it and burn it on the altar.
He shall do with the bull as he did with the bull for a sin offering; so shall he do with this: and the priest shall make atonement for them, and it shall be forgiven them.
He shall carry the bull outside the camp and burn it as he burned the first bull: it is a sin offering for the congregation.
When a ruler has sinned and acted through ignorance against any of the commandments of the LORD his God regarding things that should not be done, and is guilty;
Or if his sin, which he has committed, comes to his knowledge, he shall bring his offering, a male kid of the goats without blemish:
He shall lay his hand on the head of the goat and kill it in the place where they kill the burnt offering before the LORD: it is a sin offering.

The priest shall take some of the blood of the sin offering with his finger and put it on the horns of the altar of burnt offering, and shall pour out its blood at the base of the altar of burnt offering.
He shall burn all its fat on the altar, as the fat of the peace offerings: and the priest shall make atonement for him concerning his sin, and it shall be forgiven him.
If any one of the common people sins through ignorance while doing something against any of the commandments of the LORD regarding things that should not be done, and is guilty;
Or if his sin, which he has committed, comes to his knowledge, then he shall bring his offering, a female kid of the goats without blemish, for his sin which he has committed.
He shall lay his hand on the head of the sin offering and kill the sin offering in the place of the burnt offering.
The priest shall take some of its blood with his finger and put it on the horns of the altar of burnt offering, and shall pour out all its blood at the base of the altar.

He shall remove all the fat from it, as the fat is removed from the peace offerings; and the priest shall burn it on the altar for a sweet aroma to the LORD; and the priest shall make atonement for him, and it shall be forgiven him.
If he brings a lamb for a sin offering, he shall bring a female without blemish.
He shall lay his hand on the head of the sin offering and kill it for a sin offering in the place where they kill the burnt offering.
The priest shall take some of the blood of the sin offering with his finger and put it on the horns of the altar of burnt offering, and shall pour out all its blood at the base of the altar:

He shall remove all the fat from it, as the fat of the lamb is removed from the peace offerings; and the priest shall burn them on the altar, according to the offerings made by fire to the LORD: and the priest shall make atonement for his sin that he has committed, and it shall be forgiven him.
If a person sins and hears the voice of swearing, and is a witness, whether they have seen or known of it; if they do not speak up, then they shall bear their guilt.

If a person touches any unclean thing, whether it be the carcass of an unclean animal, or the carcass of unclean livestock, or the carcass of unclean creeping things, and if it is hidden from them; they shall also be unclean and guilty.
If they touch the uncleanness of a person, whatever uncleanness it may be that a person is defiled by, and it is hidden from them; when they become aware of it, then they shall be guilty.

If a person swears, pronouncing with their lips to do evil or to do good, whatever it may be that a person pronounces with an oath, and it is hidden from them; when they become aware of it, then they shall be guilty in one of these matters.
And it shall be that when they are guilty in one of these things, they shall confess that they have sinned in that matter:

They shall bring their trespass offering to the LORD for the sin they have committed, a female from the flock, a lamb or a kid of the goats, for a sin offering; and the priest shall make atonement for them concerning their sin.

If they are unable to bring a lamb, then they shall bring for their trespass, which they have committed, two turtledoves or two young pigeons to the LORD; one for a sin offering and the other for a burnt offering.
They shall bring them to the priest, who shall offer the one for the sin offering first, and wring off its head from its neck, but shall not divide it asunder:
The priest shall sprinkle some of the blood of the sin offering upon the side of the altar; and the rest of the blood shall be drained at the bottom of the altar: it is a sin offering.
The second shall be offered for a burnt offering, according to the prescribed manner; and the priest shall make atonement for them for the sin they have committed, and it shall be forgiven them.

But if they are unable to bring two turtledoves or two young pigeons, then the one who sinned shall bring for their offering the tenth part of an ephah of fine flour for a sin offering; they shall put no oil on it, nor shall they put any frankincense on it: for it is a sin offering.
Then they shall bring it to the priest, and the priest shall take a handful of it, as a memorial, and burn it on the altar, according to the offerings made by fire to the LORD: it is a sin offering.

The priest shall make atonement for them regarding the sin they have committed in one of these matters, and it shall be forgiven them; and the remainder shall belong to the priest as a grain offering.
And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,

If a person commits a trespass and sins through ignorance in the holy things of the LORD; then they shall bring for their trespass to the LORD a ram without blemish from the flocks, with your valuation in shekels of silver, according to the shekel of the sanctuary, for a trespass offering.

They shall make restitution for the harm they have done in the holy thing, and shall add a fifth part to it, and give it to the priest; and the priest shall make atonement for them with the ram of the trespass offering, and it shall be forgiven them.
If a person sins and commits any of these things which are forbidden by the commandments of the LORD; even if they were unaware, they are still guilty and shall bear their iniquity.

They shall bring a ram without blemish from the flock, with your valuation, for a trespass offering to the priest; and the priest shall make atonement for them concerning their ignorance in which they erred and were unaware, and it shall be forgiven them.
It is a trespass offering: they have certainly trespassed against the LORD.
And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
If a person sins and commits a trespass against the LORD, lying to their neighbor about what was entrusted to them, or in fellowship, or in something taken by force, or deceiving their neighbor;
Or if they find something lost and lie about it, swearing falsely; in any of these actions that a person commits, sinning in them:

Then it shall be, because they have sinned and are guilty, that they must restore what they took by force, or what they have deceitfully acquired, or what was entrusted to them, or the lost item they found,
Or all that about which they have sworn falsely; they must restore it in full, adding a fifth part more to it, and give it to the rightful owner on the day of their trespass offering.
And they shall bring their trespass offering to the LORD, a ram without blemish from the flock, according to your valuation, as a trespass offering, to the priest:
And the priest shall make atonement for them before the LORD, and it shall be forgiven for anything they have done in trespassing.
And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,

Command Aaron and his sons, saying, This is the law of the burnt offering: It is the burnt offering, because of the fire burning on the altar all night until morning, and the fire of the altar shall be kept burning.

And the priest shall put on his linen garments, and his linen breeches shall be worn on his body, and he shall take up the ashes consumed by the fire from the burnt offering on the altar, and place them beside the altar.
And he shall remove his garments, put on other garments, and carry the ashes outside the camp to a clean place.

And the fire on the altar shall be kept burning; it shall not be extinguished: and the priest shall burn wood on it every morning, laying the burnt offering in order upon it; and he shall burn the fat of the peace offerings on it.
The fire shall always be burning on the altar; it shall never go out.
And this is the law of the grain offering: the sons of Aaron shall present it before the LORD, at the altar.

And he shall take a handful of the fine flour from the grain offering, along with its oil and all the frankincense that is on the grain offering, and burn it on the altar as a sweet aroma, a memorial to the LORD.
And the remainder of it shall be eaten by Aaron and his sons; it shall be eaten with unleavened bread in a holy place; they shall eat it in the courtyard of the tabernacle of meeting.
It shall not be baked with leaven. I have given it to them as their portion of my offerings made by fire; it is most holy, like the sin offering and the trespass offering.

All the males among the children of Aaron shall eat of it. It shall be a perpetual statute in your generations concerning the offerings made by fire to the LORD: everyone who touches them shall be holy.
And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,

This is the offering of Aaron and his sons, which they shall present to the LORD on the day of his anointing; a tenth of an ephah of fine flour for a perpetual grain offering, half in the morning and half at night.
In a pan, it shall be made with oil; and when it is baked, you shall bring it in: and the baked pieces of the grain offering shall be offered as a sweet aroma to the LORD.
And the priest, one of his sons who is anointed in his place, shall offer it: it is a perpetual statute to the LORD; it shall be completely burned.
For every grain offering for the priest shall be completely burned; it shall not be eaten.
And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
Speak to Aaron and his sons, saying, This is the law of the sin offering: In the place where the burnt offering is killed, the sin offering shall be killed before the LORD; it is most holy.
The priest who offers it for sin shall eat it; it shall be eaten in a holy place, in the courtyard of the tabernacle of meeting.
Whatever touches its flesh shall be holy; and when any of its blood is sprinkled on a garment, you shall wash that on which it was sprinkled in a holy place.
But the earthen vessel in which it is boiled shall be broken; and if it is boiled in a bronze pot, it shall be scoured and rinsed in water.
All the males among the priests shall eat of it; it is most holy.
And no sin offering, of which any of the blood is brought into the tabernacle of meeting to make atonement in the holy place, shall be eaten; it shall be burned in the fire.
Likewise, this is the law of the trespass offering: it is most holy.
In the place where they kill the burnt offering, they shall kill the trespass offering; and the blood thereof shall he sprinkle round about upon the altar.
And he shall offer all the fat thereof: the rump, and the fat that covereth the inwards,
And the two kidneys, and the fat that is on them, which is by the flanks, and the caul that is above the liver, with the kidneys, he shall take away.
And the priest shall burn them upon the altar for an offering made by fire unto the LORD: it is a trespass offering.
Every male among the priests shall eat thereof: it shall be eaten in the holy place: it is most holy.
As the sin offering is, so is the trespass offering: there is one law for them; the priest that maketh atonement therewith shall have it.
And the priest that offereth any man's burnt offering shall have to himself the skin of the burnt offering which he hath offered.
And all the meat offering that is baked in the oven, and all that is dressed in the frying pan, and in the pan, shall be the priest's that offereth it.
And every meat offering, mingled with oil, and dry, shall all the sons of Aaron have, one as much as another.
And this is the law of the sacrifice of peace offerings, which he shall offer unto the LORD.

If he offer it for a thanksgiving, then he shall offer with the sacrifice of thanksgiving unleavened cakes mingled with oil, and unleavened wafers anointed with oil, and cakes mingled with oil, of fine flour, fried.
Besides the cakes, he shall offer for his offering leavened bread with the sacrifice of thanksgiving of his peace offerings.
And of it, he shall offer one out of the whole oblation for a heave offering unto the LORD, and it shall be the priest's that sprinkleth the blood of the peace offerings.
And the flesh of the sacrifice of his peace offerings for thanksgiving shall be eaten the same day that it is offered; he shall not leave any of it until the morning.
But if the sacrifice of his offering be a vow, or a voluntary offering, it shall be eaten the same day that he offereth his sacrifice; and on the morrow also the remainder of it shall be eaten.
But the remainder of the flesh of the sacrifice on the third day shall be burnt with fire.

And if any of the flesh of the sacrifice of his peace offerings be eaten at all on the third day, it shall not be accepted, neither shall it be imputed unto him that offereth it: it shall be an abomination, and the soul that eateth of it shall bear his iniquity.
And the flesh that toucheth any unclean thing shall not be eaten; it shall be burnt with fire: and as for the flesh, all that is clean shall eat thereof.
But the soul that eateth of the flesh of the sacrifice of peace offerings, that pertain unto the LORD, having his uncleanness upon him, even that soul shall be cut off from his people.

Moreover, the soul that shall touch any unclean thing, as the uncleanness of man, or any unclean beast, or any abominable unclean thing, and eat of the flesh of the sacrifice of peace offerings, which pertain unto the LORD, even that soul shall be cut off from his people.
And the LORD spake unto Moses, saying,
Speak unto the children of Israel, saying, Ye shall eat no manner of fat, of ox, or of sheep, or of goat.
And the fat of the beast that dieth of itself, and the fat of that which is torn with beasts, may be used in any other use; but ye shall in no wise eat of it.
For whosoever eateth the fat of the beast, of which men offer an offering made by fire unto the LORD, even the soul that eateth it shall be cut off from his people.
Moreover, ye shall eat no manner of blood, whether it be of fowl or of beast, in any of your dwellings.
Whatsoever soul it be that eateth any manner of blood, even that soul shall be cut off from his people.
And the LORD spake unto Moses, saying,
Speak unto the children of Israel, saying, He that offereth the sacrifice of his peace offerings unto the LORD shall bring his oblation unto the LORD of the sacrifice of his peace offerings.
His own hands shall bring the offerings of the LORD made by fire, the fat with the breast; it shall he bring, that the breast may be waved for a wave offering before the LORD.
And the priest shall burn the fat upon the altar; but the breast shall be Aaron's and his sons'.
And the right shoulder shall ye give unto the priest for a heave offering of the sacrifices of your peace offerings.
He among the sons of Aaron, that offereth the blood of the peace offerings, and the fat, shall have the right shoulder for his part.

For the wave breast and the heave shoulder have I taken of the children of Israel from off the sacrifices of their peace offerings, and have given them unto Aaron the priest and unto his sons by a statute forever from among the children of Israel.

This is the portion of the anointing of Aaron, and of the anointing of his sons, out of the offerings of the LORD made by fire, in the day when he presented them to minister unto the LORD in the priest's office;
Which the LORD commanded to be given them of the children of Israel, in the day that he anointed them, by a statute forever throughout their generations.
This is the law of the burnt offering, of the meat offering, and of the sin offering, and of the trespass offering, and of the consecrations, and of the sacrifice of the peace offerings;
Which the LORD commanded Moses in mount Sinai, in the day that he commanded the children of Israel to offer their oblations unto the LORD, in the wilderness of Sinai.
And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
"Take Aaron and his sons with him, along with the garments, the anointing oil, a bull for the sin offering, two rams, and a basket of unleavened bread;
Gather all the congregation together at the entrance of the tabernacle.
Moses did as the LORD commanded him, and the assembly gathered at the entrance of the tabernacle.
Moses said to the congregation, 'This is what the LORD has commanded to be done.'
Moses brought Aaron and his sons and washed them with water.
He put the coat on Aaron, girded him with the girdle, clothed him with the robe, placed the ephod on him, and girded him with the curious girdle of the ephod, binding it to him.
He placed the breastplate on him, and in the breastplate, he put the Urim and the Thummim.
He set the mitre on his head, and on the mitre's forefront, he placed the golden plate, the holy crown, as the LORD commanded Moses.
Moses took the anointing oil and anointed the tabernacle and everything in it, sanctifying them.
He sprinkled some of the oil on the altar seven times, anointed the altar and all its vessels, including the laver and its base, to sanctify them.
He poured the anointing oil on Aaron's head and anointed him to sanctify him.
Moses brought Aaron's sons, put coats on them, girded them with girdles, and placed bonnets on them, as the LORD commanded Moses.
He brought the bull for the sin offering, and Aaron and his sons laid their hands on the head of the bull.

He killed it, and Moses took the blood, applied it to the horns of the altar all around with his finger, purified the altar, poured the blood at the base of the altar, and sanctified it to make atonement for it.
He took all the fat from the innards, the caul above the liver, the two kidneys and their fat, and Moses burned it on the altar.
But the bull, along with its hide, flesh, and dung, he burned with fire outside the camp, as the LORD commanded Moses.
He brought the ram for the burnt offering, and Aaron and his sons laid their hands on the head of the ram.
He killed it, and Moses sprinkled the blood on the altar all around.
He cut the ram into pieces; Moses burned the head, the pieces, and the fat.
He washed the innards and the legs in water, and Moses burned the whole ram on the altar: it was a burnt sacrifice, a sweet aroma, an offering made by fire to the LORD, as the LORD commanded Moses.
He brought the other ram, the ram of consecration, and Aaron and his sons laid their hands on the head of the ram.
He killed it, and Moses took some of its blood and put it on the tip of Aaron's right ear, the thumb of his right hand, and the big toe of his right foot.

He brought Aaron's sons, and Moses applied the blood to the tips of their right ears, the thumbs of their right hands, and the big toes of their right feet; Moses sprinkled the blood on the altar all around.
He took the fat, the rump, all the fat from the innards, the caul above the liver, the two kidneys and their fat, and the right shoulder.
From the basket of unleavened bread before the LORD, he took one unleavened cake, a cake of oiled bread, and one wafer, placing them on the fat and the right shoulder.
He placed all of this on Aaron's hands and his sons' hands, and waved them as a wave offering before the LORD.
Moses took them from their hands and burned them on the altar with the burnt offering: they were consecrations, a sweet aroma, an offering made by fire to the LORD.
Moses took the breast and waved it as a wave offering before the LORD; it was Moses' part from the ram of consecration, as the LORD commanded Moses.

Moses took some of the anointing oil and the blood from the altar and sprinkled it on Aaron, his garments, his sons, and their garments with him; thus he sanctified Aaron, his garments, his sons, and their garments.
Moses said to Aaron and his sons, 'Boil the flesh at the entrance of the tabernacle and eat it with the bread in the basket of consecrations, as I commanded, saying, Aaron and his sons shall eat it.'
What remains of the flesh and the bread you shall burn with fire.
You shall not leave the entrance of the tabernacle for seven days, until the days of your consecration are complete; for seven days he shall consecrate you.
As he has done today, so the LORD has commanded to do, to make atonement for you.
Therefore, you shall remain at the entrance of the tabernacle day and night for seven days, keeping the charge of the LORD, so that you do not die; for so I am commanded.
So Aaron and his sons did all that the LORD commanded through Moses.
And it came to pass on the eighth day that Moses summoned Aaron and his sons, along with the elders of Israel.
He instructed Aaron to take a young calf for a sin offering and a ram for a burnt offering, both without blemish, and to present them before the LORD.
To the children of Israel, he said, "Take a kid of the goats for a sin offering, and a calf and a lamb, both a year old and without blemish, for a burnt offering."
Additionally, he instructed them to bring a bullock and a ram for peace offerings to sacrifice before the LORD, along with a meat offering mixed with oil, for today the LORD will appear to you.
They brought what Moses commanded to the tabernacle of the congregation, and all the congregation approached and stood before the LORD.
Moses declared, "This is what the LORD has commanded you to do, and the glory of the LORD will appear to you."

He then told Aaron, "Go to the altar, offer your sin offering and your burnt offering, make atonement for yourself and for the people, and offer the people's offering, making atonement for them, as the LORD has commanded."
Aaron went to the altar and sacrificed the calf of the sin offering for himself.
Aaron's sons brought the blood to him; he dipped his finger in the blood, applied it to the horns of the altar, and poured out the blood at the base of the altar.
The fat, kidneys, and the caul above the liver of the sin offering he burned on the altar, as the LORD had commanded Moses.
The flesh and hide he burned with fire outside the camp.
He then sacrificed the burnt offering, and Aaron's sons presented the blood to him, which he sprinkled around the altar.
They presented the burnt offering to him, along with its pieces and the head, which he burned on the altar.
He washed the inwards and legs and burned them on the burnt offering on the altar.
He brought the people's offering, took the goat that was the sin offering for the people, slaughtered it, and offered it for sin, just as he had done before.
He presented the burnt offering and offered it according to the prescribed manner.
He brought the meat offering, took a handful of it, and burned it on the altar, alongside the morning's burnt sacrifice.
He also slaughtered the bullock and the ram for peace offerings for the people, and Aaron's sons presented the blood to him, which he sprinkled around the altar.
He placed the fat of the bullock and ram, including the rump, the covering of the inwards, the kidneys, and the caul above the liver, on the altar.
They placed the fat on the breasts, and he burned the fat on the altar.
Aaron waved the breasts and the right shoulder as a wave offering before the LORD, as Moses had commanded.
Aaron lifted his hand toward the people, blessed them, and came down from offering the sin offering, the burnt offering, and the peace offerings.
Moses and Aaron entered the tabernacle of the congregation, came out, and blessed the people; the glory of the LORD appeared to all the people.
A fire came out from before the LORD and consumed the burnt offering and the fat on the altar; when all the people saw it, they shouted and fell on their faces.
And Nadab and Abihu, the sons of Aaron, each took his censer, put fire in it, added incense, and offered unauthorized fire before the LORD, which He had not commanded them to do.
Then fire came out from the LORD and consumed them, and they died in the presence of the LORD.
Moses then said to Aaron, "This is what the LORD meant when He said, 'I will be sanctified in those who approach Me, and before all the people, I will be glorified.'" And Aaron remained silent.
Moses called Mishael and Elzaphan, the sons of Uzziel, Aaron's uncle, and said to them, "Come forward and carry your relatives away from the sanctuary and outside the camp."
So they approached and carried them out of the camp in their tunics, as Moses had instructed.

Moses said to Aaron, Eleazar, and Ithamar, his remaining sons, "Do not let your hair hang loose or tear your clothes, lest you die and wrath come upon the whole congregation. But let your relatives, the entire house of Israel, mourn for the fire that the LORD has kindled."
And you shall not leave the entrance of the tabernacle of meeting, lest you die, for the anointing oil of the LORD is upon you." And they did according to the word of Moses.
Then the LORD spoke to Aaron, saying,
"Do not drink wine or strong drink, you or your sons with you, when you go into the tabernacle of meeting, lest you die. This shall be a perpetual statute throughout your generations.
And you shall distinguish between holy and unholy, and between unclean and clean;
And you shall teach the children of Israel all the statutes which the LORD has spoken to them through Moses."

Moses spoke to Aaron, Eleazar, and Ithamar, his remaining sons, "Take the grain offering that remains from the offerings made by fire to the LORD, and eat it without leaven beside the altar, for it is most holy.
You shall eat it in a holy place, for it is your due and the due of your sons from the sacrifices of the LORD made by fire, for so I have been commanded.

And the wave breast and the heave shoulder you shall eat in a clean place, you and your sons and your daughters with you, for they are your due and the due of your sons, which are given from the sacrifices of the peace offerings of the children of Israel.

The heave shoulder and the wave breast shall be brought with the offerings made by fire of the fat, to wave them as a wave offering before the LORD; and they shall be yours and your sons' with you, by a perpetual statute, as the LORD has commanded."
Moses diligently inquired about the goat of the sin offering, and behold, it had been burned. He was angry with Eleazar and Ithamar, the remaining sons of Aaron, saying,
"Why have you not eaten the sin offering in the holy place, since it is most holy, and God has given it to you to bear the iniquity of the congregation, to make atonement for them before the LORD?
Look, its blood was not brought inside the holy place; you should have eaten it in the holy place, as I commanded."

And Aaron said to Moses, "Today they have offered their sin offering and their burnt offering before the LORD, and such things have happened to me. If I had eaten the sin offering today, would it have been accepted in the sight of the LORD?"
When Moses heard this, he was satisfied.
And the LORD spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying to them,
"Speak to the children of Israel, saying, 'These are the animals you may eat from all the animals on the earth.
Whatever has a split hoof, is cloven-footed, and chews the cud among the animals, that you may eat.
However, these you shall not eat from those that chew the cud or have split hooves: the camel, because it chews the cud but does not have a split hoof; it is unclean to you.
And the coney, because it chews the cud but does not have a split hoof; it is unclean to you.
And the hare, because it chews the cud but does not have a split hoof; it is unclean to you.
And the pig, though it has a split hoof and is cloven-footed, yet it does not chew the cud; it is unclean to you.
You shall not eat their flesh, and you shall not touch their carcasses; they are unclean to you.
These you may eat from all that are in the waters: whatever has fins and scales in the waters, in the seas, and in the rivers, them you may eat.
And all that do not have fins and scales in the seas and in the rivers, of all that move in the waters, and of any living thing that is in the waters, they shall be an abomination to you.
They shall be an abomination to you; you shall not eat their flesh, but you shall regard their carcasses as an abomination.
Whatever does not have fins or scales in the waters, that shall be an abomination to you.
And these are the birds you shall regard as an abomination; they shall not be eaten, they are an abomination: the eagle, the ossifrage, and the osprey,
And the vulture, and the kite after its kind;
Every raven after its kind;
And the owl, the night hawk, the cuckoo, and the hawk after its kind,
And the little owl, the cormorant, and the great owl,
And the swan, the pelican, and the gier eagle,
And the stork, the heron after its kind, and the lapwing, and the bat.
All birds that creep, going on all fours, shall be an abomination to you.
Yet these you may eat of every flying insect that goes on all fours, which have legs above their feet to leap on the earth;
Even these you may eat: the locust after its kind, the bald locust after its kind, the beetle after its kind, and the grasshopper after its kind.
But all other flying insects, which have four feet, shall be an abomination to you.
And for these you shall be unclean: whoever touches their carcass shall be unclean until evening.
And whoever carries any part of their carcass shall wash his clothes and be unclean until evening.
The carcasses of every animal that has a split hoof and is not cloven-footed or does not chew the cud are unclean to you; whoever touches them shall be unclean.
And whatever goes on its paws, among all kinds of animals that go on all fours, those are unclean to you; whoever touches their carcass shall be unclean until evening.
And he who carries their carcass shall wash his clothes and be unclean until evening; they are unclean to you.
These also shall be unclean to you among the creeping things that creep on the earth: the weasel, the mouse, and the tortoise after its kind,
And the ferret, the chameleon, the lizard, the snail, and the mole.
These are unclean to you among all that creep: whoever touches them when they are dead shall be unclean until evening.

And upon whatever any of them falls when they are dead, it shall be unclean; whether it is any vessel of wood, clothing, skin, or sack, whatever vessel it is, in which any work is done, it must be put into water, and it shall be unclean until evening; then it shall be cleansed.
And every earthen vessel into which any of them falls, whatever is in it shall be unclean; and you shall break it.
Of all food that may be eaten, that on which such water comes shall be unclean; and all drink that may be drunk in every such vessel shall be unclean.
And everything upon which any part of their carcass falls shall be unclean; whether it is an oven or a stove for pots, they shall be broken down; for they are unclean and shall be unclean to you.
Nevertheless, a fountain or a pit, where there is plenty of water, shall be clean; but that which touches their carcass shall be unclean.
And if any part of their carcass falls upon any sowing seed that is to be sown, it shall be clean.
But if any water is put on the seed, and any part of their carcass falls thereon, it shall be unclean to you.
And if any animal, of which you may eat, dies; he who touches its carcass shall be unclean until evening.
And he who eats of its carcass shall wash his clothes and be unclean until evening; he also who carries its carcass shall wash his clothes and be unclean until evening.
And every creeping thing that creeps on the earth shall be an abomination; it shall not be eaten.
Whatever goes on its belly, and whatever goes on all fours, or whatever has more feet among all creeping things that creep on the earth, you shall not eat; for they are an abomination.
You shall not make yourselves abominable with any creeping thing that creeps, nor shall you make yourselves unclean with them, that you should be defiled by them.

For I am the LORD your God: you shall therefore sanctify yourselves, and you shall be holy; for I am holy: neither shall you defile yourselves with any manner of creeping thing that creeps on the earth.
For I am the LORD who brought you up out of the land of Egypt, to be your God: you shall therefore be holy, for I am holy.
This is the law of the animals, and of the birds, and of every living creature that moves in the waters, and of every creature that creeps on the earth:
To distinguish between the unclean and the clean, and between the animal that may be eaten and the animal that may not be eaten."
And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,

"Speak to the children of Israel, saying, 'If a woman conceives and gives birth to a male child, she shall be unclean for seven days; as during the days of her separation for her infirmity, she shall remain unclean.
On the eighth day, the flesh of his foreskin shall be circumcised.
She shall then continue in the blood of her purification for thirty-three days; she shall not touch any hallowed thing, nor enter the sanctuary, until the days of her purification are fulfilled.
But if she gives birth to a female child, she shall be unclean for two weeks, as during her separation, and she shall continue in the blood of her purification for sixty-six days.

When the days of her purification are fulfilled, whether for a son or a daughter, she shall bring a lamb of the first year for a burnt offering, and a young pigeon or a turtledove for a sin offering, to the door of the tabernacle of the congregation, to the priest.
The priest shall offer it before the LORD and make atonement for her, and she shall be cleansed from the issue of her blood. This is the law for her who has given birth to a male or a female.

If she is unable to bring a lamb, then she shall bring two turtledoves or two young pigeons; one for the burnt offering and the other for a sin offering. The priest shall make atonement for her, and she shall be clean.'”
And the LORD spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying,
When a man has a rising, a scab, or a bright spot on the skin of his flesh, resembling the plague of leprosy, he shall be brought to Aaron the priest or one of his sons, the priests.

The priest shall examine the plague on the skin of the flesh; if the hair in the plague has turned white and the plague appears deeper than the skin, it is a plague of leprosy, and the priest shall declare him unclean.
If the bright spot is white on the skin of his flesh, not deeper than the skin, and the hair has not turned white, the priest shall isolate the one with the plague for seven days.
On the seventh day, the priest shall examine him again; if the plague has not changed and has not spread on the skin, the priest shall isolate him for another seven days.

On the seventh day, the priest shall examine him again; if the plague appears somewhat dark and has not spread on the skin, the priest shall declare him clean, for it is just a scab. He shall wash his clothes and be clean.
However, if the scab spreads significantly on the skin after he has been examined by the priest for cleansing, he shall be examined by the priest again.
If the priest sees that the scab has spread on the skin, he shall declare him unclean, for it is leprosy.
When a man has leprosy, he shall be brought to the priest;
The priest shall examine him; if the rising is white on the skin, has turned the hair white, and there is raw flesh in the rising,
It is an old leprosy on the skin of his flesh, and the priest shall declare him unclean and shall not isolate him, for he is unclean.
If leprosy breaks out on the skin and covers all the skin of the one with the plague from head to foot, wherever the priest looks,
Then the priest shall consider; if the leprosy has covered all his flesh, he shall declare the one with the plague clean, for it is all turned white; he is clean.
But if raw flesh appears in him, he shall be unclean.
The priest shall examine the raw flesh and declare him unclean, for the raw flesh is unclean; it is leprosy.
If the raw flesh turns back to white, he shall come to the priest;
The priest shall examine him; if the plague has turned white, the priest shall declare him clean; he is clean.
If there was a boil in the flesh, and it has healed,
And in the place of the boil, there is a white rising or a bright spot, white and somewhat reddish, and it is shown to the priest;
If the priest sees it and it is lower than the skin, and the hair has turned white, the priest shall declare him unclean, for it is a plague of leprosy that has broken out from the boil.
But if the priest examines it and sees no white hairs and it is not lower than the skin but somewhat dark, the priest shall isolate him for seven days.
If it spreads significantly on the skin, the priest shall declare him unclean, for it is a plague.
But if the bright spot remains in place and does not spread, it is a burning boil, and the priest shall declare him clean.
If there is any flesh on the skin that has a hot burning, and the quick flesh that burns has a white bright spot, somewhat reddish or white;

Then the priest shall examine it; if the hair in the bright spot has turned white and it appears deeper than the skin, it is a leprosy that has broken out from the burning; therefore, the priest shall declare him unclean, for it is the plague of leprosy.
But if the priest examines it and sees no white hair in the bright spot, and it is not lower than the other skin but somewhat dark, the priest shall isolate him for seven days.
The priest shall examine him on the seventh day; if it has spread significantly on the skin, the priest shall declare him unclean, for it is the plague of leprosy.

If the bright spot remains in place and does not spread on the skin but is somewhat dark, it is a rising from the burning, and the priest shall declare him clean, for it is an inflammation from the burning.
If a man or woman has a plague on the head or beard;

Then the priest shall examine the plague; if it appears deeper than the skin and has yellow thin hair, the priest shall declare him unclean, for it is a dry scall, even a leprosy on the head or beard.
If the priest examines the plague of the scall and sees it is not deeper than the skin and there is no black hair in it, the priest shall isolate the one with the plague of the scall for seven days.
On the seventh day, the priest shall examine the plague; if the scall has not spread, there is no yellow hair, and the scall is not deeper than the skin;
He shall be shaved, but the scall shall not be shaved; the priest shall isolate the one with the scall for another seven days.

On the seventh day, the priest shall examine the scall; if it has not spread on the skin and is not deeper than the skin, the priest shall declare him clean, and he shall wash his clothes and be clean.
But if the scall spreads significantly on the skin after his cleansing;
Then the priest shall examine him; if the scall has spread on the skin, the priest shall not look for yellow hair; he is unclean.
If the scall remains in place and there is black hair grown in it, the scall is healed; he is clean, and the priest shall declare him clean.
If a man or woman has bright spots on the skin of their flesh, even white bright spots;
Then the priest shall examine; if the bright spots on the skin of their flesh are darkish white, it is a freckled spot that grows on the skin; he is clean.
And a man whose hair has fallen off his head is bald; yet he is clean.
And he who has hair fallen off from the part of his head toward his face is forehead bald; yet he is clean.
If there is a white reddish sore on the bald head or bald forehead, it is a leprosy that has sprung up in his bald head or bald forehead.
Then the priest shall examine it; if the rising of the sore is white reddish in his bald head or bald forehead, as leprosy appears on the skin of the flesh;
He is a leprous man; he is unclean. The priest shall declare him utterly unclean; his plague is on his head.
The leper with the plague shall have his clothes torn, his head bare, and he shall cover his upper lip and cry, "Unclean, unclean."
All the days the plague is in him, he shall be defiled; he is unclean. He shall dwell alone; his habitation shall be outside the camp.
The garment that has the plague of leprosy, whether it is a woolen or linen garment;
Whether it is in the warp or woof, of linen or wool, or in a skin or anything made of skin;
If the plague is greenish or reddish in the garment or in the skin, either in the warp or woof, or in anything of skin, it is a plague of leprosy and shall be shown to the priest.
The priest shall examine the plague and isolate the one with the plague for seven days.

He shall examine the plague on the seventh day; if the plague has spread in the garment, either in the warp or woof, or in a skin or in any work made of skin, the plague is a fretting leprosy; it is unclean.
Therefore, he shall burn that garment, whether warp or woof, in woolen or linen, or anything of skin, where the plague is, for it is a fretting leprosy; it shall be burned in the fire.
If the priest examines it and sees that the plague has not spread in the garment, either in the warp or woof, or in anything of skin;
Then the priest shall command that it be washed, and he shall isolate it for another seven days.

The priest shall examine the plague after it has been washed; if the plague has not changed color and has not spread, it is unclean; you shall burn it in the fire, for it is fret inward, whether bare within or without.
If the priest examines it and sees that the plague is somewhat dark after washing, he shall tear it out of the garment, or out of the skin, or out of the warp, or out of the woof.
If it still appears in the garment, either in the warp or woof, or in anything of skin, it is a spreading plague; you shall burn that in which the plague is with fire.
The garment, whether warp or woof, or any skin item that you wash, if the plague has departed from them, shall be washed a second time and shall be clean.
This is the law regarding the plague of leprosy in a garment of woolen or linen, either in the warp or woof, or in anything of skins, to declare it clean or unclean.
And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
This shall be the law for the leper on the day of his cleansing: He shall be brought to the priest.
And the priest shall go outside the camp; and the priest shall examine him, and behold, if the leprosy has been healed in the leper,
Then the priest shall command that for him who is to be cleansed, two live and clean birds, cedar wood, scarlet yarn, and hyssop be taken.
And the priest shall command that one of the birds be killed in an earthen vessel over running water.
As for the living bird, he shall take it, along with the cedar wood, scarlet yarn, and hyssop, and shall dip them and the living bird in the blood of the bird that was killed over the running water.
And he shall sprinkle upon the one being cleansed from leprosy seven times, and shall declare him clean, and shall let the living bird loose into the open field.

And the one being cleansed shall wash his clothes, shave off all his hair, and wash himself in water, so that he may be clean; and afterward he shall come into the camp and stay outside his tent for seven days.

But on the seventh day, he shall shave off all the hair from his head, beard, and eyebrows; he shall shave off all his hair, and he shall wash his clothes, and he shall wash his body in water, and he shall be clean.

On the eighth day, he shall take two male lambs without blemish, one ewe lamb of the first year without blemish, three-tenths of an ephah of fine flour for a grain offering mixed with oil, and one log of oil.
And the priest who makes him clean shall present the man to be cleansed and those items before the LORD at the entrance of the tabernacle of meeting.
And the priest shall take one male lamb and offer it as a trespass offering, along with the log of oil, and wave them as a wave offering before the LORD.
He shall kill the lamb in the place where he kills the sin offering and the burnt offering, in the holy place; for as the sin offering is for the priest, so is the trespass offering; it is most holy.

And the priest shall take some of the blood from the trespass offering and put it on the tip of the right ear of the one being cleansed, on the thumb of his right hand, and on the big toe of his right foot.
And the priest shall take some of the log of oil and pour it into the palm of his own left hand.
And the priest shall dip his right finger in the oil that is in his left hand and sprinkle some of the oil with his finger seven times before the LORD.

Of the remaining oil in his hand, the priest shall put it on the tip of the right ear of the one being cleansed, on the thumb of his right hand, and on the big toe of his right foot, on the blood of the trespass offering.
And the rest of the oil that is in the priest's hand he shall pour on the head of the one being cleansed; and the priest shall make atonement for him before the LORD.
The priest shall offer the sin offering and make atonement for the one being cleansed from his uncleanness; afterward, he shall kill the burnt offering.
The priest shall offer the burnt offering and the grain offering on the altar; and the priest shall make atonement for him, and he shall be clean.

If he is poor and cannot afford so much, then he shall take one lamb for a trespass offering to be waved, to make atonement for him, and one-tenth of an ephah of fine flour mixed with oil for a grain offering, and a log of oil;
And two turtledoves or two young pigeons, whichever he can afford; one shall be a sin offering, and the other a burnt offering.
He shall bring them on the eighth day for his cleansing to the priest, to the entrance of the tabernacle of meeting, before the LORD.
And the priest shall take the lamb of the trespass offering and the log of oil, and the priest shall wave them as a wave offering before the LORD.

He shall kill the lamb of the trespass offering, and the priest shall take some of the blood from the trespass offering and put it on the tip of the right ear of the one being cleansed, on the thumb of his right hand, and on the big toe of his right foot.
And the priest shall pour some of the oil into the palm of his own left hand.
And the priest shall sprinkle with his right finger some of the oil that is in his left hand seven times before the LORD.

And the priest shall put some of the oil that is in his hand on the tip of the right ear of the one being cleansed, on the thumb of his right hand, and on the big toe of his right foot, on the place of the blood of the trespass offering.
And the rest of the oil that is in the priest's hand he shall put on the head of the one being cleansed, to make atonement for him before the LORD.
