from the firstborn of the children of Israel, he took the money, totaling one thousand three hundred and sixty-five shekels, according to the shekel of the sanctuary.
Moses gave the redemption money for those redeemed to Aaron and his sons, as the LORD commanded Moses.
And the LORD spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying,
"Take a census of the sons of Kohath from among the sons of Levi, by their families and the house of their fathers.
From thirty years old and upward to fifty years old, all who enter the service to perform work in the tabernacle of the congregation.
This is the service of the sons of Kohath in the tabernacle of the congregation, concerning the most holy things:
When the camp sets out, Aaron and his sons shall come, take down the covering veil, and cover the ark of testimony with it.
They shall place a covering of badgers' skins over it, and spread a cloth entirely of blue on top, and insert its staves.
On the table of showbread, they shall spread a blue cloth, and place the dishes, spoons, bowls, and covers for the bread on it; the continual bread shall be there.
They shall spread a scarlet cloth over them, cover it with a covering of badgers' skins, and insert its staves.
They shall take a blue cloth and cover the lampstand of light, along with its lamps, tongs, snuffers, and all its oil vessels used in its service.
They shall place it and all its vessels within a covering of badgers' skins and put it on a bar.
On the golden altar, they shall spread a blue cloth, cover it with a covering of badgers' skins, and insert its staves.
They shall take all the instruments of ministry used in the sanctuary, place them in a blue cloth, cover them with a covering of badgers' skins, and put them on a bar.
They shall remove the ashes from the altar and spread a purple cloth over it.
They shall place all its vessels used in service, including censers, fleshhooks, shovels, and basins, on it; they shall spread a covering of badgers' skins over it and insert its staves.

When Aaron and his sons have finished covering the sanctuary and all its vessels, as the camp is to set out, the sons of Kohath shall come to carry it; but they must not touch any holy thing, lest they die. These are the burdens of the sons of Kohath in the tabernacle of the congregation.

The office of Eleazar, the son of Aaron the priest, pertains to the oil for the light, the sweet incense, the daily grain offering, the anointing oil, and the oversight of the entire tabernacle and all that is in it, in the sanctuary and its vessels.
And the LORD spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying,
"Do not cut off the tribe of the families of the Kohathites from among the Levites.
Instead, do this for them so they may live and not die when they approach the most holy things: Aaron and his sons shall go in and assign each one his service and burden.
But they must not go in to see when the holy things are covered, lest they die."
And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
"Take a census of the sons of Gershon, by their families and the houses of their fathers.
From thirty years old and upward to fifty years old, you shall number them; all who enter to perform the service in the tabernacle of the congregation.
This is the service of the families of the Gershonites, to serve and carry burdens:

They shall bear the curtains of the tabernacle, the tabernacle of the congregation, its covering, and the covering of badgers' skins that is above it, and the hanging for the door of the tabernacle of the congregation,

And the hangings of the court, and the hanging for the door of the gate of the court, which is by the tabernacle and the altar round about, along with their cords and all the instruments of their service, and all that is made for them: so shall they serve.
At the appointment of Aaron and his sons shall be all the service of the sons of the Gershonites, in all their burdens and all their service; and you shall assign to them in charge all their burdens.
This is the service of the families of the sons of Gershon in the tabernacle of the congregation: their charge shall be under the hand of Ithamar, the son of Aaron the priest.
As for the sons of Merari, you shall number them by their families and the house of their fathers;
From thirty years old and upward to fifty years old, you shall number them, every one who enters into the service to do the work of the tabernacle of the congregation.
This is the charge of their burden, according to all their service in the tabernacle of the congregation: the boards of the tabernacle, its bars, its pillars, and its sockets,
And the pillars of the court round about, their sockets, pins, and cords, with all their instruments and all their service; you shall reckon the instruments of their burden by name.
This is the service of the families of the sons of Merari, according to all their service in the tabernacle of the congregation, under the hand of Ithamar, the son of Aaron the priest.
Moses, Aaron, and the leaders of the congregation numbered the sons of the Kohathites by their families and the house of their fathers,
From thirty years old and upward to fifty years old, every one who enters into the service for the work in the tabernacle of the congregation.
Those numbered by their families were two thousand seven hundred and fifty.

These were the ones numbered from the families of the Kohathites, all who could serve in the tabernacle of the congregation, which Moses and Aaron numbered according to the command of the LORD through Moses.
Those numbered of the sons of Gershon, by their families and the house of their fathers,
From thirty years old and upward to fifty years old, every one who enters into the service for the work in the tabernacle of the congregation,
Those numbered by their families, by the house of their fathers, were two thousand six hundred and thirty.
These are the ones numbered from the families of the sons of Gershon, all who could serve in the tabernacle of the congregation, whom Moses and Aaron numbered according to the command of the LORD.
Those numbered from the families of the sons of Merari, by their families and the house of their fathers,
From thirty years old and upward to fifty years old, every one who enters into the service for the work in the tabernacle of the congregation,
Those numbered by their families were three thousand two hundred.
These are those numbered from the families of the sons of Merari, whom Moses and Aaron numbered according to the word of the LORD through Moses.
All those numbered of the Levites, whom Moses, Aaron, and the leaders of Israel numbered, by their families and the house of their fathers,
From thirty years old and upward to fifty years old, every one who came to do the service of ministry and the service of burden in the tabernacle of the congregation.
Those numbered among them were eight thousand five hundred and eighty.
According to the command of the LORD, they were numbered by the hand of Moses, each according to his service and burden: thus they were numbered as the LORD commanded Moses.
And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
Command the children of Israel to expel from the camp every leper, everyone with an issue, and anyone who is defiled by the dead.
Both male and female shall be put outside the camp; do not allow them to defile the camp in which I dwell.
The children of Israel complied and expelled them from the camp, just as the LORD commanded Moses.
And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
Speak to the children of Israel, and tell them that if a man or woman commits any sin that people commit, thereby trespassing against the LORD, and that person is guilty;
Then they must confess their sin and make restitution for their wrongdoing, adding a fifth of the value to it, and give it to the one they have wronged.
But if the man has no relative to make restitution to, the restitution shall be made to the LORD, even to the priest, in addition to the ram of atonement, by which atonement shall be made for him.
And every offering of all the holy things brought by the children of Israel to the priest shall belong to him.
And every man's consecrated things shall belong to him: whatever any man gives to the priest shall be his.
And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
Speak to the children of Israel, and say to them, If any man's wife goes astray and commits a trespass against him,
And a man lies with her carnally, and it is hidden from her husband, and kept secret, and she is defiled, with no witness against her, nor is she caught in the act;
And if the spirit of jealousy comes upon him, and he becomes jealous of his wife, whether she is defiled or not;

Then the man shall bring his wife to the priest, and he shall bring her offering, a tenth of an ephah of barley meal; he shall pour no oil on it, nor put frankincense on it, for it is a jealousy offering, a memorial offering, bringing iniquity to remembrance.
And the priest shall bring her near and set her before the LORD;
And the priest shall take holy water in an earthen vessel, and from the dust of the tabernacle floor, the priest shall take and put it into the water;

And the priest shall set the woman before the LORD, uncover her head, and place the memorial offering in her hands, which is the jealousy offering; and the priest shall hold the bitter water that causes the curse.

And the priest shall administer an oath to her, saying, If no man has lain with you, and if you have not gone aside to uncleanness with another instead of your husband, you shall be free from this bitter water that causes the curse.
But if you have gone aside to another instead of your husband, and if you are defiled, and some man has lain with you beside your husband:

Then the priest shall administer the oath of cursing, and he shall say to the woman, The LORD make you a curse and an oath among your people, when the LORD causes your thigh to rot and your belly to swell;
And this water that causes the curse shall enter your bowels, making your belly swell and your thigh rot: And the woman shall say, Amen, amen.
And the priest shall write these curses in a book and shall blot them out with the bitter water;
And he shall cause the woman to drink the bitter water that causes the curse; and the water that causes the curse shall enter her and become bitter.
Then the priest shall take the jealousy offering from the woman's hand, wave the offering before the LORD, and offer it on the altar;
And the priest shall take a handful of the offering, even the memorial portion, and burn it on the altar, and afterward shall cause the woman to drink the water.

And when he has made her drink the water, if she is defiled and has committed a trespass against her husband, the water that causes the curse shall enter her and become bitter, and her belly shall swell, and her thigh shall rot: and the woman shall become a curse among her people.
But if the woman is not defiled, but is clean, then she shall be free and shall conceive.
This is the law regarding jealousies, when a wife goes astray to another instead of her husband and is defiled;
Or when the spirit of jealousy comes upon him, and he is jealous of his wife, and he shall set the woman before the LORD, and the priest shall carry out all this law upon her.
Then the man shall be guiltless from iniquity, and this woman shall bear her iniquity.
And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
"Speak to the children of Israel and tell them: When either a man or a woman separates themselves to make a vow of a Nazarite, dedicating themselves to the LORD:

They shall separate themselves from wine and strong drink, and shall not drink vinegar made from wine or vinegar made from strong drink; they shall not drink any liquor made from grapes, nor eat fresh grapes or dried ones.
Throughout the days of their separation, they shall eat nothing made from the vine, from the seeds to the skins.

During the entire period of their vow, no razor shall come upon their head; until the days are fulfilled during which they separate themselves to the LORD, they shall be holy and let the locks of their hair grow.
Throughout the days they separate themselves to the LORD, they shall not come near a dead body.
They shall not make themselves unclean for their father, mother, brother, or sister when they die, because the consecration of their God is upon their head.
Throughout the days of their separation, they are holy to the LORD.
If a man dies suddenly beside them and they have defiled the head of their consecration, they shall shave their head on the day of their cleansing; on the seventh day, they shall shave it.
On the eighth day, they shall bring two turtledoves or two young pigeons to the priest at the entrance of the tabernacle of the congregation.
The priest shall offer one as a sin offering and the other as a burnt offering, making atonement for them for having sinned by coming near the dead, and shall consecrate their head that same day.

They shall dedicate to the LORD the days of their separation and bring a lamb of the first year for a trespass offering; however, the days that were before shall be lost because their separation was defiled.
This is the law of the Nazarite: when the days of their separation are fulfilled, they shall be brought to the entrance of the tabernacle of the congregation.

They shall offer their offering to the LORD: one male lamb of the first year without blemish for a burnt offering, one female lamb of the first year without blemish for a sin offering, and one ram without blemish for peace offerings,
along with a basket of unleavened bread, cakes of fine flour mixed with oil, and wafers of unleavened bread anointed with oil, along with their grain offering and drink offerings.
The priest shall present them before the LORD and offer their sin offering and burnt offering.
They shall offer the ram as a sacrifice of peace offerings to the LORD, along with the basket of unleavened bread; the priest shall also offer their grain offering and drink offering.

The Nazarite shall shave the head of their separation at the entrance of the tabernacle of the congregation, take the hair from the head of their separation, and put it in the fire that is under the sacrifice of the peace offerings.

The priest shall take the boiled shoulder of the ram, one unleavened cake from the basket, and one unleavened wafer, and shall place them in the hands of the Nazarite after the hair of their separation has been shaved.
The priest shall wave them as a wave offering before the LORD; this is holy for the priest, along with the wave breast and heave shoulder; after that, the Nazarite may drink wine.

This is the law of the Nazarite who has made a vow and of their offering to the LORD for their separation, in addition to what their hand can provide; according to the vow they made, so they must do according to the law of their separation.
And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
"Speak to Aaron and his sons, saying, 'This is how you shall bless the children of Israel, saying to them:
The LORD bless you and keep you;
The LORD make His face shine upon you and be gracious to you;
The LORD lift up His countenance upon you and give you peace.'
And they shall put My name upon the children of Israel, and I will bless them."

And it came to pass on the day that Moses had completely set up the tabernacle, anointed it, sanctified it, and all its instruments, including the altar and all its vessels, and had anointed and sanctified them;
That the leaders of Israel, heads of their ancestral houses, who were the leaders of the tribes and were responsible for those who were counted, brought forth their offerings:
And they presented their offerings before the LORD: six covered wagons and twelve oxen; a wagon for two of the leaders, and for each one an ox; and they brought them before the tabernacle.
And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
"Receive these from them, that they may be used for the service of the tabernacle of the congregation; and you shall give them to the Levites, to each man according to his service."
And Moses took the wagons and the oxen and gave them to the Levites.
Two wagons and four oxen he gave to the sons of Gershon, according to their service;
And four wagons and eight oxen he gave to the sons of Merari, according to their service, under the supervision of Ithamar, the son of Aaron the priest.
But to the sons of Kohath he gave none, because their service of the sanctuary was to carry it on their shoulders.
And the leaders offered for the dedication of the altar on the day it was anointed; indeed, the leaders presented their offerings before the altar.
And the LORD said to Moses, "They shall present their offerings, each leader on his designated day, for the dedication of the altar."
And the first to offer his offering on the first day was Nahshon, the son of Amminadab, of the tribe of Judah:

And his offering was one silver charger, weighing one hundred and thirty shekels, one silver bowl of seventy shekels, according to the shekel of the sanctuary; both were filled with fine flour mixed with oil for a grain offering;
One spoon of ten shekels of gold, filled with incense;
One young bull, one ram, one lamb of the first year, for a burnt offering;
One kid of the goats for a sin offering;
And for a peace offering, two oxen, five rams, five male goats, and five lambs of the first year: this was the offering of Nahshon, the son of Amminadab.
On the second day, Nethaneel, the son of Zuar, leader of Issachar, offered:

He presented one silver charger, weighing one hundred and thirty shekels, one silver bowl of seventy shekels, according to the shekel of the sanctuary; both were filled with fine flour mixed with oil for a grain offering;
One spoon of gold weighing ten shekels, filled with incense;
One young bull, one ram, one lamb of the first year, for a burnt offering;
One kid of the goats for a sin offering;
And for a peace offering, two oxen, five rams, five male goats, and five lambs of the first year: this was the offering of Nethaneel, the son of Zuar.
On the third day, Eliab, the son of Helon, leader of the children of Zebulun, offered:

His offering was one silver charger, weighing one hundred and thirty shekels, one silver bowl of seventy shekels, according to the shekel of the sanctuary; both were filled with fine flour mixed with oil for a grain offering;
One golden spoon of ten shekels, filled with incense;
One young bull, one ram, one lamb of the first year, for a burnt offering;
One kid of the goats for a sin offering;
And for a peace offering, two oxen, five rams, five male goats, and five lambs of the first year: this was the offering of Eliab, the son of Helon.
On the fourth day, Elizur, the son of Shedeur, leader of the children of Reuben, offered:

His offering was one silver charger, weighing one hundred and thirty shekels, one silver bowl of seventy shekels, according to the shekel of the sanctuary; both were filled with fine flour mixed with oil for a grain offering;
One golden spoon of ten shekels, filled with incense;
One young bull, one ram, one lamb of the first year, for a burnt offering;
One kid of the goats for a sin offering;
And for a peace offering, two oxen, five rams, five male goats, and five lambs of the first year: this was the offering of Elizur, the son of Shedeur.
On the fifth day, Shelumiel, the son of Zurishaddai, leader of the children of Simeon, offered:

His offering was one silver charger, weighing one hundred and thirty shekels, one silver bowl of seventy shekels, according to the shekel of the sanctuary; both were filled with fine flour mixed with oil for a grain offering;
One golden spoon of ten shekels, filled with incense;
One young bull, one ram, one lamb of the first year, for a burnt offering;
One kid of the goats for a sin offering;
And for a peace offering, two oxen, five rams, five male goats, and five lambs of the first year: this was the offering of Shelumiel, the son of Zurishaddai.
On the sixth day, Eliasaph, the son of Deuel, leader of the children of Gad, offered:

His offering was one silver charger, weighing one hundred and thirty shekels, one silver bowl of seventy shekels, according to the shekel of the sanctuary; both were filled with fine flour mixed with oil for a grain offering;
One golden spoon of ten shekels, filled with incense;
One young bull, one ram, one lamb of the first year, for a burnt offering;
One kid of the goats for a sin offering;
And for a peace offering, two oxen, five rams, five male goats, and five lambs of the first year: this was the offering of Eliasaph, the son of Deuel.
On the seventh day, Elishama, the son of Ammihud, leader of the children of Ephraim, offered:

His offering was one silver charger, weighing one hundred and thirty shekels, one silver bowl of seventy shekels, according to the shekel of the sanctuary; both were filled with fine flour mixed with oil for a grain offering;
One golden spoon of ten shekels, filled with incense;
One young bull, one ram, one lamb of the first year, for a burnt offering;
One kid of the goats for a sin offering;
And for a peace offering, two oxen, five rams, five male goats, and five lambs of the first year: this was the offering of Elishama, the son of Ammihud.
On the eighth day, Gamaliel, the son of Pedahzur, leader of the children of Manasseh, offered:

His offering was one silver charger, weighing one hundred and thirty shekels, one silver bowl of seventy shekels, according to the shekel of the sanctuary; both were filled with fine flour mixed with oil for a grain offering;
One golden spoon of ten shekels, filled with incense;
One young bull, one ram, one lamb of the first year, for a burnt offering;
One kid of the goats for a sin offering;
And for a peace offering, two oxen, five rams, five male goats, and five lambs of the first year: this was the offering of Gamaliel, the son of Pedahzur.
On the ninth day, Abidan, the son of Gideoni, leader of the children of Benjamin, offered:

His offering was one silver charger, weighing one hundred and thirty shekels, one silver bowl of seventy shekels, according to the shekel of the sanctuary; both were filled with fine flour mixed with oil for a grain offering;
One golden spoon of ten shekels, filled with incense;
One young bull, one ram, one lamb of the first year, for a burnt offering;
One kid of the goats for a sin offering;
And for a peace offering, two oxen, five rams, five male goats, and five lambs of the first year: this was the offering of Abidan, the son of Gideoni.
On the tenth day, Ahiezer, the son of Ammishaddai, leader of the children of Dan, offered:

His offering was one silver charger, weighing one hundred and thirty shekels, one silver bowl of seventy shekels, according to the shekel of the sanctuary; both were filled with fine flour mixed with oil for a grain offering;
One golden spoon of ten shekels, filled with incense;
One young bull, one ram, one lamb of the first year, for a burnt offering;
One kid of the goats for a sin offering;
And for a peace offering, two oxen, five rams, five male goats, and five lambs of the first year: this was the offering of Ahiezer, the son of Ammishaddai.
On the eleventh day, Pagiel, the son of Ocran, leader of the children of Asher, offered:

His offering was one silver charger, weighing one hundred and thirty shekels, one silver bowl of seventy shekels, according to the shekel of the sanctuary; both were filled with fine flour mixed with oil for a grain offering;
One golden spoon of ten shekels, filled with incense;
One young bull, one ram, one lamb of the first year, for a burnt offering;
One kid of the goats for a sin offering;
And for a peace offering, two oxen, five rams, five male goats, and five lambs of the first year: this was the offering of Pagiel, the son of Ocran.
On the twelfth day, Ahira, the son of Enan, leader of the children of Naphtali, offered:

His offering was one silver charger, weighing one hundred and thirty shekels, one silver bowl of seventy shekels, according to the shekel of the sanctuary; both were filled with fine flour mixed with oil for a grain offering;
One golden spoon of ten shekels, filled with incense;
One young bull, one ram, one lamb of the first year, for a burnt offering;
One kid of the goats for a sin offering;
And for a peace offering, two oxen, five rams, five male goats, and five lambs of the first year: this was the offering of Ahira, the son of Enan.
This was the dedication of the altar on the day it was anointed, by the leaders of Israel: twelve silver chargers, twelve silver bowls, and twelve golden spoons:
Each silver charger weighed one hundred and thirty shekels, each bowl seventy; all the silver vessels weighed two thousand and four hundred shekels, according to the shekel of the sanctuary:
The golden spoons were twelve, filled with incense, weighing ten shekels each, according to the shekel of the sanctuary; all the gold of the spoons weighed one hundred and twenty shekels.
All the oxen for the burnt offering were twelve bulls, the rams twelve, the lambs of the first year twelve, with their grain offerings; and the kids of the goats for sin offerings were twelve.

And all the oxen for the peace offerings were twenty-four bulls, the rams sixty, the male goats sixty, and the lambs of the first year sixty. This was the dedication of the altar after it was anointed.

And when Moses entered the tabernacle of the congregation to speak with Him, he heard the voice of one speaking to him from above the mercy seat that was on the ark of the testimony, from between the two cherubim; and He spoke to him.
And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
"Speak to Aaron and tell him, 'When you light the lamps, the seven lamps shall shine in front of the candlestick.'"
And Aaron did as commanded; he lit the lamps in front of the candlestick, as the LORD instructed Moses.
The candlestick was made of beaten gold, including its shaft and flowers, crafted according to the pattern shown to Moses by the LORD.
And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
"Take the Levites from among the children of Israel and purify them."
"This is how you shall purify them: Sprinkle the water of purification on them, have them shave all their body hair, and wash their clothes to make themselves clean."
"Then they shall take a young bull with its grain offering of fine flour mixed with oil, and another young bull shall be taken for a sin offering."
"You shall present the Levites before the tabernacle of the congregation and gather the entire assembly of the children of Israel."
"You shall present the Levites before the LORD, and the children of Israel shall lay their hands on the Levites."
"And Aaron shall present the Levites before the LORD as an offering from the children of Israel, so they may perform the service of the LORD."
"The Levites shall lay their hands on the heads of the bulls; you shall offer one as a sin offering and the other as a burnt offering to the LORD, to make atonement for the Levites."
"You shall present the Levites before Aaron and his sons and offer them as an offering to the LORD."
"This is how you shall separate the Levites from among the children of Israel; the Levites shall be mine."
"After this, the Levites shall enter to perform the service of the tabernacle of the congregation; you shall purify them and offer them as an offering."
"For they are entirely dedicated to me from among the children of Israel; instead of every firstborn that opens the womb, I have taken them for myself."
"All the firstborn of the children of Israel are mine, both man and beast; on the day I struck down every firstborn in the land of Egypt, I sanctified them for myself."
"I have taken the Levites in place of all the firstborn of the children of Israel."

"I have given the Levites as a gift to Aaron and his sons from among the children of Israel, to perform the service of the children of Israel in the tabernacle of the congregation and to make atonement for the children of Israel, so that no plague will come upon the children of Israel when they approach the sanctuary."
And Moses, Aaron, and all the congregation of the children of Israel did to the Levites according to all that the LORD commanded Moses; so the children of Israel did to them.
The Levites were purified, and they washed their clothes; Aaron presented them as an offering before the LORD and made atonement for them to cleanse them.
After this, the Levites entered to perform their service in the tabernacle of the congregation before Aaron and his sons, as the LORD had commanded Moses; so they did.
And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
"This is what pertains to the Levites: from twenty-five years old and upward, they shall enter to perform the service of the tabernacle of the congregation."
"And from the age of fifty years, they shall cease performing that service and serve no longer."
"Instead, they shall assist their brethren in the tabernacle of the congregation, to keep the charge, but they shall do no service. This is what you shall do regarding the Levites and their duties."
And the LORD spoke to Moses in the wilderness of Sinai, in the first month of the second year after they had come out of the land of Egypt, saying,
Let the children of Israel also observe the Passover at its appointed time.
On the fourteenth day of this month, at evening, you shall observe it at its appointed time: according to all its rites and ceremonies, you shall observe it.
And Moses spoke to the children of Israel, instructing them to observe the Passover.
And they observed the Passover on the fourteenth day of the first month at evening in the wilderness of Sinai: according to all that the LORD commanded Moses, so did the children of Israel.
And there were certain men who were defiled by the dead body of a man, and they could not observe the Passover on that day; they came before Moses and Aaron on that day.
And those men said to him, We are defiled by the dead body of a man: why are we kept from offering the offering of the LORD at its appointed time among the children of Israel?
And Moses said to them, Stand still, and I will hear what the LORD will command concerning you.
And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
Speak to the children of Israel, saying, If any man of you or your descendants is unclean due to a dead body, or is on a journey far away, he shall still observe the Passover to the LORD.
On the fourteenth day of the second month at evening, they shall observe it, and eat it with unleavened bread and bitter herbs.
They shall leave none of it until morning, nor break any of its bones: according to all the ordinances of the Passover, they shall observe it.

But the man who is clean and is not on a journey, and neglects to observe the Passover, that same soul shall be cut off from among his people: because he did not bring the offering of the LORD at its appointed time, that man shall bear his sin.

And if a stranger sojourns among you and wishes to observe the Passover to the LORD, according to the ordinance of the Passover and according to its manner, so shall he do: you shall have one ordinance, both for the stranger and for the native of the land.

And on the day that the tabernacle was erected, the cloud covered the tabernacle, namely, the tent of the testimony: and at evening there was upon the tabernacle the appearance of fire, until morning.
So it was always: the cloud covered it by day, and the appearance of fire by night.
And when the cloud was taken up from the tabernacle, then the children of Israel journeyed; and in the place where the cloud rested, there the children of Israel pitched their tents.
At the command of the LORD, the children of Israel journeyed, and at the command of the LORD they pitched: as long as the cloud rested upon the tabernacle, they rested in their tents.
And when the cloud lingered upon the tabernacle many days, the children of Israel kept the charge of the LORD and did not journey.
And so it was, when the cloud was upon the tabernacle for a few days; according to the command of the LORD, they remained in their tents, and according to the command of the LORD, they journeyed.

And so it was, when the cloud remained from evening until morning, and the cloud was taken up in the morning, then they journeyed: whether it was by day or by night that the cloud was taken up, they journeyed.

Or whether it was for two days, or a month, or a year, that the cloud lingered upon the tabernacle, remaining there, the children of Israel remained in their tents and did not journey: but when it was taken up, they journeyed.
At the command of the LORD, they rested in their tents, and at the command of the LORD, they journeyed: they kept the charge of the LORD, at the command of the LORD by the hand of Moses.
And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
Make two trumpets of silver; they shall be made from a single piece: you will use them to call the assembly and for the journeying of the camps.
When they blow the trumpets, all the assembly shall gather at the door of the tabernacle of the congregation.
If they blow only one trumpet, then the princes, who are the heads of the thousands of Israel, shall gather to you.
When you blow an alarm, the camps on the east side shall advance.
When you blow an alarm a second time, the camps on the south side shall begin their journey; they shall blow an alarm for their journeys.
However, when the congregation is to be gathered together, you shall blow, but you shall not sound an alarm.
The sons of Aaron, the priests, shall blow the trumpets; this shall be a lasting ordinance for you throughout your generations.

If you go to war in your land against the enemy who oppresses you, you shall blow an alarm with the trumpets; and you will be remembered before the LORD your God, and you will be saved from your enemies.

On the day of your gladness, during your solemn days, and at the beginning of your months, you shall blow the trumpets over your burnt offerings and over the sacrifices of your peace offerings; this will serve as a memorial before your God: I am the LORD your God.
It came to pass on the twentieth day of the second month in the second year that the cloud was lifted from the tabernacle of the testimony.
The children of Israel set out from the wilderness of Sinai, and the cloud rested in the wilderness of Paran.
They began their journey according to the command of the LORD through Moses.
First went the standard of the camp of the children of Judah according to their armies, and over his host was Nahshon the son of Amminadab.
Over the host of the tribe of the children of Issachar was Nethaneel the son of Zuar.
Over the host of the tribe of the children of Zebulun was Eliab the son of Helon.
The tabernacle was taken down, and the sons of Gershon and the sons of Merari set out, carrying the tabernacle.
The standard of the camp of Reuben set out according to their armies, and over his host was Elizur the son of Shedeur.
Over the host of the tribe of the children of Simeon was Shelumiel the son of Zurishaddai.
Over the host of the tribe of the children of Gad was Eliasaph the son of Deuel.
The Kohathites set out, carrying the sanctuary, while the others set up the tabernacle as they arrived.
The standard of the camp of the children of Ephraim set out according to their armies, and over his host was Elishama the son of Ammihud.
Over the host of the tribe of the children of Manasseh was Gamaliel the son of Pedahzur.
Over the host of the tribe of the children of Benjamin was Abidan the son of Gideoni.
The standard of the camp of the children of Dan set out, serving as the rear guard of all the camps; over his host was Ahiezer the son of Ammishaddai.
Over the host of the tribe of the children of Asher was Pagiel the son of Ocran.
Over the host of the tribe of the children of Naphtali was Ahira the son of Enan.
Thus were the journeyings of the children of Israel according to their armies as they set out.

Moses said to Hobab, the son of Raguel the Midianite, Moses' father-in-law, "We are journeying to the place of which the LORD said, 'I will give it to you.' Come with us, and we will treat you well, for the LORD has spoken good concerning Israel."
He replied, "I will not go; I will return to my own land and to my relatives."
Moses said, "Please do not leave us, for you know how we are to camp in the wilderness, and you can be our eyes."
If you go with us, whatever good the LORD does for us, we will do the same for you.
They departed from the mount of the LORD, traveling for three days; the ark of the covenant of the LORD went before them during the three days' journey to find a resting place for them.
The cloud of the LORD was upon them by day as they left the camp.
When the ark set out, Moses said, "Rise up, LORD, and let your enemies be scattered; let those who hate you flee before you."
When it rested, he said, "Return, O LORD, to the many thousands of Israel."
And when the people complained, it displeased the LORD; He heard it, and His anger was kindled. The fire of the LORD burned among them and consumed those in the outermost parts of the camp.
The people cried out to Moses, and when Moses prayed to the LORD, the fire was quenched.
He named the place Taberah because the fire of the LORD burned among them.
The mixed multitude among them began to crave food, and the children of Israel wept again, saying, "Who will give us flesh to eat?"
"We remember the fish we ate freely in Egypt, the cucumbers, the melons, the leeks, the onions, and the garlic.
But now our souls are dried up; there is nothing at all except this manna before our eyes."
The manna was like coriander seed, and its color was like the color of bdellium.
The people went out, gathered it, ground it in mills or beat it in a mortar, baked it in pans, and made cakes of it; its taste was like the taste of fresh oil.
When the dew fell upon the camp at night, the manna fell with it.
Moses heard the people weeping throughout their families, every man at the door of his tent; the anger of the LORD was greatly kindled, and Moses was also displeased.
Moses said to the LORD, "Why have You afflicted Your servant? Why have I not found favor in Your sight, that You lay the burden of all this people upon me?

Did I conceive all this people? Did I give birth to them, that You should say to me, 'Carry them in your bosom, as a nursing father bears the sucking child,' to the land which You swore to their fathers?
Where can I get meat to give to all this people? They weep before me, saying, 'Give us flesh that we may eat.'
I cannot bear all this people alone; the burden is too heavy for me.
If You deal with me like this, kill me, I pray, if I have found favor in Your sight; do not let me see my wretchedness."

The LORD said to Moses, "Gather for Me seventy men from the elders of Israel, whom you know to be the elders of the people and officers over them; bring them to the tabernacle of the congregation, that they may stand there with you.
I will come down and talk with you there; I will take of the spirit that is upon you and put it upon them, and they shall bear the burden of the people with you, so that you do not bear it alone.

Say to the people, 'Sanctify yourselves for tomorrow, and you shall eat flesh; for you have wept in the ears of the LORD, saying, "Who will give us flesh to eat? It was better for us in Egypt." Therefore, the LORD will give you flesh, and you shall eat.
You shall not eat one day, nor two days, nor five days, nor ten days, nor twenty days;

But for a whole month, until it comes out of your nostrils and becomes loathsome to you, because you have despised the LORD who is among you and have wept before Him, saying, "Why did we ever leave Egypt?"
Moses said, "The people I am with are six hundred thousand footmen, and You have said, 'I will give them flesh that they may eat for a whole month.'
Shall the flocks and herds be slain for them to suffice them? Or shall all the fish of the sea be gathered together for them to suffice them?"
The LORD said to Moses, "Is the LORD's hand shortened? You shall see now whether My word will come to pass to you or not."
Moses went out and told the people the words of the LORD; he gathered the seventy men of the elders of the people and set them around the tabernacle.
The LORD came down in a cloud and spoke to him; He took of the spirit that was upon him and gave it to the seventy elders. When the spirit rested upon them, they prophesied and did not cease.

However, two men remained in the camp; the name of one was Eldad and the name of the other Medad. The spirit rested upon them; they were among those who were written but did not go out to the tabernacle, and they prophesied in the camp.
A young man ran and told Moses, saying, "Eldad and Medad are prophesying in the camp."
Joshua the son of Nun, the servant of Moses, one of his young men, answered and said, "My lord Moses, forbid them!"
Moses said to him, "Are you envious for my sake? Would that all the LORD's people were prophets, and that the LORD would put His spirit upon them!"
Moses returned to the camp, he and the elders of Israel.

A wind went forth from the LORD and brought quails from the sea, letting them fall by the camp, as it were a day's journey on this side and a day's journey on the other side, round about the camp, and as it were two cubits high upon the face of the earth.

The people stood up all that day, all that night, and all the next day, and they gathered the quails. He who gathered the least gathered ten homers, and they spread them out for themselves around the camp.
While the flesh was still between their teeth, before it was chewed, the wrath of the LORD was kindled against the people, and the LORD struck the people with a very great plague.
He named that place Kibrothhattaavah because there they buried the people who had craved.
The people journeyed from Kibrothhattaavah to Hazeroth and camped at Hazeroth.
And Miriam and Aaron spoke against Moses because of the Ethiopian woman he had married; indeed, he had married an Ethiopian woman.
They said, "Has the LORD indeed spoken only through Moses? Has He not also spoken through us?" And the LORD heard it.
(Now the man Moses was very humble, more than all the men on the face of the earth.)
And the LORD spoke suddenly to Moses, Aaron, and Miriam, saying, "Come out, you three, to the tabernacle of the congregation." So they three came out.
The LORD descended in the pillar of the cloud, stood at the entrance of the tabernacle, and called Aaron and Miriam; and they both came forward.
He said, "Hear now my words: If there is a prophet among you, I, the LORD, will make Myself known to him in a vision and will speak to him in a dream.
My servant Moses is not so; he is faithful in all My house.
With him, I will speak mouth to mouth, clearly, and not in dark sayings; and he shall see the likeness of the LORD. Why then were you not afraid to speak against My servant Moses?"
The anger of the LORD was kindled against them, and He departed.
The cloud departed from the tabernacle, and behold, Miriam became leprous, as white as snow; and Aaron looked at Miriam, and behold, she was leprous.
Aaron said to Moses, "Alas, my lord, I beseech you, do not lay this sin upon us, in which we have acted foolishly and in which we have sinned.
Let her not be as one dead, whose flesh is half consumed when he comes out of his mother's womb."
Moses cried out to the LORD, saying, "Heal her now, O God, I beseech You."
The LORD said to Moses, "If her father had but spit in her face, would she not be ashamed for seven days? Let her be shut out from the camp for seven days, and afterward let her be received again."
Miriam was shut out from the camp for seven days, and the people did not journey until Miriam was brought in again.
Afterward, the people moved from Hazeroth and camped in the wilderness of Paran.
And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
"Send men to explore the land of Canaan, which I am giving to the children of Israel. From each tribe of their fathers, you shall send a man, each one a leader among them."
Moses, by the command of the LORD, sent them from the wilderness of Paran; all those men were leaders of the children of Israel.
These are their names: from the tribe of Reuben, Shammua the son of Zaccur.
From the tribe of Simeon, Shaphat the son of Hori.
From the tribe of Judah, Caleb the son of Jephunneh.
From the tribe of Issachar, Igal the son of Joseph.
From the tribe of Ephraim, Oshea the son of Nun.
From the tribe of Benjamin, Palti the son of Raphu.
From the tribe of Zebulun, Gaddiel the son of Sodi.
From the tribe of Joseph, specifically from the tribe of Manasseh, Gaddi the son of Susi.
From the tribe of Dan, Ammiel the son of Gemalli.
From the tribe of Asher, Sethur the son of Michael.
From the tribe of Naphtali, Nahbi the son of Vophsi.
From the tribe of Gad, Geuel the son of Machi.
These are the names of the men whom Moses sent to spy out the land. Moses called Oshea the son of Nun, Jehoshua.
Moses sent them to explore the land of Canaan and said to them, "Go up this way southward and into the mountain.
See what the land is like, and the people who dwell there, whether they are strong or weak, few or many;
And what the land is like in which they live, whether it is good or bad; and what cities they inhabit, whether in tents or fortified cities;

And what the land is, whether it is fertile or barren, whether there are trees in it or not. Be of good courage, and bring back some of the fruit of the land." Now the season was the time of the first ripe grapes.
So they went up and explored the land from the wilderness of Zin to Rehob, as men come to Hamath.
They ascended through the south and came to Hebron, where Ahiman, Sheshai, and Talmai, the descendants of Anak, were. (Hebron was built seven years before Zoan in Egypt.)
They came to the valley of Eshcol and cut down a branch with a single cluster of grapes, which they carried on a pole between two men; they also brought back some pomegranates and figs.
The place was called the valley of Eshcol because of the cluster of grapes that the children of Israel cut down there.
They returned from exploring the land after forty days.
They went to Moses, Aaron, and the entire congregation of the children of Israel in the wilderness of Paran at Kadesh, and brought back word to them and showed them the fruit of the land.
They reported to him, saying, "We went to the land where you sent us, and surely it flows with milk and honey; here is its fruit."
However, the people who dwell in the land are strong, and the cities are fortified and very large; moreover, we saw the descendants of Anak there.
The Amalekites dwell in the land of the south; the Hittites, Jebusites, and Amorites dwell in the mountains; and the Canaanites dwell by the sea and along the banks of the Jordan.
Caleb quieted the people before Moses and said, "Let us go up at once and take possession, for we are well able to overcome it."
But the men who went up with him said, "We are not able to go up against the people, for they are stronger than we."

They brought back an evil report of the land they had explored to the children of Israel, saying, "The land through which we have gone to explore is a land that devours its inhabitants, and all the people we saw in it are of great stature.
There we saw the giants, the descendants of Anak, who come from the giants; and we were like grasshoppers in our own sight, and so we were in their sight."
And all the congregation raised their voices and cried out; the people wept that night.
The children of Israel murmured against Moses and Aaron, saying to them, "Would that we had died in the land of Egypt! Or would that we had died in this wilderness!"
"Why has the LORD brought us to this land, to fall by the sword, so that our wives and children become prey? Would it not be better for us to return to Egypt?"
They said to one another, "Let us appoint a leader and return to Egypt."
Then Moses and Aaron fell on their faces before the entire assembly of the congregation of the children of Israel.
Joshua the son of Nun and Caleb the son of Jephunneh, who were among those who explored the land, tore their clothes.
They spoke to all the congregation of the children of Israel, saying, "The land we explored is exceedingly good."
"If the LORD is pleased with us, He will bring us into this land and give it to us—a land flowing with milk and honey."
"Only do not rebel against the LORD, and do not fear the people of the land; they are our bread. Their protection has departed from them, and the LORD is with us; do not fear them."
But the entire congregation threatened to stone them with stones. Then the glory of the LORD appeared in the tabernacle before all the children of Israel.
The LORD said to Moses, "How long will this people provoke Me? How long will it be before they believe in Me, despite all the signs I have performed among them?"
"I will strike them with a plague and disinherit them, and I will make of you a nation greater and mightier than they."
Moses said to the LORD, "Then the Egyptians will hear it, for You brought up this people by Your might from among them."

"They will tell it to the inhabitants of this land; they have heard that You, LORD, are among this people, that You, LORD, are seen face to face, and that Your cloud stands over them, and that You go before them in a pillar of cloud by day and in a pillar of fire by night."
"Now if You kill all this people as one man, then the nations that have heard of Your fame will say,"
"'Because the LORD was not able to bring this people into the land He swore to give them, He has slain them in the wilderness.'"
"And now, I beseech You, let the power of my Lord be great, as You have spoken, saying,"

"The LORD is slow to anger and abundant in mercy, forgiving iniquity and transgression, but He will by no means clear the guilty, visiting the iniquity of the fathers upon the children to the third and fourth generation."
"Pardon, I beseech You, the iniquity of this people according to the greatness of Your mercy, just as You have forgiven this people from Egypt until now."
The LORD said, "I have pardoned according to your word;
But as truly as I live, all the earth shall be filled with the glory of the LORD."
"Because all those men who have seen My glory and My miracles, which I did in Egypt and in the wilderness, and have tested Me these ten times and have not heeded My voice,"
"Surely they shall not see the land which I swore to their fathers, nor shall any of those who provoked Me see it."
"But My servant Caleb, because he has a different spirit and has followed Me fully, I will bring him into the land where he went, and his descendants shall possess it."
(Now the Amalekites and the Canaanites dwelt in the valley.) "Tomorrow, turn and head into the wilderness by the way of the Red Sea."
The LORD spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying,
"How long shall I bear with this evil congregation that murmurs against Me? I have heard the murmurings of the children of Israel, which they murmur against Me."
"Say to them, 'As truly as I live,' says the LORD, 'as you have spoken in My hearing, so will I do to you:
Your carcasses shall fall in this wilderness, and all who were numbered among you, from twenty years old and upward, who have murmured against Me.'"
"Surely you shall not come into the land concerning which I swore to make you dwell therein, except for Caleb the son of Jephunneh and Joshua the son of Nun."
"But your little ones, whom you said would be a prey, I will bring in, and they shall know the land which you have despised."
"But as for you, your carcasses shall fall in this wilderness."
"And your children shall wander in the wilderness for forty years and bear your iniquities, until your carcasses are wasted in the wilderness."
"According to the number of the days you explored the land, forty days, for each day a year, you shall bear your iniquities for forty years, and you shall know My breach of promise."
"I, the LORD, have said, I will surely do it to all this evil congregation that is gathered against Me; in this wilderness they shall be consumed, and there they shall die."
"And the men whom Moses sent to explore the land, who returned and made all the congregation murmur against him by bringing up a slander upon the land,"
"Even those men who brought up the evil report about the land died by the plague before the LORD."
"But Joshua the son of Nun and Caleb the son of Jephunneh, who were among the men who went to explore the land, lived."
Moses told these things to all the children of Israel, and the people mourned greatly.
They rose early in the morning and went up to the top of the mountain, saying, "Here we are, and we will go up to the place the LORD has promised, for we have sinned."
Moses said, "Why do you now transgress the commandment of the LORD? It will not succeed."
"Do not go up, for the LORD is not among you; you will be defeated before your enemies."
"For the Amalekites and the Canaanites are there before you, and you shall fall by the sword; because you have turned away from the LORD, the LORD will not be with you."
But they presumed to go up to the hilltop; nevertheless, the ark of the covenant of the LORD and Moses did not depart from the camp.
Then the Amalekites came down, and the Canaanites who dwelt in that hill attacked them and defeated them, even to Hormah.
And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
"Speak to the children of Israel and tell them, 'When you enter the land of your dwellings, which I am giving to you,

and you make an offering by fire to the LORD, whether a burnt offering, a sacrifice in fulfilling a vow, a freewill offering, or during your solemn feasts, to create a pleasing aroma to the LORD, from the herd or from the flock:
then the one who offers their offering to the LORD shall bring a grain offering of a tenth of an ephah of flour mixed with a quarter of a hin of oil.
And you shall prepare a quarter of a hin of wine for a drink offering with the burnt offering or sacrifice for one lamb.
For a ram, you shall prepare a grain offering of two-tenths of an ephah of flour mixed with a third of a hin of oil.
And for a drink offering, you shall offer a third of a hin of wine, creating a pleasing aroma to the LORD.
When you prepare a bull for a burnt offering, or for a sacrifice in fulfilling a vow, or for peace offerings to the LORD:
then you shall bring with the bull a grain offering of three-tenths of an ephah of flour mixed with half a hin of oil.
And you shall bring for a drink offering half a hin of wine, as an offering made by fire, creating a pleasing aroma to the LORD.
This is how it shall be done for one bull, one ram, one lamb, or a goat.
According to the number you prepare, so shall you do for each one according to their number.
All who are native-born shall do these things in this manner, offering an offering made by fire, creating a pleasing aroma to the LORD.
And if a stranger sojourns with you, or anyone among you in your generations, and wishes to offer an offering made by fire, creating a pleasing aroma to the LORD; as you do, so shall he do.
There shall be one ordinance for both you and the stranger who sojourns with you, an everlasting ordinance in your generations: as you are, so shall the stranger be before the LORD.
One law and one custom shall be for you and for the stranger who sojourns with you.
And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
"Speak to the children of Israel and tell them, 'When you come into the land to which I bring you,
then it shall be, that when you eat of the bread of the land, you shall offer up a heave offering to the LORD.
You shall offer a cake from the first of your dough as a heave offering: as you do the heave offering of the threshing floor, so shall you heave it.
From the first of your dough, you shall give to the LORD a heave offering in your generations.
And if you have erred and not observed all these commandments, which the LORD has spoken to Moses,
even all that the LORD has commanded you through the hand of Moses, from the day that the LORD commanded Moses and onward among your generations;

then it shall be, if anything is committed in ignorance without the knowledge of the congregation, that all the congregation shall offer one young bull for a burnt offering, creating a pleasing aroma to the LORD, with its grain offering and its drink offering, according to the custom, and one goat for a sin offering.

And the priest shall make atonement for all the congregation of the children of Israel, and it shall be forgiven them; for it is ignorance: and they shall bring their offering, a sacrifice made by fire to the LORD, and their sin offering before the LORD for their ignorance:
and it shall be forgiven all the congregation of the children of Israel, and the stranger who sojourns among them; since all the people were in ignorance.
And if any person sins through ignorance, then he shall bring a she-goat of the first year for a sin offering.
And the priest shall make atonement for the soul that sins ignorantly, when he sins by ignorance before the LORD, to make atonement for him; and it shall be forgiven him.
You shall have one law for the one who sins through ignorance, both for the native-born among the children of Israel and for the stranger who sojourns among them.
But the soul that acts presumptuously, whether he is born in the land or a stranger, reproaches the LORD; and that soul shall be cut off from among his people.
Because he has despised the word of the LORD and has broken His commandment, that soul shall be utterly cut off; his iniquity shall be upon him.
And while the children of Israel were in the wilderness, they found a man gathering sticks on the Sabbath day.
And those who found him gathering sticks brought him to Moses and Aaron, and to all the congregation.
And they put him in custody, because it had not been declared what should be done to him.
And the LORD said to Moses, 'The man shall surely be put to death; all the congregation shall stone him with stones outside the camp.'
And all the congregation brought him outside the camp and stoned him with stones, and he died, as the LORD commanded Moses.
And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
"Speak to the children of Israel and tell them to make fringes on the corners of their garments throughout their generations, and to put a blue cord on the fringe of the corners.

And it shall be a fringe for you to look upon and remember all the commandments of the LORD and do them; and that you do not follow your own heart and your own eyes, after which you used to go astray:
that you may remember and do all my commandments and be holy to your God.
I am the LORD your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt, to be your God: I am the LORD your God."

Now Korah, the son of Izhar, the son of Kohath, the son of Levi, along with Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab, and On, the son of Peleth, who were all descendants of Reuben, gathered a group of men.
They confronted Moses, accompanied by certain children of Israel, specifically two hundred and fifty prominent leaders of the assembly, well-known figures in the congregation.

They united against Moses and Aaron, accusing them, saying, "You take too much upon yourselves, considering that the entire congregation is holy, every one of them, and the LORD is among them. Why then do you elevate yourselves above the congregation of the LORD?"
Upon hearing this, Moses fell on his face.
He addressed Korah and all his followers, saying, "Tomorrow the LORD will reveal who belongs to Him and who is holy; He will bring near to Himself the one He has chosen."
"Do this: Take censers, Korah, and all your followers;
Put fire in them and add incense before the LORD tomorrow. The man whom the LORD chooses will be the holy one. You take too much upon yourselves, sons of Levi."
Moses then said to Korah, "Listen, I pray, you sons of Levi:

Is it a small thing to you that the God of Israel has separated you from the congregation of Israel to bring you near to Himself, to serve in the tabernacle of the LORD and to stand before the congregation to minister to them?
He has brought you near to Him, along with all your fellow Levites. Are you now seeking the priesthood as well?
This is why you and your followers have gathered against the LORD. What is Aaron that you complain against him?"
Moses sent for Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab, but they replied, "We will not come up.
Is it a trivial matter that you have brought us out of a land flowing with milk and honey to kill us in the wilderness, unless you make yourself a prince over us?
Furthermore, you have not brought us into a land flowing with milk and honey, nor given us an inheritance of fields and vineyards. Will you blind these men? We will not come up."
Moses was very angry and said to the LORD, "Do not accept their offering. I have not taken a single donkey from them, nor have I harmed any of them."
Moses instructed Korah, "You and all your followers are to present yourselves before the LORD tomorrow, you, they, and Aaron.
Each man is to take his censer, put incense in it, and bring it before the LORD—two hundred and fifty censers; you and Aaron each must also have your own censer."
So each man took his censer, put fire in them, added incense, and stood at the entrance of the tabernacle of the congregation with Moses and Aaron.
Korah gathered the entire congregation against them at the entrance of the tabernacle, and the glory of the LORD appeared to all the congregation.
The LORD spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying,
"Separate yourselves from this congregation so that I may consume them in an instant."
They fell on their faces and said, "O God, God of the spirits of all flesh, will one man sin and be angry with the entire congregation?"
The LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
"Tell the congregation to move away from the tents of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram."
Moses rose and went to Dathan and Abiram, and the elders of Israel followed him.
He said to the congregation, "Depart, I pray, from the tents of these wicked men, and do not touch anything that belongs to them, or you will be consumed in all their sins."
So they moved away from the tents of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram. Dathan and Abiram came out and stood at the entrance of their tents, along with their wives, sons, and little children.
Moses declared, "By this you will know that the LORD has sent me to do all these works; I have not done them of my own accord.
If these men die a natural death or experience the fate of all men, then the LORD has not sent me.

But if the LORD performs a new thing, and the earth opens its mouth and swallows them up, along with all that belongs to them, and they go down alive into the pit, then you will understand that these men have provoked the LORD."
As soon as he finished speaking, the ground split open beneath them.
The earth opened its mouth and swallowed them, their households, and all the men associated with Korah, along with all their possessions.
They and all that belonged to them went down alive into the pit, and the earth closed over them; they perished from among the congregation.
All Israel around them fled at their cries, saying, "Lest the earth swallow us up too!"
Then a fire came out from the LORD and consumed the two hundred and fifty men who had offered incense.
The LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
"Tell Eleazar, the son of Aaron the priest, to take the censers out of the fire and scatter the fire some distance away, for they are holy.

The censers of these sinners against their own souls should be made into broad plates for a covering of the altar, for they offered them before the LORD; therefore, they are holy and will serve as a sign to the children of Israel."
Eleazar the priest took the bronze censers, which the burned men had offered, and made them into broad plates for a covering of the altar,

to serve as a memorial to the children of Israel, so that no outsider who is not of the seed of Aaron may come near to offer incense before the LORD, lest he be like Korah and his company, as the LORD instructed him through Moses.
But the next day, the entire congregation of the children of Israel murmured against Moses and Aaron, saying, "You have killed the people of the LORD."
When the congregation gathered against Moses and Aaron, they looked toward the tabernacle of the congregation, and behold, the cloud covered it, and the glory of the LORD appeared.
Moses and Aaron went before the tabernacle of the congregation.
The LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
"Get away from this congregation so that I may consume them in an instant." They fell on their faces.

Moses said to Aaron, "Take a censer, put fire from the altar in it, add incense, and go quickly to the congregation to make atonement for them, for the wrath of the LORD has gone out; the plague has begun."
Aaron did as Moses commanded and ran into the midst of the congregation. The plague had already begun among the people, and he put on incense and made atonement for the people.
He stood between the dead and the living, and the plague was halted.
The number of those who died in the plague was fourteen thousand seven hundred, in addition to those who died because of Korah.
Aaron returned to Moses at the entrance of the tabernacle of the congregation, and the plague was stopped.
And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,

"Speak to the children of Israel, and let each of them take a rod according to the house of their fathers, with twelve rods from all their princes according to their families: write each man's name on his rod.
And you shall write Aaron's name on the rod of Levi, for one rod shall represent the head of each family.
You shall place them in the tabernacle of the congregation before the testimony, where I will meet with you.
It shall come to pass that the rod of the man I choose will blossom, and I will put an end to the complaints of the children of Israel, who murmur against you.
Moses spoke to the children of Israel, and each of their princes gave him a rod, one for each prince, totaling twelve rods: and Aaron's rod was among them.
Moses placed the rods before the LORD in the tabernacle of witness.
The next day, Moses entered the tabernacle of witness; and behold, the rod of Aaron for the house of Levi had budded, produced buds, bloomed blossoms, and yielded almonds.
Moses brought out all the rods from before the LORD to the children of Israel, and they looked and took each man his rod.
The LORD said to Moses, "Bring Aaron's rod back before the testimony, to be kept as a sign against the rebels; and you shall completely remove their complaints from me, so they do not die."
Moses did as the LORD commanded him.
The children of Israel spoke to Moses, saying, "Behold, we are dying, we are perishing, we are all perishing.
Whoever approaches anything near the tabernacle of the LORD shall die: are we to be consumed with dying?"

And the LORD spoke to Aaron, saying, "You and your sons, along with your father's household, shall bear the iniquity of the sanctuary; you and your sons shall also bear the iniquity of your priesthood."
"Bring your brethren from the tribe of Levi, your father's tribe, to join you and minister alongside you; but you and your sons shall serve before the tabernacle of witness."
"They shall keep your charge and the charge of the entire tabernacle; however, they must not approach the vessels of the sanctuary or the altar, lest they or you die."
"They shall be joined to you and keep the charge of the tabernacle of the congregation, performing all the service of the tabernacle; no outsider shall approach you."
"You shall keep the charge of the sanctuary and the charge of the altar, so that no wrath comes upon the children of Israel any longer."
"Behold, I have taken your brethren, the Levites, from among the children of Israel; they are a gift to you from the LORD to perform the service of the tabernacle of the congregation."

"Therefore, you and your sons shall maintain your priestly office concerning everything at the altar and within the veil; you shall serve. I have given your priestly office to you as a gift, and any outsider who approaches shall be put to death."

"And the LORD spoke to Aaron, saying, 'I have also given you the charge of my heave offerings of all the hallowed things of the children of Israel; they are given to you by reason of your anointing, and to your sons, by an everlasting ordinance.'"

"This shall be yours of the most holy things, reserved from the fire: every oblation, every grain offering, every sin offering, and every trespass offering that they present to me shall be most holy for you and your sons."
"In the most holy place, you shall eat it; every male shall eat it; it shall be holy to you."

"And this is yours: the heave offering of their gifts, along with all the wave offerings of the children of Israel; I have given them to you and to your sons and daughters with you, by a perpetual statute; everyone who is clean in your house may eat of it."
"All the best of the oil, all the best of the wine, and all the best of the wheat, the firstfruits of what they offer to the LORD, I have given to you."
"And whatever is first ripe in the land, which they bring to the LORD, shall be yours; everyone who is clean in your house may eat of it."
"Everything devoted in Israel shall be yours."

"Everything that opens the womb in all flesh, which they bring to the LORD, whether of men or beasts, shall be yours; however, you shall surely redeem the firstborn of man, and the firstling of unclean animals you shall redeem."
"And those to be redeemed from a month old you shall redeem according to your estimation, for the money of five shekels, after the shekel of the sanctuary, which is twenty gerahs."

"But the firstling of a cow, sheep, or goat you shall not redeem; they are holy. You shall sprinkle their blood on the altar and burn their fat as an offering made by fire, a sweet aroma to the LORD."
"The flesh of these shall be yours, just as the wave breast and the right shoulder are yours."

"All the heave offerings of the holy things, which the children of Israel offer to the LORD, I have given to you, your sons, and your daughters with you, by a perpetual statute; it is a covenant of salt forever before the LORD for you and your descendants."
"And the LORD spoke to Aaron, saying, 'You shall have no inheritance in their land, nor shall you have any part among them; I am your part and your inheritance among the children of Israel.'"
"Behold, I have given the children of Levi all the tithes in Israel for an inheritance, for their service which they perform, even the service of the tabernacle of the congregation."
"From now on, the children of Israel must not approach the tabernacle of the congregation, lest they bear sin and die."

"But the Levites shall perform the service of the tabernacle of the congregation, and they shall bear their iniquity; this shall be a perpetual statute throughout your generations, that among the children of Israel they shall have no inheritance."

"But the tithes of the children of Israel, which they offer as a heave offering to the LORD, I have given to the Levites to inherit; therefore, I have said to them, 'Among the children of Israel, they shall have no inheritance.'"
"And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,"

"Speak to the Levites and say to them, 'When you take from the children of Israel the tithes that I have given you from them for your inheritance, you shall offer up a heave offering of it to the LORD, a tenth part of the tithe.'"
"And this heave offering shall be counted to you as though it were the grain from the threshing floor and the fullness of the winepress."
"Thus, you shall also offer a heave offering to the LORD of all your tithes, which you receive from the children of Israel; and you shall give the LORD's heave offering to Aaron the priest."
"From all your gifts, you shall offer every heave offering of the LORD, of all the best of it, even the hallowed part from it."
"Therefore, you shall say to them, 'When you have heaved the best of it from it, it shall be counted to the Levites as the increase of the threshing floor and as the increase of the winepress.'"
"And you shall eat it in every place, you and your households, for it is your reward for your service in the tabernacle of the congregation."
"And you shall bear no sin because of it when you have heaved from it the best of it; neither shall you pollute the holy things of the children of Israel, lest you die."
And the LORD spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying,

This is the ordinance of the law that the LORD has commanded: Speak to the children of Israel and instruct them to bring you a red heifer without spot, in which there is no blemish, and upon which no yoke has ever come.
You shall give her to Eleazar the priest, so that he may bring her outside the camp, and one shall slay her in his presence.
Eleazar the priest shall take some of her blood with his finger and sprinkle it directly before the tabernacle of the congregation seven times.
One shall burn the heifer in his sight; her skin, her flesh, her blood, and her dung shall be burned.
The priest shall take cedar wood, hyssop, and scarlet, and cast them into the midst of the burning heifer.
Then the priest shall wash his clothes and bathe his flesh in water, and afterward he shall come into the camp; the priest shall be unclean until evening.
The one who burns her shall wash his clothes in water, bathe his flesh in water, and shall be unclean until evening.

A clean man shall gather the ashes of the heifer and lay them up outside the camp in a clean place; they shall be kept for the congregation of the children of Israel for a water of separation: it is a purification for sin.

The one who gathers the ashes of the heifer shall wash his clothes and be unclean until evening; this shall be a statute for the children of Israel and for the stranger who sojourns among them, forever.
Whoever touches the dead body of any man shall be unclean for seven days.
He shall purify himself with it on the third day, and on the seventh day he shall be clean; but if he does not purify himself on the third day, then on the seventh day he shall not be clean.

Whoever touches the dead body of any man and does not purify himself defiles the tabernacle of the LORD; that soul shall be cut off from Israel, because the water of separation was not sprinkled upon him; he remains unclean, and his uncleanness is still upon him.
This is the law when a man dies in a tent: all who enter the tent and all that is in the tent shall be unclean for seven days.
Every open vessel that has no covering bound upon it is unclean.
Whoever touches one who has been slain with a sword in the open fields, or a dead body, or a bone of a man, or a grave, shall be unclean for seven days.
For an unclean person, they shall take some of the ashes of the burnt heifer for purification from sin, and running water shall be added to it in a vessel.

A clean person shall take hyssop, dip it in the water, and sprinkle it upon the tent, upon all the vessels, upon the persons who were there, and upon anyone who touched a bone, or one slain, or one dead, or a grave.

The clean person shall sprinkle upon the unclean on the third day and on the seventh day; on the seventh day, he shall purify himself, wash his clothes, bathe himself in water, and shall be clean by evening.

But the man who is unclean and does not purify himself shall be cut off from among the congregation, because he has defiled the sanctuary of the LORD; the water of separation has not been sprinkled upon him; he is unclean.
It shall be a perpetual statute for them that the one who sprinkles the water of separation shall wash his clothes; and whoever touches the water of separation shall be unclean until evening.
Whatever the unclean person touches shall be unclean; and the soul that touches it shall be unclean until evening.
The children of Israel, the entire congregation, entered the desert of Zin in the first month. The people settled in Kadesh, where Miriam passed away and was buried.
There was no water for the congregation, so they gathered against Moses and Aaron.
The people argued with Moses, saying, "Would that we had died when our brethren died before the LORD!"
"Why have you brought the congregation of the LORD into this wilderness for us and our cattle to die?"
"Why did you lead us out of Egypt to bring us to this terrible place? It is not a place of seed, figs, vines, or pomegranates; there is no water to drink."
Moses and Aaron went from the assembly to the entrance of the tabernacle and fell on their faces; the glory of the LORD appeared to them.
The LORD spoke to Moses, saying,

"Take the rod, gather the assembly together, you and your brother Aaron, and speak to the rock before their eyes; it will yield its water, and you will bring forth water from the rock for the congregation and their animals to drink."
Moses took the rod from before the LORD as he was commanded.
Moses and Aaron gathered the congregation before the rock, and he said to them, "Listen now, you rebels; must we bring you water from this rock?"
Moses raised his hand and struck the rock twice with his rod; water gushed out abundantly, and the congregation drank, along with their animals.

The LORD spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying, "Because you did not believe in me to sanctify me in the eyes of the children of Israel, you shall not bring this congregation into the land I have given them."
This is the water of Meribah, because the children of Israel contended with the LORD, and He was sanctified among them.
Moses sent messengers from Kadesh to the king of Edom, saying, "Thus says your brother Israel: You know all the hardships that have befallen us.
Our ancestors went down to Egypt, and we have lived there a long time; the Egyptians oppressed us and our ancestors.
When we cried out to the LORD, He heard our voice, sent an angel, and brought us out of Egypt. Now we are in Kadesh, a city at the edge of your territory.

Please let us pass through your country; we will not pass through fields or vineyards, nor will we drink water from your wells. We will travel along the king's highway and will not turn to the right or left until we have passed through your borders."
Edom replied, "You shall not pass through me, or I will come out against you with the sword."
The children of Israel said, "We will travel along the highway, and if I and my cattle drink your water, I will pay for it. I will only pass through on foot."
Edom responded, "You shall not pass through." Edom came out against them with a large army and a strong hand.
Thus, Edom refused to allow Israel passage through his territory, so Israel turned away from him.
The children of Israel, the entire congregation, journeyed from Kadesh and arrived at Mount Hor.
The LORD spoke to Moses and Aaron at Mount Hor, near the border of Edom, saying,
"Aaron will be gathered to his people, for he will not enter the land I have given to the children of Israel, because you rebelled against my word at the water of Meribah.
Take Aaron and his son Eleazar and bring them up to Mount Hor.
Strip Aaron of his garments and put them on Eleazar his son; Aaron will be gathered to his people and will die there."
Moses did as the LORD commanded; they went up to Mount Hor in the sight of the entire congregation.
Moses stripped Aaron of his garments and put them on Eleazar his son; Aaron died there on top of the mountain, and Moses and Eleazar came down from the mountain.
When the entire congregation saw that Aaron was dead, they mourned for him for thirty days, all the house of Israel.
