Joshua made peace with them and made a treaty to let them live, and the leaders of the congregation swore an oath to them.
It came to pass that three days after they had made the treaty with them, they heard that they were their neighbors and that they dwelt among them.
The children of Israel journeyed and arrived at their cities on the third day. Their cities were Gibeon, Chephirah, Beeroth, and Kirjathjearim.
The children of Israel did not attack them because the leaders of the congregation had sworn an oath by the LORD God of Israel. The entire congregation murmured against the leaders.
But all the leaders said to the congregation, "We have sworn an oath by the LORD God of Israel; we cannot touch them now.
This is what we will do to them: we will let them live, so that wrath does not come upon us because of the oath we swore to them."
The leaders said to them, "Let them live; but let them be woodcutters and water carriers for the entire congregation," as the leaders had promised them.
Joshua called for them and spoke to them, saying, "Why have you deceived us by saying, 'We are very far from you,' when you actually dwell among us?
Now, therefore, you are cursed, and none of you shall be freed from being bondmen, woodcutters, and water carriers for the house of my God."

They answered Joshua, "Because it was clearly told to your servants how the LORD your God commanded His servant Moses to give you all the land and to destroy all the inhabitants of the land before you, we were terrified for our lives because of you, and we did this thing.
And now, behold, we are in your hands; do with us as it seems good and right to you."
So he did this to them and delivered them from the hand of the children of Israel, and they did not slay them.
Joshua made them woodcutters and water carriers for the congregation and for the altar of the LORD, even to this day, in the place he would choose.

Now it came to pass, when Adonizedec, king of Jerusalem, heard how Joshua had taken Ai and utterly destroyed it; just as he had done to Jericho and its king, so he had done to Ai and its king; and how the inhabitants of Gibeon had made peace with Israel and were among them;
That they feared greatly, because Gibeon was a great city, one of the royal cities, and because it was greater than Ai, and all its men were mighty.
Therefore, Adonizedec, king of Jerusalem, sent to Hoham, king of Hebron, and to Piram, king of Jarmuth, and to Japhia, king of Lachish, and to Debir, king of Eglon, saying,
"Come up to me and help me, that we may strike Gibeon, for it has made peace with Joshua and the children of Israel."

Thus, the five kings of the Amorites—the king of Jerusalem, the king of Hebron, the king of Jarmuth, the king of Lachish, and the king of Eglon—gathered together, went up with all their hosts, encamped before Gibeon, and made war against it.

And the men of Gibeon sent to Joshua at the camp in Gilgal, saying, "Do not withdraw your hand from your servants; come up to us quickly and save us, and help us, for all the kings of the Amorites who dwell in the mountains have gathered against us."
So Joshua ascended from Gilgal, he and all the warriors with him, along with all the mighty men of valor.
And the LORD said to Joshua, "Do not fear them, for I have delivered them into your hand; not a man of them shall stand before you."
Joshua therefore came upon them suddenly and marched up from Gilgal all night.

And the LORD threw them into confusion before Israel, and struck them with a great slaughter at Gibeon, chasing them along the road that goes up to Bethhoron, and struck them as far as Azekah and Makkedah.

And it came to pass, as they fled from before Israel and were going down to Bethhoron, that the LORD cast down large hailstones from heaven upon them as far as Azekah, and they died; there were more who died from the hailstones than those whom the children of Israel killed with the sword.

Then Joshua spoke to the LORD on the day when the LORD delivered up the Amorites before the children of Israel, and he said in the sight of Israel, "Sun, stand still over Gibeon; and Moon, in the valley of Ajalon."

And the sun stood still, and the moon stopped, until the people had avenged themselves upon their enemies. Is this not written in the Book of Jasher? So the sun stood still in the midst of heaven and did not hasten to go down for about a whole day.
And there was no day like that before it or after it, when the LORD heeded the voice of a man, for the LORD fought for Israel.
And Joshua returned, and all Israel with him, to the camp at Gilgal.
But these five kings fled and hid themselves in a cave at Makkedah.
And it was told to Joshua, saying, "The five kings have been found hidden in a cave at Makkedah."
And Joshua said, "Roll great stones upon the mouth of the cave, and set men by it to keep watch over them.
And do not stop, but pursue your enemies and strike the rear guard; do not allow them to enter their cities, for the LORD your God has delivered them into your hand."
And it came to pass, when Joshua and the children of Israel had finished slaying them with a very great slaughter until they were consumed, that the rest of them entered into fortified cities.
And all the people returned to the camp to Joshua at Makkedah in peace; no one spoke a word against any of the children of Israel.
Then Joshua said, "Open the mouth of the cave and bring those five kings out to me."
And they did so, bringing forth those five kings to him from the cave: the king of Jerusalem, the king of Hebron, the king of Jarmuth, the king of Lachish, and the king of Eglon.

And it came to pass, when they brought those kings to Joshua, that Joshua called for all the men of Israel and said to the captains of the men of war who went with him, "Come near, put your feet upon the necks of these kings." And they came near and put their feet upon their necks.
And Joshua said to them, "Do not fear, nor be dismayed; be strong and of good courage, for thus the LORD will do to all your enemies against whom you fight."
And afterward, Joshua struck them, killed them, and hanged them on five trees; they were hanging on the trees until evening.

And it came to pass at the time of the going down of the sun that Joshua commanded, and they took them down from the trees, cast them into the cave where they had been hidden, and laid great stones at the mouth of the cave, which remain until this very day.

And that day, Joshua took Makkedah, struck it with the edge of the sword, and utterly destroyed its king and all the souls that were in it; he let none remain, and he did to the king of Makkedah as he had done to the king of Jericho.
Then Joshua passed from Makkedah, and all Israel with him, to Libnah, and fought against Libnah.

And the LORD also delivered it, along with its king, into the hand of Israel; he struck it with the edge of the sword, and all the souls that were in it; he let none remain in it, but did to its king as he had done to the king of Jericho.
And Joshua passed from Libnah, and all Israel with him, to Lachish, and encamped against it, and fought against it.

And the LORD delivered Lachish into the hand of Israel, which took it on the second day, struck it with the edge of the sword, and all the souls that were in it, according to all that he had done to Libnah.
Then Horam, king of Gezer, came up to help Lachish; and Joshua struck him and his people, leaving none remaining.
And from Lachish, Joshua passed to Eglon, and all Israel with him; they encamped against it and fought against it.
And they took it that day, struck it with the edge of the sword, and utterly destroyed all the souls that were in it, according to all that he had done to Lachish.
And Joshua went up from Eglon, and all Israel with him, to Hebron; and they fought against it.

And they took it, struck it with the edge of the sword, and its king, all its cities, and all the souls that were in it; he left none remaining, according to all that he had done to Eglon; he utterly destroyed it and all the souls that were in it.
And Joshua returned, and all Israel with him, to Debir; and fought against it.

And he took it, its king, and all its cities; they struck them with the edge of the sword and utterly destroyed all the souls that were in it; he left none remaining, just as he had done to Hebron, so he did to Debir and its king; as he had done also to Libnah and its king.

So Joshua struck all the region of the hills, the south, the vale, the springs, and all their kings; he left none remaining, but utterly destroyed all that breathed, as the LORD God of Israel commanded.
And Joshua struck them from Kadeshbarnea even to Gaza, and all the region of Goshen, even to Gibeon.
And all these kings and their land did Joshua take at one time, because the LORD God of Israel fought for Israel.
And Joshua returned, and all Israel with him, to the camp at Gilgal.
And it came to pass, when Jabin, king of Hazor, heard these things, that he sent word to Jobab, king of Madon, and to the king of Shimron, and to the king of Achshaph.
And to the kings who were in the north of the mountains, and in the plains south of Chinneroth, and in the valley, and in the borders of Dor on the west.
And to the Canaanites on the east and on the west, and to the Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites, and Jebusites in the mountains, and to the Hivites under Hermon in the land of Mizpeh.
And they went out, they and all their armies with them, a multitude as numerous as the sand on the seashore, with many horses and chariots.
And when all these kings gathered together, they camped at the waters of Merom to fight against Israel.
And the LORD said to Joshua, "Do not be afraid of them, for tomorrow at this time I will deliver them all slain before Israel; you shall hamstring their horses and burn their chariots with fire."
So Joshua came, and all the warriors with him, against them by the waters of Merom suddenly, and they attacked them.

And the LORD delivered them into the hand of Israel, who struck them down and chased them to great Zidon, to Misrephothmaim, and to the valley of Mizpeh eastward; they struck them until none remained.
And Joshua did to them as the LORD commanded him: he hamstrung their horses and burned their chariots with fire.
At that time, Joshua turned back, took Hazor, and struck its king with the sword, for Hazor had previously been the head of all those kingdoms.
And they struck down all the souls that were in it with the edge of the sword, utterly destroying them; there was not a single breath left, and he burned Hazor with fire.
And all the cities of those kings, and all their kings, Joshua took, struck them with the edge of the sword, and utterly destroyed them, as Moses, the servant of the LORD, commanded.
But as for the cities that remained strong, Israel burned none of them, except Hazor, which Joshua burned.

And all the spoils of these cities, and the cattle, the children of Israel took as plunder for themselves; but every man they struck with the edge of the sword until they had destroyed them, leaving none to breathe.
As the LORD commanded Moses, so Moses commanded Joshua, and so Joshua did; he left nothing undone of all that the LORD commanded Moses.
So Joshua took all that land, the hills, all the southern region, the land of Goshen, the valley, the plain, and the mountain of Israel, and the valley of the same.
From Mount Halak, which goes up to Seir, even to Baalgad in the valley of Lebanon under Mount Hermon; he took all their kings, struck them, and killed them.
Joshua waged war a long time against all those kings.
There was not a city that made peace with the children of Israel, except for the Hivites, the inhabitants of Gibeon; all others they took in battle.

For it was of the LORD to harden their hearts, so they would come against Israel in battle, that He might utterly destroy them, and that they might receive no favor, but be destroyed, as the LORD commanded Moses.

At that time, Joshua came and cut off the Anakim from the mountains, from Hebron, from Debir, from Anab, and from all the mountains of Judah, and from all the mountains of Israel; Joshua utterly destroyed them along with their cities.
There were no Anakim left in the land of the children of Israel; only in Gaza, Gath, and Ashdod did some remain.

So Joshua took the whole land, according to all that the LORD had said to Moses; and Joshua gave it as an inheritance to Israel according to their divisions by their tribes. And the land rested from war.

Now these are the kings of the land, which the children of Israel defeated and possessed their land on the other side of Jordan toward the rising of the sun, from the river Arnon to Mount Hermon, and all the plain on the east:

Sihon king of the Amorites, who dwelt in Heshbon, and ruled from Aroer, which is upon the bank of the river Arnon, and from the middle of the river, and from half Gilead, even to the river Jabbok, which is the border of the children of Ammon;
And from the plain to the Sea of Chinneroth on the east, and to the Sea of the Plain, even the Salt Sea on the east, the way to Bethjeshimoth; and from the south, under Ashdothpisgah:
And the territory of Og king of Bashan, which was of the remnant of the giants, who dwelt at Ashtaroth and at Edrei,
And reigned in Mount Hermon, and in Salcah, and in all Bashan, to the border of the Geshurites and the Maachathites, and half Gilead, the border of Sihon king of Heshbon.

Them did Moses the servant of the LORD and the children of Israel defeat: and Moses the servant of the LORD gave it for a possession to the Reubenites, and the Gadites, and the half tribe of Manasseh.

And these are the kings of the country which Joshua and the children of Israel defeated on this side of Jordan on the west, from Baalgad in the valley of Lebanon even to Mount Halak, that goes up to Seir; which Joshua gave to the tribes of Israel for a possession according to their divisions;

In the mountains, and in the valleys, and in the plains, and in the springs, and in the wilderness, and in the south country; the Hittites, the Amorites, and the Canaanites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites:
The king of Jericho, one; the king of Ai, which is beside Bethel, one;
The king of Jerusalem, one; the king of Hebron, one;
The king of Jarmuth, one; the king of Lachish, one;
The king of Eglon, one; the king of Gezer, one;
The king of Debir, one; the king of Geder, one;
The king of Hormah, one; the king of Arad, one;
The king of Libnah, one; the king of Adullam, one;
The king of Makkedah, one; the king of Bethel, one;
The king of Tappuah, one; the king of Hepher, one;
The king of Aphek, one; the king of Lasharon, one;
The king of Madon, one; the king of Hazor, one;
The king of Shimronmeron, one; the king of Achshaph, one;
The king of Taanach, one; the king of Megiddo, one;
The king of Kedesh, one; the king of Jokneam of Carmel, one;
The king of Dor in the coast of Dor, one; the king of the nations of Gilgal, one;
The king of Tirzah, one: all the kings thirty-one.
Now Joshua was old and advanced in years; and the LORD said to him, "You are old and advanced in years, and there remains yet a great deal of land to be possessed."
This is the land that still remains: all the borders of the Philistines, and all of Geshuri,

From Sihor, which is in front of Egypt, even to the borders of Ekron northward, which is counted as belonging to the Canaanites: five lords of the Philistines; the Gazathites, the Ashdothites, the Eshkalonites, the Gittites, and the Ekronites; also the Avites:
From the south, all the land of the Canaanites, and Mearah that is beside the Sidonians, to Aphek, to the borders of the Amorites:
And the land of the Giblites, and all of Lebanon, toward the east, from Baalgad under Mount Hermon to the entrance of Hamath.

All the inhabitants of the hill country from Lebanon to Misrephothmaim, and all the Sidonians, I will drive out from before the children of Israel; only divide it by lot to the Israelites for an inheritance, as I have commanded you.
Now therefore divide this land for an inheritance to the nine tribes and the half-tribe of Manasseh,
With whom the Reubenites and the Gadites have received their inheritance, which Moses gave them, beyond the Jordan eastward, just as Moses the servant of the LORD gave them;
From Aroer, which is on the bank of the river Arnon, and the city that is in the midst of the river, and all the plain of Medeba to Dibon;
And all the cities of Sihon king of the Amorites, who reigned in Heshbon, to the border of the children of Ammon;
And Gilead, and the border of the Geshurites and Maachathites, and all of Mount Hermon, and all of Bashan to Salcah;
All the kingdom of Og in Bashan, who reigned in Ashtaroth and in Edrei, who remained of the remnant of the giants; for these Moses struck down and expelled.
Nevertheless, the children of Israel did not expel the Geshurites or the Maachathites; but the Geshurites and the Maachathites dwell among the Israelites to this day.
Only to the tribes of Levi he gave no inheritance; the sacrifices of the LORD God of Israel made by fire are their inheritance, as he said to them.
And Moses gave to the tribe of the children of Reuben an inheritance according to their families.
And their territory was from Aroer, which is on the bank of the river Arnon, and the city that is in the midst of the river, and all the plain by Medeba;
Heshbon, and all her cities that are in the plain; Dibon, and Bamothbaal, and Bethbaalmeon,
And Jahaza, and Kedemoth, and Mephaath,
And Kirjathaim, and Sibmah, and Zarethshahar in the mountain valley,
And Bethpeor, and Ashdothpisgah, and Bethjeshimoth,

And all the cities of the plain, and all the kingdom of Sihon king of the Amorites, who reigned in Heshbon, whom Moses struck down with the princes of Midian: Evi, Rekem, Zur, Hur, and Reba, who were dukes of Sihon, dwelling in the country.
Balaam also the son of Beor, the soothsayer, the children of Israel killed with the sword among those who were slain by them.
And the border of the children of Reuben was the Jordan, and its border. This was the inheritance of the children of Reuben according to their families, the cities and their villages.
And Moses gave an inheritance to the tribe of Gad, to the children of Gad according to their families.
And their territory was Jazer, and all the cities of Gilead, and half the land of the children of Ammon, to Aroer that is before Rabbah;
And from Heshbon to Ramathmizpeh, and Betonim; and from Mahanaim to the border of Debir;

And in the valley, Betharam, and Bethnimrah, and Succoth, and Zaphon, the rest of the kingdom of Sihon king of Heshbon, the Jordan and its border, even to the edge of the Sea of Chinnereth on the other side of the Jordan eastward.
This is the inheritance of the children of Gad according to their families, the cities, and their villages.
And Moses gave an inheritance to the half-tribe of Manasseh; this was the possession of the half-tribe of the children of Manasseh according to their families.
And their territory was from Mahanaim, all of Bashan, all the kingdom of Og king of Bashan, and all the towns of Jair, which are in Bashan, sixty cities;

And half of Gilead, and Ashtaroth, and Edrei, cities of the kingdom of Og in Bashan, were given to the children of Machir the son of Manasseh, even to one half of the children of Machir according to their families.
These are the regions which Moses distributed for inheritance in the plains of Moab, on the other side of the Jordan, near Jericho, eastward.
But to the tribe of Levi, Moses gave no inheritance; the LORD God of Israel was their inheritance, as he said to them.

And these are the countries that the children of Israel inherited in the land of Canaan, which Eleazar the priest, Joshua the son of Nun, and the heads of the fathers of the tribes of the children of Israel distributed as their inheritance.
By lot was their inheritance, as the LORD commanded through Moses, for the nine tribes and the half tribe.
For Moses had given the inheritance of two tribes and a half tribe on the other side of the Jordan: but to the Levites, he gave no inheritance among them.

For the children of Joseph were two tribes, Manasseh and Ephraim: therefore, they gave no part to the Levites in the land, except for cities to dwell in, with their suburbs for their cattle and possessions.
As the LORD commanded Moses, so the children of Israel did, and they divided the land.

Then the children of Judah came to Joshua in Gilgal, and Caleb the son of Jephunneh the Kenezite said to him, "You know the thing that the LORD said to Moses the man of God concerning you and me in Kadeshbarnea."
I was forty years old when Moses the servant of the LORD sent me from Kadeshbarnea to spy out the land; and I brought him word again as it was in my heart.
Nevertheless, my brethren who went up with me made the heart of the people melt: but I wholly followed the LORD my God.
And Moses swore on that day, saying, "Surely the land whereon your feet have trodden shall be your inheritance, and that of your children forever, because you have wholly followed the LORD my God."

And now, behold, the LORD has kept me alive, as He said, these forty-five years, even since the LORD spoke this word to Moses while the children of Israel wandered in the wilderness: and now, lo, I am this day eighty-five years old.
As yet I am as strong this day as I was on the day that Moses sent me: as my strength was then, so is my strength now, for war, both to go out and to come in.

Now therefore give me this mountain, of which the LORD spoke in that day; for you heard in that day how the Anakims were there, and that the cities were great and fortified: if the LORD will be with me, then I shall be able to drive them out, as the LORD said.
And Joshua blessed him and gave Caleb the son of Jephunneh Hebron for an inheritance.
Hebron therefore became the inheritance of Caleb the son of Jephunneh the Kenezite to this day, because he wholly followed the LORD God of Israel.
And the name of Hebron was formerly Kirjatharba; Arba was a great man among the Anakims. And the land had rest from war.
This was the inheritance of the tribe of the children of Judah by their families; the southernmost boundary extended to the border of Edom, reaching the wilderness of Zin.
Their southern border began at the shore of the Salt Sea, from the bay that faces southward.
It extended southward to Maalehacrabbim, then continued to Zin, ascending on the southern side to Kadeshbarnea, passing along to Hezron, and moving up to Adar, circling around to Karkaa.
From there, it moved toward Azmon and reached the river of Egypt; the endpoints of that border were at the sea: this shall be your southern boundary.
The eastern border was the Salt Sea, extending to the mouth of the Jordan River. The northern boundary began at the bay of the sea at the northernmost point of the Jordan.
The border ascended to Bethhogla, passing north of Betharabah, and continued to the stone of Bohan, the son of Reuben.

The border ascended toward Debir from the valley of Achor, moving northward, facing Gilgal, which is before the ascent to Adummim, located on the southern side of the river; the border then moved toward the waters of Enshemesh, with its endpoints at Enrogel.

The border ascended by the valley of the son of Hinnom to the southern side of the Jebusite, which is Jerusalem; it then rose to the top of the mountain that lies before the valley of Hinnom to the west, at the northern end of the valley of the giants.
The border was drawn from the top of the hill to the spring of the water of Nephtoah, extending to the cities of Mount Ephron; the border was drawn to Baalah, which is Kirjathjearim.
The border circled from Baalah westward to Mount Seir, passing along the side of Mount Jearim, which is Chesalon, on the northern side, then descending to Bethshemesh and continuing to Timnah.
The border extended to the side of Ekron northward; it was drawn to Shicron, passing along to Mount Baalah, and reaching Jabneel; the endpoints of the border were at the sea.
The western border was the Great Sea and its coastline. This is the boundary of the children of Judah, according to their families.
To Caleb, the son of Jephunneh, he gave a portion among the children of Judah, as commanded by the LORD to Joshua, specifically the city of Arba, the father of Anak, which is Hebron.
Caleb drove out the three sons of Anak: Sheshai, Ahiman, and Talmai, the descendants of Anak.
He then went up to the inhabitants of Debir, which was formerly known as Kirjathsepher.
Caleb declared, "Whoever attacks Kirjathsepher and captures it, I will give him my daughter Achsah as a wife."
Othniel, the son of Kenaz, Caleb's brother, captured it, and Caleb gave him his daughter Achsah as a wife.
When she came to him, she urged him to ask her father for a field; she dismounted from her donkey, and Caleb asked her, "What do you want?"
She replied, "Give me a blessing; since you have given me a south land, grant me also springs of water." He gave her the upper springs and the lower springs.
This is the inheritance of the tribe of the children of Judah according to their families.
The southernmost cities of the tribe of the children of Judah toward the border of Edom were Kabzeel, Eder, and Jagur,
Kinah, Dimonah, and Adadah,
Kedesh, Hazor, and Ithnan,
Ziph, Telem, and Bealoth,
Hazor, Hadattah, Kerioth, and Hezron, which is Hazor,
Amam, Shema, and Moladah,
Hazargaddah, Heshmon, and Bethpalet,
Hazarshual, Beersheba, and Bizjothjah,
Baalah, Iim, and Azem,
Eltolad, Chesil, and Hormah,
Ziklag, Madmannah, and Sansannah,
Lebaoth, Shilhim, Ain, and Rimmon: all the cities total twenty-nine, with their villages.
In the valley were Eshtaol, Zoreah, and Ashnah,
Zanoah, Engannim, Tappuah, and Enam,
Jarmuth, Adullam, Socoh, and Azekah,
Sharaim, Adithaim, Gederah, and Gederothaim; fourteen cities with their villages.
Zenan, Hadashah, and Migdalgad,
Dilean, Mizpeh, and Joktheel,
Lachish, Bozkath, and Eglon,
Cabbon, Lahmam, and Kithlish,
Gederoth, Bethdagon, Naamah, and Makkedah; sixteen cities with their villages.
Libnah, Ether, and Ashan,
Jiphtah, Ashnah, and Nezib,
Keilah, Achzib, and Mareshah; nine cities with their villages.
Ekron, with its towns and villages:
From Ekron to the sea, all that lay near Ashdod, with their villages:
Ashdod with its towns and villages, Gaza with its towns and villages, extending to the river of Egypt, and the Great Sea, and its border:
In the mountains were Shamir, Jattir, and Socoh,
Dannah, Kirjathsannah, which is Debir,
Anab, Eshtemoh, and Anim,
Goshen, Holon, and Giloh; eleven cities with their villages.
Arab, Dumah, and Eshean,
Janum, Bethtappuah, and Aphekah,
Humtah, Kirjatharba, which is Hebron, and Zior; nine cities with their villages.
Maon, Carmel, Ziph, and Juttah,
Jezreel, Jokdeam, and Zanoah,
Cain, Gibeah, and Timnah; ten cities with their villages.
Halhul, Bethzur, and Gedor,
Maarath, Bethanoth, and Eltekon; six cities with their villages.
Kirjathbaal, which is Kirjathjearim, and Rabbah; two cities with their villages.
In the wilderness were Betharabah, Middin, and Secacah,
Nibshan, the city of Salt, and Engedi; six cities with their villages.
As for the Jebusites, the inhabitants of Jerusalem, the children of Judah could not drive them out; thus, the Jebusites dwell with the children of Judah in Jerusalem to this day.

The territory of the children of Joseph extended from the Jordan River near Jericho, reaching to the waters of Jericho on the eastern side, and included the wilderness that ascends from Jericho to Mount Bethel.
It continued from Bethel to Luz, and then along the borders of Archi to Ataroth.
The boundary then descended westward to the region of Japhleti, reaching the lower Bethhoron and Gezer; the exits of this territory were by the sea.
Thus, the children of Joseph, namely Manasseh and Ephraim, received their inheritance.
The boundary of the children of Ephraim, according to their families, was as follows: on the eastern side, it began at Atarothaddar and extended to the upper Bethhoron.
The border then extended toward the sea to Michmethah on the northern side, and it turned eastward to Taanathshiloh, passing by it on the east to Janohah.
From Janohah, it descended to Ataroth and Naarath, reaching Jericho and exiting at the Jordan River.

The boundary extended from Tappuah westward to the Kanah River, with the exits of this territory being by the sea. This constitutes the inheritance of the tribe of Ephraim according to their families.
The designated cities for the children of Ephraim were included within the inheritance of the children of Manasseh, encompassing all the cities and their villages.
However, they did not drive out the Canaanites who lived in Gezer; thus, the Canaanites continue to dwell among the Ephraimites to this day, serving under tribute.

There was also a lot designated for the tribe of Manasseh, as he was the firstborn of Joseph; specifically, for Machir, the firstborn of Manasseh, who was the father of Gilead. Because he was a warrior, he received Gilead and Bashan.

Additionally, there was a lot for the remaining descendants of Manasseh by their families, including the children of Abiezer, Helek, Asriel, Shechem, Hepher, and Shemida. These were the male descendants of Manasseh, the son of Joseph, organized by their families.

However, Zelophehad, the son of Hepher, the son of Gilead, the son of Machir, the son of Manasseh, had no sons, only daughters. The names of his daughters were Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah.

They approached Eleazar the priest, Joshua the son of Nun, and the leaders, saying, "The LORD commanded Moses to grant us an inheritance among our relatives." Therefore, in accordance with the LORD's command, he gave them an inheritance among the relatives of their father.
Manasseh received ten portions, in addition to the land of Gilead and Bashan, which were located on the other side of the Jordan.
The daughters of Manasseh received an inheritance alongside his sons, while the remaining sons of Manasseh received the land of Gilead.
The territory of Manasseh extended from Asher to Michmethah, which lies before Shechem; the border went to the right, toward the inhabitants of Entappuah.
Manasseh had the land of Tappuah, but Tappuah on the border of Manasseh belonged to the descendants of Ephraim.

The border descended to the river Kanah, south of the river; these cities of Ephraim were among the cities of Manasseh. The territory of Manasseh was also on the north side of the river, with its boundaries reaching the sea.
To the south was Ephraim's territory, and to the north was Manasseh's, with the sea as their border. They met in Asher to the north and in Issachar to the east.

In Issachar and Asher, Manasseh had Bethshean and its towns, Ibleam and its towns, the inhabitants of Dor and its towns, the inhabitants of Endor and its towns, the inhabitants of Taanach and its towns, and the inhabitants of Megiddo and its towns, encompassing three regions.
Yet the descendants of Manasseh were unable to drive out the inhabitants of those cities; the Canaanites continued to dwell in that land.
However, when the children of Israel grew strong, they subjected the Canaanites to forced labor but did not completely drive them out.
The children of Joseph spoke to Joshua, saying, "Why have you given us only one lot and one portion to inherit, when I am a numerous people, since the LORD has blessed me so far?"

Joshua replied, "If you are a numerous people, then go up to the forested area and clear land for yourselves there in the territory of the Perizzites and giants, if the hill country of Ephraim is too small for you."

The children of Joseph responded, "The hill country is not sufficient for us, and all the Canaanites who dwell in the valley have iron chariots, both those in Bethshean and its towns, and those in the valley of Jezreel."
Joshua spoke to the house of Joseph, to Ephraim and Manasseh, saying, "You are a great people and have great power; you shall not have just one lot.

The mountain shall be yours, for it is a forest, and you shall clear it. Its outlying areas shall be yours, for you shall drive out the Canaanites, even though they have iron chariots and are strong."
And the entire congregation of the children of Israel gathered together at Shiloh and established the tabernacle of the congregation there. The land was subdued before them.
Yet, among the children of Israel, seven tribes remained who had not yet received their inheritance.
Joshua addressed the children of Israel, asking, "How long will you hesitate to take possession of the land that the LORD God of your fathers has given you?"
Select three men from each tribe, and I will send them to explore the land, describing it according to their inheritance; they shall return to me.
They will divide it into seven parts: Judah will remain in their territory to the south, while the house of Joseph will occupy their territory to the north.
You shall describe the land in seven parts and bring the descriptions to me so that I may cast lots for you here before the LORD our God.

However, the Levites have no inheritance among you, for the priesthood of the LORD is their portion; Gad, Reuben, and half the tribe of Manasseh have already received their inheritance beyond the Jordan to the east, which Moses, the servant of the LORD, granted them.

The men arose and departed, and Joshua instructed those going to survey the land, saying, "Go and traverse the land, describe it, and return to me so that I may cast lots for you before the LORD in Shiloh."
The men went and surveyed the land, documenting it by cities into seven parts in a book, and returned to Joshua at the camp in Shiloh.
Joshua cast lots for them in Shiloh before the LORD, and there he divided the land among the children of Israel according to their divisions.
The lot for the tribe of Benjamin came up according to their families, and the boundary of their lot extended between the children of Judah and the children of Joseph.
Their northern border began at the Jordan, ascending to the side of Jericho on the north, and continuing westward through the mountains; its exits were at the wilderness of Bethaven.
The border then extended from there toward Luz, to the side of Luz, which is Bethel, moving southward; it descended to Atarothadar, near the hill on the south side of lower Bethhoron.

The border was drawn from there, encompassing the corner of the sea southward, from the hill that lies before Bethhoron southward; its exits were at Kirjathbaal, which is Kirjathjearim, a city of the children of Judah: this was the western boundary.
The southern boundary began at the end of Kirjathjearim, extending westward to the waters of Nephtoah.

The border descended to the end of the mountain that lies before the valley of the son of Hinnom, which is in the valley of the giants to the north, and it descended to the valley of Hinnom, to the side of Jebusi on the south, and continued down to Enrogel.
The border was drawn from the north, extending to Enshemesh, then toward Geliloth, which is opposite the ascent of Adummim, and descended to the stone of Bohan, the son of Reuben.
It continued along the side opposite Arabah northward and descended into the Arabah.
The border extended to the side of Bethhoglah northward, with the boundary's exits at the northern bay of the salt sea at the southern end of the Jordan: this was the southern coast.
The Jordan served as the eastern boundary. This was the inheritance of the children of Benjamin, encompassing their territories according to their families.
The cities of the tribe of Benjamin, according to their families, included Jericho, Bethhoglah, and the valley of Keziz,
Betharabah, Zemaraim, and Bethel,
Avim, Pharah, and Ophrah,
Chepharhaammonai, Ophni, and Gaba; a total of twelve cities with their villages:
Gibeon, Ramah, and Beeroth,
Mizpeh, Chephirah, and Mozah,
Rekem, Irpeel, and Taralah,
Zelah, Eleph, and Jebusi, which is Jerusalem, Gibeath, and Kirjath; fourteen cities with their villages. This is the inheritance of the children of Benjamin according to their families.

And the second lot was drawn for Simeon, specifically for the tribe of the children of Simeon according to their families; their inheritance was located within the inheritance of the children of Judah.
In their inheritance, they had Beersheba, Sheba, and Moladah,
Hazarshual, Balah, and Azem,
Eltolad, Bethul, and Hormah,
Ziklag, Bethmarcaboth, and Hazarsusah,
Bethlebaoth and Sharuhen; a total of thirteen cities along with their villages.
Ain, Remmon, Ether, and Ashan; four cities with their villages.
And all the villages surrounding these cities extended to Baalathbeer, Ramath of the south. This is the inheritance of the tribe of the children of Simeon according to their families.

From the portion of the children of Judah came the inheritance of the children of Simeon, for the portion of the children of Judah was too large for them; thus, the children of Simeon received their inheritance within their territory.
The third lot was drawn for the children of Zebulun according to their families; their border extended to Sarid.
Their border ascended toward the sea, including Maralah, reaching Dabbasheth, and extending to the river before Jokneam.
It turned from Sarid eastward toward the sunrise to the border of Chislothtabor, then went out to Daberath, and ascended to Japhia,
From there, it continued along the east to Gittahhepher, to Ittahkazin, and went out to Remmonmethoar to Neah.
The border encircled it on the north side to Hannathon, and the outgoings were in the valley of Jiphthahel.
Kattath, Nahallal, Shimron, Idalah, and Bethlehem: twelve cities with their villages.
This is the inheritance of the children of Zebulun according to their families, including these cities and their villages.
The fourth lot was drawn for Issachar, for the children of Issachar according to their families.
Their border extended toward Jezreel, Chesulloth, and Shunem,
Haphraim, Shihon, and Anaharath,
Rabbith, Kishion, Abez,
Remeth, Engannim, Enhaddah, and Bethpazzez;
The border reached Tabor, Shahazimah, and Bethshemesh; the outgoings of their border were at the Jordan: sixteen cities with their villages.
This is the inheritance of the tribe of the children of Issachar according to their families, including the cities and their villages.
The fifth lot was drawn for the tribe of the children of Asher according to their families.
Their border included Helkath, Hali, Beten, and Achshaph,
Alammelech, Amad, and Misheal; it extended to Carmel westward and to Shihorlibnath.
It turned toward the sunrise to Bethdagon, reaching Zebulun and the valley of Jiphthahel toward the north side of Bethemek, Neiel, and went out to Cabul on the left.
Hebron, Rehob, Hammon, and Kanah, even to great Zidon;
Then the border turned to Ramah and the strong city Tyre; it turned to Hosah, and the outgoings were at the sea from the coast to Achzib.
Ummah, Aphek, and Rehob: twenty-two cities with their villages.
This is the inheritance of the tribe of the children of Asher according to their families, including these cities and their villages.
The sixth lot was drawn for the children of Naphtali, specifically for the children of Naphtali according to their families.
Their border was from Heleph, from Allon to Zaanannim, and Adami, Nekeb, and Jabneel, up to Lakum; the outgoings were at the Jordan.
Then the border turned westward to Aznothtabor, going out from there to Hukkok, reaching Zebulun on the south side, Asher on the west side, and Judah upon Jordan toward the sunrise.
The fenced cities included Ziddim, Zer, Hammath, Rakkath, and Chinnereth,
Adamah, Ramah, and Hazor,
Kedesh, Edrei, and Enhazor,
Iron, Migdalel, Horem, Bethanath, and Bethshemesh; nineteen cities with their villages.
This is the inheritance of the tribe of the children of Naphtali according to their families, including the cities and their villages.
The seventh lot was drawn for the tribe of the children of Dan according to their families.
Their inheritance included Zorah, Eshtaol, and Irshemesh,
Shaalabbin, Ajalon, and Jethlah,
Elon, Thimnathah, and Ekron,
Eltekeh, Gibbethon, and Baalath,
Jehud, Beneberak, and Gathrimmon,
Mejarkon and Rakkon, with the border before Japho.

The territory of the children of Dan was too small for them; therefore, the children of Dan went up to fight against Leshem, captured it, struck it with the edge of the sword, possessed it, and dwelt there, naming it Dan after their father.
This is the inheritance of the tribe of the children of Dan according to their families, including these cities and their villages.
When they had completed dividing the land for inheritance by their borders, the children of Israel gave an inheritance to Joshua the son of Nun among them.
According to the word of the LORD, they gave him the city he requested, Timnathserah in the hill country of Ephraim; he built the city and dwelt there.

These are the inheritances that Eleazar the priest, Joshua the son of Nun, and the heads of the fathers of the tribes of the children of Israel divided by lot in Shiloh before the LORD, at the entrance of the tabernacle of the congregation. Thus, they completed the division of the land.
The LORD spoke to Joshua, saying,
"Speak to the children of Israel, saying, 'Designate cities of refuge, as I instructed you through Moses:
So that anyone who unintentionally kills another person may flee there; these cities shall serve as a refuge from the avenger of blood.

When someone flees to one of these cities, they must stand at the entrance of the city gate and present their case to the elders of that city. They will take him into the city and provide him a place to live among them.
If the avenger of blood pursues him, they shall not surrender the slayer to him, for he struck his neighbor unintentionally and had no prior hatred for him.

He shall remain in that city until he stands before the congregation for judgment and until the death of the high priest who is serving at that time; then the slayer may return to his own city and house, to the city from which he fled.
They designated Kedesh in Galilee in the hill country of Naphtali, Shechem in the hill country of Ephraim, and Kirjatharba, which is Hebron, in the hill country of Judah.

On the east side of the Jordan, near Jericho, they assigned Bezer in the wilderness, belonging to the tribe of Reuben, Ramoth in Gilead, belonging to the tribe of Gad, and Golan in Bashan, belonging to the tribe of Manasseh.

These were the cities designated for all the children of Israel and for the foreigner residing among them, so that anyone who unintentionally kills another person may flee there and not die at the hands of the avenger of blood until they stand before the congregation."
Then the heads of the Levite families approached Eleazar the priest, Joshua the son of Nun, and the leaders of the tribes of the children of Israel.
They spoke to them at Shiloh in the land of Canaan, saying, "The LORD commanded through Moses to give us cities to dwell in, along with their surrounding pasturelands for our livestock."
The children of Israel, at the command of the LORD, allocated these cities and their pasturelands to the Levites from their inheritance.

The lot was drawn for the families of the Kohathites, and the children of Aaron the priest, who were Levites, received by lot from the tribes of Judah, Simeon, and Benjamin, a total of thirteen cities.
The remaining children of Kohath received by lot from the families of the tribes of Ephraim, Dan, and the half-tribe of Manasseh, a total of ten cities.
The children of Gershon received by lot from the families of the tribes of Issachar, Asher, Naphtali, and the half-tribe of Manasseh in Bashan, a total of thirteen cities.
The children of Merari received by their families from the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and Zebulun, a total of twelve cities.
The children of Israel allocated these cities and their pasturelands to the Levites by lot, as the LORD commanded through Moses.
They designated cities from the tribe of Judah and the tribe of Simeon, which are mentioned here by name.
The children of Aaron, from the families of the Kohathites, who were descendants of Levi, received the first lot.
They were given the city of Arba, the father of Anak, which is Hebron, located in the hill country of Judah, along with its surrounding pasturelands.
However, the fields of the city and its villages were given to Caleb the son of Jephunneh as his possession.
Thus, the children of Aaron the priest received Hebron with its pasturelands, designated as a city of refuge for the slayer, along with Libnah and its pasturelands,
Jattir and its pasturelands, and Eshtemoa and its pasturelands,
Holon and its pasturelands, and Debir and its pasturelands,
Ain and its pasturelands, Juttah and its pasturelands, and Bethshemesh and its pasturelands; a total of nine cities from those two tribes.
From the tribe of Benjamin, they received Gibeon and its pasturelands, Geba and its pasturelands,
Anathoth and its pasturelands, and Almon and its pasturelands; a total of four cities.
In total, the cities of the children of Aaron, the priests, amounted to thirteen cities with their pasturelands.
The families of the remaining children of Kohath, the Levites, received their cities by lot from the tribe of Ephraim.
They were given Shechem and its pasturelands in the hill country of Ephraim, designated as a city of refuge for the slayer, along with Gezer and its pasturelands,
Kibzaim and its pasturelands, and Bethhoron and its pasturelands; a total of four cities.
From the tribe of Dan, they received Eltekeh and its pasturelands, Gibbethon and its pasturelands,
Aijalon and its pasturelands, and Gathrimmon and its pasturelands; a total of four cities.
From the half-tribe of Manasseh, they received Tanach and its pasturelands, and Gathrimmon and its pasturelands; a total of two cities.
In total, there were ten cities with their pasturelands for the families of the remaining children of Kohath.

To the children of Gershon, from the families of the Levites, they allocated Golan in Bashan and its pasturelands, designated as a city of refuge for the slayer, along with Beeshterah and its pasturelands; a total of two cities.
From the tribe of Issachar, they received Kishon and its pasturelands, Dabareh and its pasturelands,
Jarmuth and its pasturelands, and Engannim and its pasturelands; a total of four cities.
From the tribe of Asher, they received Mishal and its pasturelands, Abdon and its pasturelands,
Helkath and its pasturelands, and Rehob and its pasturelands; a total of four cities.

From the tribe of Naphtali, they received Kedesh in Galilee and its pasturelands, designated as a city of refuge for the slayer, along with Hammothdor and its pasturelands, and Kartan and its pasturelands; a total of three cities.
In total, the cities of the Gershonites according to their families amounted to thirteen cities with their pasturelands.
To the families of the children of Merari, the remaining Levites, they allocated from the tribe of Zebulun, Jokneam and its pasturelands, and Kartah and its pasturelands,
Dimnah and its pasturelands, and Nahalal and its pasturelands; a total of four cities.
From the tribe of Reuben, they received Bezer and its pasturelands, and Jahazah and its pasturelands,
Kedemoth and its pasturelands, and Mephaath and its pasturelands; a total of four cities.
From the tribe of Gad, they received Ramoth in Gilead and its pasturelands, designated as a city of refuge for the slayer, along with Mahanaim and its pasturelands,
Heshbon and its pasturelands, and Jazer and its pasturelands; a total of four cities.
Thus, all the cities for the children of Merari by their families, which remained of the families of the Levites, amounted to twelve cities by their lot.
In total, all the cities of the Levites within the possession of the children of Israel were forty-eight cities with their pasturelands.
Each of these cities had its surrounding pasturelands; thus, all these cities were accounted for.
The LORD gave Israel all the land He swore to give to their ancestors; they took possession of it and settled there.
The LORD provided them rest on every side, as He had sworn to their ancestors; not a single enemy stood against them; the LORD delivered all their enemies into their hands.
Nothing failed of any good thing that the LORD had spoken to the house of Israel; all came to pass.
Then Joshua summoned the Reubenites, the Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh,
and said to them, "You have faithfully followed all that Moses, the servant of the LORD, commanded you, and you have obeyed my instructions in everything I commanded you.
You have not abandoned your fellow Israelites these many days up to this day, but have upheld the charge of the commandment of the LORD your God.

Now the LORD your God has granted rest to your fellow Israelites, as He promised them; therefore, return to your tents and to the land of your possession, which Moses, the servant of the LORD, assigned to you on the other side of the Jordan.

But be very careful to observe the commandment and the law that Moses, the servant of the LORD, gave you: to love the LORD your God, to walk in all His ways, to keep His commandments, to hold fast to Him, and to serve Him with all your heart and with all your soul."
So Joshua blessed them and sent them away, and they went to their tents.

To the half-tribe of Manasseh, Moses had given land in Bashan, but to the other half, Joshua gave land among their brothers on this side of the Jordan, westward. When Joshua sent them away to their tents, he also blessed them,

and he said to them, "Return with great wealth to your tents, with very much livestock, with silver, gold, bronze, iron, and with a great quantity of clothing; divide the spoils of your enemies with your brothers."

The children of Reuben, the children of Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh returned and departed from the children of Israel at Shiloh, which is in the land of Canaan, to go to the region of Gilead, to the land of their possession, which they had received according to the word of the LORD through Moses.

When they reached the borders of the Jordan in the land of Canaan, the children of Reuben, the children of Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh built an altar by the Jordan, a large altar visible from afar.

The children of Israel heard it said, "Behold, the children of Reuben, the children of Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh have built an altar opposite the land of Canaan, at the borders of the Jordan, at the crossing point for the children of Israel."
When the children of Israel heard this, the entire congregation gathered at Shiloh to go to war against them.
The children of Israel sent Phinehas, the son of Eleazar the priest, to the children of Reuben, the children of Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh in the land of Gilead,
along with ten leaders, one from each chief house throughout all the tribes of Israel; each was the head of a family among the thousands of Israel.
They went to the children of Reuben, the children of Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh in the land of Gilead and spoke to them, saying,

"Thus says the whole congregation of the LORD: What is this trespass you have committed against the God of Israel, turning away this day from following the LORD by building an altar for yourselves, thereby rebelling against the LORD?
Is the iniquity of Peor too small for us, from which we have not been cleansed to this day, even though a plague came upon the congregation of the LORD?
But now you must turn away this day from following the LORD? If you rebel today against the LORD, tomorrow His anger will be against the whole congregation of Israel.

Nevertheless, if the land you possess is unclean, then cross over to the land of the LORD's possession, where the LORD's tabernacle dwells, and take possession among us; but do not rebel against the LORD, nor against us, by building an altar beside the altar of the LORD our God.
Did not Achan, the son of Zerah, commit a trespass regarding the accursed thing, and wrath fell on all the congregation of Israel? That man did not perish alone in his iniquity."
Then the children of Reuben, the children of Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh answered the heads of the thousands of Israel,
"The LORD God of gods knows, and Israel will know; if it is in rebellion or in transgression against the LORD, do not save us this day.
If we have built an altar to turn away from following the LORD, or to offer burnt offerings or grain offerings, or to offer peace offerings on it, let the LORD Himself require it.
And if we have not done it out of fear of this thing, saying, 'In time to come your children might speak to our children, saying, What have you to do with the LORD God of Israel?'

For the LORD has made the Jordan a border between us and you, you children of Reuben and children of Gad; you have no part in the LORD, so your children might make our children cease from fearing the LORD.
Therefore, we said, 'Let us now prepare to build an altar, not for burnt offerings or sacrifices,

but as a witness between us and you and our generations after us, that we may perform the service of the LORD before Him with our burnt offerings, sacrifices, and peace offerings; so that your children may not say to our children in time to come, "You have no part in the LORD."

Therefore, we said, when they say this to us or to our generations in the future, we may say, 'Behold the pattern of the altar of the LORD, which our fathers made, not for burnt offerings or sacrifices, but as a witness between us and you.'

God forbid that we should rebel against the LORD and turn away this day from following the LORD by building an altar for burnt offerings, grain offerings, or sacrifices, besides the altar of the LORD our God that is before His tabernacle."

When Phinehas the priest and the leaders of the congregation, the heads of the thousands of Israel who were with him, heard the words that the children of Reuben, the children of Gad, and the children of Manasseh spoke, it pleased them.

Phinehas, the son of Eleazar the priest, said to the children of Reuben, the children of Gad, and the children of Manasseh, "Today we know that the LORD is among us, because you have not committed this trespass against the LORD; now you have delivered the children of Israel from the hand of the LORD."

Phinehas, the son of Eleazar the priest, and the leaders returned from the children of Reuben and the children of Gad in the land of Gilead to the land of Canaan, to the children of Israel, and brought them word again.
The matter pleased the children of Israel, and they blessed God and did not intend to go up against them in battle to destroy the land where the children of Reuben and Gad dwelt.
The children of Reuben and the children of Gad named the altar Ed, for it shall be a witness between us that the LORD is God.
And it came to pass a long time after the LORD had granted Israel rest from all their surrounding enemies, that Joshua grew old and advanced in age.
Joshua summoned all of Israel, along with their elders, leaders, judges, and officers, and said to them, "I am old and advanced in age."
"You have witnessed all that the LORD your God has done to these nations on your behalf; for the LORD your God is the one who has fought for you."
"Behold, I have allocated to you by lot the remaining nations as an inheritance for your tribes, from the Jordan River, including all the nations I have cut off, up to the great sea to the west."
"And the LORD your God will drive them out before you and remove them from your sight; you shall possess their land, as the LORD your God has promised you."
"Therefore, be very courageous to observe and do all that is written in the book of the law of Moses, turning neither to the right nor to the left."
"Do not associate with these nations that remain among you; do not mention the names of their gods, nor make oaths by them, nor serve them, nor bow down to them."
"But hold fast to the LORD your God, as you have done to this day."
"For the LORD has driven out great and powerful nations before you; yet, no one has been able to stand against you to this day."
"One of you shall chase a thousand, for the LORD your God fights for you, as He has promised."
"Take careful heed to yourselves, that you love the LORD your God."
"But if you turn back and cling to the remnant of these nations that remain among you, and intermarry with them, and associate with them, and they with you,"

"Know for certain that the LORD your God will no longer drive out any of these nations before you; they will become snares and traps for you, and whips on your sides, and thorns in your eyes, until you perish from this good land which the LORD your God has given you."

"And behold, this day I am going the way of all the earth; and you know in your hearts and souls that not one thing has failed of all the good things which the LORD your God spoke concerning you; all have come to pass, and not one thing has failed."

"Therefore, it shall come to pass that as all the good things have come upon you, which the LORD your God promised you, so the LORD will bring upon you all the evil things, until He has destroyed you from this good land which the LORD your God has given you."

"When you have transgressed the covenant of the LORD your God, which He commanded you, and have gone and served other gods, and bowed down to them, then the anger of the LORD will be kindled against you, and you shall perish quickly from the good land which He has given you."
And Joshua gathered all the tribes of Israel at Shechem, calling for the elders, heads, judges, and officers of Israel; they presented themselves before God.

Joshua addressed all the people, saying, "Thus says the LORD God of Israel: Your ancestors lived on the other side of the river in ancient times, including Terah, the father of Abraham and Nahor, and they served other gods."
"I took your father Abraham from the other side of the river, led him through all the land of Canaan, multiplied his descendants, and gave him Isaac."
"I gave Isaac two sons, Jacob and Esau; I assigned Esau the region of Mount Seir to possess, while Jacob and his children went down to Egypt."
"I also sent Moses and Aaron, and I plagued Egypt with the wonders I performed among them; afterward, I brought you out."
"I brought your ancestors out of Egypt, and you came to the sea; the Egyptians pursued your ancestors with chariots and horsemen to the Red Sea."

"When they cried out to the LORD, He put darkness between you and the Egyptians, and brought the sea upon them, covering them; your eyes have seen what I did in Egypt, and you dwelt in the wilderness for a long time."

"I brought you into the land of the Amorites, who lived on the other side of the Jordan; they fought against you, but I gave them into your hand so that you might possess their land, and I destroyed them before you."
"Then Balak son of Zippor, king of Moab, arose and waged war against Israel, sending for Balaam son of Beor to curse you."
"But I would not listen to Balaam; instead, he blessed you, and I delivered you from his hand."

"You crossed the Jordan and came to Jericho, where the men of Jericho fought against you, along with the Amorites, Perizzites, Canaanites, Hittites, Girgashites, Hivites, and Jebusites; I delivered them into your hand."
"I sent the hornet ahead of you, which drove them out before you, even the two kings of the Amorites; but not by your sword or bow."
"I have given you a land for which you did not labor, and cities you did not build; you dwell in them, and eat from vineyards and olive groves you did not plant."
"Now, therefore, fear the LORD and serve Him in sincerity and truth; put away the gods your ancestors served on the other side of the river and in Egypt, and serve the LORD."

"If it seems evil to you to serve the LORD, choose this day whom you will serve: whether the gods your ancestors served beyond the river, or the gods of the Amorites in whose land you dwell; but as for me and my house, we will serve the LORD."
The people answered, "God forbid that we should forsake the LORD to serve other gods."

"For the LORD our God is the one who brought us and our ancestors out of the land of Egypt, from the house of bondage, and performed those great signs in our sight, preserving us throughout our journey and among all the peoples through whom we passed."
"The LORD drove out before us all the peoples, including the Amorites who lived in the land; therefore, we will also serve the LORD, for He is our God."
Joshua said to the people, "You cannot serve the LORD, for He is a holy God; He is a jealous God; He will not forgive your transgressions or your sins."
"If you forsake the LORD and serve foreign gods, He will turn and do you harm, consuming you after He has done you good."
The people replied to Joshua, "No, we will serve the LORD."
Joshua said to the people, "You are witnesses against yourselves that you have chosen the LORD to serve Him." They replied, "We are witnesses."
"Now, therefore," he said, "put away the foreign gods that are among you, and incline your hearts to the LORD God of Israel."
The people said to Joshua, "The LORD our God we will serve, and His voice we will obey."
So Joshua made a covenant with the people that day, establishing a statute and an ordinance at Shechem.
Joshua wrote these words in the book of the law of God, took a large stone, and set it up there under an oak near the sanctuary of the LORD.

Joshua said to all the people, "Behold, this stone shall be a witness against us; for it has heard all the words of the LORD which He spoke to us; it shall therefore be a witness to you, lest you deny your God."
So Joshua let the people depart, each to their own inheritance.
After these things, Joshua son of Nun, the servant of the LORD, died at the age of one hundred and ten years.
They buried him in the territory of his inheritance at Timnathserah, in the hill country of Ephraim, north of the hill of Gaash.
Israel served the LORD throughout the days of Joshua and the days of the elders who outlived him, who had known all the works of the LORD that He had done for Israel.

The bones of Joseph, which the children of Israel brought up from Egypt, were buried at Shechem, in the parcel of ground Jacob bought from the sons of Hamor, the father of Shechem, for a hundred pieces of silver; it became the inheritance of the children of Joseph.
Eleazar son of Aaron died, and they buried him on a hill that belonged to Phinehas his son, which was given to him in the hill country of Ephraim.
After the death of Joshua, the children of Israel inquired of the LORD, asking, "Who will go up first to fight against the Canaanites?"
The LORD responded, "Judah shall go up; behold, I have delivered the land into his hands."
Judah then said to his brother Simeon, "Come with me to my territory, so we can fight against the Canaanites; I will also go with you to your territory." So Simeon joined him.
Judah advanced, and the LORD delivered the Canaanites and the Perizzites into their hands; they killed ten thousand men at Bezek.
They discovered Adonibezek in Bezek, fought against him, and defeated the Canaanites and the Perizzites.
However, Adonibezek fled, and they pursued him, captured him, and cut off his thumbs and big toes.
Adonibezek remarked, "Seventy kings, with their thumbs and big toes cut off, gathered scraps under my table; as I have done, so God has repaid me." They brought him to Jerusalem, where he died.
The children of Judah fought against Jerusalem, captured it, struck it with the sword, and set the city ablaze.
Afterward, the children of Judah went down to battle against the Canaanites living in the hill country, the Negev, and the lowland.
Judah attacked the Canaanites in Hebron (formerly known as Kirjatharba) and killed Sheshai, Ahiman, and Talmai.
From there, he went against the inhabitants of Debir (formerly known as Kirjathsepher).
Caleb declared, "Whoever attacks and captures Kirjathsepher, I will give my daughter Achsah to him as a wife."
Othniel, the son of Kenaz, Caleb's younger brother, captured it, and Caleb gave him his daughter Achsah as a wife.
When she came to him, she urged him to ask her father for a field; she dismounted from her donkey, and Caleb asked her, "What do you want?"
She replied, "Give me a blessing; you have given me a south land; now give me also springs of water." Caleb granted her the upper and lower springs.
The descendants of the Kenite, Moses' father-in-law, went up from the city of palm trees with the children of Judah into the wilderness of Judah, south of Arad, and settled among the people.
Judah and his brother Simeon attacked the Canaanites in Zephath and completely destroyed it; the city was named Hormah.
Judah also captured Gaza, its territory, Askelon, its territory, and Ekron, its territory.
The LORD was with Judah, and he drove out the inhabitants of the hill country, but he could not drive out the inhabitants of the valley because they had iron chariots.
They gave Hebron to Caleb, as Moses had instructed, and he expelled the three sons of Anak from there.
The children of Benjamin did not drive out the Jebusites who lived in Jerusalem; thus, the Jebusites live with the children of Benjamin in Jerusalem to this day.
The house of Joseph also went up against Bethel, and the LORD was with them.
The house of Joseph sent spies to scout Bethel (formerly known as Luz).
The spies saw a man coming out of the city and said to him, "Show us the entrance to the city, and we will show you mercy."
When he showed them the entrance to the city, they struck the city with the sword but let the man and his family go free.
The man went to the land of the Hittites, built a city, and named it Luz, which remains its name to this day.

Manasseh did not drive out the inhabitants of Bethshean and its towns, nor Taanach and its towns, nor the inhabitants of Dor and its towns, nor the inhabitants of Ibleam and its towns, nor the inhabitants of Megiddo and its towns; the Canaanites continued to dwell in that land.
When Israel became strong, they subjected the Canaanites to forced labor but did not completely drive them out.
Ephraim did not drive out the Canaanites living in Gezer; thus, the Canaanites continued to dwell in Gezer among them.
Zebulun did not drive out the inhabitants of Kitron or Nahalol; the Canaanites lived among them and became tributaries.
Asher did not drive out the inhabitants of Accho, Zidon, Ahlab, Achzib, Helbah, Aphik, or Rehob;
the Asherites lived among the Canaanites, the inhabitants of the land, because they did not drive them out.

Naphtali did not drive out the inhabitants of Bethshemesh or Bethanath; instead, he lived among the Canaanites, the inhabitants of the land, but the inhabitants of Bethshemesh and Bethanath became tributaries to them.
The Amorites forced the children of Dan into the mountains, preventing them from coming down to the valley.
However, the Amorites continued to dwell in Mount Heres, Aijalon, and Shaalbim; yet the hand of the house of Joseph prevailed, and they became tributaries.
The territory of the Amorites extended from the ascent of Akrabbim, from the rock, and upward.

An angel of the LORD ascended from Gilgal to Bochim and said, "I brought you up from Egypt and led you to the land I promised to your ancestors; I declared that I would never break my covenant with you.
You must not make any agreements with the inhabitants of this land; you must tear down their altars. Yet you have not obeyed my voice. Why have you done this?
Therefore, I also declared that I will not drive them out before you; they will be like thorns in your sides, and their gods will be a trap for you.
When the angel of the LORD spoke these words to all the children of Israel, the people raised their voices and wept.
They named that place Bochim and offered sacrifices there to the LORD.
After Joshua dismissed the people, the children of Israel went to their respective inheritances to possess the land.
The people served the LORD throughout the days of Joshua and all the days of the elders who outlived him, those who had witnessed all the great works the LORD had done for Israel.
Joshua, the son of Nun, the servant of the LORD, died at the age of one hundred and ten.
They buried him in the territory of his inheritance at Timnath-heres, in the hill country of Ephraim, north of the hill Gaash.
That entire generation was gathered to their ancestors, and another generation arose after them that did not know the LORD or the works He had done for Israel.
The children of Israel did evil in the sight of the LORD and served Baalim.
They forsook the LORD God of their fathers, who had brought them out of Egypt, and followed other gods, the gods of the surrounding peoples, bowing down to them and provoking the LORD to anger.
They abandoned the LORD and served Baal and Ashtaroth.

The anger of the LORD burned against Israel, and He delivered them into the hands of plunderers who stripped them, and He sold them into the hands of their enemies all around, so they could no longer stand against their enemies.
Wherever they went, the hand of the LORD was against them for harm, as the LORD had said and sworn to them; they were greatly distressed.
Nevertheless, the LORD raised up judges who delivered them from the hands of those who plundered them.

Yet they would not listen to their judges; instead, they went after other gods and bowed down to them. They quickly turned away from the path their fathers had walked, obeying the commandments of the LORD; they did not do so.

When the LORD raised up judges for them, He was with the judge and delivered them from the hands of their enemies throughout the judge's lifetime, for the LORD was moved to pity by their groanings because of those who oppressed and afflicted them.

But when the judge died, they returned and corrupted themselves more than their fathers, following other gods to serve and bow down to them; they did not cease from their own practices or their stubborn ways.
The anger of the LORD burned against Israel, and He said, "Because this people has violated my covenant that I commanded their fathers and has not listened to my voice,
I will no longer drive out any of the nations that Joshua left when he died.
I will use them to test Israel, to see whether they will keep the way of the LORD and walk in it as their fathers did."
Therefore, the LORD left those nations, without hastily driving them out, nor did He deliver them into the hand of Joshua.
Now these are the nations that the LORD left to test Israel, specifically those among the Israelites who had not experienced all the wars of Canaan.
This was so that the generations of the children of Israel might learn about warfare, especially those who had previously known nothing about it.
These included five lords of the Philistines, all the Canaanites, the Sidonians, and the Hivites who lived in the mountains of Lebanon, from Mount Baalhermon to the entrance of Hamath.
They were meant to test Israel to see if they would listen to the commandments of the LORD, which He commanded their ancestors through Moses.
The children of Israel lived among the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites.
They took their daughters as wives and gave their own daughters to their sons, and they served their gods.
The children of Israel did evil in the sight of the LORD; they forgot the LORD their God and served Baalim and the Asherah poles.
As a result, the anger of the LORD burned against Israel, and He sold them into the hands of Chushanrishathaim, king of Mesopotamia, and the children of Israel served him for eight years.
When the children of Israel cried out to the LORD, He raised up a deliverer for them, Othniel, the son of Kenaz, Caleb's younger brother.
The Spirit of the LORD came upon him, and he judged Israel; he went to war, and the LORD delivered Chushanrishathaim, king of Mesopotamia, into his hands, and he prevailed against him.
The land had peace for forty years, until Othniel, the son of Kenaz, died.
The children of Israel again did evil in the sight of the LORD, and the LORD strengthened Eglon, the king of Moab, against Israel because they had done evil in His sight.
He gathered the children of Ammon and Amalek, went and struck Israel, and took possession of the city of palm trees.
So the children of Israel served Eglon, the king of Moab, for eighteen years.

But when the children of Israel cried out to the LORD, He raised up a deliverer for them, Ehud, the son of Gera, a Benjamite, a left-handed man; by him, the children of Israel sent a tribute to Eglon, the king of Moab.
Ehud made himself a double-edged dagger about a cubit long and strapped it to his right thigh under his clothing.
He brought the tribute to Eglon, king of Moab, who was a very fat man.
After he had finished presenting the tribute, he sent away the people who had carried it.
But he himself turned back from the stone images near Gilgal and said, "I have a secret message for you, O king." The king said, "Keep silence!" And all who stood by him went out from him.
Ehud approached him while he was sitting in his cool upper room and said, "I have a message from God for you." The king rose from his seat.
Ehud reached with his left hand, took the dagger from his right thigh, and plunged it into the king's belly.
The blade went in after the haft, and the fat closed over the blade so that he could not draw the dagger out of his belly, and excrement came out.
Then Ehud went out through the porch, shut the doors of the upper room behind him, and locked them.
When he had gone out, his servants came; and when they saw that the doors of the upper room were locked, they said, "Surely he is covering his feet in the inner chamber."
They waited until they were embarrassed; but when he still did not open the doors of the upper room, they took the key and opened them, and there lay their lord, dead on the floor.
Ehud escaped while they tarried, passing beyond the stone images and escaping to Seirath.
When he arrived, he blew a trumpet in the mountains of Ephraim, and the children of Israel went down with him from the mountains, and he led them.

He said to them, "Follow me, for the LORD has delivered your enemies, the Moabites, into your hands." So they followed him down and took the fords of the Jordan against Moab, allowing no one to cross over.
At that time, they killed about ten thousand Moabite men, all strong and valiant; not one escaped.
So Moab was subdued that day under the hand of Israel, and the land had peace for eighty years.
After him came Shamgar, the son of Anath, who killed six hundred men of the Philistines with an ox goad; he also delivered Israel.
The children of Israel once again committed evil in the sight of the LORD after the death of Ehud.
The LORD allowed them to fall into the hands of Jabin, the king of Canaan, who ruled in Hazor; his army's commander was Sisera, who lived in Harosheth of the Gentiles.
The children of Israel cried out to the LORD, for he had nine hundred iron chariots and had severely oppressed them for twenty years.
Deborah, a prophetess and the wife of Lapidoth, was judging Israel at that time.
She lived under the palm tree of Deborah, located between Ramah and Bethel in the hill country of Ephraim, and the children of Israel came to her for judgment.

She sent for Barak, the son of Abinoam, from Kedesh in Naphtali, and said to him, "Has not the LORD God of Israel commanded you to go and gather at Mount Tabor, taking with you ten thousand men from the tribes of Naphtali and Zebulun?
I will lure Sisera, the commander of Jabin's army, along with his chariots and troops, to the river Kishon and give him into your hands."
Barak replied, "If you go with me, I will go; but if you do not go with me, I will not go."

She answered, "Certainly, I will go with you; however, the journey you are taking will not bring you glory, for the LORD will deliver Sisera into the hands of a woman." Deborah then arose and went with Barak to Kedesh.
Barak summoned Zebulun and Naphtali to Kedesh, and he marched up with ten thousand men at his feet, with Deborah accompanying him.
Now Heber the Kenite, a descendant of Hobab, Moses' father-in-law, had separated himself from the Kenites and pitched his tent near the plain of Zaanaim, close to Kedesh.
They informed Sisera that Barak, the son of Abinoam, had gone up to Mount Tabor.
Sisera gathered all his chariots, including nine hundred iron chariots, and all his troops, from Harosheth of the Gentiles to the river Kishon.

Deborah said to Barak, "Get up, for this is the day the LORD has delivered Sisera into your hands. Is not the LORD going ahead of you?" So Barak descended from Mount Tabor, followed by ten thousand men.
The LORD routed Sisera, his chariots, and his entire army before Barak; Sisera leaped from his chariot and fled on foot.
Barak pursued the chariots and the army all the way to Harosheth of the Gentiles, and all of Sisera's troops fell by the sword; not a single man was left.
However, Sisera fled on foot to the tent of Jael, the wife of Heber the Kenite, for there was peace between Jabin, the king of Hazor, and the house of Heber the Kenite.
Jael went out to meet Sisera and said to him, "Turn in, my lord, turn in to me; do not be afraid." When he turned in to her tent, she covered him with a blanket.
He said to her, "Please give me a little water to drink, for I am thirsty." She opened a skin of milk, gave him a drink, and covered him.
He then said to her, "Stand at the entrance of the tent, and if anyone comes and asks you, 'Is there anyone here?' say, 'No.'"
Jael, Heber's wife, took a tent peg and a hammer in her hand, quietly approached him, and drove the peg through his temple into the ground, for he was fast asleep and exhausted. So he died.
As Barak pursued Sisera, Jael came out to meet him and said, "Come, I will show you the man you are looking for." When he entered her tent, he saw Sisera lying dead, with the tent peg in his temple.
So on that day, God subdued Jabin, the king of Canaan, before the children of Israel.
The children of Israel pressed on and prevailed against Jabin, the king of Canaan, until they had destroyed him completely.
Then Deborah and Barak, the son of Abinoam, sang on that day, saying,
Praise the LORD for avenging Israel, when the people willingly offered themselves.
Hear, O kings; give ear, O princes; I, even I, will sing to the LORD; I will praise the LORD God of Israel.
LORD, when You went out from Seir, when You marched from the field of Edom, the earth trembled, and the heavens poured down rain; the clouds also dropped water.
The mountains melted before the LORD, even Sinai before the LORD God of Israel.
In the days of Shamgar, son of Anath, in the days of Jael, the highways were deserted, and travelers walked along byways.
The inhabitants of the villages ceased; they ceased in Israel, until I, Deborah, arose, a mother in Israel.
They chose new gods; then war was at the gates: was there a shield or spear seen among forty thousand in Israel?
My heart is with the governors of Israel, who offered themselves willingly among the people. Bless the LORD.
Speak, you who ride on white donkeys, you who sit in judgment, and walk along the way.
