Those who are delivered from the noise of archers at the watering places, there they shall recount the righteous acts of the LORD, the righteous acts toward the inhabitants of His villages in Israel; then the people of the LORD shall go down to the gates.
Awake, awake, Deborah! Awake, awake, sing a song! Arise, Barak, and lead your captives away, son of Abinoam.
Then He made him who remains have dominion over the nobles among the people; the LORD made me have dominion over the mighty.
Out of Ephraim came a root against Amalek; after you, Benjamin, among your people; out of Machir came down governors, and out of Zebulun those who handle the pen of the writer.
And the princes of Issachar were with Deborah; even Issachar, and Barak: he was sent on foot into the valley. For the divisions of Reuben there were great thoughts of heart.
Why did you stay among the sheepfolds, to hear the bleating of the flocks? For the divisions of Reuben there were great searchings of heart.
Gilead stayed beyond the Jordan; and why did Dan remain in ships? Asher continued on the seashore and stayed in his inlets.
Zebulun and Naphtali were a people who risked their lives to the death in the high places of the field.
The kings came and fought; then the kings of Canaan fought in Taanach by the waters of Megiddo; they took no gain of money.
They fought from heaven; the stars in their courses fought against Sisera.
The river Kishon swept them away, that ancient river, the river Kishon. O my soul, you have trodden down strength.
Then the horse hooves were broken by the means of the prancing, the prancing of their mighty ones.
Curse Meroz, said the angel of the LORD; curse bitterly the inhabitants thereof; because they did not come to the help of the LORD, to the help of the LORD against the mighty.
Blessed above women shall Jael, the wife of Heber the Kenite, be; blessed shall she be above women in the tent.
He asked for water, and she gave him milk; she brought forth butter in a lordly dish.
She put her hand to the tent peg, and her right hand to the workmen's hammer; and with the hammer, she struck Sisera, she struck off his head, when she had pierced and struck through his temples.
At her feet, he bowed, he fell, he lay down; at her feet, he bowed, he fell; where he bowed, there he fell down dead.
The mother of Sisera looked out at a window and cried through the lattice, "Why is his chariot so long in coming? Why do the wheels of his chariots tarry?"
Her wise ladies answered her; yes, she returned answer to herself,

"Have they not sped? Have they not divided the prey; to every man a damsel or two; to Sisera a prey of diverse colors, a prey of diverse colors of needlework, of diverse colors of needlework on both sides, meet for the necks of those who take the spoil?"
So let all Your enemies perish, O LORD; but let those who love Him be like the sun when it goes forth in its might. And the land had rest for forty years.
The children of Israel committed evil in the sight of the LORD, and as a result, the LORD allowed them to be oppressed by Midian for seven years.
The Midianites gained the upper hand against Israel, and due to their oppression, the Israelites made dens, caves, and strongholds in the mountains.
When Israel had sown their crops, the Midianites, along with the Amalekites and the people from the east, came up against them.
They camped against Israel and destroyed the produce of the land, reaching as far as Gaza, leaving no sustenance for Israel—neither sheep, oxen, nor donkeys.
They came with their livestock and tents, overwhelming in number like locusts; both they and their camels were countless, entering the land to devastate it.
Israel was greatly impoverished because of the Midianites, and the children of Israel cried out to the LORD for help.
When the children of Israel cried out to the LORD because of the Midianites,
the LORD sent a prophet to them, saying, "Thus says the LORD God of Israel: I brought you up from Egypt and delivered you from the house of bondage.
I rescued you from the Egyptians and from all who oppressed you, driving them out before you and giving you their land.
I said to you, 'I am the LORD your God; do not fear the gods of the Amorites, in whose land you dwell.' But you have not obeyed my voice."
An angel of the LORD came and sat under an oak tree in Ophrah, belonging to Joash the Abiezrite; his son Gideon was threshing wheat in the winepress to hide it from the Midianites.
The angel of the LORD appeared to him and said, "The LORD is with you, mighty warrior."

Gideon replied, "Pardon me, my Lord, if the LORD is with us, why has all this happened to us? Where are all his wonders that our ancestors told us about, saying, 'Did not the LORD bring us up from Egypt?' But now the LORD has abandoned us and given us into the hands of the Midianites."
The LORD turned to him and said, "Go in the strength you have and save Israel out of Midian's hand. Am I not sending you?"
Gideon answered, "Pardon me, my Lord, but how can I save Israel? My clan is the weakest in Manasseh, and I am the least in my family."
The LORD said to him, "I will be with you, and you will strike down all the Midianites, leaving none alive."
Gideon replied, "If I have found favor in your eyes, give me a sign that it is really you talking to me.
Please do not go away until I come back and bring my offering and set it before you." The LORD said, "I will wait until you return."

Gideon went inside, prepared a young goat, and made unleavened bread from an ephah of flour. He put the meat in a basket and the broth in a pot, and brought them out to him under the oak and presented them.
The angel of God said to him, "Take the meat and the unleavened bread and place them on this rock and pour out the broth." Gideon did so.

Then the angel of the LORD touched the meat and the unleavened bread with the tip of the staff that was in his hand; fire flared from the rock, consuming the meat and the bread. The angel of the LORD disappeared.
When Gideon realized that it was the angel of the LORD, he exclaimed, "Alas, Sovereign LORD! I have seen the angel of the LORD face to face!"
But the LORD said to him, "Peace! Do not be afraid. You are not going to die."
So Gideon built an altar to the LORD there and called it The LORD Is Peace. To this day it stands in Ophrah of the Abiezrites.
That same night the LORD said to him, "Take the second bull from your father's herd, the one seven years old. Tear down your father's altar to Baal and cut down the Asherah pole beside it.
Then build a proper altar to the LORD your God on the top of this height, using the wood of the Asherah pole that you cut down. Offer the second bull as a burnt offering."
So Gideon took ten of his servants and did as the LORD told him. But because he was afraid of his family and the townspeople, he did it at night rather than in the daytime.
Early the next morning, when the people of the town got up, there was Baal's altar, demolished, with the Asherah pole beside it cut down, and the second bull sacrificed on the newly built altar!
They asked each other, "Who did this?" When they carefully investigated, they were told, "Gideon son of Joash did it."
The people of the town demanded of Joash, "Bring out your son. He must die because he has broken down Baal's altar and cut down the Asherah pole beside it."

But Joash replied to the hostile crowd around him, "Are you going to plead Baal's cause? Are you trying to save him? Whoever fights for him shall be put to death by morning. If Baal really is a god, he can defend himself when someone breaks down his altar."
So because Gideon broke down Baal's altar, they gave him the name Jerub-Baal that day, saying, "Let Baal contend with him."
Now all the Midianites, Amalekites, and other eastern peoples joined forces and crossed over the Jordan and camped in the Valley of Jezreel.
Then the Spirit of the LORD came on Gideon, and he blew a trumpet, summoning the Abiezrites to follow him.
He sent messengers throughout Manasseh, calling them to arms, and also into Asher, Zebulun, and Naphtali; so they went up to meet them.
Gideon said to God, "If you will save Israel by my hand as you have promised—
look, I will place a wool fleece on the threshing floor. If there is dew only on the fleece and all the ground is dry, then I will know that you will save Israel by my hand, as you said."
And that is what happened. Gideon rose early the next day; he squeezed the fleece and wrung out the dew—a bowl full of water.
Then Gideon said to God, "Do not be angry with me. Let me make just one more request. Allow me one more test with the fleece. This time make the fleece dry and the ground covered with dew."
That night God did so. Only the fleece was dry; all the ground was covered with dew.
Then Jerubbaal, who is Gideon, and all the people with him rose early and camped beside the well of Harod, while the Midianite host was on the north side, near the hill of Moreh in the valley.
And the LORD said to Gideon, "The people with you are too many for me to deliver the Midianites into their hands, lest Israel boast against me, saying, 'My own hand has saved me.'

Now therefore, go and proclaim in the ears of the people, saying, 'Whoever is fearful and afraid, let him return and depart early from Mount Gilead.' So twenty-two thousand of the people returned, leaving ten thousand.

And the LORD said to Gideon, "The people are still too many; bring them down to the water, and I will test them for you there. It shall be that of whom I say to you, 'This one shall go with you,' he shall go; and of whomsoever I say to you, 'This one shall not go with you,' he shall not go."

So he brought the people down to the water, and the LORD said to Gideon, "Everyone who laps the water with his tongue, as a dog laps, you shall set apart by himself; likewise, everyone who bows down on his knees to drink."
The number of those who lapped, bringing water to their mouths, was three hundred men; but all the rest of the people knelt down to drink water.
And the LORD said to Gideon, "By the three hundred men who lapped, I will save you and deliver the Midianites into your hand; let all the other people go, every man to his place."

So the people took provisions in their hands and their trumpets; and he sent all the rest of Israel, every man to his tent, and retained those three hundred men. The Midianite host was below him in the valley.
That same night, the LORD said to him, "Arise, go down to the host, for I have delivered it into your hand.
But if you are afraid to go down, go with Phurah your servant down to the host.
And you shall hear what they say; afterward, your hands shall be strengthened to go down to the host." So he went down with Phurah his servant to the outskirts of the armed men in the host.
The Midianites, the Amalekites, and all the children of the east lay in the valley like a multitude of grasshoppers; their camels were without number, as the sand by the seashore for multitude.

When Gideon arrived, he overheard a man telling his companion about a dream, saying, "I dreamed a dream, and behold, a cake of barley bread tumbled into the host of Midian, came to a tent, struck it, and it fell, overturning it so that the tent lay flat."
His companion answered, "This is nothing else but the sword of Gideon the son of Joash, a man of Israel; for into his hand God has delivered Midian and all the host."
When Gideon heard the telling of the dream and its interpretation, he worshipped, returned to the host of Israel, and said, "Arise, for the LORD has delivered into your hand the host of Midian."
He divided the three hundred men into three companies, and he put a trumpet in every man's hand, with empty pitchers and lamps within the pitchers.
He said to them, "Look at me and do likewise; when I come to the outskirts of the camp, as I do, so shall you do.
When I blow the trumpet, I and all who are with me, then you also blow the trumpets all around the camp and say, 'The sword of the LORD and of Gideon!'"

So Gideon and the hundred men who were with him came to the outskirts of the camp at the beginning of the middle watch, just as they had newly set the watch. They blew the trumpets and broke the pitchers that were in their hands.
The three companies blew the trumpets, broke the pitchers, held the lamps in their left hands, and the trumpets in their right hands to blow with. They cried, "The sword of the LORD and of Gideon!"
They stood every man in his place around the camp, and all the host ran, cried out, and fled.

The three hundred blew the trumpets, and the LORD set every man's sword against his fellow throughout all the host; and the host fled to Bethshittah in Zererath and to the border of Abelmeholah, unto Tabbath.
The men of Israel gathered together from Naphtali, Asher, and all Manasseh, and pursued after the Midianites.

Gideon sent messengers throughout all Mount Ephraim, saying, "Come down against the Midianites and take the waters before them as far as Bethbarah and the Jordan." Then all the men of Ephraim gathered together and took the waters as far as Bethbarah and the Jordan.

They captured two princes of the Midianites, Oreb and Zeeb; they killed Oreb at the rock of Oreb and Zeeb they killed at the winepress of Zeeb, and they pursued Midian, bringing the heads of Oreb and Zeeb to Gideon on the other side of the Jordan.
And the men of Ephraim said to him, "Why have you treated us this way, not calling us when you went to fight the Midianites?" And they argued with him fiercely.
He replied, "What have I done now compared to you? Is not the gleaning of the grapes of Ephraim better than the harvest of Abiezer?
God has delivered into your hands the princes of Midian, Oreb and Zeeb; what was I able to do compared to you?" Their anger toward him subsided when he said this.
Gideon crossed the Jordan, along with the three hundred men who were with him, weary but still pursuing.
He said to the men of Succoth, "Please give loaves of bread to the people who are following me, for they are exhausted, and I am pursuing Zebah and Zalmunna, the kings of Midian."
The princes of Succoth replied, "Are the hands of Zebah and Zalmunna now in your possession, that we should give bread to your army?"
Gideon responded, "When the LORD has delivered Zebah and Zalmunna into my hands, I will tear your flesh with the thorns of the wilderness and with briers."
He then went up to Penuel and spoke to them in the same way; the men of Penuel answered him as the men of Succoth had.
He also told the men of Penuel, "When I return in peace, I will tear down this tower."
Zebah and Zalmunna were in Karkor, along with their army, about fifteen thousand men, all that remained of the eastern armies; for one hundred and twenty thousand men who drew swords had fallen.
Gideon went by the way of those who lived in tents on the east of Nobah and Jogbehah, and he struck down the army, for it was secure.
When Zebah and Zalmunna fled, he pursued them, capturing the two kings of Midian, Zebah and Zalmunna, and he routed their entire army.
Gideon, the son of Joash, returned from battle before sunrise,
and caught a young man from Succoth, inquiring of him; he described to Gideon the princes of Succoth and their elders, seventy-seven men in total.

He went to the men of Succoth and said, "Look, Zebah and Zalmunna, whom you taunted me about, saying, 'Are the hands of Zebah and Zalmunna now in your possession, that we should give bread to your weary men?'"
He took the elders of the city and taught the men of Succoth a lesson with thorns from the wilderness and briers.
He demolished the tower of Penuel and killed the men of the city.
Then he asked Zebah and Zalmunna, "What kind of men did you kill at Tabor?" They answered, "They were like you; each one resembled the sons of a king."
He said, "They were my brothers, the sons of my mother. As the LORD lives, if you had spared their lives, I would not kill you."
He then said to Jether, his firstborn, "Get up and kill them." But the youth did not draw his sword, for he was afraid, being still a youth.
Zebah and Zalmunna said, "Rise yourself and kill us, for as the man is, so is his strength." Gideon arose and killed Zebah and Zalmunna, taking the ornaments from their camels' necks.
The men of Israel said to Gideon, "Rule over us, both you and your son and your grandson, for you have delivered us from the hand of Midian."
Gideon replied, "I will not rule over you, nor shall my son rule over you; the LORD shall rule over you."
Gideon then said to them, "I would like to make a request of you: give me every man the earrings of his plunder." (For they had golden earrings, because they were Ishmaelites.)
They answered, "We will willingly give them." They spread a garment and cast in every man the earrings of his plunder.

The weight of the golden earrings he requested was one thousand seven hundred shekels of gold, besides the ornaments, collars, and purple garments worn by the kings of Midian, and the chains that were around their camels' necks.
Gideon made an ephod from this and placed it in his city, Ophrah; and all Israel went there to worship it, which became a snare to Gideon and his household.
Thus, Midian was subdued before the children of Israel, and they did not lift their heads again. The land had peace for forty years during the days of Gideon.
Jerubbaal, the son of Joash, went and lived in his own house.
Gideon had seventy sons born to him, for he had many wives.
His concubine who lived in Shechem also bore him a son, whom he named Abimelech.
Gideon, the son of Joash, died at a good old age and was buried in the tomb of Joash his father, in Ophrah of the Abiezrites.
As soon as Gideon died, the children of Israel turned again and worshiped the Baals, making Baalberith their god.
The children of Israel did not remember the LORD their God, who had delivered them from the hands of all their enemies on every side.
They did not show kindness to the house of Jerubbaal, that is, Gideon, for all the good he had done for Israel.
And Abimelech, the son of Jerubbaal, went to Shechem to speak with his mother's relatives and the entire family of his maternal grandfather, saying,
"Please speak to all the men of Shechem and ask them: Which is better for you, that all seventy sons of Jerubbaal reign over you, or that one reign over you? Remember, I am your own flesh and blood."
His mother's relatives conveyed all these words to the men of Shechem, and their hearts inclined to follow Abimelech, for they said, "He is our brother."
They gave him seventy pieces of silver from the temple of Baal-berith, with which Abimelech hired reckless and worthless men to follow him.
He went to his father's house in Ophrah and killed his brothers, the seventy sons of Jerubbaal, on one stone; however, Jotham, the youngest son of Jerubbaal, escaped because he hid himself.
All the men of Shechem gathered together, along with the house of Millo, and they made Abimelech king at the oak of the pillar in Shechem.
When Jotham heard this, he stood on the top of Mount Gerizim, raised his voice, and cried out, "Listen to me, men of Shechem, that God may listen to you."
Once, the trees went out to anoint a king over themselves, and they said to the olive tree, "Reign over us."
But the olive tree replied, "Should I give up my abundance, which honors both God and man, to be promoted over the trees?"
Then the trees said to the fig tree, "Come, reign over us."
But the fig tree answered, "Should I forsake my sweetness and my good fruit to be promoted over the trees?"
Next, the trees said to the vine, "Come, reign over us."
The vine replied, "Should I leave my wine, which cheers both God and man, to be promoted over the trees?"
Finally, all the trees said to the bramble, "Come, reign over us."
The bramble said to the trees, "If you truly anoint me as king over you, then come and take refuge in my shade; but if not, let fire come out from me and consume the cedars of Lebanon."
Now, if you have acted truly and sincerely in making Abimelech king, and if you have treated Jerubbaal and his family well, and have done to him as he deserves;
(For my father risked his life for you and delivered you from the hand of Midian;
And today you have risen against my father's house, killing his seventy sons on one stone, and made Abimelech, the son of his maidservant, king over the men of Shechem because he is your brother;)
If you have acted truly and sincerely with Jerubbaal and his house today, then rejoice in Abimelech, and let him rejoice in you.
But if not, let fire come out from Abimelech and consume the men of Shechem and the house of Millo; and let fire come out from the men of Shechem and from the house of Millo and consume Abimelech.
Then Jotham ran away, fled, and went to Beer, where he lived in fear of his brother Abimelech.
After Abimelech had reigned for three years over Israel,
God sent an evil spirit between Abimelech and the men of Shechem, and the men of Shechem dealt treacherously with Abimelech,

So that the violence done to the seventy sons of Jerubbaal would come to light, and their blood would be laid upon Abimelech, their brother, who killed them, and upon the men of Shechem, who aided him in the murder of his brothers.
The men of Shechem set ambushes for him in the mountains and robbed all who passed by; this was reported to Abimelech.
Gaal, the son of Ebed, came with his brothers and went to Shechem, and the men of Shechem put their trust in him.
They went out into the fields, gathered their vineyards, trod the grapes, celebrated, and went into the house of their god, where they ate, drank, and cursed Abimelech.

Gaal, the son of Ebed, said, "Who is Abimelech, and who is Shechem, that we should serve him? Is he not the son of Jerubbaal? And Zebul, his officer? We should serve the men of Hamor, the father of Shechem. Why should we serve him?
I wish this people were under my command! I would remove Abimelech." He then said to Abimelech, "Increase your army and come out."
When Zebul, the ruler of the city, heard the words of Gaal, the son of Ebed, his anger was stirred.
He secretly sent messengers to Abimelech, saying, "Look, Gaal, the son of Ebed, and his brothers have come to Shechem, and they are fortifying the city against you.
Now, therefore, rise up by night, you and the people with you, and lie in wait in the field.
In the morning, as soon as the sun is up, rise early and set upon the city. When he and the people with him come out against you, you may do to them as you find opportunity."
Abimelech and all the people with him rose up by night and laid in wait against Shechem in four companies.
Gaal, the son of Ebed, went out and stood at the entrance of the city gate, and Abimelech and the people with him rose up from their ambush.
When Gaal saw the people, he said to Zebul, "Look, people are coming down from the tops of the mountains." Zebul replied, "You see the shadows of the mountains as if they were men."
Gaal spoke again, "Look, people are coming down from the middle of the land, and another company is coming along the plain of Meonenim."
Zebul said to him, "Where is your mouth now, with which you said, 'Who is Abimelech, that we should serve him?' Is this not the people you despised? Go out now and fight with them."
Gaal went out before the men of Shechem and fought with Abimelech.
Abimelech chased him, and he fled before him, and many fell wounded, even to the entrance of the gate.
Abimelech stayed at Arumah, and Zebul drove out Gaal and his brothers so they could not dwell in Shechem.
The next day, the people went out into the fields, and this was reported to Abimelech.
He took the people, divided them into three companies, and laid in wait in the field. When the people came out of the city, he rose up against them and struck them.
Abimelech and the company with him rushed forward and stood at the entrance of the city gate, while the two other companies attacked all the people in the fields and killed them.
Abimelech fought against the city all that day, took the city, killed the people in it, demolished the city, and sowed it with salt.
When all the men of the tower of Shechem heard this, they entered the stronghold of the house of their god Berith.
Abimelech was informed that all the men of the tower of Shechem had gathered together.

He went up to Mount Zalmon with all the people with him, took an axe, cut down a branch from the trees, laid it on his shoulder, and said to the people with him, "What you have seen me do, hurry and do as I have done."
All the people likewise cut down their branches, followed Abimelech, and set the stronghold on fire, so that all the men of the tower of Shechem died, about a thousand men and women.
Then Abimelech went to Thebez, encamped against it, and took it.
But there was a strong tower within the city, and all the men and women of the city fled there, shut themselves in, and went up to the top of the tower.
Abimelech came to the tower and fought against it, approaching the door to burn it with fire.
A certain woman dropped a millstone on Abimelech's head, crushing his skull.
He quickly called to his armor-bearer, saying, "Draw your sword and kill me, so that people will not say of me, 'A woman killed him.'" His armor-bearer thrust him through, and he died.
When the men of Israel saw that Abimelech was dead, they each returned to their homes.
Thus God repaid the wickedness of Abimelech, which he committed against his father by killing his seventy brothers.
And all the evil of the men of Shechem God returned upon their heads, and the curse of Jotham, the son of Jerubbaal, came upon them.
After Abimelech, Tola, the son of Puah and grandson of Dodo, a man from the tribe of Issachar, arose to defend Israel. He resided in Shamir, located in the mountains of Ephraim.
He judged Israel for twenty-three years before he died and was buried in Shamir.
Following him, Jair, a Gileadite, emerged and judged Israel for twenty-two years.
Jair had thirty sons who rode on thirty young donkeys, and they possessed thirty cities, known as Havothjair to this day, situated in the land of Gilead.
Jair passed away and was buried in Camon.

The children of Israel again did evil in the sight of the LORD, serving Baalim, Ashtaroth, and the gods of Syria, Zidon, Moab, the Ammonites, and the Philistines, forsaking the LORD and not serving Him.
The anger of the LORD burned against Israel, and He sold them into the hands of the Philistines and the Ammonites.
That year, they harassed and oppressed the children of Israel for eighteen years, affecting all the Israelites on the other side of the Jordan in the land of the Amorites, which is in Gilead.
Additionally, the Ammonites crossed the Jordan to fight against Judah, Benjamin, and the house of Ephraim, causing great distress for Israel.
The children of Israel cried out to the LORD, saying, "We have sinned against You, for we have forsaken our God and served Baalim."
The LORD responded to the children of Israel, "Did I not deliver you from the Egyptians, the Amorites, the Ammonites, and the Philistines?
The Zidonians, Amalekites, and Maonites also oppressed you, and you cried out to Me, and I delivered you from their hands.
Yet you have forsaken Me and served other gods; therefore, I will no longer deliver you.
Go and cry out to the gods you have chosen; let them save you in your time of trouble."
The children of Israel replied to the LORD, "We have sinned; do to us whatever seems good to You; only deliver us this day, we pray."
They removed the foreign gods from among them and served the LORD, and His soul was grieved for the misery of Israel.
Then the Ammonites gathered together and camped in Gilead, while the children of Israel assembled and camped in Mizpeh.
The people and leaders of Gilead said to one another, "Who is the man that will begin to fight against the Ammonites? He shall be the head over all the inhabitants of Gilead."
Now Jephthah the Gileadite was a mighty warrior, and he was the son of a prostitute: Gilead was his father.
Gilead's wife bore him sons; as his wife's sons grew up, they expelled Jephthah, saying to him, "You shall not inherit in our father's house, for you are the son of a foreign woman."
Then Jephthah fled from his brothers and settled in the land of Tob, where a group of worthless men gathered around him and went out with him.
After some time, the children of Ammon waged war against Israel.
When the children of Ammon made war against Israel, the elders of Gilead went to bring Jephthah back from the land of Tob.
They said to Jephthah, "Come, be our commander, so we can fight the children of Ammon."
Jephthah replied to the elders of Gilead, "Did you not hate me and drive me from my father's house? Why have you come to me now when you are in trouble?"
The elders of Gilead said to Jephthah, "We have now turned back to you, so that you may go with us and fight against the children of Ammon, and be our leader over all the inhabitants of Gilead."
Jephthah asked the elders of Gilead, "If you bring me back to fight against the children of Ammon, and the LORD delivers them into my hands, will I be your leader?"
The elders of Gilead replied to Jephthah, "The LORD is our witness; we will do as you say."
Then Jephthah went with the elders of Gilead, and the people made him their leader and commander. Jephthah spoke all his words before the LORD at Mizpeh.
Jephthah sent messengers to the king of the children of Ammon, asking, "What do you have against me that you have come to fight in my land?"

The king of the children of Ammon responded to Jephthah's messengers, "Israel took my land when they came up from Egypt, from Arnon to Jabbok and to the Jordan. Now, therefore, restore those lands to me peacefully."
Jephthah sent messengers back to the king of the children of Ammon,
saying, "This is what Jephthah says: Israel did not take the land of Moab or the land of the children of Ammon.
When Israel came up from Egypt, they walked through the wilderness to the Red Sea and arrived at Kadesh.

Then Israel sent messengers to the king of Edom, saying, 'Please let us pass through your land,' but the king of Edom refused. They also sent a message to the king of Moab, but he did not consent, so Israel remained in Kadesh.

Then they traveled through the wilderness, circled the land of Edom and Moab, and came to the east side of Moab, camping on the other side of Arnon, but did not enter the territory of Moab, for Arnon was the border of Moab.
Israel sent messengers to Sihon, king of the Amorites, the king of Heshbon, asking, 'Let us pass through your land to our destination.'
But Sihon did not trust Israel to pass through his territory; instead, he gathered all his people, camped at Jahaz, and fought against Israel.

The LORD God of Israel delivered Sihon and all his people into the hands of Israel, and they struck them down, so Israel took possession of all the land of the Amorites, the inhabitants of that region.
They took all the territory of the Amorites, from Arnon to Jabbok, and from the wilderness to the Jordan.
So now the LORD God of Israel has dispossessed the Amorites before His people Israel, and should you possess it?
Will you not possess what Chemosh, your god, gives you to possess? So whatever the LORD our God drives out before us, we will possess.
Are you any better than Balak, son of Zippor, king of Moab? Did he ever contend with Israel or fight against them,
while Israel lived in Heshbon and its towns, in Aroer and its towns, and in all the cities along the Arnon for three hundred years? Why did you not recover them during that time?
Therefore, I have not sinned against you, but you are doing me wrong by waging war against me. May the LORD be the judge today between the children of Israel and the children of Ammon."
However, the king of the children of Ammon did not listen to the words of Jephthah that he sent him.
Then the Spirit of the LORD came upon Jephthah, and he passed through Gilead and Manasseh, and crossed over Mizpeh of Gilead, and from Mizpeh of Gilead he went to the children of Ammon.
Jephthah made a vow to the LORD, saying, "If you will indeed deliver the children of Ammon into my hands,
then whatever comes out of the doors of my house to meet me when I return in peace from the children of Ammon shall surely be the LORD's, and I will offer it up as a burnt offering."
So Jephthah crossed over to the children of Ammon to fight against them, and the LORD delivered them into his hands.
He struck them from Aroer to Minnith, a total of twenty cities, and to the plain of the vineyards, with a very great slaughter. Thus, the children of Ammon were subdued before the children of Israel.
When Jephthah returned to his house in Mizpeh, his daughter came out to meet him with timbrels and dances; she was his only child; besides her, he had neither son nor daughter.

When he saw her, he tore his clothes and exclaimed, "Alas, my daughter! You have brought me very low, and you are one of those who trouble me, for I have made a vow to the LORD, and I cannot go back."
She said to him, "My father, if you have made a vow to the LORD, do to me according to what has gone out of your mouth, since the LORD has avenged you of your enemies, the children of Ammon."
She then said to her father, "Let this thing be done for me: allow me two months to roam the mountains and weep for my virginity, I and my friends."
He said, "Go." He sent her away for two months, and she went with her companions and wept for her virginity on the mountains.
At the end of two months, she returned to her father, who did to her according to his vow, and she had never known a man. It became a custom in Israel
that the daughters of Israel went yearly to lament the daughter of Jephthah the Gileadite for four days each year.

The men of Ephraim gathered together and went northward, saying to Jephthah, "Why did you go to fight against the children of Ammon without calling us to join you? We will burn your house down over you."
Jephthah replied, "I and my people were in serious conflict with the children of Ammon, and when I called for your help, you did not rescue me from their hands."

"When I realized that you would not help me, I took my life into my own hands and went to battle against the children of Ammon, and the LORD delivered them into my hands. Why then have you come to fight against me today?"

Jephthah then gathered all the men of Gilead and fought against Ephraim. The men of Gilead defeated Ephraim because they had said, "You Gileadites are fugitives from Ephraim among the Ephraimites and Manassites."

The Gileadites seized the fords of the Jordan before the Ephraimites. When the escaped Ephraimites said, "Let me cross over," the men of Gilead asked him, "Are you an Ephraimite?" If he replied, "No,"

they said to him, "Then say 'Shibboleth.'" He answered, "Sibboleth," for he could not pronounce it correctly. They seized him and killed him at the fords of the Jordan, and at that time, forty-two thousand Ephraimites fell.
Jephthah judged Israel for six years. Then Jephthah the Gileadite died and was buried in one of the cities of Gilead.
After him, Ibzan of Bethlehem judged Israel.
He had thirty sons and thirty daughters, whom he sent abroad, and he brought in thirty daughters from abroad for his sons. He judged Israel for seven years.
Then Ibzan died and was buried at Bethlehem.
After him, Elon, a Zebulonite, judged Israel for ten years.
Elon the Zebulonite died and was buried in Aijalon in the territory of Zebulun.
After him, Abdon the son of Hillel, a Pirathonite, judged Israel.
He had forty sons and thirty grandsons who rode on seventy donkeys, and he judged Israel for eight years.
Abdon the son of Hillel the Pirathonite died and was buried in Pirathon in the land of Ephraim, in the hill country of the Amalekites.
The children of Israel once again did evil in the sight of the LORD, and as a result, the LORD handed them over to the Philistines for forty years.
There was a certain man from Zorah, belonging to the family of the Danites, named Manoah; his wife was unable to have children.
The angel of the LORD appeared to the woman and said, "Behold, you are barren and have not borne a child, but you will conceive and give birth to a son."
Therefore, be careful not to drink wine or strong drink, and do not eat anything unclean.
For you will conceive and give birth to a son, and no razor shall touch his head, for the child will be a Nazarite to God from birth, and he will begin to deliver Israel from the Philistines.

The woman hurried and told her husband, saying, "A man of God came to me, and his appearance was like that of an angel of God, very awesome. I did not ask him where he was from, and he did not tell me his name."

But he said to me, "You will conceive and give birth to a son; now be sure not to drink wine or strong drink, and do not eat anything unclean, for the child will be a Nazarite to God from birth until the day of his death."
Then Manoah prayed to the LORD, saying, "O my Lord, please let the man of God whom you sent come to us again and teach us what we should do for the child who is to be born."
God listened to Manoah's voice, and the angel of God came again to the woman while she was in the field; but Manoah her husband was not with her.
The woman ran quickly and told her husband, "Look, the man who came to me the other day has appeared to me!"
Manoah got up and followed his wife, and when he came to the man, he asked, "Are you the man who spoke to the woman?" He replied, "I am."
Manoah said, "Now let your words come to pass. What shall we do for the child?"
The angel of the LORD said to Manoah, "Of all that I told the woman, let her be careful.
She must not eat anything that comes from the vine, nor drink wine or strong drink, nor eat any unclean thing; all that I commanded her, let her observe."
Manoah said to the angel of the LORD, "Please let us detain you until we prepare a young goat for you."

The angel of the LORD said to Manoah, "Even if you detain me, I will not eat your food; but if you offer a burnt offering, you must offer it to the LORD." Manoah did not realize that he was an angel of the LORD.
Manoah asked the angel of the LORD, "What is your name, so that when your words come to pass, we may honor you?"
The angel of the LORD replied, "Why do you ask my name, seeing it is wonderful?"
So Manoah took a young goat with a grain offering and offered it on a rock to the LORD; and the angel did wondrously, and Manoah and his wife watched.
As the flame went up toward heaven from the altar, the angel of the LORD ascended in the flame of the altar. Manoah and his wife watched and fell on their faces to the ground.
The angel of the LORD did not appear again to Manoah and his wife. Then Manoah realized that he was an angel of the LORD.
Manoah said to his wife, "We will surely die, because we have seen God."

But his wife said to him, "If the LORD had intended to kill us, He would not have accepted a burnt offering and a grain offering from our hands, nor would He have shown us all these things, nor would He have told us such things at this time."
The woman gave birth to a son and named him Samson; the child grew, and the LORD blessed him.
The Spirit of the LORD began to stir him at times in the camp of Dan, between Zorah and Eshtaol.
Samson traveled to Timnath and noticed a woman among the daughters of the Philistines.
He returned to his parents and said, "I have seen a woman in Timnath from the Philistines; please get her for me as my wife."

His father and mother replied, "Is there not a woman among your relatives or among all our people that you would choose a wife from the uncircumcised Philistines?" Samson insisted, "Get her for me; she pleases me."
However, his parents were unaware that this was part of the LORD's plan to create an opportunity against the Philistines, who were ruling over Israel at that time.
Samson, along with his parents, went to Timnath and reached the vineyards there, where a young lion suddenly roared at him.
The Spirit of the LORD came powerfully upon him, and he tore the lion apart as easily as one would a young goat, without anything in his hand; he did not tell his parents what he had done.
He then went down and spoke to the woman, and she was pleasing to him.
Later, he returned to take her as his wife and diverted to see the lion's carcass, where he found a swarm of bees and honey inside.
He scooped some honey into his hands and ate it as he walked, then shared it with his parents, but he did not mention that he had taken it from the lion's carcass.
His father went to meet the woman, and Samson hosted a feast there, as was customary for young men.
When the guests saw him, they brought thirty companions to join him.
Samson proposed a riddle to them: "If you can solve it within the seven days of the feast, I will give you thirty linen garments and thirty changes of clothes.
But if you cannot solve it, you must give me thirty linen garments and thirty changes of clothes." They agreed, "Tell us your riddle so we can hear it."
He said, "Out of the eater came something to eat, and out of the strong came something sweet." They were unable to solve the riddle in three days.

On the seventh day, they approached Samson's wife, urging her to persuade him to reveal the riddle, threatening to burn her and her father's house if she did not. "Did you invite us here to take what we have?" they asked.

Samson's wife cried before him, saying, "You hate me and do not love me; you have posed a riddle to my people but have not told me the answer." He replied, "I have not even told my father or mother; should I tell you?"
She wept for seven days while the feast continued, and on the seventh day, he finally told her because she pressed him hard. She then revealed the riddle to her people.

The men of the city asked him before sunset on the seventh day, "What is sweeter than honey? What is stronger than a lion?" He responded, "If you had not plowed with my heifer, you would not have solved my riddle."

The Spirit of the LORD came upon him, and he went down to Ashkelon, killed thirty men, took their belongings, and gave the garments to those who had solved the riddle. His anger flared, and he returned to his father's house.
Meanwhile, Samson's wife was given to his companion, who had been his friend.

But it came to pass after a while, during the wheat harvest, that Samson visited his wife with a young goat; and he said, "I will go into my wife in her chamber." However, her father did not allow him to enter.
Her father replied, "I truly thought you had completely despised her; therefore, I gave her to your companion. Is not her younger sister more beautiful than she? Please take her instead."
Samson responded regarding them, "Now I shall be more justified than the Philistines, even though I am doing them harm."
Samson went and caught three hundred foxes, took torches, and tied them tail to tail, placing a torch between each pair.
After setting the torches on fire, he released them into the standing grain of the Philistines, burning up both the sheaves and the standing grain, along with the vineyards and olive trees.

Then the Philistines asked, "Who has done this?" They were told, "Samson, the son-in-law of the Timnite, because he took his wife and gave her to his companion." The Philistines then went up and burned her and her father to death.
Samson said to them, "Although you have done this, I will take revenge on you, and after that, I will stop."
He struck them down with a great slaughter, and then he went down and dwelt at the top of the rock Etam.
The Philistines went up and camped in Judah, spreading out in Lehi.
The men of Judah asked, "Why have you come against us?" They answered, "We have come to bind Samson, to do to him as he has done to us."

Then three thousand men of Judah went to the top of the rock Etam and said to Samson, "Do you not know that the Philistines rule over us? What have you done to us?" He replied, "As they did to me, so I have done to them."
They said to him, "We have come down to bind you, so we can deliver you into the hands of the Philistines." Samson said to them, "Swear to me that you will not attack me yourselves."
They answered him, "No; we will bind you securely and deliver you into their hands, but we will not kill you." They bound him with two new ropes and brought him up from the rock.
When he arrived at Lehi, the Philistines shouted against him, and the Spirit of the LORD came mightily upon him. The ropes on his arms became like burnt flax, and his bonds fell off his hands.
He found a fresh jawbone of a donkey, reached out his hand, took it, and killed a thousand men with it.
Samson said, "With the jawbone of a donkey, I have piled them in heaps; with the jawbone of a donkey, I have slain a thousand men."
When he finished speaking, he threw away the jawbone and named that place Ramathlehi.
He was very thirsty and called on the LORD, saying, "You have granted this great victory to your servant, and now shall I die of thirst and fall into the hands of the uncircumcised?"
But God opened up a hollow place in the jawbone, and water came out. When he drank, his spirit revived, and he named it Enhakkore, which is in Lehi to this day.
He judged Israel for twenty years during the days of the Philistines.
Samson went to Gaza, where he encountered a harlot and engaged with her.
The Gazites were informed, saying, "Samson has come here." They surrounded him and waited for him all night at the city gate, remaining silent until morning, when they planned to kill him.

Samson lay until midnight, then arose, took the city gate doors and the two posts, and carried them away, bar and all, placing them on his shoulders and bringing them to the top of a hill near Hebron.
Later, he fell in love with a woman in the valley of Sorek named Delilah.

The lords of the Philistines approached her, saying, "Entice him and discover the source of his great strength, so we can overpower him and bind him to afflict him; we will each give you eleven hundred pieces of silver."
Delilah asked Samson, "Please tell me the source of your great strength and how you could be bound to be subdued."
Samson replied, "If they bind me with seven fresh bowstrings that have not been dried, I will become weak like any other man."
The lords of the Philistines brought her seven fresh bowstrings, and she bound him with them.

Men were lying in wait in her chamber. She said to him, "The Philistines are upon you, Samson." He broke the bowstrings as easily as a thread of flax is broken by fire, so his strength remained unknown.
Delilah said to Samson, "You have mocked me and told me lies. Now, please tell me how you could be bound."
He answered, "If they bind me with new ropes that have never been used, I will become weak like any other man."
Delilah took new ropes and bound him, then said, "The Philistines are upon you, Samson." There were men lying in wait in the chamber, but he broke the ropes off his arms like a thread.
Delilah said to Samson, "You have mocked me and told me lies. Tell me how you could be bound." He replied, "If you weave the seven locks of my hair into a web."
She fastened his hair with a pin and said, "The Philistines are upon you, Samson." He woke from his sleep, pulled out the pin and the web, and escaped.
She asked him, "How can you say you love me when your heart is not with me? You have mocked me three times and have not revealed the source of your strength."
As she pressed him daily with her words and urged him, his soul was vexed to the point of death.

Finally, he revealed all his heart to her, saying, "No razor has ever touched my head, for I have been a Nazarite to God from my mother's womb. If I am shaved, my strength will leave me, and I will become weak like any other man."

When Delilah realized he had told her everything, she called for the lords of the Philistines, saying, "Come up this time, for he has revealed all his heart to me." The lords of the Philistines came with money in hand.
She made him sleep on her knees, called for a man, and had him shave off the seven locks of his hair. She began to afflict him, and his strength left him.
She said, "The Philistines are upon you, Samson." He woke from his sleep and thought, "I will go out as before and shake myself free." He did not realize that the LORD had departed from him.
The Philistines seized him, gouged out his eyes, brought him down to Gaza, and bound him with bronze shackles; he ground grain in the prison.
However, his hair began to grow back after it had been shaved.
The lords of the Philistines gathered to offer a great sacrifice to their god Dagon and to celebrate, saying, "Our god has delivered Samson, our enemy, into our hands."
When the people saw him, they praised their god, saying, "Our god has delivered our enemy into our hands, the destroyer of our land, who has killed many of us."
As their hearts were merry, they said, "Call for Samson, so he can entertain us." They brought him out of the prison, and he entertained them, standing between the pillars.
Samson said to the boy holding his hand, "Let me feel the pillars on which the house stands, so I can lean against them."
The house was filled with men and women, and all the lords of the Philistines were there, with about three thousand people on the roof watching Samson entertain them.
Samson called out to the LORD, saying, "O Lord God, remember me, I pray, and strengthen me just this once, O God, that I may be avenged on the Philistines for my two eyes."
He grasped the two middle pillars on which the house rested, one with his right hand and the other with his left.

Samson said, "Let me die with the Philistines." He pushed with all his might, and the house fell on the lords and all the people inside. The number of those he killed at his death was greater than those he had killed during his life.
Afterward, his brothers and all his father's household came down, took him, and buried him between Zorah and Eshtaol in the tomb of Manoah, his father. He judged Israel for twenty years.
There was a man from the hill country of Ephraim named Micah.

He said to his mother, "The eleven hundred shekels of silver that were taken from you, which you cursed and spoke about in my hearing, look, the silver is with me; I took it." His mother replied, "Blessed be you by the LORD, my son."

After he returned the eleven hundred shekels of silver to his mother, she said, "I had dedicated the silver entirely to the LORD from my hand for my son, to make a carved image and a cast image; now, therefore, I will return it to you."
Yet he returned the money to his mother, and she took two hundred shekels of silver and gave them to the silversmith, who made a carved image and a cast image. They were placed in Micah's house.
Micah had a shrine and made an ephod and household gods, and he consecrated one of his sons to be his priest.
In those days, there was no king in Israel; everyone did what was right in their own eyes.
There was a young man from Bethlehem in Judah, from the family of Judah, who was a Levite and was living there.
The man left the city of Bethlehem in Judah to find a place to stay, and he came to the hill country of Ephraim, to Micah's house, as he traveled.
Micah asked him, "Where are you coming from?" He answered, "I am a Levite from Bethlehem in Judah, and I am going to stay wherever I can find a place."
Micah said to him, "Stay with me and be a father and priest to me, and I will give you ten shekels of silver a year, a set of clothes, and your food." So the Levite agreed to stay.
The Levite was pleased to stay with Micah, and the young man became like one of his sons.
Micah consecrated the Levite, and the young man became his priest and was in Micah's house.
Then Micah said, "Now I know that the LORD will be good to me, since I have a Levite as my priest."

In those days, there was no king in Israel; during that time, the tribe of the Danites sought an inheritance to dwell in, for up to that day, their inheritance had not been allocated among the tribes of Israel.

The children of Dan sent five men from their family, valiant men from Zorah and Eshtaol, to spy out the land and explore it; they instructed them, "Go, search the land." When they arrived at Mount Ephraim, they lodged at the house of Micah.
While they were near Micah's house, they recognized the voice of the young Levite and turned in, asking him, "Who brought you here? What are you doing in this place? What do you have here?"
He replied, "Micah deals with me in this way; he has hired me, and I am his priest."
They then said to him, "Please inquire of God for us, so we may know if our journey will be successful."
The priest answered them, "Go in peace; the LORD is with you on your journey."

The five men departed and went to Laish, observing the people there, how they lived in security, like the Zidonians, quiet and untroubled; there was no magistrate in the land to shame them in anything, and they were far from the Zidonians, having no dealings with anyone.
They returned to their brethren in Zorah and Eshtaol, and their brethren asked them, "What do you say?"
They replied, "Arise, let us go up against them, for we have seen the land, and it is very good. Why are you hesitating? Do not be lazy in going to possess the land."
"When you go, you will come to a people who are secure and to a large land, for God has given it into your hands; a place where there is no lack of anything on earth."
From there, six hundred men from the family of the Danites, armed for battle, departed from Zorah and Eshtaol.
They went up and camped at Kirjathjearim in Judah; therefore, they named that place Mahanehdan, which remains to this day, behind Kirjathjearim.
They moved on to Mount Ephraim and arrived at the house of Micah.

Then the five men who had spied out the land of Laish spoke to their brethren, saying, "Do you know that there are in these houses an ephod, teraphim, a graven image, and a molten image? Now, therefore, consider what you should do."
They turned toward the house of the young Levite, to Micah's house, and greeted him.
The six hundred armed men from the children of Dan stood at the entrance of the gate.
The five men who had spied out the land entered and took the graven image, the ephod, the teraphim, and the molten image; the priest stood at the entrance of the gate with the six hundred armed men.
They went into Micah's house and took the carved image, the ephod, the teraphim, and the molten image. The priest asked them, "What are you doing?"

They replied, "Be quiet, put your hand over your mouth, and come with us; be a father and a priest to us. Is it better for you to be a priest to the house of one man, or to be a priest to a tribe and family in Israel?"
The priest's heart was glad, and he took the ephod, the teraphim, and the graven image, and went in the midst of the people.
So they turned and departed, placing the little ones, the cattle, and the carriage in front of them.
When they were a good distance from Micah's house, the men who lived near Micah gathered together and overtook the children of Dan.
They called out to the children of Dan, who turned and asked Micah, "What is the matter with you, that you come with such a company?"
Micah replied, "You have taken away my gods that I made, and the priest, and you have gone away; what do I have left? Why do you ask me what is the matter?"
The children of Dan warned him, "Do not let your voice be heard among us, lest angry men attack you, and you lose your life along with your household."
The children of Dan continued on their way, and when Micah saw that they were too strong for him, he turned and went back to his house.
They took the items Micah had made, along with the priest, and went to Laish, a people who were quiet and secure; they struck them with the edge of the sword and burned the city with fire.
There was no deliverer because it was far from Zidon, and they had no dealings with anyone; it was in the valley near Bethrehob. They built a city and dwelt there.
They named the city Dan, after their father Dan, who was born to Israel; however, the city was originally called Laish.
The children of Dan set up the graven image, and Jonathan, the son of Gershom, the son of Manasseh, and his sons served as priests to the tribe of Dan until the day of the land's captivity.
They continued to set up Micah's graven image, which he had made, throughout the time that the house of God was in Shiloh.
And it came to pass in those days, when there was no king in Israel, that a certain Levite was sojourning on the side of Mount Ephraim, who took a concubine from Bethlehem in Judah.
And his concubine was unfaithful to him, and went away to her father's house in Bethlehem, where she stayed for four whole months.

Her husband arose and went after her to speak kindly to her and bring her back, taking his servant and a couple of donkeys with him; she brought him into her father's house, and when the father of the young woman saw him, he rejoiced to meet him.
The father-in-law, the young woman's father, detained him, and he stayed with him for three days, eating, drinking, and lodging there.

On the fourth day, when they arose early in the morning, he prepared to depart, but the young woman's father said to his son-in-law, "Comfort your heart with a morsel of bread, and afterward you may go your way."
They sat down, ate, and drank together, for the young woman's father had said to the man, "Please be content and stay the night, and let your heart be merry."
When the man rose to depart, his father-in-law urged him, so he stayed there again.
He arose early on the fifth day to depart, and the young woman's father said, "Comfort your heart, I pray you." They lingered until afternoon, and they both ate together.

When the man rose to depart, he, his concubine, and his servant, his father-in-law, the young woman's father, said to him, "Behold, the day is drawing to a close; please stay the night. The day is ending; lodge here so that your heart may be merry, and tomorrow you can get an early start on your way home."
But the man would not stay that night; he rose up and departed, and came to Jebus, which is Jerusalem; and he had two donkeys saddled, and his concubine was with him.
As they were near Jebus, the day was far spent; the servant said to his master, "Come, please, let us turn into this city of the Jebusites and lodge in it."
But his master said to him, "We will not turn aside into the city of a stranger, who is not of the children of Israel; we will pass over to Gibeah."
He then said to his servant, "Come, let us draw near to one of these places to lodge for the night, in Gibeah or in Ramah."
They continued on their way, and the sun set upon them as they were by Gibeah, which belongs to Benjamin.
They turned aside there to go in and lodge in Gibeah; and when he went in, he sat down in the street of the city, for no one took them into his house to lodge.
And behold, an old man came in from his work in the field at evening; he was also from Mount Ephraim and sojourned in Gibeah, but the men of the place were Benjamites.
When he lifted up his eyes, he saw a wayfaring man in the street of the city, and the old man said, "Where are you going? And where do you come from?"

He said to him, "We are passing from Bethlehem in Judah toward the side of Mount Ephraim; I am from there, and I went to Bethlehem in Judah, but now I am going to the house of the LORD; and there is no man who will receive me into his house."
"Yet there is both straw and feed for our donkeys, and there is bread and wine for me, for your maidservant, and for the young man who is with your servants; there is no lack of anything."
And the old man said, "Peace be with you; however, let all your needs be upon me; only do not lodge in the street."
So he brought him into his house, gave feed to the donkeys, and they washed their feet and ate and drank.

While they were making their hearts merry, behold, the men of the city, certain sons of Belial, surrounded the house, beating on the door, and spoke to the master of the house, the old man, saying, "Bring out the man who came into your house, that we may know him."
And the master of the house went out to them and said, "No, my brothers, I beg you, do not act so wickedly; since this man has come into my house, do not commit this folly."
"Behold, here is my daughter, a maiden, and his concubine; let me bring them out now, and humble them, and do with them what seems good to you; but to this man do not do such a vile thing."

But the men would not listen to him; so the man took his concubine and brought her out to them, and they knew her and abused her all night until morning; and when the day began to dawn, they let her go.
Then the woman came in at dawn and fell down at the door of the man's house where her lord was, until it was light.

Her lord rose up in the morning, opened the doors of the house, and went out to go his way; and behold, the woman, his concubine, had fallen down at the door of the house, and her hands were on the threshold.
He said to her, "Get up, and let us be going." But there was no answer. So the man took her up upon a donkey, and he rose up and went to his place.
When he came into his house, he took a knife, laid hold of his concubine, and divided her, along with her bones, into twelve pieces, and sent her throughout all the territories of Israel.

And it was so, that all who saw it said, "There has been no such deed done or seen since the day that the children of Israel came up out of the land of Egypt until this day; consider it, take counsel, and speak your minds."
Then all the children of Israel went out, and the congregation gathered together as one man, from Dan to Beersheba, including the land of Gilead, to the LORD in Mizpeh.
And the leaders of all the people, from all the tribes of Israel, presented themselves in the assembly of the people of God, four hundred thousand foot soldiers who drew the sword.
(Now the children of Benjamin heard that the children of Israel had gone up to Mizpeh.) Then the children of Israel said, "Tell us, how did this wickedness occur?"
And the Levite, the husband of the woman who was slain, answered and said, "I came to Gibeah, which belongs to Benjamin, with my concubine, to lodge."
And the men of Gibeah rose against me, surrounded the house where I was staying by night, and intended to kill me; they forced my concubine, and she is dead.
So I took my concubine, cut her into pieces, and sent her throughout all the territory of the inheritance of Israel, for they have committed lewdness and folly in Israel.
Behold, you are all children of Israel; give your advice and counsel here.
And all the people arose as one man, saying, "We will not return to our tents, nor will we turn into our houses."
But now this is what we will do to Gibeah; we will go up by lot against it.

And we will take ten men from a hundred throughout all the tribes of Israel, and a hundred from a thousand, and a thousand from ten thousand, to gather provisions for the people, so that they may do to Gibeah of Benjamin according to all the folly they have committed in Israel.
So all the men of Israel were gathered against the city, united as one man.
And the tribes of Israel sent men throughout all the tribe of Benjamin, saying, "What wickedness is this that has been done among you?"

Now therefore deliver to us the men, the children of Belial, who are in Gibeah, so that we may put them to death and remove evil from Israel. But the children of Benjamin would not listen to the voice of their brethren, the children of Israel.
But the children of Benjamin gathered themselves together from the cities to Gibeah, to go out to battle against the children of Israel.
At that time, the children of Benjamin were numbered at twenty-six thousand men who drew the sword, besides the inhabitants of Gibeah, who were numbered at seven hundred chosen men.
Among all this people, there were seven hundred chosen men who were left-handed; every one could sling stones at a hair's breadth and not miss.
And the men of Israel, besides Benjamin, were numbered at four hundred thousand men who drew the sword; all these were men of war.

And the children of Israel arose and went up to the house of God, and asked counsel of God, saying, "Which of us shall go up first to battle against the children of Benjamin?" And the LORD said, "Judah shall go up first."
And the children of Israel rose up in the morning and encamped against Gibeah.
And the men of Israel went out to battle against Benjamin; they arranged themselves to fight against them at Gibeah.
And the children of Benjamin came out of Gibeah and struck down twenty-two thousand men of Israel that day.
And the men of Israel encouraged themselves and set their battle array again in the same place where they had arranged themselves the first day.

(And the children of Israel went up and wept before the LORD until evening, and asked counsel of the LORD, saying, "Shall I go up again to battle against the children of Benjamin, my brother?" And the LORD said, "Go up against him.")
And the children of Israel approached the children of Benjamin the second day.
And Benjamin went out against them from Gibeah the second day and struck down eighteen thousand men of the children of Israel; all these drew the sword.

Then all the children of Israel, and all the people, went up to the house of God, wept, sat there before the LORD, fasted that day until evening, and offered burnt offerings and peace offerings before the LORD.
And the children of Israel inquired of the LORD (for the ark of the covenant of God was there in those days,

And Phinehas, the son of Eleazar, the son of Aaron, stood before it in those days), saying, "Shall I yet again go out to battle against the children of Benjamin, my brother, or shall I cease?" And the LORD said, "Go up; for tomorrow I will deliver them into your hand."
And Israel set ambushes around Gibeah.
And the children of Israel went up against the children of Benjamin on the third day and arranged themselves against Gibeah, as they had done before.

And the children of Benjamin went out against the people and were drawn away from the city; they began to strike down the people and kill, as they had done before, on the highways, one going up to the house of God and the other to Gibeah in the field, about thirty men of Israel.
And the children of Benjamin said, "They are defeated before us, as in the first battle." But the children of Israel said, "Let us flee and draw them away from the city to the highways."
And all the men of Israel rose up out of their places and arranged themselves at Baaltamar; and the ambushes of Israel came forth from their hiding places, even from the meadows of Gibeah.
And there came against Gibeah ten thousand chosen men from all Israel, and the battle was fierce; but they did not know that evil was near them.
And the LORD struck down Benjamin before Israel, and the children of Israel destroyed twenty-five thousand one hundred men of the Benjamites that day; all these drew the sword.
So the children of Benjamin saw that they were defeated; for the men of Israel gave ground to the Benjamites, because they trusted in the ambushes they had set near Gibeah.
And the ambushes hurried and rushed upon Gibeah; and the ambushes drew themselves along and struck all the city with the edge of the sword.
Now there was an appointed signal between the men of Israel and the ambushes, that they should make a great flame with smoke rise up out of the city.
And when the men of Israel retreated in the battle, Benjamin began to strike and kill about thirty men of Israel; for they said, "Surely they are defeated before us, as in the first battle."
But when the flame began to rise up out of the city with a pillar of smoke, the Benjamites looked behind them, and behold, the flame of the city ascended to heaven.
And when the men of Israel turned back, the men of Benjamin were amazed; for they saw that evil had come upon them.
Therefore, they turned their backs before the men of Israel toward the wilderness; but the battle overtook them, and those who came out of the cities were destroyed in their midst.
Thus they enclosed the Benjamites round about, chased them, and trampled them down easily toward Gibeah, in the direction of the sunrise.
And there fell eighteen thousand men of Benjamin; all these were men of valor.

And they turned and fled toward the wilderness to the rock of Rimmon; and they gleaned five thousand men from them on the highways, and pursued hard after them to Gidom, and killed two thousand men of them.
So all who fell that day of Benjamin were twenty-five thousand men who drew the sword; all these were men of valor.
But six hundred men turned and fled to the wilderness to the rock Rimmon, and stayed in the rock Rimmon for four months.

And the men of Israel turned again upon the children of Benjamin and struck them with the edge of the sword, as well as the men of every city, the beasts, and all that came to hand; they also set fire to all the cities they came to.
The men of Israel had sworn at Mizpeh, declaring that none of them would give their daughters to the tribe of Benjamin as wives.
The people gathered at the house of God, remaining there until evening, lifting their voices and weeping bitterly before God.
They cried out, "O LORD God of Israel, why has this happened in Israel, causing one tribe to be missing today?"
The next day, the people rose early, built an altar there, and offered burnt offerings and peace offerings.

The children of Israel asked, "Which tribe of Israel did not come up with the congregation to the LORD?" They had made a solemn oath regarding anyone who did not join them at Mizpeh, declaring, "He shall surely be put to death."
The children of Israel felt remorse for their brother Benjamin, saying, "Today, one tribe has been cut off from Israel."
They wondered how they could provide wives for those who remained, given that they had sworn to the LORD not to give their daughters to them as wives.
They inquired, "Which tribe of Israel did not come to Mizpeh to the LORD?" And indeed, no one from Jabeshgilead had joined the assembly.
The people were counted, and it was confirmed that none of the inhabitants of Jabeshgilead were present.
The congregation sent twelve thousand of their bravest men, commanding them, "Go and strike down the inhabitants of Jabeshgilead, including the women and children."
"This is what you shall do: utterly destroy every male and every woman who has known a man."
They discovered four hundred young virgins among the inhabitants of Jabeshgilead, who had never been with a man, and brought them to the camp at Shiloh, in the land of Canaan.
The entire congregation sent some to speak to the children of Benjamin who were in the rock of Rimmon, calling out to them peacefully.
At that time, Benjamin returned, and they provided them with the wives they had saved alive from Jabeshgilead, but it was not enough for them.
The people felt remorse for Benjamin, realizing that the LORD had caused a division among the tribes of Israel.
Then the elders of the congregation said, "How can we provide wives for those who remain, since the women of Benjamin have been destroyed?"
They stated, "There must be an inheritance for the survivors of Benjamin, so that a tribe is not wiped out from Israel."
However, they could not give their daughters as wives, for the children of Israel had sworn, saying, "Cursed be anyone who gives a wife to Benjamin."
Then they said, "Look, there is an annual feast of the LORD in Shiloh, located on the north side of Bethel, east of the highway that goes up from Bethel to Shechem, and south of Lebonah."
Therefore, they instructed the children of Benjamin, saying, "Go and hide in the vineyards;
And watch. If the daughters of Shiloh come out to dance, then you may come out of the vineyards and each man catch a wife from the daughters of Shiloh, and return to the land of Benjamin."

When their fathers or brothers come to us to complain, we will say to them, "Be kind to them for our sake, for we did not provide each man with a wife in the war; you did not give them to them at this time, so you should not be guilty."
The children of Benjamin did as instructed, taking wives according to their number from those who danced, and they returned to their inheritance, rebuilding the cities and settling in them.
The children of Israel then departed, each man returning to his tribe and family, going out to his own inheritance.
In those days, there was no king in Israel; everyone did what was right in their own eyes.
In the days when the judges ruled, a famine arose in the land. A man from Bethlehem in Judah went to live temporarily in the country of Moab, along with his wife and two sons.

The man's name was Elimelech, his wife's name was Naomi, and their two sons were named Mahlon and Chilion; they were Ephrathites from Bethlehem in Judah. They entered the country of Moab and settled there.
Elimelech, Naomi's husband, died, leaving her and her two sons behind.
The sons took Moabite wives; one was named Orpah and the other Ruth, and they lived there for about ten years.
Both Mahlon and Chilion also died, leaving Naomi without her two sons and her husband.
Then Naomi decided to return with her daughters-in-law from the country of Moab, for she had heard that the LORD had provided food for His people.
So she set out from the place where she had been living, accompanied by her two daughters-in-law, and they began their journey back to the land of Judah.
Naomi said to her daughters-in-law, "Go back, each of you, to your mother's house. May the LORD show you kindness, as you have shown kindness to the dead and to me."
"May the LORD grant that each of you find rest in the home of another husband." She kissed them, and they wept aloud.
They said to her, "We will go back with you to your people."
But Naomi replied, "Return home, my daughters. Why would you come with me? Am I going to have any more sons, who could become your husbands?
Return home, my daughters; I am too old to have another husband. Even if I thought there was still hope for me, even if I had a husband tonight and gave birth to sons,
would you wait until they grew up? Would you remain unmarried for them? No, my daughters; it is more bitter for me than for you, because the LORD's hand has turned against me."
At this they wept again. Orpah kissed her mother-in-law goodbye, but Ruth clung to her.
Naomi said, "Look, your sister-in-law is going back to her people and her gods. Go back with her."
But Ruth replied, "Don't urge me to leave you or to turn back from you. Where you go, I will go, and where you stay, I will stay. Your people will be my people, and your God my God.
Where you die, I will die, and there I will be buried. May the LORD deal with me, be it ever so severely, if even death separates you and me."
When Naomi realized that Ruth was determined to go with her, she stopped urging her.
So the two of them traveled until they arrived in Bethlehem. When they entered Bethlehem, the whole town was stirred because of them, and the women exclaimed, "Can this be Naomi?"
"Don't call me Naomi," she told them. "Call me Mara, because the Almighty has made my life very bitter.
I went away full, but the LORD has brought me back empty. Why call me Naomi? The LORD has afflicted me; the Almighty has brought misfortune upon me."
So Naomi returned from Moab accompanied by Ruth the Moabitess, her daughter-in-law, arriving in Bethlehem as the barley harvest was beginning.
Naomi had a relative of her husband’s, a wealthy and influential man from the family of Elimelech; his name was Boaz.
Ruth the Moabitess said to Naomi, "Please let me go to the fields and glean ears of corn from the one in whose sight I may find favor." Naomi replied, "Go, my daughter."
Ruth went, and she gleaned in the fields after the harvesters; she happened to find herself in a part of the field belonging to Boaz, who was a relative of Elimelech.
Just then, Boaz arrived from Bethlehem and greeted the harvesters, saying, "The LORD be with you." They responded, "The LORD bless you."
Boaz then asked his foreman, "Whose young woman is this?"
The foreman answered, "She is the Moabitess who returned with Naomi from the country of Moab.
She said, 'Please let me glean and gather among the sheaves after the harvesters.' She has been in the field from morning until now, except for a short rest in the house."
Boaz said to Ruth, "Listen carefully, my daughter. Do not go to glean in another field or leave this one, but stay close to my young women.

Keep your eyes on the field that they are harvesting, and follow along after them. I have instructed the young men not to touch you. When you are thirsty, go to the jars and drink from what the young men have drawn."
She fell on her face, bowing to the ground, and asked him, "Why have I found favor in your eyes that you notice me, a foreigner?"

Boaz replied, "I have been told all about what you have done for your mother-in-law since the death of your husband, how you left your father and mother and your homeland to come to a people you did not know before.
May the LORD repay you for what you have done; may you be richly rewarded by the LORD, the God of Israel, under whose wings you have come to take refuge."
Ruth said, "I hope to find favor in your eyes, my lord, for you have comforted me and spoken kindly to your servant, though I do not have the standing of one of your servant girls."

Boaz said to her, "At mealtime, come here and eat some bread, and dip it in the vinegar." She sat down with the harvesters, and he offered her some roasted grain. She ate all she wanted and had some left over.
When she got up to glean, Boaz instructed his men, "Let her gather among the sheaves and do not reprimand her.
Even pull out some stalks for her from the bundles and leave them for her to glean, and do not rebuke her."
So Ruth gleaned in the field until evening, and she threshed the barley she had gathered, and it amounted to about an ephah.
She carried it back to town, and her mother-in-law saw how much she had gleaned. Ruth also brought out and gave her what she had left over after she had eaten enough.

Her mother-in-law asked her, "Where did you glean today? Where did you work? Blessed be the man who took notice of you!" Ruth told her mother-in-law about the one at whose place she had been working. The name of the man she worked with today is Boaz."

Naomi said to her daughter-in-law, "The LORD bless him! He has not stopped showing his kindness to the living and the dead." She added, "That man is our close relative; he is one of our guardian-redeemers."
Ruth the Moabitess said, "He even said to me, 'Stay with my workers until they finish harvesting all my grain.'"
Naomi said to Ruth her daughter-in-law, "It is good, my daughter, that you go out with his young women, so that you will not be harmed in another field."
So Ruth stayed close to the women of Boaz to glean until the barley and wheat harvests were finished, and she lived with her mother-in-law.
Naomi, her mother-in-law, said to her, "My daughter, should I not seek rest for you, so that it may be well with you?
And is not Boaz our relative, with whose maidens you were? Look, he is winnowing barley tonight at the threshing floor.
Therefore, wash yourself, anoint yourself, and put on your best clothes, and go down to the floor; but do not make yourself known to the man until he has finished eating and drinking.
