Then Saul went to Ramah and came to a great well in Sechu. He asked, "Where are Samuel and David?" One answered, "They are at Naioth in Ramah."
He went to Naioth in Ramah, and the Spirit of God came upon him as well; he continued on and prophesied until he reached Naioth in Ramah.
He also stripped off his clothes and prophesied before Samuel in the same manner, lying down naked all that day and night. Therefore, they say, "Is Saul also among the prophets?"
And David fled from Naioth in Ramah, and came to Jonathan, saying, "What have I done? What is my iniquity? What is my sin before your father that he seeks my life?"
Jonathan replied, "God forbid; you shall not die. My father will do nothing, great or small, without telling me. Why would he hide this from me? It is not so."

David swore again, saying, "Your father knows that I have found favor in your eyes, and he says, 'Do not let Jonathan know, or he will be grieved.' But truly, as the LORD lives and as your soul lives, there is but a step between me and death."
Jonathan said to David, "Whatever your soul desires, I will do it for you."
David said to Jonathan, "Behold, tomorrow is the new moon, and I should not fail to sit with the king at the meal. Let me go and hide in the field until the evening of the third day."
"If your father misses me at all, say, 'David earnestly asked leave of me to run to Bethlehem, his city, for there is a yearly sacrifice for the family there.'"
"If he says, 'It is well,' then your servant will have peace; but if he is very angry, then be sure that evil is determined by him."
"Therefore, deal kindly with your servant, for you have brought me into a covenant of the LORD with you. If there is iniquity in me, kill me yourself; why should you bring me to your father?"
Jonathan replied, "Far be it from you! If I knew for certain that evil was determined by my father against you, would I not tell you?"
David asked Jonathan, "Who will tell me? What if your father answers you harshly?"
Jonathan said to David, "Come, let us go out into the field." So they both went out into the field.
Jonathan said to David, "O LORD God of Israel, when I have sounded my father tomorrow or the third day, and if there is good toward David, and I do not send to you and let you know,

may the LORD do so and much more to Jonathan. But if it pleases my father to do you evil, I will let you know and send you away, that you may go in peace. May the LORD be with you, as He has been with my father."
"And you shall not only show me the kindness of the LORD while I live, that I may not die,
but also you shall not cut off your kindness from my house forever, not even when the LORD has cut off every one of David's enemies from the face of the earth."
So Jonathan made a covenant with the house of David, saying, "Let the LORD require it at the hand of David's enemies."
Jonathan caused David to swear again, for he loved him as he loved his own soul.
Then Jonathan said to David, "Tomorrow is the new moon, and you will be missed because your seat will be empty."
"When you have stayed three days, go down quickly and come to the place where you hid yourself when the business was in hand, and remain by the stone Ezel."
"I will shoot three arrows on the side of it, as though I shot at a mark."

"Behold, I will send a lad, saying, 'Go, find out the arrows.' If I say to the lad, 'Behold, the arrows are on this side of you, take them,' then come, for there is peace for you and no hurt; as the LORD lives."
"But if I say to the young man, 'Behold, the arrows are beyond you; go your way,' then the LORD has sent you away."
"And as for the matter we have spoken of, behold, the LORD be between you and me forever."
So David hid in the field, and when the new moon came, the king sat down to eat.
The king sat on his seat, as at other times, by the wall, and Jonathan arose, and Abner sat by Saul's side, but David's place was empty.
Nevertheless, Saul did not say anything that day, for he thought, "Something has happened to him; he is not clean; surely he is not clean."

It came to pass on the next day, the second day of the month, that David's place was empty, and Saul said to Jonathan his son, "Why has the son of Jesse not come to the meal, either yesterday or today?"
Jonathan answered Saul, "David earnestly asked leave of me to go to Bethlehem."

He said, "Let me go, I pray you, for our family has a sacrifice in the city, and my brother has commanded me to be there. Now, if I have found favor in your eyes, let me go and see my brothers. Therefore, he has not come to the king's table."

Then Saul's anger was kindled against Jonathan, and he said to him, "You son of a perverse, rebellious woman! Do I not know that you have chosen the son of Jesse to your own shame and to the shame of your mother's nakedness?
For as long as the son of Jesse lives on the ground, you shall not be established, nor your kingdom. Now send and bring him to me, for he shall surely die."
Jonathan answered Saul, "Why should he be killed? What has he done?"
Saul cast a javelin at him to strike him, and Jonathan knew that it was determined by his father to kill David.
So Jonathan arose from the table in fierce anger and did not eat any food the second day of the month, for he was grieved for David because his father had done him shame.
In the morning, Jonathan went out into the field at the appointed time with David, and a little lad was with him.
He said to his lad, "Run, find out now the arrows which I shoot." As the lad ran, he shot an arrow beyond him.
When the lad came to the place where the arrow Jonathan had shot fell, Jonathan cried out to the lad, "Is not the arrow beyond you?"
Jonathan called out to the lad, "Make haste, do not delay." The lad gathered up the arrows and came to his master.
But the lad knew nothing; only Jonathan and David knew the matter.
Jonathan gave his equipment to his lad and said to him, "Go, carry them to the city."
As soon as the lad was gone, David arose from his hiding place, fell on his face to the ground, and bowed three times. They kissed one another and wept together until David exceeded.

Jonathan said to David, "Go in peace, for we have sworn both of us in the name of the LORD, saying, 'The LORD be between me and you, and between my descendants and your descendants forever.'" And he arose and departed, and Jonathan went into the city.
David arrived at Nob to see Ahimelech the priest, who was frightened by David's presence and asked him, "Why are you alone, and why is no one with you?"
David replied to Ahimelech, "The king has tasked me with a mission and instructed me to keep it confidential. I have directed my servants to a specific location."
"Now, what do you have on hand? Please give me five loaves of bread or whatever you have available."
The priest responded to David, "I have no ordinary bread, only consecrated bread, provided the young men have kept themselves from women."
David assured the priest, "Indeed, we have been abstinent for three days since my departure, and the young men's vessels are holy. The bread is somewhat common, even though it was sanctified today."

So the priest gave him the consecrated bread, as there was no other bread available except the showbread, which had been removed from before the LORD to make room for hot bread on the day it was taken away.
On that day, a certain servant of Saul was present, detained before the LORD; his name was Doeg, an Edomite, the chief of Saul's herdsmen.
David asked Ahimelech, "Do you have a spear or sword here? I did not bring my sword or weapons because I was in a hurry for the king's business."

The priest replied, "The sword of Goliath the Philistine, whom you killed in the valley of Elah, is here, wrapped in a cloth behind the ephod. If you want it, take it, for there is no other sword here." David said, "There is none like it; give it to me."
David then fled that day out of fear of Saul and went to Achish, the king of Gath.
The servants of Achish said to him, "Isn't this David, the king of the land? Didn't they sing about him in dances, saying, 'Saul has slain his thousands, and David his ten thousands'?"
David took these words to heart and was very afraid of Achish, the king of Gath.
He changed his behavior in front of them, pretending to be insane, scratching at the doors of the gate, and letting his saliva run down his beard.
Achish then said to his servants, "Look, you see the man is mad. Why have you brought him to me?
Do I need madmen that you have brought this fellow to act like a madman in my presence? Should this man come into my house?"
David then departed from there and escaped to the cave of Adullam. When his brothers and all his father's household heard of it, they went down to him there.
Everyone who was in distress, in debt, or discontented gathered around him, and he became their captain; about four hundred men were with him.
David then went to Mizpeh in Moab and said to the king of Moab, "Please let my father and mother come and stay with you until I know what God will do for me."
He brought them before the king of Moab, and they stayed with him as long as David was in the stronghold.
The prophet Gad said to David, "Do not stay in the stronghold; depart and go to the land of Judah." So David left and went to the forest of Hareth.
When Saul heard that David had been discovered, and the men who were with him (Saul was staying in Gibeah under a tree in Ramah, holding his spear, with all his servants standing around him),

Saul said to his servants who were with him, "Listen now, you Benjamites; will the son of Jesse give every one of you fields and vineyards and make you all captains of thousands and captains of hundreds?

You have all conspired against me, and no one informs me that my son has made a covenant with the son of Jesse. None of you is sorry for me or informs me that my son has stirred up my servant against me to lie in wait, as he is doing today."
Then Doeg the Edomite, who was in charge of Saul's servants, answered, "I saw the son of Jesse coming to Nob, to Ahimelech the son of Ahitub.
He inquired of the LORD for him, gave him provisions, and gave him the sword of Goliath the Philistine."
Then the king sent for Ahimelech the priest, the son of Ahitub, and all his father's household, the priests who were in Nob; and they all came to the king.
Saul said, "Listen now, son of Ahitub." He answered, "Here I am, my lord."

Saul said to him, "Why have you conspired against me, you and the son of Jesse, by giving him bread and a sword and inquiring of God for him, so that he would rise against me to lie in wait, as he is doing today?"
Ahimelech answered the king, "Who among all your servants is as faithful as David, the king's son-in-law, who goes at your bidding and is honored in your house?

Did I begin to inquire of God for him? Far be it from me! Let not the king impute anything to his servant or to any of my father's household, for your servant knew nothing of all this, not even a little."
The king said, "You shall surely die, Ahimelech, you and all your father's household."

The king said to the guards who stood around him, "Turn and kill the priests of the LORD, because their hand is also with David, and they knew when he fled and did not inform me." But the king's servants would not put forth their hand to strike the priests of the LORD.
Then the king said to Doeg, "You turn and kill the priests." So Doeg the Edomite turned and struck the priests, killing on that day eighty-five persons who wore a linen ephod.
He also struck Nob, the city of the priests, with the edge of the sword, both men and women, children and infants, oxen, donkeys, and sheep, with the edge of the sword.
One of the sons of Ahimelech, the son of Ahitub, named Abiathar, escaped and fled after David.
Abiathar informed David that Saul had killed the priests of the LORD.
David said to Abiathar, "I knew that day when Doeg the Edomite was there that he would surely tell Saul. I have caused the death of all the persons of your father's household.
Stay with me; do not be afraid, for he who seeks my life seeks your life, but with me, you shall be safe."
Then they informed David, saying, "Look, the Philistines are attacking Keilah and stealing from the threshing floors."
Therefore, David sought guidance from the LORD, asking, "Should I go and strike these Philistines?" The LORD replied to David, "Go, strike the Philistines, and rescue Keilah."
David's men said to him, "Look, we are afraid here in Judah; how much more if we go to Keilah against the Philistine armies?"
Then David sought the LORD again. The LORD answered him, saying, "Get up, go down to Keilah; for I will hand the Philistines over to you."
So David and his men went to Keilah, fought the Philistines, took their livestock, and inflicted a great defeat on them. Thus, David saved the inhabitants of Keilah.
It happened that when Abiathar, the son of Ahimelech, fled to David at Keilah, he brought an ephod with him.
When Saul was informed that David had come to Keilah, he said, "God has delivered him into my hands, for he has entered a town with gates and bars."
Saul gathered all the people for battle to go down to Keilah and besiege David and his men.
David realized that Saul was plotting against him, so he said to Abiathar the priest, "Bring me the ephod."
Then David prayed, "O LORD God of Israel, your servant has heard that Saul is coming to Keilah to destroy the city for my sake.
Will the men of Keilah surrender me to him? Will Saul come down as your servant has heard? O LORD God of Israel, I ask you to tell your servant." The LORD replied, "He will come down."
David then asked, "Will the men of Keilah hand me and my men over to Saul?" The LORD answered, "They will surrender you."
So David and his approximately six hundred men arose and left Keilah, going wherever they could. It was reported to Saul that David had escaped from Keilah, so he refrained from pursuing him.
David stayed in the wilderness strongholds and remained in the mountains of Ziph. Saul sought him every day, but God did not deliver David into his hands.
David saw that Saul had come out to seek his life, and he was in the wilderness of Ziph, in a forest.
Jonathan, Saul's son, went to David in the forest and strengthened his hand in God.
He said to him, "Do not be afraid, for my father Saul will not find you; you will be king over Israel, and I will be next to you. My father Saul knows this."
The two made a covenant before the LORD; David stayed in the forest, and Jonathan returned to his home.
Then the Ziphites went up to Saul at Gibeah, saying, "Isn't David hiding among us in the strongholds of the forest, on the hill of Hachilah, south of Jeshimon?
Now, therefore, O king, come down according to all your heart's desire, and we will hand him over to you."
Saul replied, "Blessed are you of the LORD, for you have shown compassion to me.
Go, I pray, prepare yet, and find out where he is hiding and who has seen him there; for I have been told that he is very crafty.

So, be aware of all the hiding places where he conceals himself, and return to me with certainty, and I will go with you. If he is in the land, I will search for him among all the thousands of Judah."
They arose and went to Ziph before Saul, but David and his men were in the wilderness of Maon, in the plain south of Jeshimon.
Saul and his men went to seek him, and they informed David. Therefore, he went down to a rock and stayed in the wilderness of Maon. When Saul heard this, he pursued David in the wilderness of Maon.
Saul went on one side of the mountain, while David and his men were on the other side. David hurried to escape from Saul, for Saul and his men were surrounding David and his men to capture them.
But a messenger came to Saul, saying, "Hurry and come, for the Philistines have invaded the land."
So Saul returned from pursuing David and went to fight against the Philistines; therefore, they called that place Selahammahlekoth.
David then went up from there and dwelt in the strongholds at Engedi.
And it came to pass, when Saul returned from pursuing the Philistines, that it was reported to him, saying, "Behold, David is in the wilderness of Engedi."
Then Saul took three thousand chosen men from all Israel and went to search for David and his men among the rocks of the wild goats.
He came to the sheepfolds along the way, where there was a cave; and Saul went in to relieve himself, while David and his men remained in the recesses of the cave.

The men of David said to him, "Behold, the day of which the LORD spoke to you, saying, 'I will deliver your enemy into your hand, that you may do to him as it seems good to you.'" Then David arose and secretly cut off a corner of Saul's robe.
Afterward, David's heart troubled him because he had cut off the corner of Saul's robe.
He said to his men, "The LORD forbid that I should do this thing to my master, the LORD's anointed, to stretch out my hand against him, for he is the anointed of the LORD."
So David restrained his men with these words and did not allow them to rise against Saul. But Saul got up from the cave and went on his way.
David also arose afterward, went out of the cave, and called after Saul, saying, "My lord the king!" When Saul looked behind him, David bowed with his face to the ground.
David said to Saul, "Why do you listen to the words of men who say, 'David seeks your harm'?

Behold, this day your eyes have seen that the LORD delivered you today into my hand in the cave, and some urged me to kill you; but I spared you, and said, 'I will not put forth my hand against my lord, for he is the LORD's anointed.'

Moreover, my father, see, yes, see the corner of your robe in my hand! For in that I cut off the corner of your robe and did not kill you, know and see that there is neither evil nor transgression in my hand, and I have not sinned against you; yet you hunt my soul to take it.
The LORD judge between me and you, and the LORD avenge me of you; but my hand shall not be upon you.
As the ancient proverb says, 'Wickedness proceeds from the wicked,' but my hand shall not be upon you.
After whom has the king of Israel come out? After whom do you pursue? After a dead dog, after a flea.
The LORD therefore be the judge, and judge between me and you, and see, and plead my cause, and deliver me from your hand.
When David had finished speaking these words to Saul, Saul said, "Is this your voice, my son David?" And Saul lifted up his voice and wept.
He said to David, "You are more righteous than I, for you have rewarded me with good, whereas I have rewarded you with evil.
And you have shown this day how you have dealt well with me; for when the LORD had delivered me into your hand, you did not kill me.
For if a man finds his enemy, will he let him go away unharmed? Therefore, may the LORD reward you with good for what you have done to me this day.
And now, behold, I know well that you shall surely be king, and that the kingdom of Israel shall be established in your hand.
Swear now therefore to me by the LORD that you will not cut off my descendants after me, and that you will not destroy my name from my father's house."
And David swore to Saul. And Saul went home, but David and his men went up to the stronghold.
And Samuel passed away; all the Israelites gathered together, mourned for him, and buried him in his home at Ramah. David then arose and went down to the wilderness of Paran.
In Maon, there was a man whose possessions were in Carmel; he was very wealthy, owning three thousand sheep and a thousand goats, and he was shearing his sheep in Carmel.
The man's name was Nabal, and his wife was Abigail. She was intelligent and beautiful, but Nabal was harsh and wicked in his actions; he belonged to the house of Caleb.
David learned in the wilderness that Nabal was shearing his sheep.
David sent ten young men, instructing them to go to Carmel, greet Nabal in his name, and deliver a message.
They were to say to him who lives in prosperity, "Peace be to you, peace be to your house, and peace be to all that you have."
David continued, "I have heard that you have shearers. Your shepherds were with us, and we did not harm them, nor was anything missing from them while they were in Carmel."
"Ask your young men, and they will tell you. Please let my young men find favor in your sight, for we come on a good day. I ask you to give whatever you can to your servants and to your son David."
When David's young men arrived, they spoke to Nabal all these words in the name of David and then waited.
Nabal responded to David's servants, saying, "Who is David? Who is the son of Jesse? There are many servants these days who break away from their masters."
"Should I take my bread, my water, and the meat I have prepared for my shearers and give it to men whose origins I do not know?"
So David's young men turned back, returned, and reported all these words to him.

David said to his men, "Each of you, strap on your sword." They did so, and David also strapped on his sword. About four hundred men followed David, while two hundred stayed behind to guard the supplies.
One of the young men informed Abigail, Nabal's wife, saying, "Look, David sent messengers from the wilderness to greet our master, but he insulted them."
"The men treated us very well, and we were not harmed, nor did we miss anything while we were with them in the fields."
"They were like a protective wall around us both day and night while we were tending the sheep."
"Now, therefore, consider what you should do, for evil is determined against our master and his entire household. He is such a wicked man that no one can speak to him."

Abigail hurried and took two hundred loaves of bread, two bottles of wine, five dressed sheep, five measures of roasted grain, one hundred clusters of raisins, and two hundred cakes of figs, placing them on donkeys.
She instructed her servants, "Go on ahead of me; I will follow you." But she did not inform her husband Nabal.
As she rode on the donkey, she came down a hidden path on the hill, and behold, David and his men were coming down toward her, and she met them.
David had said, "It was in vain that I protected all that this man has in the wilderness, so that nothing was missing from him, and he has repaid me evil for good."
"May God do so to David's enemies, and more also, if I leave any of Nabal's men alive by morning."
When Abigail saw David, she quickly dismounted from the donkey, fell on her face before him, and bowed to the ground.
She fell at his feet and said, "On me, my lord, be the blame. Let your servant speak in your presence and hear the words of your servant."
"Please do not pay attention to this worthless man, Nabal, for he is just like his name; Nabal means 'fool,' and folly is with him. I, your servant, did not see the young men you sent."

"Now, my lord, as the LORD lives and as you live, since the LORD has kept you from bloodshed and from avenging yourself with your own hands, let your enemies and those who seek harm against you be like Nabal."
"Now, let this gift that your servant has brought to my lord be given to the young men who follow you."

"I ask you to forgive the offense of your servant, for the LORD will surely make a lasting dynasty for my lord because you fight the battles of the LORD, and no wrongdoing has been found in you all your days."

"Yet a man has risen to pursue you and seek your life, but the life of my lord shall be bound securely in the bundle of the living with the LORD your God, and the lives of your enemies he will hurl away as from the pocket of a sling."
"When the LORD has done for my lord all the good he has promised concerning you and has appointed you ruler over Israel,"

"this will not be a source of grief or a troubled conscience for you, my lord, either for shedding blood without cause or for avenging yourself. When the LORD has dealt well with my lord, remember your servant."
David said to Abigail, "Praise be to the LORD, the God of Israel, who has sent you today to meet me."
"Blessed is your advice, and blessed are you, for you have kept me from bloodshed and from avenging myself with my own hand."
"Indeed, as the LORD, the God of Israel lives, who has kept me from harming you, if you had not come quickly to meet me, not one male belonging to Nabal would have been left by morning."
David accepted from her hand what she had brought him and said, "Go home in peace. I have heard your words and granted your request."
When Abigail returned to Nabal, he was holding a feast in his house like that of a king. Nabal's heart was merry within him, for he was very drunk; so she told him nothing until morning.
In the morning, when the wine had gone out of Nabal and his wife told him these things, his heart died within him, and he became like a stone.
About ten days later, the LORD struck Nabal, and he died.

When David heard that Nabal was dead, he said, "Praise be to the LORD, who has upheld my cause against Nabal for treating me with contempt and has kept his servant from doing wrong. The LORD has brought Nabal's wrongdoing down on his own head." Then David sent word to Abigail, asking her to become his wife.
When David's servants came to Abigail at Carmel, they said to her, "David has sent us to you to take you to him as his wife."
She arose, bowed down with her face to the ground, and said, "Here is your servant, ready to wash the feet of the servants of my lord."
Abigail hurried, mounted her donkey, and followed the messengers of David, and she became his wife.
David also took Ahinoam of Jezreel, and both of them became his wives.
However, Saul had given his daughter Michal, David's wife, to Phalti, the son of Laish, who was from Gallim.
And the Ziphites approached Saul at Gibeah, saying, "Isn't David hiding in the hill of Hachilah, which is opposite Jeshimon?"
Then Saul rose and went down to the wilderness of Ziph, taking with him three thousand chosen men of Israel to search for David in the wilderness of Ziph.
Saul camped in the hill of Hachilah, which is opposite Jeshimon, along the way. Meanwhile, David remained in the wilderness and saw that Saul had come after him into the wilderness.
David sent out spies and confirmed that Saul had indeed come.

David then went to the place where Saul had camped; he observed where Saul lay, along with Abner the son of Ner, the captain of his army. Saul was lying in the trench, and the people were camped around him.
David spoke to Ahimelech the Hittite and Abishai the son of Zeruiah, Joab's brother, saying, "Who will go down with me to Saul in the camp?" Abishai replied, "I will go down with you."
So David and Abishai approached the camp at night, and behold, Saul was sleeping in the trench, with his spear stuck in the ground at his head, while Abner and the people were camped around him.
Then Abishai said to David, "God has delivered your enemy into your hand today. Now, let me strike him with the spear to the ground at once; I won't need to strike him a second time."
But David said to Abishai, "Do not destroy him, for who can stretch out his hand against the LORD's anointed and be guiltless?"
David continued, "As the LORD lives, the LORD will strike him, or his day will come to die, or he will go into battle and perish."
"Far be it from me to stretch out my hand against the LORD's anointed. Now, please take the spear that is at his head and the jug of water, and let us go."
So David took the spear and the jug of water from Saul's head, and they escaped without anyone noticing, for they were all asleep; a deep sleep from the LORD had fallen upon them.
David then crossed to the other side and stood on the top of a hill far away, with a great distance between them.
David called out to the people and to Abner the son of Ner, saying, "Do you not answer, Abner?" Abner replied, "Who are you that calls to the king?"
David said to Abner, "Aren't you a valiant man? Who is like you in Israel? Why then have you not guarded your lord the king? For one of the people came to destroy your lord the king."

"This is not good what you have done. As the LORD lives, you deserve to die because you have not kept watch over your master, the LORD's anointed. Now see where the king's spear is and the jug of water that was at his head."
Saul recognized David's voice and said, "Is this your voice, my son David?" David replied, "It is my voice, my lord, O king."
Saul asked, "Why does my lord pursue his servant? What have I done? What evil is in my hand?"

"Now, I pray you, let my lord the king hear the words of his servant. If the LORD has stirred you up against me, let Him accept an offering; but if it is the children of men, may they be cursed before the LORD, for they have driven me out this day from abiding in the inheritance of the LORD, saying, 'Go, serve other gods.'"
"Now, let not my blood fall to the ground before the LORD, for the king of Israel has come out to seek a flea, like one who hunts a partridge in the mountains."
Saul said, "I have sinned; return, my son David, for I will no longer harm you, because your life was precious in my sight today. Behold, I have acted foolishly and made a great mistake."
David replied, "Here is the king's spear! Let one of the young men come over and fetch it."
"The LORD reward every man for his righteousness and faithfulness; for the LORD delivered you into my hand today, but I would not stretch out my hand against the LORD's anointed."
"And behold, as your life was highly valued in my sight today, so let my life be valued in the sight of the LORD, and let Him deliver me from all tribulation."
Then Saul said to David, "Blessed are you, my son David! You shall both do great things and also prevail." So David went on his way, and Saul returned to his place.

And David said to himself, "I will surely perish one day by the hand of Saul. There is nothing better for me than to quickly escape to the land of the Philistines. Then Saul will give up searching for me in any part of Israel, and I will be safe from him."
So David arose and crossed over with the six hundred men who were with him to Achish, the son of Maoch, king of Gath.
David and his men settled with Achish at Gath, each man with his household, including David with his two wives, Ahinoam the Jezreelitess and Abigail the Carmelitess, Nabal's widow.
When Saul was informed that David had fled to Gath, he no longer sought him.

David said to Achish, "If I have found favor in your eyes, please give me a place in one of the towns in the country so that I may dwell there. Why should your servant live in the royal city with you?"
Achish granted him Ziklag that day, which is why Ziklag has belonged to the kings of Judah to this day.
David lived in the land of the Philistines for a year and four months.
David and his men went up and attacked the Geshurites, the Gezrites, and the Amalekites, for those nations had long been the inhabitants of the land, extending as far as Shur and the land of Egypt.
David struck down the land, leaving no man or woman alive, and took the sheep, oxen, donkeys, camels, and clothing, then returned to Achish.
Achish asked, "Where did you raid today?" David replied, "Against the southern region of Judah, the southern region of the Jerahmeelites, and the southern region of the Kenites."

David spared no man or woman alive to bring news to Gath, saying, "Lest they inform on us, saying, 'This is what David did,' and this will be his practice as long as he lives in the land of the Philistines."
Achish believed David, saying, "He has made his people Israel utterly despise him; therefore, he will be my servant forever."
And it came to pass in those days that the Philistines assembled their armies for battle against Israel. Achish said to David, "Know for certain that you and your men will go out with me to fight."
David replied to Achish, "Surely you know what your servant can do." Achish responded, "Therefore, I will make you my permanent bodyguard."
Now Samuel was dead, and all of Israel mourned for him, burying him in Ramah, his hometown. Saul had removed those with familiar spirits and wizards from the land.
The Philistines gathered and camped at Shunem, while Saul assembled all of Israel and pitched his camp at Gilboa.
When Saul saw the Philistine army, he was afraid, and his heart trembled greatly.
Saul inquired of the LORD, but the LORD did not answer him, neither through dreams, Urim, nor prophets.
Then Saul said to his servants, "Find me a woman who has a familiar spirit so I can go to her and inquire of her." His servants replied, "There is a woman with a familiar spirit at Endor."
Saul disguised himself, changed his clothes, and went with two men to the woman at night. He said, "Please consult the spirit for me and bring up the one I name."
The woman replied, "You know what Saul has done: he has cut off those with familiar spirits and wizards from the land. Why then do you set a trap for my life to cause me to die?"
Saul swore to her by the LORD, saying, "As the LORD lives, you will not be punished for this."
The woman asked, "Whom shall I bring up for you?" He answered, "Bring me up Samuel."
When the woman saw Samuel, she let out a loud scream and said to Saul, "Why have you deceived me? You are Saul!"
The king said to her, "Do not be afraid. What do you see?" The woman replied, "I see gods ascending from the earth."
He asked her, "What does he look like?" She said, "An old man is coming up, and he is covered with a mantle." Saul realized it was Samuel, and he bowed with his face to the ground.

Samuel said to Saul, "Why have you disturbed me by bringing me up?" Saul answered, "I am in great distress; the Philistines are waging war against me, and God has departed from me and answers me no more, neither by prophets nor dreams. Therefore, I have called you to tell me what I should do."
Samuel replied, "Why do you ask me, since the LORD has departed from you and has become your enemy?"
The LORD has done to you as He spoke through me: He has torn the kingdom from your hand and given it to your neighbor, David.
Because you did not obey the voice of the LORD and did not execute His fierce wrath upon Amalek, the LORD has done this to you today.

Furthermore, the LORD will deliver Israel along with you into the hands of the Philistines, and tomorrow you and your sons will be with me. The LORD will also hand over the army of Israel to the Philistines.
Immediately, Saul fell to the ground, terrified by Samuel's words, and he had no strength left in him, for he had eaten nothing all day and night.
The woman approached Saul and saw that he was greatly troubled. She said, "Your servant has obeyed your voice; I put my life in my hands and listened to your words."
"Now, please listen to your servant's voice and let me set a morsel of bread before you. Eat, so you may have strength for your journey."
But he refused, saying, "I will not eat." However, his servants and the woman urged him, and he listened to their voice. So he got up from the ground and sat on the bed.
The woman had a fat calf in her house; she hurried, killed it, took flour, kneaded it, and baked unleavened bread.
She brought it before Saul and his servants, and they ate. Then they rose and went away that night.
The Philistines assembled all their armies at Aphek, while the Israelites camped by a spring in Jezreel.
The lords of the Philistines marched on in groups of hundreds and thousands, but David and his men followed behind with Achish.

The princes of the Philistines questioned, "What are these Hebrews doing here?" Achish replied to the princes, "Isn't this David, the servant of Saul, the king of Israel? He has been with me for some time now, and I have found no fault in him since he joined me."

The princes of the Philistines were angry with Achish and said, "Send this man back so he can return to the place you assigned him. Let him not go into battle with us, or he may become an adversary. How could he reconcile with his master? Would it not be by taking the heads of these men?"
"Isn't this the David they sang about in dances, saying, 'Saul has slain his thousands, and David his ten thousands'?"

Achish then called David and said, "As the LORD lives, you have been honest, and your conduct with me in the army is commendable. I have found no wrongdoing in you since the day you came to me, but the lords do not favor you."
"Therefore, return and go in peace, so you do not displease the lords of the Philistines."

David replied to Achish, "What have I done? What have you found in your servant from the time I have been with you until now that would prevent me from fighting against the enemies of my lord the king?"
Achish answered, "I know you are good in my sight, like an angel of God, but the princes of the Philistines have said, 'He must not go into battle with us.'"
"Therefore, rise early in the morning with your master's servants who have come with you. As soon as it is light, depart."
So David and his men got up early in the morning to return to the land of the Philistines, while the Philistines went up to Jezreel.
And it came to pass, when David and his men arrived at Ziklag on the third day, that the Amalekites had invaded the south, including Ziklag, and had struck Ziklag, burning it with fire.
They had taken the women captive who were there; they did not kill anyone, whether great or small, but carried them away and went on their way.
So David and his men approached the city, and, behold, it was burned with fire; their wives, sons, and daughters had been taken captive.
Then David and the people with him raised their voices and wept until they had no strength left to weep.
David's two wives were taken captive: Ahinoam the Jezreelitess and Abigail, the wife of Nabal the Carmelite.
David was greatly distressed, for the people spoke of stoning him, as the souls of all the people were grieved, each man for his sons and daughters; but David found strength in the LORD his God.
David said to Abiathar the priest, Ahimelech's son, "Please bring me the ephod." Abiathar brought the ephod to David.
David inquired of the LORD, saying, "Shall I pursue this raiding party? Will I overtake them?" The LORD answered him, "Pursue, for you will certainly overtake them and succeed in the rescue."
So David went, he and the six hundred men with him, and they came to the brook Besor, where those who were left behind stayed.
But David pursued, he and four hundred men; two hundred stayed behind because they were too exhausted to cross the brook Besor.
They found an Egyptian in the field and brought him to David. They gave him bread, and he ate; they made him drink water.
They also gave him a piece of a cake of figs and two clusters of raisins; when he had eaten, his strength returned, for he had not eaten bread or drunk water for three days and three nights.
David asked him, "To whom do you belong, and where are you from?" He replied, "I am a young man of Egypt, a servant of an Amalekite; my master abandoned me because I fell sick three days ago."
"We raided the Negev of the Cherethites, the territory belonging to Judah, and the Negev of Caleb; we burned Ziklag."
David asked him, "Can you lead me down to this raiding party?" He answered, "Swear to me by God that you will not kill me or hand me over to my master, and I will lead you down to them."

When he had led David down, they were scattered over the countryside, eating and drinking and dancing because of the great amount of plunder they had taken from the land of the Philistines and from the land of Judah.
David attacked them from dusk until the evening of the next day, and none of them escaped except four hundred young men who rode off on camels and fled.
David recovered everything the Amalekites had taken, including his two wives.
Nothing was missing: small or great, sons or daughters, nor anything else they had taken; David brought everything back.
He took all the flocks and herds, which were driven ahead of the other livestock, and said, "This is David's plunder."

David returned to the two hundred men who had been too exhausted to follow him and who had been left behind at the brook Besor. They went out to meet David and the people with him, and when David approached them, he greeted them.

Then all the wicked men and troublemakers among those who had gone with David said, "Since they did not go out with us, we will not share with them any of the plunder we recovered; each man may take his wife and children and go."
David replied, "No, my brothers, you must not do that with what the LORD has given us. He has protected us and delivered into our hands the raiding party that came against us.
Who will listen to what you say? The share of the man who stayed with the supplies is to be the same as that of him who went down to the battle. All will share alike."
This became a statute and ordinance for Israel from that day to this.
When David arrived at Ziklag, he sent some of the plunder to the elders of Judah, who were his friends, saying, "Here is a gift for you from the plunder of the enemies of the LORD."
He sent it to those in Bethel, in south Ramoth, and in Jattir,
to those in Aroer, in Siphmoth, and in Eshtemoa,
to those in Rachal, in the cities of the Jerahmeelites, and in the cities of the Kenites,
to those in Hormah, in Chorashan, and in Athach,
to those in Hebron, and to all the places where David and his men had roamed.
Now the Philistines engaged in battle against Israel, and the men of Israel fled from the Philistines, falling slain on Mount Gilboa.
The Philistines pursued Saul and his sons relentlessly, killing Jonathan, Abinadab, and Melchishua, Saul's sons.
The battle pressed heavily against Saul, and the archers struck him; he was gravely wounded by their arrows.

Saul then said to his armor-bearer, "Draw your sword and run me through with it; lest these uncircumcised men come and run me through and mistreat me." But his armor-bearer was too afraid to do so. Therefore, Saul took his own sword and fell upon it.
When his armor-bearer saw that Saul was dead, he also fell on his sword and died alongside him.
Thus, Saul, his three sons, his armor-bearer, and all his men died together that same day.

When the men of Israel on the other side of the valley and those across the Jordan saw that the Israelite army had fled and that Saul and his sons were dead, they abandoned their cities and fled; the Philistines then came and settled in them.
The next day, when the Philistines came to strip the slain, they found Saul and his three sons fallen on Mount Gilboa.
They cut off his head, stripped off his armor, and sent word throughout the land of the Philistines to proclaim it in the temples of their idols and among the people.
They placed his armor in the temple of Ashtaroth and fastened his body to the wall of Bethshan.
When the inhabitants of Jabesh-gilead heard what the Philistines had done to Saul,
all the valiant men arose, traveled all night, took the body of Saul and the bodies of his sons from the wall of Bethshan, and brought them to Jabesh, where they burned them.
They took their bones and buried them under a tree at Jabesh, and they fasted for seven days.
After the death of Saul, it came to pass that David returned from defeating the Amalekites and stayed two days in Ziklag.
On the third day, a man emerged from Saul's camp, his clothes torn and dust on his head. When he approached David, he fell to the ground in reverence.
David asked him, "Where do you come from?" The man replied, "I have escaped from the camp of Israel."
David inquired, "What happened? Please tell me." The man answered, "The people have fled from the battle, many are fallen and dead; Saul and his son Jonathan are also dead."
David asked the young man, "How do you know that Saul and Jonathan are dead?"
The young man explained, "As I happened upon Mount Gilboa, I saw Saul leaning on his spear, with chariots and horsemen pursuing him closely.
When he looked back and saw me, he called out to me, and I answered, 'Here I am.'
He asked me, 'Who are you?' I replied, 'I am an Amalekite.'
He then said, 'Please stand over me and kill me, for I am in great anguish, yet my life remains in me.'
So I stood over him and killed him, knowing he could not survive after falling. I took the crown from his head and the bracelet from his arm and brought them to my lord."
David grasped his clothes and tore them, and all the men with him did the same.
They mourned, wept, and fasted until evening for Saul, for Jonathan his son, for the people of the LORD, and for the house of Israel, because they had fallen by the sword.
David asked the young man, "Where are you from?" He replied, "I am the son of a stranger, an Amalekite."
David questioned him, "How were you not afraid to stretch out your hand to destroy the LORD's anointed?"
David called one of the young men and said, "Go near and strike him down." The young man struck him, and he died.
David declared, "Your blood is on your own head; your own mouth has testified against you, saying, 'I have killed the LORD's anointed.'"
David lamented with this lamentation over Saul and over Jonathan his son:
(He also instructed them to teach the children of Judah the use of the bow; behold, it is written in the book of Jasher.)
"The beauty of Israel is slain on your high places; how the mighty have fallen!
Do not tell it in Gath, do not publish it in the streets of Askelon; lest the daughters of the Philistines rejoice, lest the daughters of the uncircumcised triumph.
O mountains of Gilboa, let there be no dew or rain upon you, nor fields of offerings; for there the shield of the mighty was cast away, the shield of Saul, as if he had not been anointed with oil.
From the blood of the slain, from the fat of the mighty, the bow of Jonathan did not turn back, and the sword of Saul did not return empty.
Saul and Jonathan were beloved and pleasant in their lives, and in their death, they were not separated; they were swifter than eagles, they were stronger than lions.
Daughters of Israel, weep for Saul, who clothed you in scarlet and adorned you with gold ornaments.
How the mighty have fallen in the midst of battle! O Jonathan, you were slain on your high places.
I am distressed for you, my brother Jonathan; you were very dear to me; your love for me was wonderful, surpassing the love of women.
How the mighty have fallen, and the weapons of war have perished!

And it came to pass after this that David inquired of the LORD, saying, "Shall I go up into any of the cities of Judah?" And the LORD said unto him, "Go up." David then asked, "Whither shall I go up?" And He replied, "Unto Hebron."
So David went up there, along with his two wives, Ahinoam the Jezreelitess and Abigail, the widow of Nabal the Carmelite.
David brought his men with him, each man with his household, and they settled in the cities of Hebron.
The men of Judah came, and there they anointed David as king over the house of Judah. They informed David that the men of Jabeshgilead were the ones who buried Saul.
David sent messengers to the men of Jabeshgilead, saying, "Blessed be you of the LORD, for you have shown this kindness to your lord, even to Saul, and have buried him."
"And now may the LORD show you kindness and truth; and I will also repay you this kindness because you have done this thing."
"Therefore, let your hands be strengthened, and be valiant, for your master Saul is dead, and the house of Judah has anointed me king over them."
But Abner, the son of Ner, captain of Saul's host, took Ishbosheth, the son of Saul, and brought him to Mahanaim.
He made him king over Gilead, the Ashurites, Jezreel, Ephraim, Benjamin, and all Israel.
Ishbosheth, Saul's son, was forty years old when he began to reign over Israel, and he reigned for two years. However, the house of Judah followed David.
The time that David was king in Hebron over the house of Judah was seven years and six months.
Abner, the son of Ner, and the servants of Ishbosheth, the son of Saul, went out from Mahanaim to Gibeon.
Joab, the son of Zeruiah, and the servants of David went out and met together by the pool of Gibeon; they sat down, one on one side of the pool and the other on the opposite side.
Abner said to Joab, "Let the young men arise and play before us." Joab replied, "Let them arise."
Then twelve young men from Benjamin, belonging to Ishbosheth, and twelve from the servants of David arose and approached each other.
They caught hold of one another by the head and thrust their swords into each other's sides, so they fell down together. Therefore, that place was called Helkathhazzurim, which is in Gibeon.
There was a fierce battle that day; Abner and the men of Israel were beaten before the servants of David.
There were three sons of Zeruiah present: Joab, Abishai, and Asahel. Asahel was as swift as a gazelle.
Asahel pursued Abner, and in his pursuit, he did not turn to the right or to the left.
Abner looked back and asked, "Are you Asahel?" He answered, "I am."
Abner said to him, "Turn aside to your right or to your left, and seize one of the young men and take his armor." But Asahel refused to turn aside from following him.
Abner again said to Asahel, "Turn aside from following me; why should I strike you to the ground? How could I face Joab, your brother?"

However, Asahel refused to turn aside, so Abner struck him with the back end of his spear under the fifth rib, and the spear came out behind him. He fell and died on the spot, and all who came to the place where Asahel fell and died stood still.
Joab and Abishai pursued Abner, and the sun set as they reached the hill of Ammah, which lies before Giah, along the way to the wilderness of Gibeon.
The children of Benjamin gathered themselves together after Abner and formed one troop, standing on the top of a hill.

Then Abner called to Joab, saying, "Shall the sword devour forever? Do you not know that it will be bitterness in the end? How long will it be before you tell the people to return from pursuing their brethren?"
Joab replied, "As God lives, if you had not spoken, surely by morning the people would have ceased pursuing their brothers."
So Joab blew a trumpet, and all the people stood still, ceasing to pursue Israel and fighting no more.
Abner and his men walked all night through the plain, crossed the Jordan, went through all Bithron, and arrived at Mahanaim.
Joab returned from pursuing Abner, and when he had gathered all the people together, there were nineteen men and Asahel missing from David's servants.
But the servants of David had struck down three hundred and sixty men of Benjamin and Abner's men.
They took up Asahel and buried him in the tomb of his father, which was in Bethlehem. Joab and his men traveled all night and arrived in Hebron at dawn.
There was a prolonged conflict between the house of Saul and the house of David; however, David grew stronger, while the house of Saul became weaker.
David had sons born to him in Hebron, and his firstborn was Amnon, by Ahinoam the Jezreelitess.
His second son was Chileab, by Abigail, the wife of Nabal the Carmelite; the third was Absalom, the son of Maacah, the daughter of Talmai, king of Geshur.
The fourth son was Adonijah, the son of Haggith; the fifth was Shephatiah, the son of Abital.
The sixth son was Ithream, by Eglah, David's wife. These were the children born to David in Hebron.
During the ongoing war between the house of Saul and the house of David, Abner strengthened his position for the house of Saul.
Saul had a concubine named Rizpah, the daughter of Aiah, and Ishbosheth confronted Abner, asking why he had gone in to his father's concubine.

Abner was furious at Ishbosheth's words and replied, "Am I a dog's head? I have shown kindness today to the house of Saul, your father, his brothers, and his friends, and I have not delivered you into David's hands. Why then do you accuse me of wrongdoing regarding this woman?"
May God deal with Abner, and more so, unless I do for David what the LORD has sworn to him;
to transfer the kingdom from the house of Saul and establish David's throne over Israel and Judah, from Dan to Beersheba.
Ishbosheth could not respond to Abner because he was afraid of him.
Abner sent messengers to David, asking, "Whose is the land?" He also said, "Make a covenant with me, and my hand will be with you to unite all Israel to you."
David replied, "I will make a covenant with you, but one thing I require: You must not see my face unless you bring Michal, Saul's daughter, when you come to see me."
David sent messengers to Ishbosheth, Saul's son, saying, "Give me my wife Michal, whom I married for a hundred Philistine foreskins."
Ishbosheth sent and took her from her husband, Phaltiel, the son of Laish.
Her husband followed her, weeping as he went to Bahurim. Abner told him, "Go back," and he returned.
Abner spoke to the elders of Israel, saying, "In the past, you sought David to be king over you.
Now do it, for the LORD has spoken concerning David, saying, 'By my servant David, I will save my people Israel from the Philistines and all their enemies.'"
Abner also spoke to the tribe of Benjamin and then went to David in Hebron to communicate what seemed good to Israel and the whole house of Benjamin.
Abner came to David in Hebron with twenty men, and David made a feast for Abner and his men.

Abner said to David, "I will rise and gather all Israel to my lord the king, so they may make a covenant with you, and you may reign over all that your heart desires." David sent Abner away, and he went in peace.
Meanwhile, David's servants and Joab returned from pursuing a troop, bringing a great spoil with them; but Abner was not with David in Hebron, as David had sent him away in peace.
When Joab and his men arrived, they informed Joab that Abner, the son of Ner, had come to the king and had been sent away in peace.
Joab approached the king and asked, "What have you done? Abner came to you; why did you send him away? He has gone in peace."
"You know that Abner, the son of Ner, came to deceive you, to learn your comings and goings, and to know all that you do."
After Joab left David, he sent messengers after Abner, who brought him back from the well of Sirah, but David was unaware of it.
When Abner returned to Hebron, Joab took him aside at the gate to speak with him privately and struck him under the fifth rib, killing him for the blood of Asahel, his brother.
Later, when David heard of it, he declared, "I and my kingdom are innocent before the LORD forever regarding the blood of Abner, the son of Ner.
Let the guilt rest on Joab and his father's house; may there not be a single male in Joab's house who has a discharge, is a leper, leans on a staff, falls by the sword, or lacks bread."
Joab and his brother Abishai killed Abner because he had slain their brother Asahel at Gibeon during the battle.
David instructed Joab and all the people with him, "Tear your clothes, put on sackcloth, and mourn for Abner." King David himself followed the bier.
They buried Abner in Hebron, and the king raised his voice and wept at Abner's grave, and all the people wept.
The king lamented over Abner, saying, "Did Abner die like a fool?
Your hands were not bound, nor your feet put in fetters; you fell as a man falls before wicked men." All the people wept again for him.
When the people urged David to eat while it was still day, he swore, "May God deal with me, and more so, if I eat bread or anything else until the sun sets."
All the people noticed this and were pleased, as everything the king did pleased them.
For all the people and all Israel understood that day that it was not the king's intention to kill Abner, the son of Ner.
The king said to his servants, "Do you not know that a prince and a great man has fallen this day in Israel?
I am weak today, though anointed king, and these men, the sons of Zeruiah, are too harsh for me. The LORD will repay the evildoer according to his wickedness."
When Saul's son learned of Abner's death in Hebron, his hands grew weak, and all the Israelites were filled with fear.
Saul's son had two captains: one was named Baanah, and the other Rechab, the sons of Rimmon, a Beerothite from the tribe of Benjamin (for Beeroth was also considered part of Benjamin).
The Beerothites fled to Gittaim and have lived there as sojourners to this day.

Jonathan, Saul's son, had a son who was lame in both feet. He was five years old when news of Saul and Jonathan's death came from Jezreel. His nurse picked him up and fled, but in her haste, he fell and became lame. His name was Mephibosheth.
The sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, Rechab and Baanah, went to the house of Ishbosheth around midday while he was lying on his bed.
They entered the house as if they were there to fetch wheat, but they struck him under the fifth rib; then Rechab and Baanah, his brother, escaped.
When they entered the house, he was lying in his bed in his bedroom. They struck him, killed him, beheaded him, and took his head, fleeing through the plain all night.

They brought Ishbosheth's head to David in Hebron and said to the king, "Look, the head of Ishbosheth, the son of Saul, your enemy, who sought your life; the LORD has avenged my lord the king today on Saul and his descendants."
David responded to Rechab and Baanah, the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, saying, "As the LORD lives, who has redeemed my soul from all adversity,
when someone told me, 'Saul is dead,' thinking he was bringing good news, I seized him and killed him in Ziklag, assuming I would reward him for his tidings.
How much more, when wicked men have slain a righteous person in his own house, on his bed? Should I not now require his blood from your hands and remove you from the earth?"
David commanded his young men, and they killed them, cut off their hands and feet, and hung them over the pool in Hebron. However, they buried Ishbosheth's head in the tomb of Abner in Hebron.
Then all the tribes of Israel came to David at Hebron and said, "Behold, we are your bone and your flesh."
In the past, when Saul was king over us, you were the one who led Israel in and out: and the LORD said to you, "You shall shepherd my people Israel, and you shall be a leader over Israel."
So all the elders of Israel came to the king at Hebron; and King David made a covenant with them in Hebron before the LORD: and they anointed David as king over Israel.
David was thirty years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for forty years.
In Hebron, he reigned over Judah for seven years and six months; and in Jerusalem, he reigned for thirty-three years over all Israel and Judah.

The king and his men went to Jerusalem to confront the Jebusites, the inhabitants of the land, who said to David, "You will not enter here unless you remove the blind and the lame," thinking, "David cannot enter here."
Nevertheless, David captured the stronghold of Zion; that is the city of David.

On that day, David declared, "Whoever climbs up the water shaft and strikes down the Jebusites, the blind and the lame whom I despise, he shall be chief and captain." Therefore, they said, "The blind and the lame shall not enter the house."
So David settled in the stronghold and called it the city of David. He built around it from Millo inward.
David continued to grow stronger, and the LORD God of hosts was with him.
Hiram, king of Tyre, sent messengers to David, along with cedar trees, carpenters, and masons; and they built David a house.
David realized that the LORD had established him as king over Israel and had exalted his kingdom for the sake of His people Israel.
David took more concubines and wives from Jerusalem after he came from Hebron, and more sons and daughters were born to David.
These are the names of those born to him in Jerusalem: Shammuah, Shobab, Nathan, and Solomon,
Ibhar, Elishua, Nepheg, and Japhia,
And Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphalet.
When the Philistines heard that they had anointed David as king over Israel, they all went up to search for David; and David heard of it and went down to the stronghold.
The Philistines also came and spread out in the valley of Rephaim.

David inquired of the LORD, saying, "Shall I go up against the Philistines? Will you deliver them into my hand?" The LORD answered David, "Go up, for I will surely deliver the Philistines into your hand."
David went to Baalperazim and struck them there, saying, "The LORD has broken through my enemies before me like a breakthrough of water." Therefore, he named that place Baalperazim.
They left their idols there, and David and his men burned them.
The Philistines came up again and spread out in the valley of Rephaim.
When David inquired of the LORD, He said, "You shall not go up; but circle around behind them and come upon them opposite the mulberry trees.
And when you hear the sound of marching in the tops of the mulberry trees, then you shall act quickly, for then the LORD will go out before you to strike the camp of the Philistines."
David did as the LORD commanded him and struck down the Philistines from Geba to Gazer.
Once again, David assembled all the chosen men of Israel, totaling thirty thousand.
David rose and set out with all the people accompanying him from Baale of Judah to retrieve the ark of God, which is called by the name of the LORD of hosts, who dwells between the cherubim.
They placed the ark of God on a new cart and brought it out of the house of Abinadab in Gibeah, with Uzzah and Ahio, the sons of Abinadab, driving the new cart.
As they transported the ark of God from the house of Abinadab in Gibeah, Ahio went ahead of the ark.
David and all the house of Israel played before the LORD with various instruments made of fir wood, including harps, psalteries, timbrels, cornets, and cymbals.
When they reached Nachon's threshing floor, Uzzah reached out his hand to steady the ark of God, for the oxen stumbled.
The anger of the LORD was aroused against Uzzah, and God struck him there for his error, resulting in his death beside the ark of God.
David was displeased because the LORD had inflicted a breach upon Uzzah, and he named the place Perezuzzah, which remains to this day.
That day, David was afraid of the LORD and asked, "How can the ark of the LORD come to me?"
Consequently, David decided not to bring the ark of the LORD into the city of David; instead, he took it aside to the house of Obededom the Gittite.
The ark of the LORD remained in the house of Obededom the Gittite for three months, and the LORD blessed Obededom and his entire household.

Word reached King David that the LORD had blessed the house of Obededom and all that belonged to him because of the ark of God. So David went to bring up the ark of God from the house of Obededom to the city of David with great joy.
As those carrying the ark of the LORD took six steps, David sacrificed oxen and fatlings.
David danced before the LORD with all his might, wearing a linen ephod.
Thus, David and all the house of Israel brought up the ark of the LORD with shouts and the sound of trumpets.
As the ark of the LORD entered the city of David, Michal, Saul's daughter, looked out from a window and saw King David leaping and dancing before the LORD; she despised him in her heart.
They brought the ark of the LORD in and placed it in the center of the tabernacle that David had pitched for it. David offered burnt offerings and peace offerings before the LORD.
Once David finished offering the burnt offerings and peace offerings, he blessed the people in the name of the LORD of hosts.
He distributed to all the people, both men and women, a cake of bread, a portion of meat, and a flagon of wine. Then everyone departed to their homes.

David returned to bless his household, and Michal, the daughter of Saul, came out to meet him, saying, "How glorious was the king of Israel today, who uncovered himself in the sight of the handmaids of his servants, as one of the vain fellows shamelessly uncovers himself!"

David replied to Michal, "It was before the LORD, who chose me over your father and all his house to appoint me ruler over the people of the LORD, over Israel. Therefore, I will celebrate before the LORD.
I will become even more undignified than this, and I will be humble in my own sight; but as for the maidservants you mentioned, I will be honored by them."
Consequently, Michal, the daughter of Saul, had no children until the day of her death.
And it came to pass, when the king sat in his house, and the LORD had granted him peace all around from all his enemies;
That the king said to Nathan the prophet, "Look now, I dwell in a house of cedar, but the ark of God resides within curtains."
And Nathan said to the king, "Go, do all that is in your heart; for the LORD is with you."
And it came to pass that night, that the word of the LORD came to Nathan, saying,
"Go and tell my servant David, 'Thus says the LORD, will you build me a house to dwell in?'"
"Since the time I brought the children of Israel up from Egypt to this day, I have not dwelt in a house, but have walked in a tent and in a tabernacle."

"In all the places where I have walked with all the children of Israel, did I ever speak a word with any of the tribes of Israel, whom I commanded to shepherd my people Israel, saying, 'Why have you not built me a house of cedar?'"
"Now therefore, you shall say to my servant David, 'Thus says the LORD of hosts, I took you from the sheepfold, from following the sheep, to be ruler over my people, over Israel.'"
"And I was with you wherever you went, and have cut off all your enemies from before you, and have made you a great name, like the name of the great men who are on the earth."

"Moreover, I will appoint a place for my people Israel, and will plant them, that they may dwell in their own place, and be disturbed no more; neither shall the children of wickedness afflict them anymore, as in the past,"
"And since the time I commanded judges to be over my people Israel, and have caused you to rest from all your enemies. Also, the LORD tells you that He will make you a house."
"And when your days are fulfilled, and you sleep with your fathers, I will set up your seed after you, which shall come from your body, and I will establish his kingdom."
"He shall build a house for my name, and I will establish the throne of his kingdom forever."
"I will be his father, and he shall be my son. If he commits iniquity, I will chasten him with the rod of men, and with the stripes of the children of men;"
"But my mercy shall not depart from him, as I took it from Saul, whom I removed before you."
"And your house and your kingdom shall be established forever before you: your throne shall be established forever."
"According to all these words, and according to all this vision, so Nathan spoke to David."
Then King David went in, and sat before the LORD, and he said, "Who am I, O Lord GOD? And what is my house, that you have brought me this far?"
"And this was yet a small thing in your sight, O Lord GOD; but you have also spoken of your servant's house for a long time to come. And is this the manner of man, O Lord GOD?"
"And what can David say more to you? For you, Lord GOD, know your servant."
"For your word's sake, and according to your own heart, you have done all these great things, to make your servant know them."
"Therefore you are great, O LORD God: for there is none like you, nor is there any God besides you, according to all that we have heard with our ears."

"And what one nation on earth is like your people, even like Israel, whom God went to redeem for a people to himself, and to make a name for himself, and to do for you great and awesome things for your land, before your people, whom you redeemed to yourself from Egypt, from the nations and their gods?"
"For you have confirmed to yourself your people Israel to be a people forever: and you, LORD, have become their God."
"And now, O LORD God, the word that you have spoken concerning your servant, and concerning his house, establish it forever, and do as you have said."
"And let your name be magnified forever, saying, 'The LORD of hosts is the God over Israel': and let the house of your servant David be established before you."
"For you, O LORD of hosts, God of Israel, have revealed to your servant, saying, 'I will build you a house': therefore your servant has found in his heart to pray this prayer to you."
"And now, O Lord GOD, you are that God, and your words are true, and you have promised this goodness to your servant:"

"Therefore now let it please you to bless the house of your servant, that it may continue forever before you: for you, O Lord GOD, have spoken it: and with your blessing let the house of your servant be blessed forever."
And after this, it came to pass that David struck the Philistines and subdued them; David took Methegammah from the hand of the Philistines.

He also struck Moab, measuring them with a line, casting them down to the ground; with two lines, he measured to put to death, and with one full line, to keep alive. Thus, the Moabites became David's servants and brought gifts.
David also struck Hadadezer, the son of Rehob, king of Zobah, as he went to recover his territory at the river Euphrates.
David took from him a thousand chariots, seven hundred horsemen, and twenty thousand foot soldiers; he hamstrung all the chariot horses but reserved enough for a hundred chariots.
When the Syrians of Damascus came to aid Hadadezer, king of Zobah, David killed twenty-two thousand of the Syrians.
Then David established garrisons in Syria of Damascus; the Syrians became David's servants and brought gifts. The LORD preserved David wherever he went.
David took the gold shields that belonged to the servants of Hadadezer and brought them to Jerusalem.
From Betah and Berothai, cities of Hadadezer, King David took a great quantity of bronze.
When Toi, king of Hamath, heard that David had defeated the entire army of Hadadezer,

he sent his son Joram to King David to greet him and bless him because he had fought against Hadadezer and defeated him, as Hadadezer had been at war with Toi. Joram brought with him vessels of silver, gold, and bronze.
King David dedicated these to the LORD, along with the silver and gold he had dedicated from all the nations he had subdued:
from Syria, Moab, the children of Ammon, the Philistines, Amalek, and the spoil of Hadadezer, son of Rehob, king of Zobah.
David gained a reputation when he returned from striking down the Syrians in the Valley of Salt, killing eighteen thousand men.
He established garrisons in Edom; throughout all Edom, he placed garrisons, and all the Edomites became David's servants. The LORD preserved David wherever he went.
David reigned over all Israel, executing judgment and justice for all his people.
Joab, the son of Zeruiah, was over the army, and Jehoshaphat, the son of Ahilud, was the recorder.
Zadok, the son of Ahitub, and Ahimelech, the son of Abiathar, were the priests, and Seraiah was the scribe.
Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada, was in charge of both the Cherethites and the Pelethites, and David's sons were chief officials.
And David asked, "Is there anyone left from the house of Saul to whom I can show kindness for Jonathan's sake?"
There was a servant from the house of Saul named Ziba. When they called him to David, the king asked, "Are you Ziba?" He replied, "I am your servant."
The king inquired, "Is there anyone from the house of Saul to whom I can show God's kindness?" Ziba answered, "Jonathan has a son who is lame in both feet."
The king asked, "Where is he?" Ziba replied, "He is in the house of Machir, the son of Ammiel, in Lodebar."
King David then sent for him and brought him from the house of Machir, the son of Ammiel, in Lodebar.
When Mephibosheth, the son of Jonathan and the grandson of Saul, came to David, he fell on his face and showed reverence. David called out, "Mephibosheth!" He answered, "Here is your servant!"

David said to him, "Do not be afraid, for I will surely show you kindness for the sake of your father Jonathan. I will restore to you all the land that belonged to your grandfather Saul, and you will always eat at my table."
Mephibosheth bowed down and said, "What is your servant, that you should notice a dead dog like me?"
Then the king called Ziba, Saul's servant, and said to him, "I have given your master's grandson everything that belonged to Saul and his family.

You and your sons and your servants are to farm the land for him and bring in the crops so that your master's grandson may be provided for. Mephibosheth, your master's grandson, will always eat at my table." Ziba had fifteen sons and twenty servants.
Ziba replied to the king, "Your servant will do whatever my lord the king has commanded." The king said, "Mephibosheth will eat at my table like one of the king's sons."
Mephibosheth had a young son named Micha, and all who lived in Ziba's household were servants to Mephibosheth.
So Mephibosheth lived in Jerusalem, for he always ate at the king's table, and he was lame in both feet.
And it came to pass after this that the king of the Ammonites died, and his son Hanun reigned in his place.

Then David said, "I will show kindness to Hanun, the son of Nahash, as his father showed kindness to me." So David sent his servants to comfort him for the loss of his father. David's servants arrived in the land of the Ammonites.

The princes of the Ammonites said to Hanun their lord, "Do you think that David honors your father by sending comforters to you? Hasn't David rather sent his servants to explore the city, spy it out, and overthrow it?"
Therefore, Hanun took David's servants, shaved off half of their beards, cut their garments in the middle, up to their buttocks, and sent them away.
When David was informed, he sent to meet them because the men were greatly ashamed. The king said, "Stay in Jericho until your beards have grown back, and then return."

When the Ammonites saw that they had become a stench to David, they sent and hired the Syrians of Bethrehob and the Syrians of Zoba, twenty thousand foot soldiers, and from King Maacah, a thousand men, and from Ishtob, twelve thousand men.
When David heard of this, he sent Joab and all the mighty men of valor.
The Ammonites came out and arranged their battle at the entrance of the city gate, while the Syrians of Zoba, Rehob, Ishtob, and Maacah were in the field by themselves.
When Joab saw that the battle was against him in front and behind, he selected the best men of Israel and arranged them against the Syrians.
The rest of the people he placed under the command of his brother Abishai, to arrange them against the Ammonites.
He said, "If the Syrians are too strong for me, then you shall help me; but if the Ammonites are too strong for you, then I will come and help you."
"Be strong and let us show ourselves courageous for our people and for the cities of our God; and may the LORD do what seems good to Him."
Joab drew near, along with the people who were with him, to battle against the Syrians, and they fled before him.
When the Ammonites saw that the Syrians had fled, they also fled before Abishai and entered the city. So Joab returned from the Ammonites and came to Jerusalem.
When the Syrians saw that they were defeated before Israel, they regrouped.
Hadarezer sent and brought out the Syrians who were beyond the river, and they came to Helam, with Shobach, the commander of Hadarezer's army, leading them.
When it was reported to David, he gathered all Israel together, crossed the Jordan, and came to Helam. The Syrians arranged themselves against David and fought with him.
The Syrians fled before Israel, and David killed seven hundred charioteers and forty thousand horsemen of the Syrians, and he struck down Shobach, the commander of their army, who died there.
When all the kings who were servants of Hadarezer saw that they were defeated by Israel, they made peace with Israel and served them. Thus, the Syrians were afraid to help the Ammonites any longer.

And it came to pass, after the year had expired, at the time when kings go forth to battle, that David sent Joab, and his servants with him, and all Israel; and they destroyed the children of Ammon and besieged Rabbah. But David remained still at Jerusalem.

And it came to pass in the evening, that David arose from his bed and walked upon the roof of the king's house: and from the roof, he saw a woman washing herself; and the woman was very beautiful to behold.
And David sent and inquired after the woman. And one said, Is not this Bathsheba, the daughter of Eliam, the wife of Uriah the Hittite?
And David sent messengers and took her; and she came in unto him, and he lay with her; for she was purified from her uncleanness: and she returned unto her house.
And the woman conceived and sent and told David, saying, I am with child.
And David sent to Joab, saying, Send me Uriah the Hittite. And Joab sent Uriah to David.
And when Uriah came unto him, David demanded of him how Joab was, and how the people were, and how the war prospered.
And David said to Uriah, Go down to your house and wash your feet. And Uriah departed out of the king's house, and there followed him a portion of food from the king.
But Uriah slept at the door of the king's house with all the servants of his lord and did not go down to his house.
And when they had told David, saying, Uriah did not go down to his house, David said unto Uriah, Did you not come from your journey? Why then did you not go down to your house?

And Uriah said unto David, The ark, and Israel, and Judah, are dwelling in tents; and my lord Joab, and the servants of my lord, are encamped in the open fields; shall I then go into my house to eat and drink, and to lie with my wife? As you live, and as your soul lives, I will not do this thing.
And David said to Uriah, Stay here today also, and tomorrow I will let you depart. So Uriah stayed in Jerusalem that day and the next.
And when David had called him, he ate and drank before him; and he made him drunk: and at evening he went out to lie on his bed with the servants of his lord, but did not go down to his house.
And it came to pass in the morning that David wrote a letter to Joab and sent it by the hand of Uriah.
And he wrote in the letter, saying, Set Uriah in the forefront of the hottest battle, and withdraw from him, that he may be struck down and die.
And it came to pass, when Joab observed the city, that he assigned Uriah to a place where he knew that valiant men were.
And the men of the city went out and fought with Joab: and there fell some of the people of the servants of David; and Uriah the Hittite died also.
Then Joab sent and told David all the things concerning the war;
And charged the messenger, saying, When you have finished telling the matters of the war to the king,
And if it happens that the king's wrath arises, and he says unto you, Why did you approach so near to the city when you fought? Did you not know that they would shoot from the wall?

Who killed Abimelech the son of Jerubbesheth? Did not a woman cast a piece of a millstone upon him from the wall, so that he died at Thebez? Why did you go near the wall? Then say you, Your servant Uriah the Hittite is dead also.
So the messenger went and came and showed David all that Joab had sent him for.
And the messenger said unto David, Surely the men prevailed against us, and came out unto us into the field, and we were upon them even unto the entrance of the gate.
And the shooters shot from off the wall upon your servants; and some of the king's servants are dead, and your servant Uriah the Hittite is dead also.
