Then David said unto the messenger, Thus shall you say unto Joab, Let not this thing displease you, for the sword devours one as well as another: make your battle stronger against the city and overthrow it: and encourage him.
And when the wife of Uriah heard that Uriah her husband was dead, she mourned for her husband.
And when the mourning was over, David sent and fetched her to his house, and she became his wife and bore him a son. But the thing that David had done displeased the LORD.
And the LORD sent Nathan to David. He came to him and said, "There were two men in one city; one was rich, and the other was poor.
The rich man had an abundance of flocks and herds.

But the poor man had nothing except for one little ewe lamb, which he had bought and raised; it grew up with him and his children. It ate from his plate, drank from his cup, and lay in his bosom; it was like a daughter to him.

Then a traveler came to the rich man, and he was unwilling to take from his own flock or herd to prepare a meal for the wayfaring man who had come to him; instead, he took the poor man's lamb and prepared it for the man who had come to him.
David's anger was greatly aroused against the man, and he said to Nathan, "As the LORD lives, the man who has done this shall surely die!
He must restore the lamb fourfold, because he did this thing and had no pity."
Nathan said to David, "You are the man! Thus says the LORD God of Israel: I anointed you king over Israel, and I delivered you from the hand of Saul.
I gave you your master's house and your master's wives into your bosom, and I gave you the house of Israel and Judah; and if that had been too little, I would have given you even more.

Why have you despised the commandment of the LORD to do evil in His sight? You have killed Uriah the Hittite with the sword and taken his wife to be your wife, and you have slain him with the sword of the children of Ammon.
Now, therefore, the sword shall never depart from your house, because you have despised Me and taken the wife of Uriah the Hittite to be your wife.

Thus says the LORD: Behold, I will raise up evil against you from your own house, and I will take your wives before your eyes and give them to your neighbor, and he shall lie with your wives in the sight of this sun.
For you did it secretly, but I will do this thing before all Israel and before the sun."
David said to Nathan, "I have sinned against the LORD." Nathan replied, "The LORD has also put away your sin; you shall not die.
However, because by this deed you have given great occasion to the enemies of the LORD to blaspheme, the child born to you shall surely die."
Nathan then departed to his house. The LORD struck the child that Uriah's wife bore to David, and it became very sick.
David therefore pleaded with God for the child; he fasted, went in, and lay all night on the ground.
The elders of his house arose and went to him to raise him from the ground, but he would not, nor did he eat bread with them.

On the seventh day, the child died. David's servants feared to tell him that the child was dead, for they said, "While the child was alive, we spoke to him, and he would not listen to our voice; how can we tell him that the child is dead? He may do something desperate."
But when David saw that his servants whispered, he perceived that the child was dead. Therefore, David asked his servants, "Is the child dead?" They said, "He is dead."

Then David arose from the ground, washed, anointed himself, changed his clothes, went into the house of the LORD, and worshiped. Afterward, he came to his own house, and when he requested, they set bread before him, and he ate.
His servants said to him, "What is this that you have done? You fasted and wept for the child while it was alive, but when the child died, you arose and ate bread."
He said, "While the child was alive, I fasted and wept; for I said, 'Who can tell whether the LORD will be gracious to me, that the child may live?'
But now he is dead; why should I fast? Can I bring him back again? I shall go to him, but he shall not return to me."
David comforted Bathsheba, his wife, and went in to her and lay with her. She bore a son, and he named him Solomon; the LORD loved him.
He sent by the hand of Nathan the prophet, and he named him Jedidiah because of the LORD.
Joab fought against Rabbah of the children of Ammon and took the royal city.
Joab sent messengers to David, saying, "I have fought against Rabbah and taken the city of waters.
Now, therefore, gather the rest of the people together, and encamp against the city and take it, lest I take the city and it be called by my name."
David gathered all the people together, went to Rabbah, fought against it, and took it.
He took the king's crown from his head; its weight was a talent of gold with precious stones, and it was set on David's head. He brought out the spoil of the city in great abundance.

He brought out the people who were in it and put them under saws, under iron harrows, and under axes of iron, and made them pass through the brick kiln. Thus he did to all the cities of the children of Ammon. So David and all the people returned to Jerusalem.
And it came to pass after this that Absalom, the son of David, had a beautiful sister named Tamar; and Amnon, the son of David, loved her.
Amnon was so distressed that he fell sick for his sister Tamar, for she was a virgin, and Amnon found it difficult to do anything to her.
But Amnon had a friend named Jonadab, the son of Shimeah, David's brother; and Jonadab was a very cunning man.
He said to Amnon, "Why are you, being the king's son, so thin from day to day? Will you not tell me?" And Amnon replied, "I love Tamar, my brother Absalom's sister."

Jonadab said to him, "Lie down on your bed and pretend to be ill. When your father comes to see you, say to him, 'Please let my sister Tamar come and give me something to eat, and let her prepare the food in my sight so that I may see it and eat it from her hand.'"

So Amnon lay down and pretended to be ill. When the king came to see him, Amnon said to the king, "Please let Tamar, my sister, come and make me a couple of cakes in my sight so that I may eat from her hand."
Then David sent home to Tamar, saying, "Go now to your brother Amnon's house and prepare food for him."
So Tamar went to her brother Amnon's house, and he was lying down. She took flour, kneaded it, made cakes in his sight, and baked the cakes.
She took a pan and served them to him, but he refused to eat. Amnon said, "Have everyone leave me." So everyone left him.
Amnon then said to Tamar, "Bring the food into the chamber so that I may eat from your hand." Tamar took the cakes she had made and brought them into the chamber to Amnon, her brother.
When she brought them to him to eat, he grabbed her and said, "Come lie with me, my sister."
She answered him, "No, my brother, do not force me; for no such thing should be done in Israel. Do not commit this folly."
"And where would I carry my shame? And as for you, you would be like one of the fools in Israel. Now therefore, I pray you, speak to the king; he will not withhold me from you."
However, he would not listen to her voice; but being stronger than she, he forced her and lay with her.
Then Amnon hated her exceedingly, so that the hatred he had for her was greater than the love he had for her. Amnon said to her, "Get up and go away."
She said to him, "There is no cause; this evil in sending me away is greater than the other that you did to me." But he would not listen to her.
He then called his servant who attended him and said, "Put this woman out from me and bolt the door after her."
She had a robe of many colors on her, for with such robes were the king's daughters who were virgins dressed. His servant brought her out and bolted the door after her.
Tamar put ashes on her head, tore her robe of many colors that was on her, laid her hand on her head, and went away crying.

Absalom, her brother, said to her, "Has Amnon, your brother, been with you? Hold your peace now, my sister; he is your brother; do not take this thing to heart." So Tamar remained desolate in her brother Absalom's house.
But when King David heard of all these things, he was very angry.
Absalom spoke to his brother Amnon neither good nor bad, for Absalom hated Amnon because he had forced his sister Tamar.
It came to pass after two full years that Absalom had sheep shearers in Baalhazor, which is near Ephraim; and Absalom invited all the king's sons.
Absalom came to the king and said, "Behold now, your servant has sheep shearers; let the king, I beseech you, and his servants go with your servant."
The king said to Absalom, "No, my son, let us not all go now, lest we be a burden to you." But he pressed him; however, he would not go, but blessed him.
Then Absalom said, "If not, please let my brother Amnon go with us." The king said to him, "Why should he go with you?"
But Absalom pressed him until he let Amnon and all the king's sons go with him.

Now Absalom had commanded his servants, saying, "Watch when Amnon's heart is merry with wine, and when I say to you, 'Strike Amnon,' then kill him. Do not fear; have I not commanded you? Be courageous and be valiant."
The servants of Absalom did to Amnon as Absalom had commanded. Then all the king's sons arose, and every man got up on his mule and fled.
While they were on their way, tidings came to David, saying, "Absalom has slain all the king's sons, and not one of them is left."
Then the king arose, tore his garments, and lay on the ground; and all his servants stood by with their clothes torn.

Jonadab, the son of Shimeah, David's brother, answered and said, "Let not my lord suppose that they have slain all the young men, the king's sons; for only Amnon is dead. This has been determined by Absalom from the day he forced his sister Tamar."
"Now therefore, let not my lord the king take the thing to heart, to think that all the king's sons are dead; for only Amnon is dead."
But Absalom fled. The young man who kept watch lifted up his eyes and looked, and behold, there came much people by the way of the hillside behind him.
Jonadab said to the king, "Behold, the king's sons are coming; as your servant said, so it is."
As soon as he had finished speaking, behold, the king's sons came and lifted up their voices and wept; and the king and all his servants wept very bitterly.
But Absalom fled and went to Talmai, the son of Ammihud, king of Geshur. And David mourned for his son every day.
So Absalom fled and went to Geshur, and was there for three years.
The soul of King David longed to go forth to Absalom, for he was comforted concerning Amnon, seeing he was dead.
Now Joab, the son of Zeruiah, noticed that the king's heart was inclined toward Absalom.

Joab sent for a wise woman from Tekoah and instructed her, "Please pretend to be a mourner, wear mourning clothes, and do not anoint yourself with oil; act like a woman who has mourned for a long time for the dead."
"Go to the king and speak in this manner to him." So Joab provided her with the words to say.
When the woman from Tekoah spoke to the king, she fell on her face to the ground, showed respect, and said, "Help, O king."
The king asked her, "What troubles you?" She replied, "I am indeed a widow, and my husband is dead."
"Your servant had two sons, and they fought together in the field, and there was no one to separate them; one struck the other and killed him."

"Now the whole family has risen against your servant, saying, 'Hand over the one who killed his brother so we can put him to death for the life of his brother whom he killed.' They want to destroy the heir as well, and thus extinguish the last ember I have left, leaving my husband with neither name nor remnant on the earth."
The king said to the woman, "Go to your house, and I will give orders concerning you."
The woman of Tekoah replied to the king, "My lord, O king, let the iniquity be on me and my father's house; let the king and his throne be guiltless."
The king said, "Whoever speaks to you, bring him to me, and he shall not harm you anymore."

Then she said, "I pray you, let the king remember the LORD your God, so that the avengers of blood do not destroy any more, lest they kill my son." He replied, "As the LORD lives, not one hair of your son shall fall to the ground."
The woman said, "Let your servant speak one word to my lord the king." He said, "Speak."
The woman asked, "Why then have you thought such a thing against the people of God? For the king speaks as if he is at fault, in that he does not bring back his banished."

"For we must all die, and are like water spilled on the ground, which cannot be gathered up again; God does not respect any person, yet He devises means so that His banished are not expelled from Him."

"Now that I have come to speak to my lord the king about this matter, it is because the people have made me afraid. Your servant said, 'I will now speak to the king; perhaps the king will grant the request of his servant.'"
"For the king will listen, to deliver his servant from the hand of the man who would destroy me and my son together from the inheritance of God."
"Then your servant said, 'The word of my lord the king will be comforting, for my lord the king is like an angel of God, discerning good and evil; may the LORD your God be with you.'"
The king answered the woman, "Do not hide from me what I am about to ask you." The woman replied, "Let my lord the king speak."

The king asked, "Is not the hand of Joab with you in all this?" The woman answered, "As your soul lives, my lord the king, no one can turn to the right or to the left from anything that my lord the king has spoken; for your servant Joab commanded me and put all these words in the mouth of your servant."
"To bring about this form of speech, your servant Joab has done this thing; and my lord is wise, like the wisdom of an angel of God, to know all things that are on the earth."
The king said to Joab, "Behold, I have granted this request; go therefore, and bring the young man Absalom back."

Joab fell to the ground on his face, bowed himself, and thanked the king, saying, "Today your servant knows that I have found favor in your sight, my lord, O king, because you have fulfilled the request of your servant."
So Joab arose and went to Geshur, and brought Absalom to Jerusalem.
The king said, "Let him return to his own house, and let him not see my face." So Absalom returned to his own house and did not see the king's face.
But in all Israel, there was no one as praised for beauty as Absalom; from the sole of his foot to the crown of his head, there was no blemish in him.
When he cut his hair (for it was customary to cut it at the end of every year because it was heavy on him), he weighed the hair of his head at two hundred shekels by the king's weight.
Absalom had three sons and one daughter, whose name was Tamar; she was a woman of beautiful appearance.
Absalom lived in Jerusalem for two full years and did not see the king's face.
Therefore, Absalom sent for Joab to send him to the king, but Joab would not come to him; and when he sent again the second time, he still would not come.
So he said to his servants, "Look, Joab's field is near mine, and he has barley there; go and set it on fire." And Absalom's servants set the field on fire.
Then Joab arose, went to Absalom's house, and asked him, "Why have your servants set my field on fire?"

Absalom answered Joab, "Behold, I sent to you, saying, 'Come here, that I may send you to the king to ask, "Why have I come from Geshur? It would have been better for me to remain there. Now therefore, let me see the king's face; and if there is any iniquity in me, let him kill me."'"
So Joab came to the king and told him; and when he called for Absalom, he came to the king, bowed himself on his face to the ground before the king, and the king kissed Absalom.
And it came to pass after this that Absalom prepared chariots and horses, along with fifty men to run before him.

Absalom rose up early and stood beside the way of the gate. When any man with a controversy came to the king for judgment, Absalom called to him and asked, "Of what city are you?" The man replied, "Your servant is from one of the tribes of Israel."
Absalom said to him, "See, your matters are good and right, but there is no one appointed by the king to hear you."
Absalom added, "Oh, that I were made judge in the land! Then every man with a suit or cause could come to me, and I would give him justice!"
Whenever any man approached him to pay respect, he would reach out his hand, take hold of him, and kiss him.
In this manner, Absalom acted toward all of Israel who came to the king for judgment, thus stealing the hearts of the men of Israel.
After forty years, Absalom said to the king, "Please let me go and fulfill my vow, which I have made to the LORD in Hebron."
"For your servant made a vow while I was in Geshur, Syria, saying, 'If the LORD brings me back to Jerusalem, then I will serve the LORD.'"
The king said to him, "Go in peace." So he arose and went to Hebron.
But Absalom sent spies throughout all the tribes of Israel, saying, "As soon as you hear the sound of the trumpet, declare, 'Absalom reigns in Hebron!'"
With Absalom went two hundred men from Jerusalem who were invited; they went in their simplicity, unaware of anything.
Absalom also sent for Ahithophel the Gilonite, David's counselor, from his city, Giloh, while he offered sacrifices. The conspiracy grew strong, as the people continued to increase with Absalom.
A messenger came to David, saying, "The hearts of the men of Israel are with Absalom."

David said to all his servants with him in Jerusalem, "Arise, and let us flee; otherwise, we will not escape from Absalom. Make haste to depart, lest he overtake us suddenly and bring evil upon us, striking the city with the edge of the sword."
The king's servants replied, "Behold, your servants are ready to do whatever my lord the king commands."
The king went out, and all his household followed him. He left ten women, who were concubines, to take care of the house.
The king went out, and all the people followed him, stopping at a distance.
All his servants passed by him, including the Cherethites, the Pelethites, and the Gittites—six hundred men who had come from Gath—who passed on before the king.
Then the king said to Ittai the Gittite, "Why are you also going with us? Return to your place and stay with the king, for you are a foreigner and an exile.
You came only yesterday; should I make you wander with us today? I am going wherever I can; return and take your brothers with you. May mercy and truth be with you."
Ittai answered the king, saying, "As the LORD lives, and as my lord the king lives, surely in whatever place my lord the king is, whether in death or life, there also will your servant be."
David said to Ittai, "Go and cross over." So Ittai the Gittite crossed over, along with all his men and the little ones with him.
The entire country wept loudly, and all the people crossed over. The king also crossed over the brook Kidron, and all the people moved toward the wilderness.
And behold, Zadok and all the Levites were with him, carrying the ark of the covenant of God. They set down the ark of God, and Abiathar went up until all the people had passed out of the city.
The king said to Zadok, "Carry back the ark of God into the city. If I find favor in the eyes of the LORD, He will bring me back and show me both it and His dwelling place.
But if He says, 'I have no delight in you,' here I am; let Him do to me as seems good to Him."
The king also said to Zadok the priest, "Are you not a seer? Return to the city in peace, you and your two sons with you, Ahimaaz your son and Jonathan the son of Abiathar.
I will wait in the plains of the wilderness until I receive word from you to inform me."
Zadok and Abiathar carried the ark of God back to Jerusalem, and they stayed there.
David went up the ascent of Mount Olivet, weeping as he went, with his head covered and barefoot. All the people with him covered their heads and went up, weeping as they went.
One told David, "Ahithophel is among the conspirators with Absalom." David prayed, "O LORD, I ask You to turn the counsel of Ahithophel into foolishness."
When David reached the top of the mount where he worshiped God, Hushai the Archite came to meet him with his coat torn and dust on his head.
David said to him, "If you go with me, you will be a burden to me.

But if you return to the city and say to Absalom, 'I will be your servant, O king; as I have been your father's servant until now, so I will now also be your servant,' then you can defeat the counsel of Ahithophel for me.
And do you not have Zadok and Abiathar the priests with you? Therefore, whatever you hear from the king's house, you shall tell it to Zadok and Abiathar the priests.
Behold, they have their two sons with them, Ahimaaz, Zadok's son, and Jonathan, Abiathar's son; by them, you shall send me everything you hear."
So Hushai, David's friend, entered the city, and Absalom came into Jerusalem.

As David passed the crest of the hill, Ziba, the servant of Mephibosheth, approached him with two donkeys saddled, carrying two hundred loaves of bread, one hundred bunches of raisins, one hundred summer fruits, and a bottle of wine.

The king asked Ziba, "What do you mean by these?" Ziba replied, "The donkeys are for the king's household to ride on; the bread and summer fruits are for the young men to eat; and the wine is for those who are faint in the wilderness to drink."
The king then inquired, "Where is your master's son?" Ziba answered, "He is staying in Jerusalem, for he said, 'Today the house of Israel will restore to me the kingdom of my father.'"
The king told Ziba, "All that belonged to Mephibosheth is now yours." Ziba humbly requested, "I beseech you, let me find favor in your sight, my lord, O king."
When King David arrived at Bahurim, a man from the house of Saul named Shimei, the son of Gera, came out cursing as he approached.
He threw stones at David and all the servants of King David, while all the people and mighty men were on his right and left.
Shimei cursed, saying, "Get out, get out, you bloody man, you worthless man!

The LORD has brought upon you all the blood of the house of Saul, in whose place you have reigned; the LORD has given the kingdom into the hand of Absalom your son. You are caught in your own mischief, for you are a bloody man."
Abishai, the son of Zeruiah, said to the king, "Why should this dead dog curse my lord the king? Let me go over and take off his head."
The king replied, "What do I have to do with you, sons of Zeruiah? Let him curse, for the LORD has told him to curse David. Who can say, 'Why have you done this?'"

David said to Abishai and all his servants, "My own son, who came from my own body, seeks my life. How much more might this Benjamite do it? Leave him alone and let him curse, for the LORD has commanded him.
Perhaps the LORD will look upon my affliction and repay me with good for his cursing today."
As David and his men continued on their way, Shimei followed along the hillside, cursing, throwing stones, and kicking up dust.
The king and all the people with him grew weary and refreshed themselves there.
Absalom and all the men of Israel arrived in Jerusalem, accompanied by Ahithophel.
When Hushai the Archite, David's friend, came to Absalom, he said, "Long live the king! Long live the king!"
Absalom asked Hushai, "Is this your loyalty to your friend? Why did you not go with your friend?"
Hushai replied, "No, but I will serve the one whom the LORD, this people, and all the men of Israel choose. I will remain with him."
He continued, "And whom should I serve? Should I not serve in the presence of his son? Just as I served in your father's presence, so will I serve in yours."
Absalom then said to Ahithophel, "Give us your counsel on what we should do."

Ahithophel advised Absalom, "Go in to your father's concubines, whom he has left to take care of the house. All Israel will hear that you have made yourself odious to your father, and the hands of all who are with you will be strengthened."
So they pitched a tent for Absalom on the roof, and he went in to his father's concubines in the sight of all Israel.
The counsel of Ahithophel in those days was regarded as if one had consulted the oracle of God; so was all the counsel of Ahithophel, both with David and with Absalom.
Moreover, Ahithophel said to Absalom, "Let me choose twelve thousand men, and I will rise and pursue David this night.
I will come upon him while he is weary and weak-handed, and I will make him afraid; all the people with him shall flee, and I will strike down the king alone.
I will bring back all the people to you; the man you seek is as if all have returned, so all the people shall be at peace."
This advice pleased Absalom and all the elders of Israel.
Then Absalom said, "Call Hushai the Archite as well, and let us hear what he has to say."
When Hushai arrived, Absalom spoke to him, saying, "Ahithophel has given this counsel: should we follow his advice? If not, speak up."
Hushai replied to Absalom, "The counsel that Ahithophel has given is not good at this time.
For you know your father and his men; they are mighty warriors, and they are as fierce as a bear robbed of her cubs in the field. Your father is a man of war and will not stay with the people.
Behold, he is hiding now in some pit or another place; and when some of them are overthrown at the first attack, whoever hears it will say, 'There is a slaughter among the people following Absalom.'
Even the bravest, whose heart is like that of a lion, will melt away, for all Israel knows that your father is a mighty man, and those with him are valiant.
Therefore, I advise that all Israel be gathered to you, from Dan to Beersheba, as numerous as the sand by the sea; and that you go into battle in person.
Then we will come upon him in a place where he can be found, and we will fall upon him like dew on the ground; not one of him or his men will be left.
Moreover, if he has entered a city, all Israel will bring ropes to that city, and we will drag it into the river, until not one small stone remains."

Absalom and all the men of Israel said, "The counsel of Hushai the Archite is better than the counsel of Ahithophel." For the LORD had determined to defeat the good counsel of Ahithophel, so that evil might come upon Absalom.
Then Hushai said to Zadok and Abiathar the priests, "This is what Ahithophel advised Absalom and the elders of Israel; and this is what I have counseled.
Now, send quickly and tell David, 'Do not spend the night in the plains of the wilderness, but cross over quickly; lest the king and all the people with him be swallowed up.'"
Jonathan and Ahimaaz stayed at Enrogel, for they could not be seen entering the city; a servant girl went and told them, and they went and informed King David.
However, a young man saw them and told Absalom; but they both quickly escaped and came to a man's house in Bahurim, which had a well in his courtyard, where they went down.
The woman took and spread a covering over the well's mouth and scattered grain on it, so that nothing was known.

When Absalom's servants came to the woman at the house, they asked, "Where are Ahimaaz and Jonathan?" The woman replied, "They have crossed over the brook." When they searched and could not find them, they returned to Jerusalem.
After they had departed, the two men came up out of the well and went to King David, saying, "Arise, and cross quickly over the water, for Ahithophel has counseled against you."
Then David arose, and all the people with him crossed over the Jordan; by morning light, not one of them was left behind.
When Ahithophel saw that his counsel was not followed, he saddled his donkey, went home to his city, put his household in order, hanged himself, and died; he was buried in the tomb of his father.
Then David came to Mahanaim, and Absalom crossed over the Jordan with all the men of Israel.
Absalom made Amasa captain of the army instead of Joab; Amasa was the son of a man named Ithra, an Israelite, who had married Abigail, the daughter of Nahash, sister of Zeruiah, Joab's mother.
So Israel and Absalom camped in the land of Gilead.
When David arrived at Mahanaim, Shobi the son of Nahash from Rabbah of the Ammonites, Machir the son of Ammiel from Lodebar, and Barzillai the Gileadite from Rogelim
brought beds, basins, earthenware vessels, wheat, barley, flour, parched grain, beans, lentils, and parched pulse,
as well as honey, butter, sheep, and cheese from the herd, for David and the people with him to eat; for they said, "The people are hungry, weary, and thirsty in the wilderness."
And David counted the people who were with him, appointing captains over thousands and captains over hundreds.

David divided the people into three groups: one under Joab, another under Abishai, the son of Zeruiah (Joab's brother), and the last under Ittai the Gittite. The king told the people, "I will surely go with you myself."

But the people replied, "You must not go out with us; for if we flee, they will not care about us; and if half of us die, they will not care about us either. You are worth ten thousand of us; it is better for you to help us from the city."
The king responded, "I will do what seems best to you." He stood by the gate, and all the people exited by hundreds and thousands.
The king instructed Joab, Abishai, and Ittai, saying, "Be gentle for my sake with the young man, Absalom." All the people heard the king give the captains this charge concerning Absalom.
The people went out to the field against Israel, and the battle took place in the forest of Ephraim.
The servants of David struck down the people of Israel, and there was a great slaughter that day, with twenty thousand men killed.
The battle spread across the entire region, and the forest claimed more lives that day than the sword did.

Absalom encountered the servants of David. He was riding a mule, which went under the thick branches of a large oak. His head got caught in the oak, and he was left hanging between heaven and earth, while the mule beneath him ran away.
A certain man saw this and reported it to Joab, saying, "I saw Absalom hanging in an oak."
Joab asked the man, "You saw him? Why didn't you strike him down right there? I would have given you ten shekels of silver and a belt."

The man replied to Joab, "Even if I were to receive a thousand shekels of silver, I would not lay a hand on the king's son. We heard the king command you, Abishai, and Ittai, saying, 'Beware that no one touches the young man Absalom.'
If I had acted against my own life, it would have been a betrayal, for nothing is hidden from the king, and you would have set yourself against me."
Joab then said, "I cannot delay with you." He took three javelins in his hand and thrust them through Absalom's heart while he was still alive in the oak.
Ten young men who carried Joab's armor surrounded Absalom and struck him down, killing him.
Joab blew the trumpet, and the people stopped pursuing Israel, for Joab had restrained them.
They took Absalom and threw him into a large pit in the forest, piling a massive heap of stones over him. All Israel fled, each to their own tent.

During his lifetime, Absalom had erected a pillar for himself in the king's valley, saying, "I have no son to keep my name alive." He named the pillar after himself, and it is called Absalom's place to this day.
Ahimaaz, the son of Zadok, said, "Let me run and bring the king news of how the LORD has avenged him on his enemies."
Joab replied, "You will not bring news today; you will bring news another day. Today, you will not bring news because the king's son is dead."
Joab then told Cushi, "Go and tell the king what you have seen." Cushi bowed to Joab and ran.
Ahimaaz, the son of Zadok, urged Joab again, "Please let me also run after Cushi." Joab asked, "Why do you want to run, my son, when you have no news ready?"
But he insisted, "Let me run." Joab said, "Run." So Ahimaaz ran by the way of the plain and outran Cushi.
David was sitting between the two gates, and the watchman went up to the roof over the gate to the wall. He lifted his eyes and saw a man running alone.
The watchman called out and told the king. The king said, "If he is alone, he brings news." As the man approached, he drew near.
The watchman saw another man running and called to the porter, saying, "Look, another man is running alone." The king said, "He also brings news."
The watchman said, "The running of the first man looks like the running of Ahimaaz, the son of Zadok." The king said, "He is a good man and comes with good news."

Ahimaaz called out and said to the king, "All is well." He fell to the ground before the king and said, "Blessed be the LORD your God, who has delivered up the men who raised their hands against my lord the king."
The king asked, "Is the young man Absalom safe?" Ahimaaz replied, "When Joab sent the king's servant and me, your servant, I saw a great commotion, but I did not know what it was."
The king said to him, "Turn aside and stand here." So he turned aside and stood still.
Then Cushi arrived and said, "Tidings, my lord the king! The LORD has avenged you today of all who rose up against you."
The king asked Cushi, "Is the young man Absalom safe?" Cushi replied, "May the enemies of my lord the king and all who rise against you to harm you be like that young man."

The king was deeply moved and went up to the chamber over the gate, weeping. As he went, he said, "O my son Absalom, my son, my son Absalom! If only I had died instead of you, O Absalom, my son, my son!"
And it was reported to Joab, "Look, the king is weeping and mourning for Absalom."
And the victory that day turned into mourning for all the people, for they heard that day how the king was grieving for his son.
The people stealthily returned to the city that day, like those who are ashamed and flee in battle.
But the king covered his face and cried out with a loud voice, "O my son Absalom, O Absalom, my son, my son!"
Joab entered the king's house and said, "You have shamed the faces of all your servants today, who have saved your life, and the lives of your sons, daughters, wives, and concubines.

You love your enemies and hate your friends. For you have declared today that you care neither for princes nor servants; for I perceive that if Absalom had lived and all of us had died today, it would have pleased you.

Now, therefore, arise, go out, and speak kindly to your servants; for I swear by the LORD, if you do not go out, not one will stay with you this night, and that will be worse for you than all the evil that has befallen you from your youth until now."
Then the king arose and sat at the gate. They told all the people, "Behold, the king sits at the gate." And all the people came before the king, for Israel had fled, each man to his tent.

All the people were in conflict throughout all the tribes of Israel, saying, "The king saved us from the hand of our enemies and delivered us from the hand of the Philistines; and now he has fled from the land because of Absalom.
And Absalom, whom we anointed over us, is dead in battle. Now, why do you not speak a word about bringing the king back?"

King David sent to Zadok and Abiathar the priests, saying, "Speak to the elders of Judah, saying, 'Why are you the last to bring the king back to his house? For the speech of all Israel has come to the king, even to his house.'
You are my brothers, my bones and my flesh; why then are you the last to bring back the king?"
And say to Amasa, "Are you not of my bone and of my flesh? God do so to me, and more also, if you are not captain of the host before me continually in place of Joab."
He won the hearts of all the men of Judah, as if they were one man, so that they sent this word to the king: "Return, you and all your servants."
So the king returned and came to the Jordan. And Judah came to Gilgal to meet the king and to conduct him over the Jordan.
Shimei the son of Gera, a Benjamite from Bahurim, hurried and came down with the men of Judah to meet King David.
There were a thousand men of Benjamin with him, and Ziba, the servant of the house of Saul, with his fifteen sons and twenty servants; they crossed over the Jordan before the king.
A ferry boat went over to carry the king's household and to do what he thought best. Shimei the son of Gera fell down before the king as he crossed over the Jordan,
And said to the king, "Let not my lord impute iniquity to me, nor remember what your servant did perversely the day my lord the king went out of Jerusalem; do not take it to heart.
For your servant knows that I have sinned; therefore, behold, I am the first this day of all the house of Joseph to come down to meet my lord the king."
But Abishai the son of Zeruiah answered and said, "Should not Shimei be put to death for this, because he cursed the LORD's anointed?"

And David said, "What do I have to do with you, sons of Zeruiah, that you should be adversaries to me today? Should any man be put to death in Israel today? For do I not know that I am king over Israel today?"
Therefore, the king said to Shimei, "You shall not die." And the king swore to him.
Mephibosheth the son of Saul came down to meet the king; he had neither dressed his feet, trimmed his beard, nor washed his clothes from the day the king departed until the day he returned in peace.
When he came to Jerusalem to meet the king, the king said to him, "Why did you not go with me, Mephibosheth?"
And he answered, "My lord, O king, my servant deceived me; for your servant said, 'I will saddle a donkey for myself, that I may ride on it and go with the king,' because your servant is lame.
He has slandered your servant to my lord the king; but my lord the king is like an angel of God; do therefore what is good in your eyes.
For all my father's house were but dead men before my lord the king; yet you set your servant among those who eat at your own table. What right do I have to cry any more to the king?"
And the king said to him, "Why do you speak any more of your matters? I have said, 'You and Ziba divide the land.'"
And Mephibosheth said to the king, "Yes, let him take all, forasmuch as my lord the king has come again in peace to his own house."
Barzillai the Gileadite came down from Rogelim and went over the Jordan with the king to conduct him over the Jordan.
Now Barzillai was a very old man, eighty years old; he had provided the king with sustenance while he lay at Mahanaim, for he was a very great man.
The king said to Barzillai, "Come over with me, and I will feed you with me in Jerusalem."
Barzillai said to the king, "How long have I to live, that I should go up with the king to Jerusalem?

I am this day eighty years old; can I discern between good and evil? Can your servant taste what I eat or drink? Can I hear any more the voice of singing men and singing women? Why then should your servant be a burden to my lord the king?
Your servant will go a little way over the Jordan with the king; why should the king recompense me with such a reward?

Let your servant, I pray you, turn back again, that I may die in my own city and be buried by the grave of my father and mother. But behold, your servant Chimham; let him go over with my lord the king, and do to him what seems good to you."
The king answered, "Chimham shall go over with me, and I will do to him what seems good to you; and whatever you require of me, that will I do for you."
All the people crossed over the Jordan. When the king had crossed over, he kissed Barzillai and blessed him; and he returned to his own place.
Then the king went on to Gilgal, and Chimham went on with him; all the people of Judah conducted the king, and also half the people of Israel.

And behold, all the men of Israel came to the king and said to him, "Why have our brothers, the men of Judah, stolen you away and brought the king and his household and all David's men with him over the Jordan?"
All the men of Judah answered the men of Israel, "Because the king is near of kin to us; why then be angry about this matter? Have we eaten at all at the king's expense? Or has he given us any gift?"

The men of Israel answered the men of Judah and said, "We have ten parts in the king, and we have also more right in David than you; why then did you despise us, that our advice should not be first had in bringing back our king?" And the words of the men of Judah were fiercer than the words of the men of Israel.

And there was a man of Belial named Sheba, the son of Bichri, a Benjamite; he blew a trumpet and proclaimed, "We have no part in David, nor any inheritance in the son of Jesse. Every man to his tents, O Israel!"
So every man of Israel departed from David and followed Sheba the son of Bichri, while the men of Judah remained loyal to their king, from the Jordan to Jerusalem.

When David arrived at his house in Jerusalem, he took the ten women, his concubines, whom he had left to care for the house, and placed them under guard. He provided for them but did not go in to them, so they remained confined until the day of their death, living as widows.
Then the king said to Amasa, "Gather the men of Judah for me within three days, and be here present."
Amasa went to assemble the men of Judah, but he delayed longer than the time David had set for him.
David said to Abishai, "Now Sheba the son of Bichri will do us more harm than Absalom did. Take your lord's servants and pursue him, lest he find fortified cities and escape us."
Joab's men, along with the Cherethites, the Pelethites, and all the mighty men, went out from Jerusalem to pursue Sheba the son of Bichri.
When they reached the great stone in Gibeon, Amasa went before them. Joab was dressed in his battle garment, with a sword fastened to his side in its sheath; as he walked, it fell out.
Joab asked Amasa, "Are you well, my brother?" and took Amasa by the beard with his right hand to kiss him.

But Amasa did not notice the sword in Joab's hand, and Joab struck him in the fifth rib, spilling his entrails on the ground. He did not strike him again, and Amasa died. Joab and his brother Abishai then pursued Sheba the son of Bichri.
One of Joab's men stood by him and said, "Whoever is for Joab and for David, let him follow Joab."

Amasa lay in a pool of blood in the middle of the highway. When the man saw that all the people stood still, he moved Amasa off the highway into the field and covered him with a cloth, noticing that everyone who passed by stood still.
Once Amasa was removed from the highway, all the people continued after Joab to pursue Sheba the son of Bichri.
Joab went through all the tribes of Israel to Abel, to Bethmaachah, and all the Berites, and they gathered together to pursue him.
They besieged him in Abel of Bethmaachah, building a mound against the city, which stood in the trench, while all the people with Joab battered the wall to bring it down.
Then a wise woman cried out from the city, "Listen, listen! Please say to Joab, 'Come here so I can speak with you.'"
When he approached her, the woman asked, "Are you Joab?" He replied, "I am." She then said, "Listen to the words of your servant." He answered, "I am listening."
She continued, "In the past, they used to say, 'Seek counsel at Abel,' and that settled the matter.
I am one of those who are peaceable and faithful in Israel; you seek to destroy a city that is a mother in Israel. Why would you swallow up the inheritance of the LORD?"
Joab replied, "Far be it from me to swallow up or destroy.

That is not the case; a man from the hill country of Ephraim, Sheba the son of Bichri, has lifted his hand against the king, against David. Hand him over, and I will depart from the city." The woman said to Joab, "His head will be thrown to you over the wall."

The woman went to all the people in her wisdom, and they cut off the head of Sheba the son of Bichri and threw it out to Joab. He blew a trumpet, and they dispersed from the city, each man returning to his tent. Joab then returned to Jerusalem to the king.
Now Joab was in command of all the army of Israel, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada was over the Cherethites and the Pelethites.
Adoram was in charge of the tribute, and Jehoshaphat the son of Ahilud was the recorder.
Sheva was the scribe, and Zadok and Abiathar were the priests.
Ira the Jairite was also a chief ruler under David.

There was a famine during the reign of David that lasted three years, year after year; David sought guidance from the LORD. The LORD responded, saying it was due to Saul and his violent household, as he had killed the Gibeonites.

The king summoned the Gibeonites and spoke to them; (the Gibeonites were not part of the children of Israel, but were remnants of the Amorites; the children of Israel had sworn an oath to them, yet Saul had attempted to kill them out of zeal for the children of Israel and Judah.)
David asked the Gibeonites, "What can I do for you? How can I make atonement so that you may bless the inheritance of the LORD?"
The Gibeonites replied, "We do not want silver or gold from Saul or his household; nor should you kill any man in Israel for us." David responded, "Whatever you say, I will do for you."
They answered the king, "The man who consumed us and plotted against us to eliminate us from the land of Israel,
Let seven of his sons be handed over to us, and we will hang them before the LORD in Gibeah of Saul, whom the LORD chose." The king agreed, saying, "I will give them to you."
However, the king spared Mephibosheth, the son of Jonathan, the son of Saul, because of the oath the LORD had made between David and Jonathan.

The king took the two sons of Rizpah, the daughter of Aiah, whom she bore to Saul, named Armoni and Mephibosheth; and the five sons of Michal, the daughter of Saul, whom she raised for Adriel, the son of Barzillai the Meholathite.
He handed them over to the Gibeonites, who hanged them on a hill before the LORD. All seven were executed together during the harvest season, at the beginning of the barley harvest.

Rizpah, the daughter of Aiah, took sackcloth and spread it on a rock, from the start of the harvest until rain fell upon them from heaven. She did not allow the birds of the air to rest on them by day, nor the beasts of the field by night.
David was informed of what Rizpah, the concubine of Saul, had done.

David went and retrieved the bones of Saul and the bones of Jonathan, his son, from the men of Jabeshgilead, who had taken them from the street of Bethshan, where the Philistines had hanged them after killing Saul at Gilboa.
He brought the bones of Saul and Jonathan from there and gathered the bones of those who had been hanged.

They buried the bones of Saul and Jonathan in the land of Benjamin, in Zelah, in the tomb of Kish, his father. They fulfilled all that the king commanded, and afterward, God was appeased for the land.
Furthermore, the Philistines waged war against Israel again; David and his servants went down to fight the Philistines, and David grew weary.
Ishbibenob, one of the descendants of the giant, whose spear weighed three hundred shekels of bronze and who was armed with a new sword, intended to kill David.

But Abishai, the son of Zeruiah, came to David's aid, struck down the Philistine, and killed him. Then David's men swore to him, saying, "You shall no longer go out with us to battle, lest you extinguish the light of Israel."
After this, there was another battle with the Philistines at Gob, where Sibbechai the Hushathite killed Saph, one of the descendants of the giant.
There was yet another battle in Gob against the Philistines, where Elhanan, the son of Jaareoregim, a Bethlehemite, killed the brother of Goliath the Gittite, whose spear was like a weaver's beam.
Another battle took place in Gath, where there was a man of great stature who had six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot, totaling twenty-four; he was also a descendant of the giant.
When he defied Israel, Jonathan, the son of Shimeah, David's brother, killed him.
These four were born to the giant in Gath and fell by the hand of David and his servants.
And David spoke to the LORD the words of this song on the day that the LORD delivered him from the hand of all his enemies, and from the hand of Saul:
He said, "The LORD is my rock, my fortress, and my deliverer;
The God of my rock; in Him will I trust: He is my shield, the horn of my salvation, my high tower, my refuge, my savior; You save me from violence.
I will call on the LORD, who is worthy to be praised; so shall I be saved from my enemies.
When the waves of death surrounded me, the floods of ungodly men made me afraid;
The sorrows of hell surrounded me; the snares of death confronted me;
In my distress, I called upon the LORD and cried to my God; He heard my voice from His temple, and my cry entered His ears.
Then the earth shook and trembled; the foundations of heaven moved and shook because He was angry.
There went up smoke from His nostrils, and fire from His mouth devoured; coals were kindled by it.
He bowed the heavens and came down; darkness was under His feet.
He rode upon a cherub and flew; He was seen upon the wings of the wind.
He made darkness His pavilions round about Him, dark waters, and thick clouds of the skies.
Through the brightness before Him, coals of fire were kindled.
The LORD thundered from heaven, and the Most High uttered His voice.
He sent out arrows and scattered them; lightning and discomfited them.
The channels of the sea appeared, and the foundations of the world were discovered at the rebuke of the LORD, at the blast of the breath of His nostrils.
He sent from above, took me; He drew me out of many waters;
He delivered me from my strong enemy and from those who hated me, for they were too strong for me.
They confronted me in the day of my calamity, but the LORD was my support.
He brought me forth into a large place; He delivered me because He delighted in me.
The LORD rewarded me according to my righteousness; according to the cleanness of my hands, He recompensed me.
For I have kept the ways of the LORD and have not wickedly departed from my God.
For all His judgments were before me; and as for His statutes, I did not depart from them.
I was also upright before Him and kept myself from my iniquity.
Therefore, the LORD has recompensed me according to my righteousness; according to my cleanness in His sight.
With the merciful, You will show Yourself merciful; with the upright man, You will show Yourself upright.
With the pure, You will show Yourself pure; and with the froward, You will show Yourself unsavory.
And the afflicted people, You will save; but Your eyes are upon the haughty, that You may bring them down.
For You are my lamp, O LORD; the LORD will lighten my darkness.
For by You, I have run through a troop; by my God, I have leaped over a wall.
As for God, His way is perfect; the word of the LORD is tested; He is a shield to all who trust in Him.
For who is God, except the LORD? And who is a rock, except our God?
God is my strength and power; He makes my way perfect.
He makes my feet like the feet of deer and sets me on my high places.
He teaches my hands to war, so that a bow of steel is broken by my arms.
You have also given me the shield of Your salvation; Your gentleness has made me great.
You have enlarged my steps under me, so that my feet did not slip.
I have pursued my enemies and destroyed them; I did not turn back until I had consumed them.
And I have consumed them and wounded them, so they could not rise; yes, they have fallen under my feet.
For You have girded me with strength for battle; those who rose up against me, You have subdued under me.
You have also given me the necks of my enemies, that I might destroy those who hate me.
They looked, but there was none to save; even to the LORD, but He answered them not.
Then I beat them as small as the dust of the earth; I stamped them as the mire of the street and spread them abroad.
You also have delivered me from the strivings of my people; You have kept me to be head of the heathen; a people I did not know shall serve me.
Strangers shall submit themselves to me; as soon as they hear, they shall be obedient to me.
Strangers shall fade away, and they shall be afraid from their close places.
The LORD lives; blessed be my rock; exalted be the God of the rock of my salvation.
It is God who avenges me and brings down the people under me.
And who brings me forth from my enemies; You have also lifted me up on high above those who rose up against me; You have delivered me from the violent man.
Therefore, I will give thanks to You, O LORD, among the heathen, and I will sing praises to Your name.
He is the tower of salvation for His king and shows mercy to His anointed, to David, and to his seed forevermore.
Now these are the last words of David. David the son of Jesse spoke, and the man who was raised up on high, the anointed of the God of Jacob, and the sweet psalmist of Israel, declared,
The Spirit of the LORD spoke by me, and His word was on my tongue.
The God of Israel said, the Rock of Israel spoke to me, He who rules over men must be just, ruling in the fear of God.
And he shall be like the light of the morning, when the sun rises, even a morning without clouds; like the tender grass springing out of the earth by clear shining after rain.

Although my house is not so with God; yet He has made with me an everlasting covenant, ordered in all things, and sure: for this is all my salvation, and all my desire, even if He does not cause it to grow.
But the sons of Belial shall all be like thorns thrust away, because they cannot be taken with hands:
But the man who touches them must be fenced with iron and the staff of a spear; and they shall be utterly burned with fire in the same place.

These are the names of the mighty men whom David had: The Tachmonite who sat in the seat, chief among the captains; he was Adino the Eznite: he lifted up his spear against eight hundred, whom he killed at one time.
And after him was Eleazar the son of Dodo the Ahohite, one of the three mighty men with David, when they defied the Philistines who were gathered together for battle, and the men of Israel had fled:

He arose, and struck the Philistines until his hand was weary, and his hand clung to the sword: and the LORD wrought a great victory that day; and the people returned after him only to take the spoil.

And after him was Shammah the son of Agee the Hararite. And the Philistines were gathered together into a troop, where there was a piece of ground full of lentils: and the people fled from the Philistines.
But he stood in the midst of the ground, defended it, and killed the Philistines: and the LORD wrought a great victory.
And three of the thirty chief went down, and came to David in the harvest time to the cave of Adullam: and the troop of the Philistines pitched in the valley of Rephaim.
And David was then in a stronghold, and the garrison of the Philistines was then in Bethlehem.
And David longed, and said, Oh that someone would give me a drink from the water of the well of Bethlehem, which is by the gate!

And the three mighty men broke through the host of the Philistines, drew water from the well of Bethlehem, that was by the gate, and brought it to David: nevertheless he would not drink it, but poured it out to the LORD.

And he said, Far be it from me, O LORD, that I should do this: is this not the blood of the men who went in jeopardy of their lives? therefore he would not drink it. These things did these three mighty men.
And Abishai, the brother of Joab, the son of Zeruiah, was chief among three. And he lifted up his spear against three hundred, and killed them, and had a name among the three.
Was he not the most honorable of the three? therefore he was their captain: however, he did not attain to the first three.

And Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, the son of a valiant man, of Kabzeel, who had done many acts, he killed two lionlike men of Moab: he also went down and killed a lion in the midst of a pit in the time of snow:

And he killed an Egyptian, a goodly man: and the Egyptian had a spear in his hand; but he went down to him with a staff, plucked the spear out of the Egyptian's hand, and killed him with his own spear.
These things did Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and had a name among the three mighty men.
He was more honorable than the thirty, but he did not attain to the first three. And David set him over his guard.
Asahel the brother of Joab was one of the thirty; Elhanan the son of Dodo of Bethlehem,
Shammah the Harodite, Elika the Harodite,
Helez the Paltite, Ira the son of Ikkesh the Tekoite,
Abiezer the Anethothite, Mebunnai the Hushathite,
Zalmon the Ahohite, Maharai the Netophathite,
Heleb the son of Baanah, a Netophathite, Ittai the son of Ribai from Gibeah of the children of Benjamin,
Benaiah the Pirathonite, Hiddai of the brooks of Gaash,
Abialbon the Arbathite, Azmaveth the Barhumite,
Eliahba the Shaalbonite, of the sons of Jashen, Jonathan,
Shammah the Hararite, Ahiam the son of Sharar the Hararite,
Eliphelet the son of Ahasbai, the son of the Maachathite, Eliam the son of Ahithophel the Gilonite,
Hezrai the Carmelite, Paarai the Arbite,
Igal the son of Nathan of Zobah, Bani the Gadite,
Zelek the Ammonite, Nahari the Beerothite, armor-bearer to Joab the son of Zeruiah,
Ira an Ithrite, Gareb an Ithrite,
Uriah the Hittite: thirty-seven in all.
And once more, the anger of the LORD was ignited against Israel, prompting Him to incite David to say, "Go, take a census of Israel and Judah."
The king instructed Joab, the commander of his army, who was with him, "Go now through all the tribes of Israel, from Dan to Beersheba, and count the people, so that I may know their number."
Joab replied to the king, "May the LORD your God increase the people a hundredfold, and may the eyes of my lord the king see it; but why does my lord the king take pleasure in this?"
Despite Joab's objections, the king's command prevailed over Joab and the commanders of the army. Joab and the commanders left the king's presence to count the people of Israel.
They crossed the Jordan and camped at Aroer, on the right side of the city that lies in the midst of the river of Gad, and toward Jazer.
Then they traveled to Gilead and the land of Tahtimhodshi; they reached Danjaan and approached Zidon.
They arrived at the stronghold of Tyre and all the cities of the Hivites and Canaanites, and they went southward to Judah, even to Beersheba.
After surveying the entire land, they returned to Jerusalem at the end of nine months and twenty days.
Joab reported the total number of people to the king: there were in Israel eight hundred thousand valiant men who drew the sword, and the men of Judah numbered five hundred thousand.

David's heart was troubled after he had counted the people. He said to the LORD, "I have sinned greatly in what I have done; now, I plead with you, O LORD, take away the guilt of your servant, for I have acted very foolishly."
In the morning, the word of the LORD came to the prophet Gad, David's seer, saying,
"Go and tell David, 'This is what the LORD says: I am giving you three options; choose one of them for me to carry out against you.'"

So Gad went to David and said, "Shall there come upon you three years of famine in your land? Or will you flee for three months before your enemies while they pursue you? Or shall there be three days of plague in your land? Now consider and decide what answer I should return to Him who sent me."
David replied to Gad, "I am in deep distress. Let us fall into the hands of the LORD, for His mercy is great; but do not let me fall into the hands of men."
So the LORD sent a plague upon Israel from the morning until the appointed time, and seventy thousand men died from Dan to Beersheba.

When the angel stretched out his hand to destroy Jerusalem, the LORD relented concerning the disaster and said to the angel who was destroying the people, "Enough! Withdraw your hand." The angel of the LORD was then at the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.
David spoke to the LORD when he saw the angel striking down the people, and he said, "I have sinned; I have done wrong. These sheep, what have they done? Let your hand fall upon me and my family."
That day, Gad came to David and said, "Go up and build an altar to the LORD on the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite."
David followed Gad's instructions and went up as the LORD commanded.
Araunah looked and saw the king and his servants approaching him, and he went out and bowed down before the king with his face to the ground.
Araunah asked, "Why has my lord the king come to his servant?" David replied, "To buy your threshing floor, so I can build an altar to the LORD, that the plague may be halted."
Araunah said to David, "Let my lord the king take whatever he wishes and offer it up; here are oxen for the burnt offering, and the threshing sledges and yokes for the wood."
All these things Araunah, as a king, gave to the king. He said to David, "May the LORD your God accept you."

But the king replied to Araunah, "No, I insist on buying it for a price; I will not offer burnt offerings to the LORD my God that cost me nothing." So David bought the threshing floor and the oxen for fifty shekels of silver.
David built an altar to the LORD there and offered burnt offerings and peace offerings. Thus, the LORD was moved by the prayer for the land, and the plague was halted in Israel.
Now King David was old and advanced in years; they covered him with blankets, but he felt no warmth.
Therefore, his servants said to him, "Let us find a young virgin for my lord the king; let her stand before the king, cherish him, and lie in his bosom, so that my lord the king may feel warmth."
So they searched for a beautiful young woman throughout all the territories of Israel and found Abishag, a Shunammite, and brought her to the king.
The young woman was very beautiful and cared for the king, ministering to him, but the king did not know her intimately.
Then Adonijah, the son of Haggith, exalted himself, saying, "I will be king." He prepared chariots, horsemen, and fifty men to run before him.
His father had never displeased him by asking, "Why have you done this?" He was also a very handsome man, and his mother bore him after Absalom.
He conferred with Joab, the son of Zeruiah, and Abiathar the priest; they followed Adonijah and supported him.
But Zadok the priest, Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, Nathan the prophet, Shimei, Rei, and the mighty men who belonged to David were not with Adonijah.
Adonijah sacrificed sheep, oxen, and fat cattle by the stone of Zoheleth, which is near Enrogel, and invited all his brothers, the king's sons, and all the men of Judah, the king's servants.
However, Nathan the prophet, Benaiah, the mighty men, and Solomon, his brother, he did not invite.
Therefore, Nathan spoke to Bathsheba, the mother of Solomon, saying, "Have you not heard that Adonijah, the son of Haggith, is reigning, and our lord David knows nothing about it?
Now, therefore, come, let me give you counsel, so that you may save your own life and the life of your son Solomon.
Go to King David and say to him, 'Did you not, my lord, O king, swear to your servant, saying, "Solomon your son shall reign after me, and he shall sit upon my throne"? Why then does Adonijah reign?'
Behold, while you are still speaking with the king, I will come in after you and confirm your words."
Bathsheba went to the king in his chamber; the king was very old, and Abishag the Shunammite was ministering to him.
Bathsheba bowed and did obeisance to the king. The king asked, "What do you want?"
She said to him, "My lord, you swore by the LORD your God to your servant, saying, 'Solomon your son shall reign after me, and he shall sit upon my throne.'
Now, behold, Adonijah reigns, and you, my lord the king, do not know it.
He has sacrificed oxen, fat cattle, and sheep in abundance, and has called all the king's sons, Abiathar the priest, and Joab the captain of the army; but he has not called Solomon, your servant.
And you, my lord, O king, the eyes of all Israel are upon you to tell them who shall sit on the throne of my lord the king after him.
Otherwise, when my lord the king sleeps with his fathers, I and my son Solomon will be counted as offenders."
While she was still speaking with the king, Nathan the prophet also came in.
They told the king, "Nathan the prophet is here." When he came in before the king, he bowed with his face to the ground.
Nathan said, "My lord, O king, have you said, 'Adonijah shall reign after me, and he shall sit upon my throne'?

For he has gone down today and has sacrificed oxen, fat cattle, and sheep in abundance, and has called all the king's sons, the captains of the army, and Abiathar the priest; and behold, they eat and drink before him and say, 'Long live King Adonijah!'
But me, your servant, and Zadok the priest, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and your servant Solomon, he has not called.
Is this thing done by my lord the king, and you have not shown it to your servant who should sit on the throne of my lord the king after him?"
Then King David answered, "Call me Bathsheba." She came into the king's presence and stood before him.
The king swore, saying, "As the LORD lives, who has redeemed my soul from all distress,
Even as I swore to you by the LORD God of Israel, saying, 'Solomon your son shall reign after me, and he shall sit upon my throne in my place,' so will I certainly do this day."
Then Bathsheba bowed with her face to the ground and did reverence to the king, saying, "Let my lord King David live forever."
King David said, "Call me Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada." They came before the king.
The king also said to them, "Take with you the servants of your lord, and have Solomon my son ride on my own mule, and bring him down to Gihon.
Let Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet anoint him there as king over Israel; blow the trumpet and say, 'Long live King Solomon!'
Then you shall come up after him, so that he may come and sit upon my throne; for he shall be king in my place, and I have appointed him to be ruler over Israel and Judah."
Benaiah the son of Jehoiada answered the king, saying, "Amen! May the LORD God of my lord the king say so too.
As the LORD has been with my lord the king, may He be with Solomon and make his throne greater than the throne of my lord King David."
So Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, the Cherethites, and the Pelethites went down and had Solomon ride on King David's mule and brought him to Gihon.
Zadok the priest took a horn of oil from the tabernacle and anointed Solomon. They blew the trumpet, and all the people said, "Long live King Solomon!"
All the people followed him, piping with pipes and rejoicing with great joy, so that the earth shook with the sound of them.
Adonijah and all the guests with him heard it as they finished eating. When Joab heard the sound of the trumpet, he said, "Why is this noise of the city in an uproar?"
While he was still speaking, behold, Jonathan, the son of Abiathar the priest, came; and Adonijah said to him, "Come in; for you are a valiant man and bring good tidings."
Jonathan answered and said to Adonijah, "Indeed, our lord King David has made Solomon king.
The king has sent with him Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, the Cherethites, and the Pelethites, and they have caused him to ride on the king's mule.
Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet have anointed him king in Gihon, and they have come up from there rejoicing, so that the city is in an uproar. This is the noise you have heard.
And moreover, Solomon sits on the throne of the kingdom.

Furthermore, the king's servants have come to bless our lord King David, saying, 'May God make the name of Solomon better than your name, and make his throne greater than your throne.' And the king bowed himself upon the bed.
The king also said, 'Blessed be the LORD God of Israel, who has given one to sit on my throne this day, my own eyes seeing it.'
All the guests who were with Adonijah were afraid, and they rose up and went every man his way.
Adonijah feared because of Solomon, and arose, went, and took hold of the horns of the altar.

It was told Solomon, saying, "Behold, Adonijah fears King Solomon; for he has taken hold of the horns of the altar, saying, 'Let King Solomon swear to me today that he will not slay his servant with the sword.'"
Solomon said, "If he shows himself to be a worthy man, not a hair of him shall fall to the earth; but if wickedness is found in him, he shall die."
So King Solomon sent, and they brought him down from the altar. He came and bowed himself to King Solomon, and Solomon said to him, "Go to your house."
As the days of David approached for him to die, he charged his son Solomon, saying,
"I am going the way of all the earth; be strong and show yourself a man.

Keep the charge of the LORD your God, walk in His ways, keep His statutes, commandments, judgments, and testimonies, as written in the law of Moses, so that you may prosper in all you do and wherever you turn.

This is so that the LORD may fulfill His promise to me, saying, 'If your children heed their way, walking before me in truth with all their heart and soul, there will not fail you a man on the throne of Israel.'

Furthermore, you know what Joab son of Zeruiah did to me, and what he did to the two captains of Israel's hosts, Abner son of Ner and Amasa son of Jether, whom he killed, shedding blood in peace and staining his belt and shoes with innocent blood.
Act according to your wisdom, and do not let his gray hair go down to the grave in peace.
But show kindness to the sons of Barzillai the Gileadite, and let them eat at your table, for they came to me when I fled from your brother Absalom.

And behold, you have Shimei son of Gera, a Benjamite from Bahurim, who cursed me with a grievous curse when I went to Mahanaim; but he came down to meet me at the Jordan, and I swore to him by the LORD, saying, 'I will not put you to death with the sword.'
Now, do not hold him guiltless, for you are a wise man and know what you ought to do to him; but bring his gray hair down to the grave with blood."
So David slept with his fathers and was buried in the city of David.
David reigned over Israel for forty years: seven years in Hebron and thirty-three years in Jerusalem.
Then Solomon sat on the throne of his father David, and his kingdom was established greatly.
Adonijah son of Haggith came to Bathsheba, the mother of Solomon. She asked, "Do you come peaceably?" He replied, "Peaceably."
He added, "I have something to say to you." She said, "Speak on."
He said, "You know that the kingdom was mine, and all Israel set their faces on me to reign; however, the kingdom has turned and become my brother's, for it was his from the LORD.
Now I ask one petition of you; do not deny me." She said, "Say on."
He said, "Please speak to King Solomon (for he will not refuse you) to give me Abishag the Shunammite as a wife."
Bathsheba replied, "Very well; I will speak to the king for you."
Bathsheba went to King Solomon to speak on behalf of Adonijah. The king rose to meet her, bowed to her, sat on his throne, and had a seat set for his mother, who sat at his right hand.
Then she said, "I desire one small petition of you; please do not refuse me." The king said, "Ask, my mother; for I will not refuse you."
She said, "Let Abishag the Shunammite be given to Adonijah your brother as a wife."

King Solomon answered his mother, "Why do you ask for Abishag the Shunammite for Adonijah? Ask for him the kingdom as well, for he is my elder brother; even for him, for Abiathar the priest, and for Joab son of Zeruiah."
Then King Solomon swore by the LORD, saying, "God do so to me, and more also, if Adonijah has not spoken this word against his own life.
Now, as the LORD lives, who has established me and set me on the throne of my father David, and who has made me a house as He promised, Adonijah shall be put to death this day."
King Solomon sent Benaiah son of Jehoiada, and he struck him down so that he died.

To Abiathar the priest, the king said, "Go to Anathoth, to your own fields; you are worthy of death, but I will not put you to death at this time because you carried the ark of the LORD God before my father David and because you have been afflicted in all that my father was afflicted."
So Solomon expelled Abiathar from being priest to the LORD, fulfilling the word of the LORD concerning the house of Eli in Shiloh.
Then news came to Joab, for Joab had sided with Adonijah, though he had not sided with Absalom. Joab fled to the tabernacle of the LORD and took hold of the horns of the altar.
It was reported to King Solomon that Joab had fled to the tabernacle of the LORD and was by the altar. Then Solomon sent Benaiah son of Jehoiada, saying, "Go, strike him down."

Benaiah came to the tabernacle of the LORD and said to him, "Thus says the king, 'Come out.'" He answered, "No, I will die here." Benaiah brought the king word again, saying, "Thus said Joab, and thus he answered me."
The king said to him, "Do as he has said, strike him down and bury him, so you may take away the innocent blood which Joab shed from me and from my father's house.

The LORD shall return his blood upon his own head, for he fell upon two men more righteous and better than he, and killed them with the sword, my father David not knowing it, namely, Abner son of Ner, captain of the host of Israel, and Amasa son of Jether, captain of the host of Judah.

Their blood shall therefore return upon the head of Joab and upon the head of his descendants forever; but upon David, and upon his descendants, and upon his house, and upon his throne, there shall be peace forever from the LORD."
So Benaiah son of Jehoiada went up, struck him down, and killed him; and he was buried in his own house in the wilderness.
The king put Benaiah son of Jehoiada in his place over the army, and Zadok the priest he put in the place of Abiathar.
The king sent for Shimei and said to him, "Build yourself a house in Jerusalem and dwell there, and do not go out from there to any place.
For it shall be that on the day you go out and cross the brook Kidron, you shall know for certain that you shall surely die; your blood shall be upon your own head."
Shimei said to the king, "The saying is good; as my lord the king has said, so will your servant do." So Shimei dwelt in Jerusalem many days.
But it happened at the end of three years that two of Shimei's servants ran away to Achish son of Maachah, king of Gath. They told Shimei, "Behold, your servants are in Gath."
Shimei arose, saddled his donkey, and went to Gath to Achish to seek his servants; Shimei went and brought his servants from Gath.
It was reported to Solomon that Shimei had gone from Jerusalem to Gath and had returned.

The king sent for Shimei and said to him, "Did I not make you swear by the LORD and warned you, saying, 'Know for certain that on the day you go out and walk abroad anywhere, you shall surely die'? And you said to me, 'The word I have heard is good.'
Why then have you not kept the oath of the LORD and the commandment that I charged you with?
The king said moreover to Shimei, "You know all the wickedness that your heart is privy to, that you did to David my father; therefore the LORD shall return your wickedness upon your own head.
And King Solomon shall be blessed, and the throne of David shall be established before the LORD forever."
So the king commanded Benaiah son of Jehoiada, who went out and struck him down so that he died. Thus, the kingdom was established in the hand of Solomon.

And Solomon formed an alliance with Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, and took Pharaoh's daughter, bringing her to the city of David, until he completed the construction of his own palace, the house of the LORD, and the surrounding wall of Jerusalem.
Only the people offered sacrifices at high places, as there was no temple built in the name of the LORD up to that time.
Solomon loved the LORD, following the statutes of his father David; however, he sacrificed and burned incense at high places.
The king went to Gibeon to offer sacrifices there, for it was the most prominent high place; Solomon offered a thousand burnt offerings on that altar.
In Gibeon, the LORD appeared to Solomon in a dream at night, and God said, "Ask what I shall give you."

Solomon replied, "You have shown great mercy to your servant David my father, as he walked before you in truth, righteousness, and uprightness of heart; and you have kept for him this great kindness by giving him a son to sit on his throne, as it is today.
And now, O LORD my God, you have made your servant king in place of David my father, but I am just a little child; I do not know how to go out or come in.
Your servant is among the people you have chosen, a great people, too numerous to be counted.
Therefore, give your servant an understanding heart to judge your people, so I can discern between good and evil; for who is able to judge this great people of yours?"
The speech pleased the LORD, that Solomon had asked for this.
God said to him, "Because you have asked for this and not for long life, riches, or the life of your enemies, but for understanding to discern judgment;
Behold, I have done according to your words: I have given you a wise and understanding heart; so that there has been none like you before, nor shall any arise like you after.
I have also given you what you did not ask for, both riches and honor, so that there will not be anyone among the kings like you all your days.
And if you walk in my ways, keeping my statutes and commandments, as your father David did, then I will lengthen your days."
Solomon awoke, and behold, it was a dream. He returned to Jerusalem, stood before the ark of the covenant of the LORD, offered burnt offerings, peace offerings, and made a feast for all his servants.
Then two women, who were harlots, came to the king and stood before him.
One woman said, "O my lord, this woman and I live in one house; and I gave birth to a child while she was in the house.
And on the third day after my child was born, this woman also gave birth; we were alone together in the house, with no one else present.
During the night, this woman's child died because she lay on him.
She arose at midnight, took my son from beside me while your servant slept, laid him in her bosom, and placed her dead child in my bosom.
When I awoke in the morning to nurse my child, behold, he was dead; but when I examined him closely in the morning, I realized it was not my son whom I had borne."

The other woman said, "No! The living child is my son, and the dead one is yours." The first woman replied, "No! The dead one is your son, and the living one is mine." Thus they argued before the king.
Then the king said, "The one says, 'This is my son who is alive, and your son is dead,' while the other says, 'No! Your son is dead, and my son is alive.'"
The king ordered, "Bring me a sword." They brought a sword before the king.
The king said, "Divide the living child in two, and give half to one and half to the other."

Then the woman whose child was alive spoke to the king, for her compassion for her son was strong. She said, "O my lord, give her the living child, and do not kill him!" But the other said, "Let it be neither mine nor yours; divide it."
The king responded, "Give her the living child, and do not kill him; she is his mother."
