When Elijah heard it, he wrapped his face in his cloak, went out, and stood at the entrance of the cave. Then a voice came to him, asking, "What are you doing here, Elijah?"

He answered, "I have been very zealous for the LORD God of hosts; because the children of Israel have forsaken your covenant, torn down your altars, and killed your prophets with the sword; and I, even I alone, am left, and they seek my life to take it away."
The LORD said to him, "Go back the way you came, and go to the desert of Damascus. When you get there, anoint Hazael to be king over Aram.
Also, anoint Jehu son of Nimshi to be king over Israel, and anoint Elisha son of Shaphat from Abel Meholah to succeed you as prophet."
Jehu will put to death any who escape the sword of Hazael, and Elisha will put to death any who escape the sword of Jehu.
Yet I reserve seven thousand in Israel—all whose knees have not bowed down to Baal and whose mouths have not kissed him.
So he left there and found Elisha son of Shaphat, who was plowing with twelve yoke of oxen before him, and he was with the twelfth. Elijah passed by him and threw his cloak around him.
Elisha left the oxen, ran after Elijah, and said, "Let me kiss my father and mother goodbye, and then I will follow you." Elijah replied, "Go back; what have I done to you?"

So Elisha returned to him, took a yoke of oxen, slaughtered them, boiled their flesh using the plow equipment, and gave it to the people, and they ate. Then he arose and followed Elijah, becoming his servant.
And Benhadad, the king of Syria, gathered all his forces together: there were thirty-two kings with him, along with horses and chariots; he went up and besieged Samaria, waging war against it.
He sent messengers to Ahab, king of Israel, in the city, saying, "Thus says Benhadad,
'Your silver and gold are mine; your wives and children, the most beautiful, are also mine.'"
The king of Israel replied, "My lord, O king, according to your word, I am yours, and all that I possess."
The messengers returned, saying, "Thus speaks Benhadad: Although I have previously sent to you, saying, 'You shall deliver to me your silver, gold, wives, and children,'

I will send my servants to you tomorrow at this time, and they shall search your house and the houses of your servants; whatever is desirable in your eyes, they shall take in their hands and carry away."

Then the king of Israel called all the elders of the land and said, "Please pay attention and see how this man seeks trouble: he sent to me for my wives, children, silver, and gold, and I did not deny him."
All the elders and the people replied, "Do not listen to him or consent."

So he told the messengers of Benhadad, "Tell my lord the king: All that you requested from your servant at first I will do; but this thing I cannot do." The messengers departed and brought him word again.
Benhadad sent to him, saying, "May the gods do so to me, and more also, if the dust of Samaria is enough for handfuls for all the people who follow me."
The king of Israel answered, "Tell him, 'Let not the one who puts on his armor boast like the one who takes it off.'"
When Benhadad heard this message, while he and the kings were drinking in the pavilions, he said to his servants, "Prepare yourselves." They prepared to attack the city.
Then a prophet came to Ahab, king of Israel, saying, "Thus says the LORD: Have you seen this great multitude? Behold, I will deliver it into your hand today, and you shall know that I am the LORD."
Ahab asked, "By whom?" The prophet replied, "Thus says the LORD: By the young men of the princes of the provinces." Ahab then asked, "Who will lead the battle?" The prophet answered, "You."
Ahab counted the young men of the princes of the provinces, and they were two hundred thirty-two; after them, he counted all the people of Israel, totaling seven thousand.
They went out at noon, but Benhadad was drinking heavily in the pavilions with the thirty-two kings who supported him.
The young men of the princes of the provinces went out first; Benhadad sent out messengers, who reported, "Men have come out of Samaria."
He said, "If they have come out for peace, take them alive; if they have come out for war, take them alive."
So the young men of the princes of the provinces came out of the city, followed by the army.
They each struck down their opponent, and the Syrians fled; Israel pursued them, and Benhadad, king of Syria, escaped on a horse with the cavalry.
The king of Israel went out, struck down the horses and chariots, and inflicted a great slaughter on the Syrians.
The prophet came to the king of Israel and said, "Go, strengthen yourself, and consider what you should do, for at the turn of the year, the king of Syria will come against you."

The servants of the king of Syria said to him, "Their gods are gods of the hills; that is why they were stronger than we. But let us fight against them in the plain, and surely we will be stronger than they."
"Do this: remove the kings, every man from his place, and put captains in their stead.

Number an army like the army you lost, horse for horse, and chariot for chariot; we will fight against them in the plain, and surely we will be stronger than they." He listened to their advice and did so.
At the turn of the year, Benhadad numbered the Syrians and went up to Aphek to fight against Israel.
The children of Israel were numbered and all present, and they went against them; the children of Israel camped before them like two little flocks of goats, but the Syrians filled the land.

A man of God came and spoke to the king of Israel, saying, "Thus says the LORD: Because the Syrians have said, 'The LORD is God of the hills, but not God of the valleys,' I will deliver this great multitude into your hand, and you shall know that I am the LORD."
They camped opposite each other for seven days. On the seventh day, the battle was joined, and the children of Israel killed one hundred thousand foot soldiers of the Syrians in one day.
The rest fled to Aphek, into the city; and a wall fell on twenty-seven thousand of the men who remained. Benhadad fled and went into the city, into an inner chamber.

His servants said to him, "Behold, we have heard that the kings of the house of Israel are merciful kings; let us put sackcloth around our waists and ropes on our heads, and go out to the king of Israel; perhaps he will spare your life."

So they put sackcloth around their waists and ropes on their heads, and went to the king of Israel, saying, "Your servant Benhadad says, 'Please let me live.'" Ahab replied, "Is he still alive? He is my brother."

The men observed closely to see if any sign would come from him, and they quickly caught it, saying, "Your brother Benhadad." Ahab said, "Go, bring him." Benhadad came out to him, and Ahab took him up into the chariot.

Benhadad said to him, "The cities my father took from your father, I will restore; and you shall make streets for yourself in Damascus, as my father made in Samaria." Ahab replied, "I will send you away with this covenant." So he made a covenant with him and sent him away.
A certain man of the sons of the prophets said to his neighbor by the word of the LORD, "Strike me, I pray." But the man refused to strike him.
Then he said to him, "Because you have not obeyed the voice of the LORD, as soon as you depart from me, a lion shall kill you." As soon as he left, a lion found him and killed him.
He found another man and said, "Strike me, I pray." The man struck him, wounding him.
The prophet departed, waited for the king by the way, and disguised himself with ashes on his face.

As the king passed by, he cried out to the king: "Your servant went out into the midst of the battle; and behold, a man turned aside and brought a man to me, saying, 'Guard this man; if he is missing, your life shall be for his life, or else you shall pay a talent of silver.'"
While your servant was busy here and there, he was gone. The king of Israel said to him, "Your judgment shall be as you have decided."
He hurried and removed the ashes from his face, and the king of Israel recognized him as one of the prophets.
He said to him, "Thus says the LORD: Because you have let go of a man whom I appointed for destruction, your life shall go for his life, and your people for his people."
The king of Israel went to his house heavy and displeased, and he came to Samaria.
And it came to pass after these events that Naboth the Jezreelite owned a vineyard located in Jezreel, adjacent to the palace of Ahab, king of Samaria.

And Ahab spoke to Naboth, saying, "Give me your vineyard so that I may have it for a garden of herbs, since it is close to my house. I will give you a better vineyard in exchange, or if you prefer, I will pay you its value in money."
But Naboth replied to Ahab, "The LORD forbid that I should give you the inheritance of my ancestors."

Ahab returned to his home sullen and angry because of Naboth's response: he had said, "I will not give you the inheritance of my fathers." He lay down on his bed, turned away his face, and refused to eat.
Then Jezebel, his wife, came to him and asked, "Why is your spirit so sad that you do not eat?"

He answered her, "Because I spoke to Naboth the Jezreelite and said, 'Give me your vineyard for money, or if you prefer, I will give you another vineyard in exchange.' But he replied, 'I will not give you my vineyard.'"
Jezebel, his wife, said to him, "Are you now the king of Israel? Get up, eat, and let your heart be cheerful; I will get you the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite."
So she wrote letters in Ahab's name, sealed them with his seal, and sent the letters to the elders and nobles in his city, where Naboth lived.
In the letters, she instructed, "Proclaim a fast and seat Naboth in a prominent place among the people.
And set two men, sons of Belial, opposite him to testify against him, saying, 'You have blasphemed God and the king.' Then take him out and stone him to death."
The men of the city, including the elders and nobles who lived there, acted as Jezebel had instructed and followed the contents of the letters she sent.
They proclaimed a fast and placed Naboth in a prominent position among the people.

Then two men, children of Belial, came in and sat before him. The men of Belial testified against Naboth in front of the people, saying, "Naboth has blasphemed God and the king." They then took him outside the city and stoned him to death.
Afterward, they sent a message to Jezebel, saying, "Naboth has been stoned and is dead."

When Jezebel heard that Naboth had been stoned and was dead, she said to Ahab, "Get up, take possession of the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite, which he refused to sell you for money, for Naboth is dead."
When Ahab heard that Naboth was dead, he got up to go down to the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite to take possession of it.
Then the word of the LORD came to Elijah the Tishbite, saying,
"Arise, go down to meet Ahab, king of Israel, who is in Samaria; he is in the vineyard of Naboth, where he has gone to take possession.

You shall speak to him, saying, 'Thus says the LORD: Have you murdered and also taken possession?' You shall say to him, 'Thus says the LORD: In the place where dogs licked the blood of Naboth, dogs shall lick your blood, even yours.'"
Ahab said to Elijah, "Have you found me, O my enemy?" He answered, "I have found you because you have sold yourself to do evil in the sight of the LORD.
Behold, I will bring calamity upon you, and will cut off your descendants, and will eliminate from Ahab every male, both bond and free in Israel.

I will make your house like the house of Jeroboam the son of Nebat, and like the house of Baasha the son of Ahijah, because of the provocation with which you have provoked me to anger and caused Israel to sin.
And concerning Jezebel, the LORD said, 'The dogs shall eat Jezebel by the wall of Jezreel.
Anyone belonging to Ahab who dies in the city, the dogs shall eat; and anyone who dies in the field, the birds of the air shall eat.'"
But there was no one like Ahab who sold himself to do wickedness in the sight of the LORD, whom Jezebel, his wife, stirred up.
He acted very abominably in following idols, as the Amorites did, whom the LORD cast out before the children of Israel.
When Ahab heard those words, he tore his clothes, put on sackcloth, fasted, lay in sackcloth, and went about softly.
Then the word of the LORD came to Elijah the Tishbite, saying,

"Do you see how Ahab has humbled himself before me? Because he has humbled himself before me, I will not bring the calamity in his days; but in his son's days, I will bring the calamity upon his house."
They maintained three years of peace without conflict between Syria and Israel.
In the third year, Jehoshaphat, the king of Judah, visited the king of Israel.
The king of Israel addressed his servants, saying, "Do you not know that Ramoth in Gilead belongs to us? Why are we still sitting idle and not taking it from the king of Syria?"
He then asked Jehoshaphat, "Will you join me in battle at Ramothgilead?" Jehoshaphat replied, "I am as you are; my people are your people, and my horses are your horses."
Jehoshaphat urged the king of Israel, "Please inquire today of the word of the LORD."

The king of Israel gathered about four hundred prophets and asked them, "Shall I go to battle against Ramothgilead, or should I refrain?" They answered, "Go up, for the LORD will deliver it into the king's hand."
Jehoshaphat then asked, "Is there not a prophet of the LORD here that we may inquire of?"

The king of Israel replied, "There is one man, Micaiah son of Imlah, through whom we can inquire of the LORD, but I hate him because he never prophesies good about me, only evil." Jehoshaphat responded, "Let not the king say so."
The king of Israel then called an officer and said, "Hasten to bring Micaiah son of Imlah."
The king of Israel and Jehoshaphat sat on their thrones, dressed in their robes, in a designated area at the entrance of the gate of Samaria, while all the prophets prophesied before them.
Zedekiah son of Chenaanah made iron horns and declared, "Thus says the LORD: With these you shall push the Syrians until you have destroyed them."
All the prophets prophesied similarly, saying, "Go up to Ramothgilead and succeed, for the LORD will deliver it into the king's hand."
The messenger who had gone to summon Micaiah said to him, "Look, the words of the prophets are unanimous in declaring good to the king. Please let your word be like theirs and speak favorably."
Micaiah replied, "As the LORD lives, whatever the LORD says to me, that will I speak."

When he came to the king, the king asked him, "Micaiah, shall we go to battle against Ramothgilead, or shall we refrain?" Micaiah answered, "Go and prosper, for the LORD will deliver it into the king's hand."
The king said to him, "How many times must I make you swear to tell me nothing but the truth in the name of the LORD?"
Micaiah replied, "I saw all Israel scattered on the hills like sheep without a shepherd, and the LORD said, 'These have no master; let each return home in peace.'"
The king of Israel turned to Jehoshaphat and said, "Did I not tell you that he would prophesy no good concerning me, but only evil?"
Micaiah continued, "Therefore, hear the word of the LORD: I saw the LORD sitting on His throne, and all the host of heaven standing beside Him, on His right and on His left."
The LORD asked, "Who will persuade Ahab to go up and fall at Ramothgilead?" One spirit suggested one thing, and another spirit suggested another.
Then a spirit came forward and stood before the LORD, saying, "I will persuade him."
The LORD asked, "How?" The spirit replied, "I will go out and be a lying spirit in the mouth of all his prophets." The LORD said, "You will persuade him and succeed; go and do it."
So now, behold, the LORD has put a lying spirit in the mouths of all these prophets, and the LORD has declared disaster against you.
Zedekiah son of Chenaanah approached Micaiah and struck him on the cheek, asking, "Which way did the Spirit of the LORD go from me to speak to you?"
Micaiah replied, "You will see on that day when you go to hide in an inner chamber."
The king of Israel ordered, "Take Micaiah and return him to Amon, the governor of the city, and to Joash, the king's son.
Tell them, 'Thus says the king: Put this man in prison and feed him with the bread of affliction and the water of affliction until I return in peace.'"
Micaiah declared, "If you return at all in peace, the LORD has not spoken through me." He added, "Listen, all you people!"
So the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat went up to Ramothgilead.
The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, "I will disguise myself and enter the battle, but you wear your robes." The king of Israel disguised himself and went into battle.
The king of Syria commanded his thirty-two captains of chariots, saying, "Do not fight with anyone small or great, except the king of Israel."
When the captains of the chariots saw Jehoshaphat, they said, "Surely this is the king of Israel." They turned to fight against him, and Jehoshaphat cried out.
When the captains of the chariots realized he was not the king of Israel, they turned back from pursuing him.
A certain man drew his bow at random and struck the king of Israel between the joints of his armor. He said to the charioteer, "Turn around and take me out of the battle, for I am wounded."
The battle raged that day, and the king was propped up in his chariot facing the Syrians. He died in the evening, and blood flowed from the wound into the chariot.
A proclamation was made throughout the army at sunset, saying, "Every man to his city, and every man to his own country."
So the king died and was brought to Samaria, where he was buried.
Someone washed the chariot at the pool of Samaria, and the dogs licked up his blood, as was prophesied by the word of the LORD.
Now the rest of the acts of Ahab, all that he did, the ivory house he built, and all the cities he constructed, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
Ahab rested with his ancestors, and his son Ahaziah succeeded him as king.
Jehoshaphat son of Asa began to reign over Judah in the fourth year of Ahab king of Israel.
Jehoshaphat was thirty-five years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for twenty-five years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Azubah, daughter of Shilhi.

He walked in all the ways of his father Asa and did not turn aside from it, doing what was right in the eyes of the LORD; however, the high places were not removed, and the people continued to offer sacrifices and burn incense on the high places.
Jehoshaphat made peace with the king of Israel.
Now the rest of the acts of Jehoshaphat, his might, and how he waged war, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah?
He removed the remnant of the male cult prostitutes that remained in the days of his father Asa.
At that time, there was no king in Edom; a deputy served as king.
Jehoshaphat built ships of Tarshish to go to Ophir for gold, but they did not go, for the ships were wrecked at Eziongeber.
Ahaziah son of Ahab said to Jehoshaphat, "Let my servants go with your servants in the ships." But Jehoshaphat refused.
Jehoshaphat rested with his ancestors and was buried with them in the city of David his father. His son Jehoram succeeded him as king.
Ahaziah son of Ahab began to reign over Israel in Samaria in the seventeenth year of Jehoshaphat king of Judah, and he reigned for two years over Israel.
He did evil in the sight of the LORD, following the ways of his father, his mother, and Jeroboam son of Nebat, who caused Israel to sin.
He served Baal, worshipped him, and provoked the LORD God of Israel to anger, just as his father had done.
Moab rebelled against Israel following the death of Ahab.
Ahaziah fell through a lattice in his upper chamber in Samaria and became ill; he sent messengers to inquire of Baalzebub, the god of Ekron, whether he would recover from his illness.

However, the angel of the LORD instructed Elijah the Tishbite, "Arise, go meet the messengers of the king of Samaria, and tell them, 'Is it not because there is no God in Israel that you are going to inquire of Baalzebub, the god of Ekron?'"
Therefore, the LORD declares, "You shall not come down from the bed on which you have gone up; you shall surely die." And Elijah departed.
When the messengers returned to him, he asked, "Why have you returned?"

They replied, "A man came to meet us and said, 'Go back to the king who sent you and tell him, Thus says the LORD: Is it not because there is no God in Israel that you are sending to inquire of Baalzebub, the god of Ekron? Therefore, you shall not come down from the bed on which you have gone up; you shall surely die.'"
He then asked them, "What kind of man was he who came to meet you and told you these things?"
They answered, "He was a hairy man, with a leather belt around his waist." He said, "It is Elijah the Tishbite."
Then the king sent a captain with fifty men to Elijah. When they found him sitting on top of a hill, the captain said to him, "Man of God, the king has said, 'Come down!'"
Elijah responded to the captain, "If I am a man of God, let fire come down from heaven and consume you and your fifty men." Fire came down from heaven and consumed him and his fifty.
The king sent another captain with fifty men, and he said to Elijah, "O man of God, the king has said, 'Come down quickly!'"
Elijah replied, "If I am a man of God, let fire come down from heaven and consume you and your fifty." The fire of God came down from heaven and consumed him and his fifty.
A third captain approached, fell on his knees before Elijah, and pleaded, "O man of God, I pray you, let my life and the lives of these fifty servants be precious in your sight."
"Look, fire came down from heaven and burned up the two captains of the former fifties with their men; please let my life be precious in your sight."
The angel of the LORD said to Elijah, "Go down with him; do not be afraid of him." So he arose and went down with him to the king.

He said to the king, "Thus says the LORD: Since you have sent messengers to inquire of Baalzebub, the god of Ekron, is it not because there is no God in Israel to inquire of His word? Therefore, you shall not come down from the bed on which you have gone up; you shall surely die."
So he died according to the word of the LORD that Elijah had spoken. Jehoram reigned in his place in the second year of Jehoram, the son of Jehoshaphat, king of Judah, because he had no son.
Now, are not the rest of the acts of Ahaziah that he did written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
And it came to pass, when the LORD was about to take Elijah up to heaven in a whirlwind, that Elijah went with Elisha from Gilgal.

And Elijah said to Elisha, "Stay here, I pray you; for the LORD has sent me to Bethel." But Elisha replied, "As the LORD lives, and as your soul lives, I will not leave you." So they went down to Bethel.
The sons of the prophets at Bethel came out to Elisha and said to him, "Do you know that the LORD will take away your master from you today?" He answered, "Yes, I know it; be quiet."

Elijah then said to him, "Elisha, stay here, I pray you; for the LORD has sent me to Jericho." Elisha replied, "As the LORD lives, and as your soul lives, I will not leave you." So they came to Jericho.
The sons of the prophets at Jericho approached Elisha and said, "Do you know that the LORD will take away your master from you today?" He answered, "Yes, I know it; be quiet."
Elijah said to him, "Stay here, I pray you; for the LORD has sent me to the Jordan." Elisha replied, "As the LORD lives, and as your soul lives, I will not leave you." And the two of them went on.
Fifty men from the sons of the prophets stood at a distance, watching them as they stood by the Jordan.
Elijah took his mantle, wrapped it together, and struck the waters, which parted to the right and to the left, so that the two of them crossed over on dry ground.
When they had crossed over, Elijah said to Elisha, "Ask what I shall do for you before I am taken away from you." Elisha replied, "I pray you, let a double portion of your spirit be upon me."
Elijah said, "You have asked a difficult thing; nevertheless, if you see me when I am taken from you, it shall be so for you; but if not, it shall not be so."
As they continued walking and talking, suddenly a chariot of fire and horses of fire appeared and separated the two of them; and Elijah went up by a whirlwind into heaven.
Elisha saw it and cried out, "My father, my father, the chariot of Israel and its horsemen!" And he saw him no more. He took hold of his own clothes and tore them in two pieces.
He picked up the mantle of Elijah that had fallen from him and went back, standing by the bank of the Jordan.

He took the mantle of Elijah that had fallen from him, struck the waters, and said, "Where is the LORD God of Elijah?" When he struck the waters, they parted to the right and to the left, and Elisha crossed over.
When the sons of the prophets who were at Jericho saw him, they said, "The spirit of Elijah rests on Elisha." They came to meet him and bowed to the ground before him.

They said to him, "Look, there are with your servants fifty strong men; let them go, we pray you, and search for your master, lest perhaps the Spirit of the LORD has taken him up and cast him upon some mountain or into some valley." But he said, "You shall not send anyone."
When they urged him until he was ashamed, he said, "Send." So they sent fifty men, and they searched for three days but did not find him.
When they returned to him (for he had stayed at Jericho), he said to them, "Did I not tell you, 'Do not go'?"
The men of the city said to Elisha, "Please notice, the situation of this city is pleasant, as my lord sees; but the water is bad, and the ground is barren."
He said, "Bring me a new bowl and put salt in it." So they brought it to him.
He went to the spring of the waters, threw the salt in there, and said, "Thus says the LORD: I have healed these waters; there shall be no more death or barrenness from them."
So the waters were healed to this day, according to the word of Elisha that he spoke.
He went up from there to Bethel; and as he was going up the road, some little children came out of the city and mocked him, saying, "Get out of here, you bald head! Get out of here, you bald head!"
He turned around, looked at them, and cursed them in the name of the LORD. Then two bears came out of the woods and mauled forty-two of the children.
From there he went to Mount Carmel, and from there he returned to Samaria.
Now Jehoram, the son of Ahab, began to reign over Israel in Samaria during the eighteenth year of Jehoshaphat, king of Judah, and he reigned for twelve years.
He committed evil in the sight of the LORD, but not as his father and mother did; he removed the image of Baal that his father had made.
Nevertheless, he adhered to the sins of Jeroboam, the son of Nebat, which caused Israel to sin; he did not turn away from them.
Mesha, the king of Moab, was a sheepmaster and rendered to the king of Israel one hundred thousand lambs and one hundred thousand rams, along with their wool.
However, when Ahab died, the king of Moab rebelled against the king of Israel.
King Jehoram set out from Samaria at that time and took a census of all Israel.

He sent a message to Jehoshaphat, the king of Judah, saying, "The king of Moab has rebelled against me. Will you go with me to battle against Moab?" Jehoshaphat replied, "I will go; I am as you are, my people as your people, and my horses as your horses."
Jehoram then asked, "Which way shall we go up?" Jehoshaphat answered, "The way through the wilderness of Edom."
So the king of Israel, the king of Judah, and the king of Edom went on a circuitous route for seven days, but there was no water for the army or the cattle that followed them.
The king of Israel exclaimed, "Alas! The LORD has brought these three kings together to deliver them into the hand of Moab!"

But Jehoshaphat asked, "Is there not a prophet of the LORD here that we may inquire of the LORD through him?" One of the servants of the king of Israel answered, "Here is Elisha, the son of Shaphat, who poured water on the hands of Elijah."
Jehoshaphat said, "The word of the LORD is with him." So the king of Israel, Jehoshaphat, and the king of Edom went down to see him.

Elisha said to the king of Israel, "What do I have to do with you? Go to the prophets of your father and the prophets of your mother." The king of Israel replied, "No, for the LORD has called these three kings together to deliver them into the hand of Moab."
Elisha said, "As the LORD of hosts lives, before whom I stand, surely, if it were not for the presence of Jehoshaphat, king of Judah, I would not look at you or see you."
"Now bring me a minstrel." And when the minstrel played, the hand of the LORD came upon him.
He said, "Thus says the LORD: Make this valley full of ditches."
"For thus says the LORD: You shall not see wind, nor shall you see rain; yet that valley shall be filled with water, so that you may drink, both you and your cattle, and your beasts."
"This is but a light thing in the sight of the LORD; He will also deliver the Moabites into your hand."
"And you shall strike every fortified city and every choice city, and you shall cut down every good tree, and stop up all the wells of water, and ruin every good piece of land with stones."
It came to pass in the morning, when the grain offering was offered, that water came by the way of Edom, and the country was filled with water.
When all the Moabites heard that the kings had come up to fight against them, they gathered all who were able to put on armor and stood at the border.
They rose early in the morning, and the sun shone upon the water, and the Moabites saw the water on the other side as red as blood.
They said, "This is blood; the kings are surely slain, and they have struck each other down. Now, Moab, to the spoil!"
When they came to the camp of Israel, the Israelites rose up and struck the Moabites, causing them to flee before them; they continued to strike the Moabites even in their own territory.

They destroyed the cities, and on every good piece of land, each man cast his stone and filled it; they stopped all the wells of water and cut down all the good trees. Only in Kirharaseth did they leave the stones; however, the slingers went around and struck it.
When the king of Moab saw that the battle was too fierce for him, he took with him seven hundred men who drew swords to break through to the king of Edom, but they could not.

Then he took his eldest son, who was to reign in his place, and offered him as a burnt offering on the wall. There was great indignation against Israel, and they departed from him and returned to their own land.

A certain woman from the wives of the sons of the prophets cried out to Elisha, saying, "Your servant, my husband, is dead; and you know that your servant feared the LORD. Now the creditor has come to take my two sons as bondmen."
Elisha asked her, "What can I do for you? Tell me, what do you have in your house?" She replied, "Your maidservant has nothing in the house except a pot of oil."
He instructed her, "Go, borrow vessels from all your neighbors, empty vessels; do not borrow a few."
"When you come in, shut the door behind you and your sons, and pour the oil into all those vessels, setting aside the full ones."
So she went from him, shut the door behind her and her sons, who brought the vessels to her, and she poured out the oil.
When the vessels were full, she said to her son, "Bring me another vessel." He replied, "There is not another vessel." And the oil stopped flowing.
She went and told the man of God, and he said, "Go, sell the oil, pay your debt, and you and your children can live on the rest."
One day, Elisha passed through Shunem, where a prominent woman lived. She urged him to eat bread, and whenever he passed by, he would stop there to eat.
She said to her husband, "I perceive that this is a holy man of God who continually passes by us."
"Let us make a small room on the roof and put a bed, a table, a chair, and a lamp there for him. When he comes to us, he can stay there."
One day, he came to the room and lay down there.
He said to Gehazi, his servant, "Call this Shunammite." When he called her, she stood before him.

He asked Gehazi, "Tell her, you have taken such good care of us; what can we do for you? Would you like me to speak to the king or the commander of the army?" She answered, "I dwell among my own people."
"What then can be done for her?" Gehazi replied, "She has no son, and her husband is old."
He said, "Call her." When she came in, she stood at the door.
He said, "About this time next year, you will embrace a son." She said, "No, my lord, man of God, do not lie to your maidservant."
But the woman conceived and bore a son at the appointed time, as Elisha had said.
When the child grew, one day he went out to his father, who was with the reapers.
He said to his father, "My head, my head!" The father told a servant, "Carry him to his mother."
When he had taken him and brought him to his mother, he sat on her knees until noon, and then he died.
She went up, laid him on the bed of the man of God, shut the door, and went out.
She called to her husband, "Send me one of the young men and one of the donkeys, so I can run to the man of God and come back."
He asked, "Why will you go to him today? It is neither the new moon nor the Sabbath." She said, "It will be well."
Then she saddled a donkey and said to her servant, "Drive and go forward; do not slow down for me unless I tell you."
So she went and came to the man of God at Mount Carmel. When the man of God saw her from a distance, he said to Gehazi, "Look, there is the Shunammite."
"Run to meet her and ask her, 'Is it well with you? Is it well with your husband? Is it well with the child?'" She answered, "It is well."

When she reached the man of God on the hill, she caught him by the feet, but Gehazi came near to push her away. The man of God said, "Leave her alone, for her soul is troubled within her, and the LORD has hidden it from me and has not told me."
She said, "Did I ask for a son, my lord? Did I not say, 'Do not deceive me'?"

He said to Gehazi, "Gird up your loins, take my staff in your hand, and go your way. If you meet anyone, do not greet him; and if anyone greets you, do not answer him. Lay my staff on the face of the child."
The mother of the child said, "As the LORD lives and as your soul lives, I will not leave you." So he arose and followed her.
Gehazi went on ahead and laid the staff on the child's face, but there was neither voice nor hearing. He returned to meet Elisha and said, "The child has not awakened."
When Elisha came into the house, he saw the child dead on his bed.
He went in, shut the door behind them both, and prayed to the LORD.
He went up, lay on the child, putting his mouth on his mouth, his eyes on his eyes, and his hands on his hands. As he stretched himself upon him, the flesh of the child became warm.
He returned and walked in the house back and forth, then went up and stretched himself upon him again. The child sneezed seven times and opened his eyes.
He called Gehazi and said, "Call this Shunammite." So he called her, and when she came in, he said, "Take up your son."
She went in, fell at his feet, bowed to the ground, and took up her son and went out.

Elisha returned to Gilgal, and there was a famine in the land. The sons of the prophets were sitting before him, and he said to his servant, "Put on the large pot and cook stew for the sons of the prophets."
One went out into the field to gather herbs and found a wild vine. He gathered wild gourds and filled his lap, then came and sliced them into the pot of stew, for they did not know what they were.
They poured out the stew for the men to eat, but as they were eating, they cried out, "O man of God, there is death in the pot!" They could not eat it.
But he said, "Bring flour." He threw it into the pot and said, "Pour out for the people that they may eat." There was no harm in the pot.
A man came from Baalshalisha, bringing the man of God bread from the firstfruits, twenty loaves of barley, and fresh grain in the husk. He said, "Give it to the people so they may eat."
His servant said, "What, should I set this before a hundred men?" He said again, "Give it to the people so they may eat, for thus says the LORD: They shall eat and have some left over."
So he set it before them, and they ate and had some left over, according to the word of the LORD.

Now Naaman, the captain of the king of Syria's army, was a distinguished man in the eyes of his master and held in high regard, for through him the LORD had granted victory to Syria; he was also a valiant warrior, but he suffered from leprosy.
The Syrians had raided the land of Israel and taken captive a young girl, who became a servant to Naaman's wife.
She said to her mistress, "If only my lord were with the prophet in Samaria! He would heal him of his leprosy."
One of Naaman's attendants went in and informed him, saying, "This is what the girl from Israel said."
The king of Syria replied, "Go now, and I will send a letter to the king of Israel." So he set out, taking with him ten talents of silver, six thousand pieces of gold, and ten sets of clothing.
He delivered the letter to the king of Israel, stating, "When this letter reaches you, know that I have sent my servant Naaman to you so that you may heal him of his leprosy."

When the king of Israel read the letter, he tore his clothes and exclaimed, "Am I God, able to kill and bring back to life? Why does this man send someone to me to be healed of leprosy? Consider, please, and see how he is trying to pick a fight with me."

When Elisha, the man of God, heard that the king of Israel had torn his clothes, he sent a message to the king, saying, "Why have you torn your clothes? Let him come to me, and he will know that there is a prophet in Israel."
So Naaman arrived with his horses and chariot and stopped at the entrance to Elisha's house.
Elisha sent a messenger to say to him, "Go, wash yourself in the Jordan seven times, and your flesh will be restored, and you will be cleansed."
Naaman became angry and went away, saying, "I thought he would surely come out to me, stand and call on the name of the LORD his God, wave his hand over the spot, and cure me of my leprosy.
Are not the rivers Abana and Pharpar in Damascus better than all the waters of Israel? Couldn't I wash in them and be cleansed?" So he turned and went off in a rage.
His servants approached him and said, "My father, if the prophet had told you to do something great, would you not have done it? How much more, then, when he tells you, 'Wash and be cleansed'?"
So he went down and dipped himself in the Jordan seven times, as the man of God had instructed. His flesh was restored and became like that of a young boy, and he was clean.
He returned to the man of God with all his attendants and stood before him. He said, "Now I know that there is no God in all the earth except in Israel. Please accept a gift from your servant."
But Elisha said, "As surely as the LORD lives, whom I serve, I will not accept a thing." And even though Naaman urged him, he refused.

Naaman then said, "If you will not, please let me, your servant, be given as much earth as a pair of mules can carry, for your servant will never again make burnt offerings and sacrifices to any other god but the LORD.

But may the LORD forgive your servant for this one thing: When my master enters the temple of Rimmon to bow down, and he leans on my arm, and I bow there as well—when I bow down in the temple of Rimmon, may the LORD pardon your servant for this."
Elisha said, "Go in peace." So Naaman left him and went a short distance.

But Gehazi, the servant of Elisha, the man of God, said to himself, "My master was too easy on Naaman, this Aramean, by not accepting from him what he brought. As surely as the LORD lives, I will run after him and get something from him."
So Gehazi hurried after Naaman. When Naaman saw him running after him, he got down from the chariot to meet him and asked, "Is everything all right?"

Gehazi answered, "Everything is all right. My master sent me to say, 'Two young men from the company of the prophets have just come to me from the hill country of Ephraim. Please give them a talent of silver and two sets of clothing.'"

"By all means, take two talents," said Naaman. He urged Gehazi to accept them, and then tied up the two talents of silver in two bags, with two sets of clothing. He gave them to two of his servants, and they carried them ahead of Gehazi.
When Gehazi came to the hill, he took the things from the servants and put them away in the house. He sent the men away, and they left.
When he went in and stood before his master, Elisha asked him, "Where have you been, Gehazi?" "Your servant didn't go anywhere," Gehazi answered.

Elisha said to him, "Was not my spirit with you when the man got down from his chariot to meet you? Is this the time to take money or to accept clothes, olive groves, vineyards, sheep, or cattle, or male and female servants?
Naaman's leprosy will cling to you and to your descendants forever." Gehazi went out from Elisha's presence and his skin was leprous—it had become as white as snow.
And the sons of the prophets said to Elisha, "Behold, the place where we dwell with you is too small for us.
Let us go, we pray, to the Jordan, and let each of us take a beam from there, and let us make a place for ourselves where we may dwell." And he answered, "Go."
One of them said, "Please be willing to go with your servants." And he replied, "I will go."
So he went with them, and when they arrived at the Jordan, they began to cut down trees.
But as one was felling a beam, the axe head fell into the water, and he cried out, "Alas, master! It was borrowed!"
The man of God asked, "Where did it fall?" He showed him the place, and Elisha cut a stick and threw it in there, and the iron floated.
Elisha then said, "Take it up for yourself." So he reached out his hand and took it.
Then the king of Syria waged war against Israel and consulted with his servants, saying, "In such and such a place shall be my camp."
The man of God sent a message to the king of Israel, saying, "Beware that you do not pass that place, for the Syrians are coming down there."
The king of Israel sent to the place that the man of God had warned him about, and he saved himself there, not just once or twice.
Therefore, the heart of the king of Syria was greatly troubled by this, and he called his servants and asked them, "Will you not tell me which of us is for the king of Israel?"
One of his servants replied, "None, my lord, O king; but Elisha, the prophet who is in Israel, tells the king of Israel the words that you speak in your bedroom."
He said, "Go and spy where he is, that I may send and capture him." It was reported to him, "Behold, he is in Dothan."
So he sent horses, chariots, and a great army there, and they came by night and surrounded the city.
When the servant of the man of God rose early and went out, behold, an army surrounded the city with horses and chariots. His servant said to him, "Alas, my master! What shall we do?"
He answered, "Do not fear, for those who are with us are more than those who are with them."

Elisha prayed and said, "LORD, I pray, open his eyes that he may see." The LORD opened the eyes of the young man, and he saw that the mountain was full of horses and chariots of fire all around Elisha.
When they came down to him, Elisha prayed to the LORD and said, "Strike this people with blindness, I pray." And He struck them with blindness according to the word of Elisha.
Elisha said to them, "This is not the way, nor is this the city; follow me, and I will bring you to the man you seek." But he led them to Samaria.
When they entered Samaria, Elisha said, "LORD, open the eyes of these men that they may see." The LORD opened their eyes, and they saw that they were in the midst of Samaria.
The king of Israel said to Elisha when he saw them, "My father, shall I kill them? Shall I kill them?"
He answered, "You shall not kill them. Would you kill those you have taken captive with your sword and bow? Set bread and water before them so they may eat and drink and go to their master."
He prepared a great feast for them, and when they had eaten and drunk, he sent them away, and they went to their master. So the bands of Syria did not come again into the land of Israel.
After this, Benhadad, king of Syria, gathered all his forces and went up and besieged Samaria.
There was a great famine in Samaria, and indeed, they besieged it until a donkey's head was sold for eighty pieces of silver, and a quarter of a cab of dove's dung for five pieces of silver.
As the king of Israel was passing by on the wall, a woman cried out to him, "Help, my lord, O king!"
He replied, "If the LORD does not help you, where can I find help for you? From the threshing floor or from the winepress?"
The king asked her, "What is the matter?" She answered, "This woman said to me, 'Give your son so we may eat him today, and we will eat my son tomorrow.'"
So we boiled my son and ate him, and I said to her the next day, 'Give your son so we may eat him,' but she has hidden her son."
When the king heard the words of the woman, he tore his clothes, and as he walked along the wall, the people looked, and behold, he had sackcloth underneath on his body.
Then he said, "May God do so to me and more also if the head of Elisha, son of Shaphat, remains on him today."

But Elisha was sitting in his house, and the elders were sitting with him. The king sent a man ahead of him, but before the messenger arrived, Elisha said to the elders, "Do you see how this murderer has sent someone to take away my head? Look, when the messenger comes, shut the door and hold him fast at the door. Is not the sound of his master's feet behind him?"
While he was still talking with them, behold, the messenger came down to him, and he said, "Behold, this evil is from the LORD; what should I wait for the LORD any longer?"

Then Elisha said, "Hear the word of the LORD: Thus says the LORD, tomorrow at this time a measure of fine flour will be sold for a shekel, and two measures of barley for a shekel, at the gate of Samaria."

Then a lord, on whose hand the king leaned, answered the man of God, saying, "Behold, if the LORD were to make windows in heaven, could this thing happen?" Elisha replied, "Behold, you shall see it with your own eyes, but you shall not eat of it."
There were four leprous men at the entrance of the gate, and they said to one another, "Why are we sitting here until we die?"

If we say, "We will enter the city," the famine is in the city, and we will die there; and if we sit here, we will also die. Therefore, let us go over to the camp of the Syrians: if they spare our lives, we shall live; and if they kill us, we shall but die.
They rose up at twilight to go to the camp of the Syrians, and when they reached the outskirts of the camp, behold, there was no one there.

For the LORD had caused the host of the Syrians to hear the sound of chariots and the sound of horses, even the sound of a great army. They said to one another, "Look, the king of Israel has hired the kings of the Hittites and the kings of the Egyptians to attack us."
So they arose and fled in the twilight, leaving their tents, their horses, and their donkeys, and fled for their lives.

When these lepers reached the outskirts of the camp, they entered one tent, ate and drank, and carried away silver, gold, and clothing, and went and hid it. Then they returned, entered another tent, and carried away more, and hid it as well.

Then they said to one another, "We are not doing right: this day is a day of good news, and we are keeping silent. If we wait until morning light, punishment will overtake us. Now therefore, come, let us go and tell the king's household."

So they came and called to the gatekeeper of the city, and they told him, saying, "We went to the camp of the Syrians, and behold, there was no one there, nor any voice of man; only horses tied and donkeys tied, and the tents as they were."
He called the porters, and they reported it to the king's household.

The king arose in the night and said to his servants, "I will now show you what the Syrians have done to us. They know we are hungry; therefore, they have gone out of the camp to hide themselves in the field, saying, 'When they come out of the city, we shall capture them alive and get into the city.'"

One of his servants answered and said, "Let some take, I pray you, five of the horses that remain, which are left in the city (behold, they are like all the multitude of Israel that are left in it: behold, I say, they are like all the multitude of the Israelites that are perishing), and let us send and see."
So they took two chariot horses, and the king sent after the host of the Syrians, saying, "Go and see."
They went after them to the Jordan, and lo, all the way was full of garments and vessels that the Syrians had thrown away in their haste. The messengers returned and told the king.
The people went out and plundered the tents of the Syrians. So a measure of fine flour was sold for a shekel, and two measures of barley for a shekel, just as the word of the LORD had said.

The king appointed the lord on whose hand he leaned to have charge of the gate, and the people trampled him in the gate, and he died, as the man of God had said, who spoke when the king came down to him.

And it came to pass, as the man of God had spoken to the king, saying, "Two measures of barley for a shekel, and a measure of fine flour for a shekel, shall be tomorrow at this time at the gate of Samaria."

That lord answered the man of God, saying, "Now, behold, if the LORD should make windows in heaven, could such a thing happen?" Elisha replied, "Behold, you shall see it with your own eyes, but you shall not eat of it."
And so it happened to him: for the people trampled him in the gate, and he died.

Then Elisha spoke to the woman whose son he had brought back to life, saying, "Arise, go with your household, and stay wherever you can, for the LORD has called for a famine, and it will come upon the land for seven years."
The woman arose and did as the man of God instructed; she went with her household and stayed in the land of the Philistines for seven years.
At the end of the seven years, the woman returned from the land of the Philistines and went to cry out to the king for her house and her land.
The king was speaking with Gehazi, the servant of the man of God, asking, "Tell me, please, all the great things that Elisha has done."

As Gehazi was recounting to the king how Elisha had restored a dead body to life, the woman whose son had been restored cried out to the king for her house and her land. Gehazi said, "My lord, O king, this is the woman, and this is her son whom Elisha restored to life."

When the king asked the woman, she told him her story. The king then appointed a certain officer, saying, "Restore all that was hers, and all the produce of the field since the day she left the land, even until now."
Elisha came to Damascus, and Benhadad, the king of Syria, was sick. It was reported to him, "The man of God has come here."
The king said to Hazael, "Take a gift in your hand, go meet the man of God, and inquire of the LORD through him, saying, 'Shall I recover from this disease?'"

So Hazael went to meet him, taking a gift of every good thing from Damascus, a burden of forty camels, and he stood before Elisha, saying, "Your son Benhadad, king of Syria, has sent me to you, asking, 'Shall I recover from this disease?'"
Elisha said to him, "Go, tell him, 'You may certainly recover,' but the LORD has shown me that he will surely die."
Hazael fixed his gaze steadily until he felt ashamed, and the man of God wept.

Hazael asked, "Why does my lord weep?" Elisha replied, "Because I know the evil you will do to the children of Israel: you will set their strongholds on fire, kill their young men with the sword, dash their children, and rip open their pregnant women."
Hazael said, "But what, is your servant a dog, that he should do this great thing?" Elisha answered, "The LORD has shown me that you will be king over Syria."
Hazael left Elisha and went to his master, who asked him, "What did Elisha say to you?" He replied, "He told me that you would surely recover."
The next day, he took a thick cloth, dipped it in water, and spread it over the king's face, so that he died; and Hazael reigned in his place.
In the fifth year of Joram, the son of Ahab, king of Israel, Jehoshaphat was king of Judah, and Jehoram, the son of Jehoshaphat, king of Judah, began to reign.
He was thirty-two years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for eight years in Jerusalem.
He walked in the ways of the kings of Israel, as did the house of Ahab, for the daughter of Ahab was his wife; he did evil in the sight of the LORD.
Yet the LORD would not destroy Judah for the sake of David, His servant, as He promised to give him a lamp and his children forever.
During his reign, Edom revolted from under the hand of Judah and appointed a king for themselves.
So Joram went to Zair with all his chariots; he rose by night and struck down the Edomites who had surrounded him, along with the captains of the chariots, and the people fled into their tents.
Yet Edom has revolted from under the hand of Judah to this day. At the same time, Libnah revolted.
The rest of the acts of Joram and all that he did, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah?
Joram rested with his ancestors and was buried with them in the city of David; his son Ahaziah reigned in his place.
In the twelfth year of Joram, the son of Ahab, king of Israel, Ahaziah, the son of Jehoram, king of Judah, began to reign.
Ahaziah was twenty-two years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for one year in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Athaliah, the daughter of Omri, king of Israel.
He walked in the ways of the house of Ahab and did evil in the sight of the LORD, as did the house of Ahab, for he was a son-in-law of the house of Ahab.
He joined Joram, the son of Ahab, in battle against Hazael, king of Syria, at Ramoth-gilead, and the Syrians wounded Joram.

King Joram returned to Jezreel to be healed of the wounds the Syrians had inflicted on him at Ramah, while he fought against Hazael, king of Syria. Ahaziah, the son of Jehoram, king of Judah, went down to see Joram, the son of Ahab, in Jezreel because he was sick.
And Elisha the prophet summoned one of the sons of the prophets, instructing him, "Prepare yourself, take this flask of oil in your hand, and go to Ramothgilead.
When you arrive there, look for Jehu, the son of Jehoshaphat, the son of Nimshi. Go in, and bring him away from his companions to an inner chamber.
Then take the flask of oil, pour it on his head, and declare, 'Thus says the LORD: I have anointed you king over Israel.' After that, open the door and flee; do not linger."
So the young prophet went to Ramothgilead.
Upon his arrival, he found the captains of the army sitting there. He said, "I have a message for you, O captain." Jehu replied, "For which of us?" He answered, "For you, O captain."
Jehu rose and entered the house. The young prophet poured the oil on his head and said to him, "Thus says the LORD God of Israel: I have anointed you king over the people of the LORD, over Israel.
You shall strike down the house of Ahab your master, so that I may avenge the blood of my servants the prophets and the blood of all the servants of the LORD at the hand of Jezebel.
For the entire house of Ahab shall perish; I will cut off from Ahab every male, both bond and free, in Israel.
I will make the house of Ahab like the house of Jeroboam, the son of Nebat, and like the house of Baasha, the son of Ahijah.
And the dogs shall eat Jezebel in the territory of Jezreel, and no one shall bury her." He then opened the door and fled.
Jehu came out to the servants of his lord, and one asked him, "Is all well? Why did this madman come to you?" He replied, "You know the man and his talk."
They said, "It is false; tell us now." He said, "This is what he said to me: 'Thus says the LORD: I have anointed you king over Israel.'"
Then they hurried, each man taking off his garment and laying it under him on the top of the stairs, and they blew the trumpets, proclaiming, "Jehu is king!"
So Jehu, the son of Jehoshaphat, the son of Nimshi, conspired against Joram. (Now Joram had been defending Ramothgilead, he and all Israel, against Hazael, king of Syria.

But King Joram had returned to be healed in Jezreel of the wounds inflicted by the Syrians when he fought against Hazael, king of Syria.) Jehu said, "If you are in agreement, let no one escape the city to go and tell it in Jezreel."
Jehu then rode in a chariot and went to Jezreel, for Joram was there. Ahaziah, king of Judah, had come down to visit Joram.
A watchman was standing on the tower in Jezreel, and he saw the company of Jehu approaching. He reported, "I see a company." Joram said, "Send a horseman to meet them and ask, 'Is it peace?'"

So a horseman rode out to meet him and said, "Thus says the king: Is it peace?" Jehu replied, "What do you have to do with peace? Turn around and follow me." The watchman reported, "The messenger has reached them, but he is not returning."
Then he sent out a second horseman, who came to them and said, "Thus says the king: Is it peace?" Jehu answered, "What do you have to do with peace? Turn around and follow me."
The watchman reported, "He went to them and is not returning; the driving is like the driving of Jehu, the son of Nimshi, for he drives furiously."
Joram said, "Make ready." His chariot was prepared, and Joram, king of Israel, and Ahaziah, king of Judah, went out, each in his chariot, to confront Jehu in the field of Naboth the Jezreelite.
When Joram saw Jehu, he asked, "Is it peace, Jehu?" Jehu replied, "What peace can there be as long as the harlotries of your mother Jezebel and her witchcrafts are so numerous?"
Joram turned his back and fled, saying to Ahaziah, "There is treachery, O Ahaziah!"
Jehu drew his bow with full strength and shot Joram between the shoulders; the arrow pierced his heart, and he sank down in his chariot.

Jehu then said to Bidkar, his captain, "Pick him up and throw him into the plot of ground belonging to Naboth the Jezreelite, for remember how, when I and you rode together after Ahab his father, the LORD pronounced this judgment upon him:

'Surely I have seen yesterday the blood of Naboth and the blood of his sons,' says the LORD, 'and I will repay you in this plot,' says the LORD. Now therefore, take him and cast him into the plot of ground, according to the word of the LORD."

When Ahaziah, king of Judah, saw this, he fled by the way of the garden house. Jehu pursued him and said, "Strike him down in the chariot." They did so at the ascent of Gur, which is near Ibleam. He fled to Megiddo and died there.
His servants carried him in a chariot to Jerusalem and buried him in his tomb with his ancestors in the city of David.
In the eleventh year of Joram, the son of Ahab, Ahaziah began to reign over Judah.
When Jehu arrived in Jezreel, Jezebel heard of it; she painted her eyes, adorned her head, and looked out through a window.
As Jehu entered the gate, she said, "Is it peace, Zimri, murderer of your master?"
He lifted his face to the window and asked, "Who is on my side? Who?" Two or three eunuchs looked out at him.
He commanded, "Throw her down." So they threw her down, and some of her blood splattered on the wall and on the horses, and they trampled her underfoot.
When he went in, he ate and drank, and said, "Go, see this cursed woman and bury her, for she is a king's daughter."
They went to bury her, but found no more of her than the skull, the feet, and the palms of her hands.
When they returned and told him, he said, "This is the word of the LORD that he spoke by his servant Elijah the Tishbite, saying, 'In the territory of Jezreel, dogs shall eat the flesh of Jezebel.
And the carcass of Jezebel shall be like refuse on the ground in the territory of Jezreel, so that they shall not say, 'This is Jezebel.'"
And Ahab had seventy sons residing in Samaria. Jehu wrote letters and sent them to the rulers of Jezreel, the elders, and those who raised Ahab's children, saying,
"As soon as this letter reaches you, know that your master's sons are with you, along with chariots, horses, a fortified city, and armor.
Choose the best and most suitable of your master's sons, set him on his father's throne, and defend your master's house."
However, they were extremely afraid and said, "Behold, two kings could not stand before him; how then can we?"

The one in charge of the house, the one in charge of the city, the elders, and the caretakers of the children sent a message to Jehu, saying, "We are your servants and will do all that you command; we will not appoint a king. Do what is good in your eyes."

Then he wrote a second letter to them, saying, "If you are mine and will listen to my voice, take the heads of your master's sons and bring them to me in Jezreel by tomorrow at this time." The king's sons, numbering seventy, were with the prominent men of the city who raised them.
When the letter arrived, they took the king's sons, killed seventy of them, placed their heads in baskets, and sent them to Jehu in Jezreel.
A messenger came and informed him, saying, "They have brought the heads of the king's sons." He replied, "Lay them in two heaps at the entrance of the gate until morning."
In the morning, he went out, stood, and said to all the people, "You are righteous; behold, I conspired against my master and killed him. But who killed all these?"
"Know that nothing of the word of the LORD concerning the house of Ahab will fall to the ground, for the LORD has done what He spoke through His servant Elijah."
So Jehu killed all that remained of Ahab's house in Jezreel, along with all his great men, relatives, and priests, leaving none remaining.
He then arose and departed, coming to Samaria. While he was at the shearing house along the way,

Jehu encountered the brothers of Ahaziah, king of Judah, and asked, "Who are you?" They answered, "We are the brothers of Ahaziah; we have come to greet the children of the king and the children of the queen."
He said, "Take them alive." They took them alive and killed them at the pit of the shearing house, even forty-two men; he left none of them alive.

After departing from there, he met Jehonadab, the son of Rechab, coming to meet him. He greeted him and asked, "Is your heart right, as my heart is with your heart?" Jehonadab replied, "It is." Jehu said, "If it is, give me your hand." He gave him his hand, and Jehu took him up into the chariot.
He said, "Come with me and see my zeal for the LORD." So they made him ride in his chariot.
When he arrived in Samaria, he killed all that remained of Ahab's house in Samaria, fulfilling the word of the LORD that He spoke to Elijah.
Jehu gathered all the people together and said to them, "Ahab served Baal a little, but Jehu will serve him much.

Now, therefore, summon all the prophets of Baal, all his servants, and all his priests; let none be missing, for I have a great sacrifice to offer to Baal. Whoever is missing shall not live." But Jehu did this cunningly, intending to destroy the worshippers of Baal.
Jehu said, "Proclaim a solemn assembly for Baal." They proclaimed it.

Jehu sent throughout all Israel, and all the worshippers of Baal came, so that not a single man was left out. They entered the house of Baal, and the house of Baal was filled from one end to the other.
He said to the one in charge of the vestry, "Bring out vestments for all the worshippers of Baal." He brought out the vestments.
Jehu and Jehonadab, the son of Rechab, entered the house of Baal and said to the worshippers of Baal, "Search and see that there are no servants of the LORD here, but only worshippers of Baal."

When they went in to offer sacrifices and burnt offerings, Jehu appointed eighty men outside and said, "If any of the men whom I have brought into your hands escape, the one who lets him go, his life shall be for the life of him."

As soon as he finished offering the burnt offering, Jehu said to the guards and captains, "Go in and kill them; let none escape." They struck them down with the sword, and the guards and captains cast them out and went to the city of the house of Baal.
They brought out the images from the house of Baal and burned them.
They broke down the image of Baal, tore down the house of Baal, and made it a latrine to this day.
Thus, Jehu eradicated Baal from Israel.
However, Jehu did not turn away from the sins of Jeroboam, son of Nebat, who caused Israel to sin, specifically the golden calves in Bethel and Dan.

The LORD said to Jehu, "Because you have done well in executing what is right in my eyes and have done to the house of Ahab all that was in my heart, your children of the fourth generation shall sit on the throne of Israel."
But Jehu did not take care to walk in the law of the LORD God of Israel with all his heart; he did not turn away from the sins of Jeroboam, which caused Israel to sin.
In those days, the LORD began to reduce Israel, and Hazael struck them in all the territories of Israel;
From Jordan eastward, all the land of Gilead, the Gadites, the Reubenites, and the Manassites, from Aroer, which is by the river Arnon, even Gilead and Bashan.
Now the rest of the acts of Jehu, all that he did, and all his might, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
Jehu slept with his fathers and was buried in Samaria. His son Jehoahaz reigned in his place.
The duration of Jehu's reign over Israel in Samaria was twenty-eight years.
When Athaliah, the mother of Ahaziah, saw that her son was dead, she rose up and exterminated all the royal descendants.

However, Jehosheba, the daughter of King Joram and sister of Ahaziah, took Joash, the son of Ahaziah, and rescued him from among the slain king's sons; they hid him and his nurse in the bedchamber to protect him from Athaliah, ensuring he was not killed.
He remained hidden with her in the house of the LORD for six years, while Athaliah ruled over the land.

In the seventh year, Jehoiada summoned the commanders of hundreds, along with the captains and the guards, and brought them to the house of the LORD, where he made a covenant with them and took an oath in the house of the LORD, showing them the king's son.
He instructed them, saying, "This is what you shall do: One-third of you who enter on the Sabbath shall be in charge of guarding the king's house;
another third shall be at the gate of Sur, and the remaining third at the gate behind the guard. This way, you will maintain the watch of the house, preventing it from being breached.
And two-thirds of you who go out on the Sabbath shall keep watch over the house of the LORD around the king.
You shall surround the king, each man with his weapon in hand; anyone who approaches the designated area shall be killed. You are to be with the king as he goes out and as he comes in."

The captains of the hundreds complied with all that Jehoiada the priest commanded: each man took his men who were to come in on the Sabbath, along with those who would go out, and they came to Jehoiada the priest.
The priest provided the captains of hundreds with King David's spears and shields, which were kept in the temple of the LORD.
The guards stood, each man armed, surrounding the king from the right corner of the temple to the left corner, alongside the altar and the temple.

He brought forth the king's son, placed the crown upon him, and presented him with the testimony; they made him king, anointed him, and the people clapped their hands, proclaiming, "God save the king!"
When Athaliah heard the commotion of the guards and the people, she approached them in the temple of the LORD.

Upon seeing the scene, she beheld the king standing by a pillar, as was customary, with the princes and trumpeters beside him, and all the people of the land rejoiced and blew trumpets. Athaliah tore her clothes and shouted, "Treason! Treason!"

But Jehoiada the priest instructed the captains of the hundreds, the officers of the army, saying, "Take her out from the designated area, and anyone who follows her should be killed with the sword." For the priest had declared, "Do not let her be slain in the house of the LORD."
They seized her, and she went by the way that the horses entered the king's house, where she was executed.
Jehoiada established a covenant between the LORD, the king, and the people, affirming that they would be the LORD's people; he also made a covenant between the king and the people.

All the people of the land entered the house of Baal and demolished it; they thoroughly broke down his altars and images, and they killed Mattan, the priest of Baal, before the altars. The priest appointed officers over the house of the LORD.

He gathered the commanders of hundreds, the captains, the guards, and all the people of the land; they brought the king down from the house of the LORD and entered by the gate of the guards to the king's house, where he sat on the throne of the kings.
All the people of the land rejoiced, and the city was at peace; they executed Athaliah with the sword beside the king's house.
Jehoash was seven years old when he began to reign.
In the seventh year of Jehu, Jehoash began to reign, and he reigned for forty years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Zibiah from Beersheba.
Jehoash did what was right in the sight of the LORD throughout his days while Jehoiada the priest instructed him.
However, the high places were not removed; the people continued to sacrifice and burn incense at those high places.

Jehoash instructed the priests, saying, "All the money from the dedicated offerings brought into the house of the LORD, including the money from everyone who passes the account, the money that each person is assessed, and all the money that comes into anyone's heart to bring into the house of the LORD,
Let the priests take it from their acquaintances and use it to repair the breaches of the house wherever they are found."
Yet, in the twenty-third year of King Jehoash, the priests had not repaired the breaches of the house.

Then King Jehoash called for Jehoiada the priest and the other priests and asked them, "Why are you not repairing the breaches of the house? Therefore, do not receive any more money from your acquaintances, but deliver it for the repairs of the house."
The priests agreed not to receive any more money from the people, nor to repair the breaches of the house.

But Jehoiada the priest took a chest, bored a hole in its lid, and placed it beside the altar on the right side as one enters the house of the LORD. The priests who kept the door put all the money brought into the house of the LORD into it.
When they saw that there was a large amount of money in the chest, the king's scribe and the high priest came up, put the money into bags, and counted what was found in the house of the LORD.
They gave the counted money into the hands of those who did the work and had oversight of the house of the LORD, and they used it to pay the carpenters and builders working on the house of the LORD,
As well as the masons and stonecutters, and to purchase timber and hewn stone to repair the breaches of the house of the LORD, and for all expenses related to the repairs.
However, no bowls of silver, snuffers, basins, trumpets, or any vessels of gold or silver were made for the house of the LORD from the money brought into it.
Instead, they gave that money to the workmen to repair the house of the LORD.
Moreover, they did not account for the men into whose hands they delivered the money to be used for the workmen, for they dealt faithfully.
The trespass money and sin money were not brought into the house of the LORD; it belonged to the priests.
Then Hazael, king of Syria, went up and fought against Gath and captured it; he set his sights on going up to Jerusalem.

King Jehoash of Judah took all the sacred things that Jehoshaphat, Jehoram, and Ahaziah, his ancestors, kings of Judah, had dedicated, along with his own sacred items and all the gold found in the treasures of the house of the LORD and in the king's palace, and sent it to Hazael, king of Syria, who then withdrew from Jerusalem.
The rest of the acts of Jehoash and all that he did are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah?
His servants rose up and conspired against him, killing Jehoash in the house of Millo, which goes down to Silla.

For Jozachar, the son of Shimeath, and Jehozabad, the son of Shomer, his servants, struck him down, and he died; they buried him with his ancestors in the city of David, and his son Amaziah reigned in his place.
In the twenty-third year of Joash, the son of Ahaziah, king of Judah, Jehoahaz, the son of Jehu, began to reign over Israel in Samaria, and he reigned for seventeen years.
He did what was evil in the sight of the LORD, following the sins of Jeroboam, the son of Nebat, which caused Israel to sin; he did not turn away from them.
The anger of the LORD was kindled against Israel, and He delivered them into the hand of Hazael, king of Syria, and into the hand of Benhadad, the son of Hazael, throughout their days.
Jehoahaz pleaded with the LORD, and the LORD listened to him, for He saw the oppression of Israel, as the king of Syria oppressed them.
(The LORD provided Israel with a savior, so they escaped from the hand of the Syrians; the children of Israel returned to their tents, as they had done before.
Nevertheless, they did not turn away from the sins of the house of Jeroboam, who caused Israel to sin, but continued in them; and the Asherah pole remained in Samaria.)
He left Jehoahaz with only fifty horsemen, ten chariots, and ten thousand foot soldiers; for the king of Syria had destroyed them, making them as dust in the threshing.
Now the rest of the acts of Jehoahaz, all that he did, and his might, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
Jehoahaz slept with his ancestors, and he was buried in Samaria; his son Joash reigned in his place.
In the thirty-seventh year of Joash, king of Judah, Jehoash, the son of Jehoahaz, began to reign over Israel in Samaria, and he reigned for sixteen years.
He did what was evil in the sight of the LORD; he did not turn away from all the sins of Jeroboam, the son of Nebat, who caused Israel to sin; he continued in them.
The rest of the acts of Joash, all that he did, and his might in fighting against Amaziah, king of Judah, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
Joash slept with his ancestors, and Jeroboam sat upon his throne; Joash was buried in Samaria with the kings of Israel.

Now Elisha had fallen sick with the illness of which he died. Joash, the king of Israel, came down to him, weeping over his face, and said, "O my father, my father, the chariot of Israel and its horsemen!"
Elisha said to him, "Take a bow and arrows." So he took a bow and arrows.
He said to the king of Israel, "Put your hand upon the bow." He put his hand upon it, and Elisha placed his hands upon the king's hands.

He said, "Open the window eastward." And he opened it. Then Elisha said, "Shoot." And he shot. He said, "The arrow of the LORD's deliverance, and the arrow of deliverance from Syria; for you shall strike the Syrians in Aphek until you have consumed them."
He said, "Take the arrows." And he took them. Elisha said to the king of Israel, "Strike the ground." He struck it three times and stopped.
The man of God was angry with him and said, "You should have struck five or six times; then you would have struck Syria until you had consumed it. But now you shall strike Syria only three times."
Elisha died, and they buried him. The bands of Moabites invaded the land at the beginning of the year.
As they were burying a man, they spied a band of men; they cast the man into the sepulcher of Elisha, and when the man touched the bones of Elisha, he revived and stood on his feet.
But Hazael, king of Syria, oppressed Israel throughout the days of Jehoahaz.
The LORD was gracious to them, had compassion on them, and regarded them because of His covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, and He would not destroy them or cast them from His presence as yet.
So Hazael, king of Syria, died, and his son Benhadad reigned in his place.

Jehoash, the son of Jehoahaz, recovered from Benhadad, the son of Hazael, the cities that he had taken from Jehoahaz, his father, by war. Joash defeated him three times and recovered the cities of Israel.
In the second year of Joash, son of Jehoahaz, king of Israel, Amaziah, the son of Joash, became king of Judah.
He was twenty-five years old when he began to reign and ruled for twenty-nine years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Jehoaddan, from Jerusalem.
He did what was right in the sight of the LORD, but not as his father David had done; he followed the example of Joash, his father.
However, the high places were not removed, and the people continued to sacrifice and burn incense on those high places.
As soon as the kingdom was firmly established in his hand, he executed the servants who had killed his father, the king.

But he did not kill the children of the murderers, in accordance with what is written in the book of the law of Moses, where the LORD commanded, "Fathers shall not be put to death for their children, nor shall children be put to death for their fathers; each shall be put to death for his own sin."
He struck down ten thousand Edomites in the Valley of Salt, took Selah by war, and named it Joktheel, a name it retains to this day.
Then Amaziah sent messengers to Jehoash, son of Jehoahaz, son of Jehu, king of Israel, saying, "Come, let us face each other."

In response, Jehoash, king of Israel, sent a message to Amaziah, king of Judah, saying, "The thistle in Lebanon sent a message to the cedar in Lebanon, saying, 'Give your daughter to my son as a wife.' But a wild beast passed by and trampled the thistle."
"You have indeed defeated Edom, and your heart has lifted you up. Glory in that, and stay at home. Why should you meddle in trouble, so that you fall, you and Judah with you?"
But Amaziah refused to listen. Therefore, Jehoash, king of Israel, went up, and he and Amaziah, king of Judah, faced each other at Bethshemesh, which belongs to Judah.
Judah was defeated by Israel, and every man fled to his tent.

Jehoash, king of Israel, captured Amaziah, king of Judah, son of Joash, son of Ahaziah, at Bethshemesh, and came to Jerusalem, where he broke down the wall of Jerusalem from the Ephraim Gate to the Corner Gate, a distance of four hundred cubits.
He took all the gold and silver, along with all the vessels found in the house of the LORD and in the treasures of the king's house, and he took hostages, returning to Samaria.
Now the rest of the acts of Jehoash, including his might and how he fought with Amaziah, king of Judah, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
Jehoash slept with his fathers and was buried in Samaria with the kings of Israel; his son Jeroboam reigned in his place.
