The sons of Becher were Zemira, Joash, Eliezer, Elioenai, Omri, Jerimoth, Abiah, Anathoth, and Alameth. These are the sons of Becher.
The total number of them, according to their genealogy and by their generations, heads of their father's house and mighty men of valor, was twenty thousand two hundred.
The sons of Jediael were Bilhan, and the sons of Bilhan included Jeush, Benjamin, Ehud, Chenaanah, Zethan, Tharshish, and Ahishahar.
All these were the sons of Jediael, heads of their fathers' houses, mighty men of valor, totaling seventeen thousand two hundred soldiers fit for war and battle.
Shuppim and Huppim were the children of Ir, and Hushim were the sons of Aher.
The sons of Naphtali were Jahziel, Guni, Jezer, and Shallum, the sons of Bilhah.
The sons of Manasseh included Ashriel, whom she bore; (his concubine, the Aramitess, bore Machir, the father of Gilead).
Machir took to wife the sister of Huppim and Shuppim, whose sister's name was Maachah; the name of the second was Zelophehad, who had daughters.
Maachah, the wife of Machir, bore a son and named him Peresh; his brother was named Sheresh, and his sons were Ulam and Rakem.
The sons of Ulam were Bedan. These were the sons of Gilead, the son of Machir, the son of Manasseh.
His sister Hammoleketh bore Ishod, Abiezer, and Mahalah.
The sons of Shemidah were Ahian, Shechem, Likhi, and Aniam.
The sons of Ephraim were Shuthelah, Bered his son, Tahath his son, Eladah his son, and Tahath his son.
Zabad was his son, Shuthelah his son, Ezer, and Elead, whom the men of Gath, born in that land, killed because they came down to take their cattle.
Ephraim, their father, mourned for many days, and his brethren came to comfort him.
When he went in to his wife, she conceived and bore a son, whom he named Beriah, because it went badly for his house.
(And his daughter was Sherah, who built the lower and upper Bethhoron, and Uzzensherah.)
Rephah was his son, as well as Resheph, Telah his son, and Tahan his son.
Laadan was his son, Ammihud his son, and Elishama his son.
Non was his son, and Jehoshuah was his son.
Their possessions and habitations included Bethel and its towns, eastward Naaran, and westward Gezer with its towns; Shechem and its towns, extending to Gaza and its towns.
By the borders of the children of Manasseh were Bethshean and its towns, Taanach and its towns, Megiddo and its towns, and Dor and its towns. In these dwelt the children of Joseph, the son of Israel.
The sons of Asher were Imnah, Isuah, Ishuai, Beriah, and their sister Serah.
The sons of Beriah were Heber and Malchiel, who is the father of Birzavith.
Heber begat Japhlet, Shomer, Hotham, and their sister Shua.
The sons of Japhlet were Pasach, Bimhal, and Ashvath. These are the children of Japhlet.
The sons of Shamer were Ahi, Rohgah, Jehubbah, and Aram.
The sons of his brother Helem were Zophah, Imna, Shelesh, and Amal.
The sons of Zophah were Suah, Harnepher, Shual, Beri, and Imrah,
Bezer, Hod, Shamma, Shilshah, Ithran, and Beera.
The sons of Jether were Jephunneh, Pispah, and Ara.
The sons of Ulla were Arah, Haniel, and Rezia.

All these were the children of Asher, heads of their father's house, choice and mighty men of valor, chief among the princes. The total number throughout their genealogy of those fit for war and battle was twenty-six thousand men.
Now Benjamin fathered Bela, his firstborn; Ashbel, the second; and Aharah, the third.
Nohah was the fourth, and Rapha the fifth.
The sons of Bela were Addar, Gera, and Abihud,
Abishua, Naaman, and Ahoah,
Gera, Shephuphan, and Huram.
These are the sons of Ehud, the heads of the families of the inhabitants of Geba, who were relocated to Manahath:
Naaman, Ahiah, and Gera; he removed them and fathered Uzza and Ahihud.
Shaharaim fathered children in the land of Moab after sending them away; Hushim and Baara were his wives.
By Hodesh, his wife, he fathered Jobab, Zibia, Mesha, and Malcham,
Jeuz, Shachia, and Mirma. These were his sons, heads of the families.
From Hushim, he fathered Abitub and Elpaal.
The sons of Elpaal were Eber, Misham, and Shamed, who built Ono and Lod, along with their towns:
Beriah and Shema, who were heads of the families of the inhabitants of Aijalon, who drove away the inhabitants of Gath:
Ahio, Shashak, and Jeremoth,
Zebadiah, Arad, and Ader,
Michael, Ispah, and Joha, the sons of Beriah;
Zebadiah, Meshullam, Hezeki, and Heber,
Ishmerai, Jezliah, and Jobab, the sons of Elpaal;
Jakim, Zichri, and Zabdi,
Elienai, Zilthai, and Eliel,
Adaiah, Beraiah, and Shimrath, the sons of Shimhi;
Ishpan, Heber, and Eliel,
Abdon, Zichri, and Hanan,
Hananiah, Elam, and Antothijah,
Iphedeiah and Penuel, the sons of Shashak;
Shamsherai, Shehariah, and Athaliah,
Jaresiah, Eliah, and Zichri, the sons of Jeroham.
These were heads of families, by their generations, chief men. They dwelt in Jerusalem.
At Gibeon lived the father of Gibeon, whose wife's name was Maachah:
His firstborn son was Abdon, followed by Zur, Kish, Baal, and Nadab,
Gedor, Ahio, and Zacher.
Mikloth fathered Shimeah, and these also lived with their brethren in Jerusalem, opposite them.
Ner fathered Kish, Kish fathered Saul, and Saul fathered Jonathan, Malchishua, Abinadab, and Eshbaal.
The son of Jonathan was Meribbaal, and Meribbaal fathered Micah.
The sons of Micah were Pithon, Melech, Tarea, and Ahaz.
Ahaz fathered Jehoadah; Jehoadah fathered Alemeth, Azmaveth, and Zimri; Zimri fathered Moza,
Moza fathered Binea: Rapha was his son, Eleasah his son, and Azel his son:
Azel had six sons, whose names were Azrikam, Bocheru, Ishmael, Sheariah, Obadiah, and Hanan. All these were the sons of Azel.
The sons of Eshek, his brother, were Ulam, his firstborn; Jehush, the second; and Eliphelet, the third.
The sons of Ulam were mighty men of valor, archers, and had many sons and grandsons, totaling one hundred and fifty. All these are the sons of Benjamin.
All of Israel was counted by genealogies; behold, they were recorded in the book of the kings of Israel and Judah, who were taken to Babylon due to their transgressions.
The first inhabitants who settled in their possessions in their cities were the Israelites, the priests, Levites, and the Nethinims.
In Jerusalem lived some of the children of Judah, Benjamin, Ephraim, and Manasseh;
Uthai, the son of Ammihud, the son of Omri, the son of Imri, the son of Bani, from the children of Pharez, the son of Judah.
From the Shilonites: Asaiah, the firstborn, and his sons.
From the sons of Zerah: Jeuel and their brethren, numbering six hundred and ninety.
From the sons of Benjamin: Sallu, the son of Meshullam, the son of Hodaviah, the son of Hasenuah,
And Ibneiah, the son of Jeroham, Elah, the son of Uzzi, the son of Michri, and Meshullam, the son of Shephathiah, the son of Reuel, the son of Ibnijah;
And their brethren, according to their generations, numbered nine hundred and fifty-six. All these men were leaders of their families.
Among the priests were Jedaiah, Jehoiarib, and Jachin,
And Azariah, the son of Hilkiah, the son of Meshullam, the son of Zadok, the son of Meraioth, the son of Ahitub, the ruler of the house of God;
And Adaiah, the son of Jeroham, the son of Pashur, the son of Malchijah, and Maasiai, the son of Adiel, the son of Jahzerah, the son of Meshullam, the son of Meshillemith, the son of Immer;
And their brethren, heads of their families, numbered one thousand seven hundred and sixty; very capable men for the service of the house of God.
Among the Levites were Shemaiah, the son of Hasshub, the son of Azrikam, the son of Hashabiah, from the sons of Merari;
And Bakbakkar, Heresh, Galal, and Mattaniah, the son of Micah, the son of Zichri, the son of Asaph;
And Obadiah, the son of Shemaiah, the son of Galal, the son of Jeduthun, and Berechiah, the son of Asa, the son of Elkanah, who lived in the villages of the Netophathites.
The porters were Shallum, Akkub, Talmon, Ahiman, and their brethren: Shallum was the chief;
They had been stationed at the king's gate eastward: they served as porters in the companies of the children of Levi.

Shallum, the son of Kore, the son of Ebiasaph, the son of Korah, and his brethren, from the house of his father, the Korahites, were responsible for the service, keepers of the gates of the tabernacle: their ancestors, overseeing the host of the LORD, were keepers of the entry.
Phinehas, the son of Eleazar, had been their ruler in the past, and the LORD was with him.
Zechariah, the son of Meshelemiah, was the porter at the door of the tabernacle of the congregation.

All those chosen to be porters at the gates numbered two hundred and twelve. They were counted by their genealogy in their villages, whom David and Samuel the seer appointed in their designated roles.
Thus, they and their children had oversight of the gates of the house of the LORD, specifically the house of the tabernacle, by wards.
The porters were stationed in four quarters, toward the east, west, north, and south.
Their brethren, who lived in their villages, were to come after seven days from time to time to assist them.
These Levites, the four chief porters, held their designated positions and were responsible for the chambers and treasuries of the house of God.
They lodged around the house of God, as the responsibility was upon them, and they were in charge of opening it every morning.
Certain individuals were responsible for the ministering vessels, ensuring they were brought in and out as needed.
Some were also appointed to oversee the vessels, all the instruments of the sanctuary, as well as the fine flour, wine, oil, frankincense, and spices.
Some of the sons of the priests prepared the ointment of the spices.
Mattithiah, one of the Levites, who was the firstborn of Shallum the Korahite, had the designated role over the items made in the pans.
Others from the sons of the Kohathites were responsible for the showbread, preparing it every Sabbath.
These are the singers, leaders of the Levite families, who remained in the chambers and were free, as they were engaged in that work day and night.
These chief fathers of the Levites were leaders throughout their generations; they lived in Jerusalem.
In Gibeon lived the father of Gibeon, Jehiel, whose wife's name was Maachah:
His firstborn son was Abdon, followed by Zur, Kish, Baal, Ner, and Nadab.
Also Gedor, Ahio, Zechariah, and Mikloth.
Mikloth begat Shimeam. They also lived with their brethren in Jerusalem, opposite their brethren.
Ner begat Kish; Kish begat Saul; Saul begat Jonathan, Malchishua, Abinadab, and Eshbaal.
The son of Jonathan was Meribbaal; Meribbaal begat Micah.
The sons of Micah were Pithon, Melech, Tahrea, and Ahaz.
Ahaz begat Jarah; Jarah begat Alemeth, Azmaveth, and Zimri; Zimri begat Moza;
Moza begat Binea; Rephaiah his son, Eleasah his son, and Azel his son.
Azel had six sons, whose names were Azrikam, Bocheru, Ishmael, Sheariah, Obadiah, and Hanan: these were the sons of Azel.
Now the Philistines engaged in battle against Israel; the men of Israel fled from the Philistines and fell slain on Mount Gilboa.
The Philistines pursued Saul and his sons relentlessly; they killed Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malchishua, the sons of Saul.
The battle pressed heavily upon Saul, and the archers struck him, wounding him severely.

Saul then said to his armor-bearer, "Draw your sword and run me through with it; otherwise, these uncircumcised men will come and mistreat me." But his armor-bearer was terrified and refused. So Saul took his own sword and fell on it.
When his armor-bearer saw that Saul was dead, he also fell on his sword and died.
Thus, Saul, his three sons, and all his household perished together.
When the men of Israel in the valley saw that they had fled and that Saul and his sons were dead, they abandoned their cities and fled; the Philistines then came and occupied them.
The next day, when the Philistines came to strip the slain, they found Saul and his sons fallen on Mount Gilboa.
After stripping him, they took his head and armor and sent them throughout the land of the Philistines to deliver news to their idols and to the people.
They placed his armor in the temple of their gods and hung his head in the temple of Dagon.
When the people of Jabesh-gilead heard what the Philistines had done to Saul,
all the valiant men arose, took the body of Saul and the bodies of his sons, brought them to Jabesh, buried their bones under the oak in Jabesh, and fasted for seven days.
Saul died because of his transgressions against the LORD, specifically for not adhering to the word of the LORD and for seeking counsel from a medium to inquire of it;
he did not seek guidance from the LORD. Therefore, the LORD killed him and transferred the kingdom to David, the son of Jesse.
All of Israel gathered to David at Hebron, saying, "Behold, we are your bone and your flesh."

Furthermore, in the past, even when Saul was king, you were the one who led Israel in and out; and the LORD your God said to you, "You shall shepherd my people Israel, and you shall be ruler over my people Israel."
Thus, all the elders of Israel came to the king at Hebron, and David made a covenant with them before the LORD; and they anointed David king over Israel, as the LORD had spoken through Samuel.
David and all Israel then went to Jerusalem, which is also known as Jebus, where the Jebusites, the inhabitants of the land, resided.
The inhabitants of Jebus said to David, "You shall not come here." Nevertheless, David captured the stronghold of Zion, which is the city of David.
David declared, "Whoever strikes the Jebusites first shall be chief and captain." So Joab the son of Zeruiah went up first and became chief.
David settled in the stronghold, and therefore it was called the city of David.
He built the city around it, from Millo and beyond, and Joab repaired the rest of the city.
Thus, David became greater and greater, for the LORD of hosts was with him.
These are the chief of the mighty men whom David had, who strengthened themselves with him in his kingdom, and with all Israel, to make him king, as the LORD had spoken concerning Israel.
This is the number of the mighty men whom David had: Jashobeam, a Hachmonite, the chief of the captains; he raised his spear against three hundred men and killed them at one time.
Next was Eleazar the son of Dodo, the Ahohite, one of the three mighty men.
He was with David at Pasdammim, where the Philistines gathered for battle, and there was a plot of ground full of barley; the people fled from the Philistines.
They took their stand in the middle of that plot, defended it, and struck down the Philistines; and the LORD granted them a great victory.
Three of the thirty captains went down to the rock to David, at the cave of Adullam, while the Philistine army was encamped in the valley of Rephaim.
David was then in the stronghold, and the Philistine garrison was at Bethlehem.
David longed and said, "Oh, that someone would give me a drink from the well of Bethlehem, which is by the gate!"
The three broke through the Philistine camp, drew water from the well of Bethlehem by the gate, and brought it back to David; but David would not drink it, instead, he poured it out to the LORD.

He said, "My God forbid that I should do this! Shall I drink the blood of these men who risked their lives? For they brought it at the risk of their lives." Therefore, he would not drink it. These are the deeds of the three mighty men.
Abishai, the brother of Joab, was chief of the three; he raised his spear against three hundred men and killed them, earning a name among the three.
Among the three, he was more honorable than the other two, for he was their captain; however, he did not attain to the first three.
Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, a valiant man from Kabzeel, performed many great deeds; he killed two lion-like men of Moab and went down into a pit on a snowy day and killed a lion.

He also killed an Egyptian, a man of great stature, five cubits tall; the Egyptian had a spear like a weaver's beam, but Benaiah went down to him with a staff, took the spear from the Egyptian's hand, and killed him with his own spear.
These are the deeds of Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and he earned a name among the three mighty men.
He was honored among the thirty, but did not attain to the first three; David appointed him over his guard.
The valiant men of the armies included Asahel, the brother of Joab, and Elhanan, the son of Dodo from Bethlehem,
Shammoth the Harorite, Helez the Pelonite,
Ira the son of Ikkesh the Tekoite, Abiezer the Antothite,
Sibbecai the Hushathite, Ilai the Ahohite,
Maharai the Netophathite, Heled the son of Baanah the Netophathite,
Ithai the son of Ribai of Gibeah, belonging to the children of Benjamin, Benaiah the Pirathonite,
Hurai of the brooks of Gaash, Abiel the Arbathite,
Azmaveth the Baharumite, Eliahba the Shaalbonite,
The sons of Hashem the Gizonite, Jonathan the son of Shage the Hararite,
Ahiam the son of Sacar the Hararite, Eliphal the son of Ur,
Hepher the Mecherathite, Ahijah the Pelonite,
Hezro the Carmelite, Naarai the son of Ezbai,
Joel the brother of Nathan, Mibhar the son of Haggeri,
Zelek the Ammonite, Naharai the Berothite, the armor-bearer of Joab the son of Zeruiah,
Ira the Ithrite, Gareb the Ithrite,
Uriah the Hittite, Zabad the son of Ahlai,
Adina the son of Shiza the Reubenite, a captain of the Reubenites, and thirty with him,
Hanan the son of Maachah, and Joshaphat the Mithnite,
Uzzia the Ashterathite, Shama and Jehiel, the sons of Hothan the Aroerite,
Jediael the son of Shimri, and Joha his brother, the Tizite,
Eliel the Mahavite, and Jeribai, and Joshaviah, the sons of Elnaam, and Ithmah the Moabite,
Eliel, Obed, and Jasiel the Mesobaite.
Now these are they who came to David at Ziklag, while he kept himself close because of Saul the son of Kish; they were among the mighty men, helpers in the war.
They were armed with bows and could use both the right hand and the left in hurling stones and shooting arrows from a bow, even of Saul's brethren of Benjamin.
The chief was Ahiezer, then Joash, the sons of Shemaah the Gibeathite; and Jeziel, and Pelet, the sons of Azmaveth; and Berachah, and Jehu the Antothite.
And Ismaiah the Gibeonite, a mighty man among the thirty, and over the thirty; and Jeremiah, and Jahaziel, and Johanan, and Josabad the Gederathite,
Eluzai, and Jerimoth, and Bealiah, and Shemariah, and Shephatiah the Haruphite,
Elkanah, and Jesiah, and Azareel, and Joezer, and Jashobeam, the Korhites,
And Joelah, and Zebadiah, the sons of Jeroham of Gedor.

And of the Gadites, there separated themselves unto David in the hold to the wilderness, men of might, and men of war fit for battle, who could handle shield and buckler, whose faces were like the faces of lions, and were as swift as the roes upon the mountains;
Ezer the first, Obadiah the second, Eliab the third,
Mishmannah the fourth, Jeremiah the fifth,
Attai the sixth, Eliel the seventh,
Johanan the eighth, Elzabad the ninth,
Jeremiah the tenth, Machbanai the eleventh.
These were of the sons of Gad, captains of the host: one of the least was over a hundred, and the greatest over a thousand.
These are they who crossed over Jordan in the first month, when it had overflowed all its banks; and they put to flight all those of the valleys, both toward the east and toward the west.
And there came of the children of Benjamin and Judah to the hold unto David.

And David went out to meet them, and answered and said unto them, If you have come peaceably unto me to help me, my heart shall be knit unto you: but if you have come to betray me to my enemies, seeing there is no wrong in my hands, may the God of our fathers look thereon and rebuke it.

Then the spirit came upon Amasai, who was chief of the captains, and he said, Yours are we, David, and on your side, you son of Jesse: peace, peace be unto you, and peace be to your helpers; for your God helps you. Then David received them and made them captains of the band.

And some of Manasseh fell to David when he came with the Philistines against Saul to battle; but they helped them not: for the lords of the Philistines, upon advisement, sent him away, saying, He will fall to his master Saul to the jeopardy of our heads.
As he went to Ziklag, there fell to him of Manasseh, Adnah, and Jozabad, and Jediael, and Michael, and Jozabad, and Elihu, and Zilthai, captains of the thousands that were of Manasseh.
And they helped David against the band of rovers: for they were all mighty men of valor and were captains in the host.
For at that time, day by day, there came to David to help him, until it was a great host, like the host of God.
And these are the numbers of the bands that were ready armed for war and came to David at Hebron, to turn the kingdom of Saul to him, according to the word of the LORD.
The children of Judah who bore shield and spear were six thousand and eight hundred, ready armed for war.
Of the children of Simeon, mighty men of valor for war, seven thousand and one hundred.
Of the children of Levi, four thousand and six hundred.
And Jehoiada was the leader of the Aaronites, and with him were three thousand and seven hundred;
And Zadok, a young man mighty of valor, and of his father's house, twenty-two captains.
And of the children of Benjamin, the kindred of Saul, three thousand: for hitherto the greatest part of them had kept the ward of the house of Saul.
And of the children of Ephraim, twenty thousand and eight hundred, mighty men of valor, famous throughout the house of their fathers.
And of the half tribe of Manasseh, eighteen thousand, which were expressed by name, to come and make David king.
And of the children of Issachar, who were men that had understanding of the times, to know what Israel ought to do; the heads of them were two hundred; and all their brethren were at their command.
Of Zebulun, such as went forth to battle, expert in war, with all instruments of war, fifty thousand, who could keep rank: they were not of double heart.
And of Naphtali, a thousand captains, and with them with shield and spear, thirty-seven thousand.
And of the Danites, expert in war, twenty-eight thousand and six hundred.
And of Asher, such as went forth to battle, expert in war, forty thousand.
And on the other side of Jordan, of the Reubenites, and the Gadites, and of the half tribe of Manasseh, with all manner of instruments of war for battle, one hundred and twenty thousand.
All these men of war, who could keep rank, came with a perfect heart to Hebron, to make David king over all Israel: and all the rest also of Israel were of one heart to make David king.
And there they were with David three days, eating and drinking: for their brethren had prepared for them.

Moreover, those who were near them, even unto Issachar and Zebulun and Naphtali, brought bread on asses, and on camels, and on mules, and on oxen, and meat, meal, cakes of figs, and bunches of raisins, and wine, and oil, and oxen, and sheep abundantly: for there was joy in Israel.
David consulted with the captains of thousands and hundreds, as well as every leader.

David addressed the entire congregation of Israel, saying, "If it seems good to you and is in accordance with the LORD our God, let us send word to our brethren everywhere who are left in all the land of Israel, and also to the priests and Levites in their cities and suburbs, so they may gather together with us.
Let us bring back the ark of our God, for we did not inquire of it during the days of Saul."
All the congregation agreed to this proposal, for it was right in the eyes of the people.
So David gathered all of Israel, from Shihor in Egypt to the entrance of Hemath, to bring the ark of God from Kirjathjearim.
David and all of Israel went up to Baalah, which is Kirjathjearim, belonging to Judah, to bring up the ark of God, the LORD, who dwells between the cherubim, whose name is invoked.
They transported the ark of God on a new cart from the house of Abinadab, with Uzza and Ahio driving the cart.
David and all of Israel celebrated before God with all their might, accompanied by singing, harps, psalteries, timbrels, cymbals, and trumpets.
When they reached the threshing floor of Chidon, Uzza reached out his hand to steady the ark, for the oxen stumbled.
The anger of the LORD was kindled against Uzza, and He struck him down because he touched the ark; and he died there before God.
David was displeased because the LORD had made a breach against Uzza; therefore, that place is called Perezuzza to this day.
David was afraid of God that day, saying, "How can I bring the ark of God home to me?"
So David did not bring the ark home to himself in the city of David, but instead took it to the house of Obededom the Gittite.
The ark of God remained in the house of Obededom for three months, and the LORD blessed Obededom and all that he had.
Now Hiram, the king of Tyre, sent messengers to David, along with timber from cedars, masons, and carpenters, to construct a house for him.
David recognized that the LORD had established him as king over Israel, for his kingdom was exalted because of his people Israel.
In Jerusalem, David took more wives and fathered additional sons and daughters.
These are the names of his children born in Jerusalem: Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, and Solomon,
as well as Ibhar, Elishua, and Elpalet,
and Nogah, Nepheg, and Japhia,
and Elishama, Beeliada, and Eliphalet.
When the Philistines learned that David had been anointed king over all Israel, they all went up to confront David. David heard of this and went out to meet them.
The Philistines came and positioned themselves in the valley of Rephaim.
David inquired of God, asking, "Shall I go up against the Philistines? Will you deliver them into my hand?" The LORD answered him, "Go up, for I will deliver them into your hand."
They advanced to Baalperazim, and David struck them there. David declared, "God has burst forth upon my enemies by my hand like the breaking of waters." Therefore, that place was named Baalperazim.
After they left their gods there, David commanded that they be burned with fire.
The Philistines once again spread out in the valley.
Consequently, David sought God again, and God instructed him, "Do not pursue them; turn away from them and approach them opposite the mulberry trees.
When you hear the sound of marching in the tops of the mulberry trees, then you shall go out to battle, for God has gone out before you to strike the Philistine army."
David followed God's command, and they defeated the Philistine army from Gibeon to Gazer.
The fame of David spread throughout all lands, and the LORD instilled fear of him in all nations.
And David built houses in the city of David, prepared a place for the ark of God, and pitched a tent for it.
Then David declared, "Only the Levites should carry the ark of God, for the LORD has chosen them to carry the ark and to minister to Him forever."
David gathered all of Israel in Jerusalem to bring up the ark of the LORD to the place he had prepared for it.
He assembled the descendants of Aaron and the Levites:
From the sons of Kohath: Uriel the chief, along with his hundred and twenty brethren.
From the sons of Merari: Asaiah the chief, along with his two hundred and twenty brethren.
From the sons of Gershom: Joel the chief, along with his hundred and thirty brethren.
From the sons of Elizaphan: Shemaiah the chief, along with his two hundred brethren.
From the sons of Hebron: Eliel the chief, along with his eighty brethren.
From the sons of Uzziel: Amminadab the chief, along with his hundred and twelve brethren.
David called for the priests Zadok and Abiathar, and for the Levites: Uriel, Asaiah, Joel, Shemaiah, Eliel, and Amminadab,

and said to them, "You are the leaders of the Levite families: sanctify yourselves, along with your brethren, so that you may bring up the ark of the LORD God of Israel to the place I have prepared for it."
"Because you did not do this at first, the LORD our God broke out against us, for we did not seek Him according to the prescribed order."
So the priests and the Levites sanctified themselves to bring up the ark of the LORD God of Israel.
The children of the Levites carried the ark of God on their shoulders with the staves, as Moses commanded according to the word of the LORD.
David spoke to the chief of the Levites to appoint their brethren as singers with musical instruments: psalteries, harps, and cymbals, to sound joyfully.
The Levites appointed Heman the son of Joel, and his brethren: Asaph the son of Berechiah, and from the sons of Merari, their brethren: Ethan the son of Kushaiah.
With them were their brethren of the second degree: Zechariah, Ben, Jaaziel, Shemiramoth, Jehiel, Unni, Eliab, Benaiah, Maaseiah, Mattithiah, Elipheleh, Mikneiah, Obededom, and Jeiel, the porters.
The singers, Heman, Asaph, and Ethan, were appointed to sound the cymbals of brass;
and Zechariah, Aziel, Shemiramoth, Jehiel, Unni, Eliab, Maaseiah, and Benaiah played the psalteries on Alamoth;
and Mattithiah, Elipheleh, Mikneiah, Obededom, Jeiel, and Azaziah played the harps on the Sheminith to excel.
Chenaniah, the chief of the Levites, was in charge of the singing, for he was skillful in this.
Berechiah and Elkanah served as doorkeepers for the ark.
Shebaniah, Jehoshaphat, Nethaneel, Amasai, Zechariah, Benaiah, and Eliezer, the priests, blew the trumpets before the ark of God, while Obededom and Jehiah served as doorkeepers for the ark.
So David, the elders of Israel, and the captains over thousands went to bring up the ark of the covenant of the LORD from the house of Obededom with joy.
When God helped the Levites who carried the ark of the covenant of the LORD, they offered seven bullocks and seven rams.
David was clothed in a robe of fine linen, and all the Levites who carried the ark, along with the singers and Chenaniah, the master of the song, wore linen as well; David also wore a linen ephod.
Thus, all of Israel brought up the ark of the covenant of the LORD with shouting, and with the sound of the cornet, trumpets, and cymbals, making a joyful noise with psalteries and harps.
As the ark of the covenant of the LORD entered the city of David, Michal, the daughter of Saul, looked out from a window and saw King David dancing and playing; she despised him in her heart.
They brought the ark of God and placed it in the center of the tent that David had pitched for it; they offered burnt sacrifices and peace offerings before God.
After David finished offering the burnt offerings and peace offerings, he blessed the people in the name of the LORD.
He distributed to every person in Israel, both men and women, a loaf of bread, a good piece of meat, and a flagon of wine.
David appointed certain Levites to minister before the ark of the LORD, to record, thank, and praise the LORD God of Israel.
Asaph was the chief, and next to him were Zechariah, Jeiel, Shemiramoth, Jehiel, Mattithiah, Eliab, Benaiah, and Obededom; Jeiel played the psaltery and harp, while Asaph made music with cymbals.
Benaiah and Jahaziel, the priests, played trumpets continually before the ark of the covenant of God.
On that day, David first delivered this psalm to thank the LORD into the hands of Asaph and his brethren.
Give thanks to the LORD, call upon His name, and make known His deeds among the people.
Sing to Him, sing psalms to Him, and speak of all His wondrous works.
Glory in His holy name; let the hearts of those who seek the LORD rejoice.
Seek the LORD and His strength; seek His face continually.
Remember His marvelous works that He has done, His wonders, and the judgments of His mouth.
O you descendants of Israel, His servant, you children of Jacob, His chosen ones.
He is the LORD our God; His judgments are in all the earth.
Always be mindful of His covenant, the word He commanded for a thousand generations.
Even the covenant He made with Abraham and His oath to Isaac.
He confirmed the same to Jacob as a law and to Israel as an everlasting covenant,
Saying, "To you, I will give the land of Canaan, the portion of your inheritance."
When you were but few, even a few, and strangers in it.
When they went from nation to nation, and from one kingdom to another people,
He allowed no man to do them wrong; indeed, He reproved kings for their sake,
Saying, "Do not touch My anointed ones, and do My prophets no harm."
Sing to the LORD, all the earth; proclaim His salvation from day to day.
Declare His glory among the nations, His marvelous works among all peoples.
For great is the LORD, and greatly to be praised; He is also to be feared above all gods.
For all the gods of the peoples are idols, but the LORD made the heavens.
Glory and honor are in His presence; strength and gladness are in His place.
Give to the LORD, you families of the peoples; give to the LORD glory and strength.
Give to the LORD the glory due to His name; bring an offering and come before Him; worship the LORD in the beauty of holiness.
Fear before Him, all the earth; the world shall be stable, it shall not be moved.
Let the heavens be glad, and let the earth rejoice; let men say among the nations, "The LORD reigns."
Let the sea roar, and all its fullness; let the fields rejoice, and all that is in them.
Then the trees of the forest shall sing out at the presence of the LORD, for He comes to judge the earth.
O give thanks to the LORD, for He is good; His mercy endures forever.
And say, "Save us, O God of our salvation, gather us together, and deliver us from the nations, that we may give thanks to Your holy name and glory in Your praise."
Blessed be the LORD God of Israel forever and ever. And all the people said, "Amen," and praised the LORD.
So David left Asaph and his brethren there before the ark of the covenant of the LORD to minister before the ark continually, as each day's work required.
Obededom and their brethren, sixty-eight in total; Obededom, the son of Jeduthun, and Hosah were appointed as porters.
Zadok the priest and his fellow priests were before the tabernacle of the LORD at the high place in Gibeon,
To offer burnt offerings to the LORD on the altar of burnt offering continually, morning and evening, and to do according to all that is written in the law of the LORD, which He commanded Israel.
With them were Heman and Jeduthun, and the rest who were chosen by name to give thanks to the LORD, for His mercy endures forever.
Heman and Jeduthun played trumpets and cymbals for those who were to make a sound, along with musical instruments of God. The sons of Jeduthun were porters.
And all the people departed, each man to his house; and David returned to bless his own house.
Now it came to pass, as David sat in his house, that he said to Nathan the prophet, "Behold, I dwell in a house of cedars, but the ark of the covenant of the LORD remains under curtains."
Then Nathan said to David, "Do all that is in your heart; for God is with you."
And it came to pass that same night, the word of God came to Nathan, saying,
"Go and tell my servant David, 'Thus says the LORD, You shall not build me a house to dwell in;
For I have not dwelt in a house since the day I brought up Israel to this day; but have gone from tent to tent, and from one tabernacle to another.
Wherever I have walked with all Israel, did I ever speak a word to any of the judges of Israel, whom I commanded to shepherd my people, saying, "Why have you not built me a house of cedars?"
Now therefore, you shall say to my servant David, 'Thus says the LORD of hosts, I took you from the sheepfold, from following the sheep, that you should be ruler over my people Israel;
And I have been with you wherever you have walked, and have cut off all your enemies from before you, and have made you a name like the name of the great men who are on the earth.

Also, I will appoint a place for my people Israel, and will plant them, that they may dwell in their own place and be disturbed no more; nor shall the sons of wickedness oppress them anymore, as at the beginning,
And since the time I commanded judges to be over my people Israel. Moreover, I will subdue all your enemies. Furthermore, I tell you that the LORD will build you a house.
And it shall come to pass, when your days are fulfilled and you must go to be with your fathers, that I will raise up your seed after you, who will be of your sons; and I will establish his kingdom.
He shall build me a house, and I will establish his throne forever.
I will be his father, and he shall be my son; and I will not take my mercy away from him, as I took it from him who was before you.
But I will settle him in my house and in my kingdom forever; and his throne shall be established forevermore."
According to all these words, and according to all this vision, so Nathan spoke to David.
And King David came and sat before the LORD, and said, "Who am I, O LORD God, and what is my house, that you have brought me this far?

And yet this was a small thing in your eyes, O God; for you have also spoken of your servant's house for a great while to come, and have regarded me according to the standing of a man of high degree, O LORD God.
What more can David say to you for the honor of your servant? For you know your servant.
O LORD, for your servant's sake, and according to your own heart, you have done all this greatness, in making known all these great things.
O LORD, there is none like you, nor is there any God besides you, according to all that we have heard with our ears.

And what one nation in the earth is like your people Israel, whom God went to redeem as his own people, to make you a name of greatness and terribleness, by driving out nations from before your people whom you have redeemed out of Egypt?
For your people Israel you made your own people forever; and you, O LORD, became their God.
Therefore now, O LORD, let the thing that you have spoken concerning your servant and concerning his house be established forever, and do as you have said.

Let it even be established, that your name may be magnified forever, saying, 'The LORD of hosts is the God of Israel, even a God to Israel'; and let the house of David your servant be established before you.
For you, O my God, have told your servant that you will build him a house; therefore your servant has found it in his heart to pray before you.
And now, O LORD, you are God, and have promised this goodness to your servant:
Now therefore, let it please you to bless the house of your servant, that it may be before you forever; for you bless, O LORD, and it shall be blessed forever."
Now, after this, it came to pass that David struck the Philistines, subdued them, and took Gath and its towns from the Philistines.
He also struck Moab; the Moabites then became David's servants and brought him gifts.
David defeated Hadarezer, king of Zobah, as far as Hamath, while establishing his dominion by the Euphrates River.
From him, David took a thousand chariots, seven thousand horsemen, and twenty thousand foot soldiers; he also hamstrung all the chariot horses but kept a hundred chariots for himself.
When the Syrians of Damascus came to assist Hadarezer, king of Zobah, David killed twenty-two thousand of the Syrians.
Then David placed garrisons in Damascus, and the Syrians became David's servants, bringing him gifts. Thus, the LORD preserved David wherever he went.
David took the gold shields that belonged to the servants of Hadarezer and brought them to Jerusalem.
From Tibhath and Chun, cities of Hadarezer, David brought back a great deal of bronze, which Solomon used to make the bronze sea, the pillars, and various bronze vessels.
When Tou, king of Hamath, heard that David had defeated the entire army of Hadarezer,

he sent his son Hadoram to King David to inquire about his well-being and to congratulate him for fighting against Hadarezer and defeating him (for Hadarezer had been at war with Tou), bringing with him various vessels of gold, silver, and bronze.
King David dedicated these to the LORD, along with the silver and gold he had taken from all these nations: Edom, Moab, the children of Ammon, the Philistines, and Amalek.
Additionally, Abishai, the son of Zeruiah, killed eighteen thousand Edomites in the Valley of Salt.
He established garrisons in Edom, and all the Edomites became David's servants. Thus, the LORD preserved David wherever he went.
So David reigned over all Israel, administering judgment and justice among all his people.
Joab, the son of Zeruiah, was in command of the army, and Jehoshaphat, the son of Ahilud, served as recorder.
Zadok, the son of Ahitub, and Abimelech, the son of Abiathar, were the priests, and Shavsha was the scribe.
Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada, was in charge of the Cherethites and the Pelethites, and the sons of David were chief officials around the king.
It came to pass after this that Nahash, the king of the Ammonites, died, and his son succeeded him.

David said, "I will show kindness to Hanun, the son of Nahash, because his father showed kindness to me." David sent messengers to comfort him regarding his father. Thus, David's servants entered the land of the Ammonites to console Hanun.
However, the princes of the Ammonites said to Hanun, "Do you think David honors your father by sending comforters to you? Are not his servants here to investigate, overthrow, and spy on the land?"
Consequently, Hanun took David's servants, shaved them, cut off their garments up to their buttocks, and sent them away.

Then some went and informed David of how the men had been treated. He sent to meet them, for the men were greatly ashamed. The king said, "Stay in Jericho until your beards have grown back, and then return."

When the Ammonites realized they had made themselves odious to David, Hanun and the Ammonites sent a thousand talents of silver to hire chariots and horsemen from Mesopotamia, from Maachah, and from Zobah.
They hired thirty-two thousand chariots, along with the king of Maachah and his people, who came and camped before Medeba. The Ammonites gathered from their cities and prepared for battle.
Upon hearing this, David sent Joab and all the mighty men of valor.
The Ammonites came out and arranged their forces at the city gate, while the kings who had come were in the field by themselves.
When Joab saw that the battle was set against him from both the front and the rear, he selected the best of Israel and arranged them against the Syrians.
The rest of the people he placed under the command of his brother Abishai, and they arranged themselves against the Ammonites.
He said, "If the Syrians are too strong for me, you shall help me; but if the Ammonites are too strong for you, I will help you.
Be courageous, and let us act valiantly for our people and for the cities of our God; and may the LORD do what is good in His sight."
So Joab and the men with him advanced toward the Syrians in battle, and they fled before him.
When the Ammonites saw that the Syrians had fled, they also fled before Abishai, and entered the city. Then Joab returned to Jerusalem.
When the Syrians realized they were being defeated by Israel, they sent messengers and brought in reinforcements from beyond the river, with Shophach, the commander of Hadarezer's army, leading them.

David was informed, and he gathered all Israel, crossed the Jordan, and confronted them, arranging the battle against them. When David had set the battle in array against the Syrians, they fought with him.
But the Syrians fled before Israel; David killed seven thousand of their charioteers and forty thousand foot soldiers, and he also killed Shophach, the commander of the army.
When the servants of Hadarezer saw that they were being defeated by Israel, they made peace with David and became his servants; the Syrians no longer assisted the Ammonites.

And it came to pass that after the year had ended, at the time when kings go out to battle, Joab led the army's forces and devastated the land of the Ammonites, and he besieged Rabbah. However, David remained in Jerusalem. Joab struck Rabbah and destroyed it.

David took the crown of their king from his head and discovered it weighed a talent of gold, adorned with precious stones; it was placed upon David's head. He also brought back an immense amount of plunder from the city.
He brought out the people who were in it and cut them with saws, iron harrows, and axes. Thus, David treated all the cities of the Ammonites. Then David and all the people returned to Jerusalem.
After this, a war arose at Gezer with the Philistines; during this time, Sibbechai the Hushathite killed Sippai, who was one of the descendants of the giants, and they were subdued.
There was another battle with the Philistines, and Elhanan, the son of Jair, killed Lahmi, the brother of Goliath the Gittite, whose spear shaft was like a weaver's beam.
Once again, there was a battle at Gath, where there was a man of great stature, with twenty-four fingers and toes—six on each hand and six on each foot—and he was also a descendant of the giants.
But when he taunted Israel, Jonathan, the son of Shimea, David's brother, killed him.
These were born to the giants in Gath, and they fell by the hand of David and by the hands of his servants.
And Satan rose up against Israel, inciting David to take a census of the people.
David instructed Joab and the leaders of the people, "Go and count Israel from Beersheba to Dan; then report back to me the total number so that I may know it."

Joab replied, "May the LORD increase His people a hundred times more than they are! But, my lord the king, are they not all your servants? Why then does my lord seek this? Why should he bring guilt upon Israel?"
Despite Joab's objections, the king's command prevailed. Consequently, Joab left and traveled throughout all Israel, eventually returning to Jerusalem.
Joab reported the total number of the people to David: there were one million one hundred thousand men who drew the sword in Israel, and four hundred seventy thousand men who drew the sword in Judah.
However, he did not include the tribes of Levi and Benjamin in the count, as the king's command was detestable to Joab.
God was displeased with this action, and as a result, He struck Israel.
David confessed to God, "I have sinned greatly in what I have done. Please, I beg You, remove the guilt of Your servant, for I have acted very foolishly."
The LORD spoke to Gad, David's seer, saying,
"Go and tell David, 'The LORD says: I am offering you three options; choose one of them for Me to carry out.'"
So Gad approached David and said, "The LORD says: Choose one of the following:

Either three years of famine, or three months of being defeated by your enemies while they pursue you, or three days of the sword of the LORD, a plague in the land, and the angel of the LORD destroying throughout all the territory of Israel. Now consider what answer I should give to Him who sent me."
David replied to Gad, "I am in deep distress. Let me fall into the hands of the LORD, for His mercies are very great; but do not let me fall into the hands of men."
So the LORD sent a plague upon Israel, and seventy thousand men of Israel fell.

God sent an angel to Jerusalem to destroy it, but as the angel was about to destroy it, the LORD saw and relented from the calamity, saying to the angel, "It is enough; withdraw your hand." The angel of the LORD stood by the threshing floor of Ornan the Jebusite.

David looked up and saw the angel of the LORD standing between heaven and earth, with a drawn sword in his hand stretched out over Jerusalem. David and the elders of Israel, clothed in sackcloth, fell on their faces.

David said to God, "Was it not I who ordered the census? I am the one who has sinned and acted wickedly; but these sheep, what have they done? O LORD my God, let Your hand be against me and my father's house, but do not let the plague be upon Your people."
Then the angel of the LORD instructed Gad to tell David to go up and build an altar to the LORD on the threshing floor of Ornan the Jebusite.
David went up at Gad's command, which he had spoken in the name of the LORD.
Ornan turned and saw the angel; his four sons who were with him hid themselves, as Ornan was threshing wheat.
When David approached Ornan, he looked and saw David, and he went out from the threshing floor and bowed down to David with his face to the ground.
David said to Ornan, "Let me buy this threshing floor from you at its full price, so that I may build an altar to the LORD there, and the plague may be halted from the people."

Ornan replied to David, "Take it for yourself, and let my lord the king do what is good in his eyes. Here are the oxen for burnt offerings, and the threshing implements for wood, and the wheat for the grain offering; I give it all."
But King David said to Ornan, "No, I insist on paying the full price, for I will not take what is yours for the LORD, nor offer burnt offerings that cost me nothing."
So David paid Ornan six hundred shekels of gold for the site.
David built an altar to the LORD there and offered burnt offerings and peace offerings. He called upon the LORD, and the LORD answered him with fire from heaven on the altar of burnt offering.
The LORD commanded the angel, and he sheathed his sword.
At that time, when David saw that the LORD had answered him on the threshing floor of Ornan the Jebusite, he sacrificed there.
For the tabernacle of the LORD, which Moses had made in the wilderness, and the altar of burnt offering, were at that time in the high place at Gibeon.
But David could not go before it to inquire of God, for he was afraid because of the sword of the angel of the LORD.
Then David said, "This is the house of the LORD God, and this is the altar for the burnt offerings for Israel."
And David commanded that the foreigners in the land of Israel be gathered together; he appointed masons to cut hewn stones for building the house of God.
David prepared an abundance of iron for the nails for the gates and for the joints, and he gathered brass in great quantities without weighing it.
He also collected cedar trees in abundance, for the Zidonians and the Tyrians brought much cedar wood to David.

David said, "Solomon my son is young and inexperienced, and the house that is to be built for the LORD must be exceedingly magnificent, renowned and glorious throughout all countries. Therefore, I will make preparations for it." So David made extensive preparations before his death.
Then he called for his son Solomon and instructed him to build a house for the LORD God of Israel.
David said to Solomon, "My son, it was in my heart to build a house for the name of the LORD my God.

But the word of the LORD came to me, saying, 'You have shed much blood and fought great battles; you shall not build a house for my name, because you have shed so much blood on the earth in my sight.'

Behold, a son will be born to you who will be a man of peace; I will give him rest from all his enemies around him. His name shall be Solomon, and I will grant peace and tranquility to Israel during his reign.
He shall build a house for my name; he will be my son, and I will be his father. I will establish the throne of his kingdom over Israel forever.
Now, my son, may the LORD be with you; may you prosper and build the house of the LORD your God, as He has promised you.
Only may the LORD grant you wisdom and understanding, and may He give you charge concerning Israel, so that you may keep the law of the LORD your God.
Then you will prosper if you take care to fulfill the statutes and judgments which the LORD commanded Moses concerning Israel. Be strong and courageous; do not be afraid or dismayed.

Now, behold, in my distress, I have prepared for the house of the LORD one hundred thousand talents of gold and one million talents of silver, along with brass and iron in such quantities that they cannot be weighed; for they are in abundance. I have also prepared timber and stone, and you may add to them.
Moreover, there are skilled workers with you in abundance, stonecutters and carpenters, and all kinds of craftsmen for every kind of work.
Of the gold, silver, brass, and iron, there is no limit. Arise therefore, and be doing, and may the LORD be with you."
David also commanded all the leaders of Israel to assist his son Solomon, saying,
"Is not the LORD your God with you? Has He not given you rest on every side? For He has delivered the inhabitants of the land into my hand, and the land is subdued before the LORD and His people.

Now set your heart and soul to seek the LORD your God; arise therefore, and build the sanctuary of the LORD God, to bring the ark of the covenant of the LORD and the holy vessels of God into the house that is to be built for the name of the LORD."
When David grew old and had lived a full life, he appointed his son Solomon as king over Israel.
He assembled all the leaders of Israel, along with the priests and the Levites.
The Levites were counted from the age of thirty and above, and their total number was thirty-eight thousand.
Among them, twenty-four thousand were assigned to oversee the work of the house of the LORD, while six thousand served as officers and judges.
Additionally, four thousand were designated as porters, and four thousand praised the LORD with the instruments that David had made for that purpose.
David organized them into divisions among the sons of Levi: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
The Gershonites included Laadan and Shimei.
The sons of Laadan were Jehiel, Zetham, and Joel, three in total.
The sons of Shimei were Shelomith, Haziel, and Haran, three; these were the heads of the families of Laadan.
The sons of Shimei included Jahath, Zina, Jeush, and Beriah; these four were the sons of Shimei.
Jahath was the chief, and Zizah was the second; however, Jeush and Beriah had few sons, so they were counted together with their father's house.
The sons of Kohath were Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel, totaling four.

The sons of Amram were Aaron and Moses; Aaron was set apart to sanctify the most holy things, along with his sons, forever, to burn incense before the LORD, to minister to Him, and to bless in His name forever.
Regarding Moses, the man of God, his sons were from the tribe of Levi.
The sons of Moses were Gershom and Eliezer.
Shebuel was the chief among the sons of Gershom.
The sons of Eliezer included Rehabiah as the chief; Eliezer had no other sons, but the sons of Rehabiah were numerous.
The chief among the sons of Izhar was Shelomith.
The sons of Hebron were Jeriah the first, Amariah the second, Jahaziel the third, and Jekameam the fourth.
The sons of Uzziel were Micah the first and Jesiah the second.
The sons of Merari were Mahli and Mushi; the sons of Mahli were Eleazar and Kish.
Eleazar died and had no sons, only daughters, and their brothers, the sons of Kish, took them as wives.
The sons of Mushi were Mahli, Eder, and Jeremoth, totaling three.

These were the sons of Levi according to their family houses, the heads of the families, counted by name and number, who performed the work for the service of the house of the LORD, from the age of twenty and above.
David declared, "The LORD God of Israel has granted rest to His people, allowing them to dwell in Jerusalem forever."
He also stated that the Levites would no longer carry the tabernacle or any of its vessels for service.
By David's final instructions, the Levites were counted from the age of twenty and above.
Their role was to assist the sons of Aaron in the service of the house of the LORD, in the courts, chambers, and in the purification of all holy things, as well as in the work of the house of God.
This included responsibilities for the showbread, fine flour for grain offerings, unleavened cakes, baked goods, fried items, and all manner of measurements and sizes.
They were to stand every morning to give thanks and praise to the LORD, and likewise in the evening.
They were to offer all burnt sacrifices to the LORD on the sabbaths, new moons, and set feasts, according to the prescribed order, continually before the LORD.
They were also to maintain the charge of the tabernacle of the congregation, the holy place, and the duties of the sons of Aaron, their brethren, in the service of the house of the LORD.
Now these are the divisions of the sons of Aaron: the sons of Aaron were Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
But Nadab and Abihu died before their father and had no children; therefore, Eleazar and Ithamar executed the priest's office.
And David distributed them, both Zadok of the sons of Eleazar and Ahimelech of the sons of Ithamar, according to their offices in their service.

There were more chief men found among the sons of Eleazar than among the sons of Ithamar, and thus they were divided. Among the sons of Eleazar, there were sixteen chief men of the house of their fathers, and eight among the sons of Ithamar according to the house of their fathers.
Thus they were divided by lot, one sort with another; for the governors of the sanctuary and the governors of the house of God were of the sons of Eleazar and of the sons of Ithamar.

And Shemaiah the son of Nethaneel the scribe, one of the Levites, wrote them before the king, the princes, Zadok the priest, Ahimelech the son of Abiathar, and before the chief of the fathers of the priests and Levites: one principal household was taken for Eleazar, and one was taken for Ithamar.
Now the first lot came forth to Jehoiarib, the second to Jedaiah,
the third to Harim, the fourth to Seorim,
the fifth to Malchijah, the sixth to Mijamin,
the seventh to Hakkoz, the eighth to Abijah,
the ninth to Jeshuah, the tenth to Shecaniah,
the eleventh to Eliashib, the twelfth to Jakim,
the thirteenth to Huppah, the fourteenth to Jeshebeab,
the fifteenth to Bilgah, the sixteenth to Immer,
the seventeenth to Hezir, the eighteenth to Aphses,
the nineteenth to Pethahiah, the twentieth to Jehezekel,
the one and twentieth to Jachin, the two and twentieth to Gamul,
the three and twentieth to Delaiah, the four and twentieth to Maaziah.
These were the orderings of them in their service to come into the house of the LORD, according to their manner, under Aaron their father, as the LORD God of Israel had commanded him.
And the rest of the sons of Levi were these: of the sons of Amram, Shubael; of the sons of Shubael, Jehdeiah.
Concerning Rehabiah: of the sons of Rehabiah, the first was Isshiah.
Of the Izharites, Shelomoth; of the sons of Shelomoth, Jahath.
And the sons of Hebron were Jeriah the first, Amariah the second, Jahaziel the third, and Jekameam the fourth.
Of the sons of Uzziel, Michah; of the sons of Michah, Shamir.
The brother of Michah was Isshiah; of the sons of Isshiah, Zechariah.
The sons of Merari were Mahli and Mushi; the sons of Jaaziah were Beno.
The sons of Merari by Jaaziah were Beno, Shoham, Zaccur, and Ibri.
Of Mahli came Eleazar, who had no sons.
Concerning Kish: the son of Kish was Jerahmeel.
The sons also of Mushi were Mahli, Eder, and Jerimoth. These were the sons of the Levites after the house of their fathers.

These likewise cast lots against their brethren, the sons of Aaron, in the presence of David the king, Zadok, Ahimelech, and the chief of the fathers of the priests and Levites, even the principal fathers against their younger brethren.

Moreover, David and the captains of the host separated for the service of the sons of Asaph, Heman, and Jeduthun, who were to prophesy with harps, psalteries, and cymbals. The number of the workmen according to their service was as follows:
Of the sons of Asaph: Zaccur, Joseph, Nethaniah, and Asarelah, the sons of Asaph, under the leadership of Asaph, who prophesied according to the king's order.

Of Jeduthun: the sons of Jeduthun were Gedaliah, Zeri, Jeshaiah, Hashabiah, and Mattithiah, six in total, under the guidance of their father Jeduthun, who prophesied with a harp to give thanks and praise to the LORD.
Of Heman: the sons of Heman included Bukkiah, Mattaniah, Uzziel, Shebuel, Jerimoth, Hananiah, Hanani, Eliathah, Giddalti, Romamtiezer, Joshbekashah, Mallothi, Hothir, and Mahazioth.
All these were the sons of Heman, the king's seer in the words of God, to lift up the horn. God granted Heman fourteen sons and three daughters.

All these were under the guidance of their father for song in the house of the LORD, with cymbals, psalteries, and harps, for the service of the house of God, according to the king's order to Asaph, Jeduthun, and Heman.
Thus, the total number of them, along with their brethren who were skilled in the songs of the LORD, amounted to two hundred eighty-eight.
They cast lots, ward against ward, both small and great, teacher and scholar alike.
The first lot came forth for Asaph to Joseph; the second for Gedaliah, who, with his brethren and sons, totaled twelve.
The third lot was for Zaccur; he, his sons, and his brethren also numbered twelve.
The fourth lot was for Izri; he, his sons, and his brethren were twelve.
The fifth lot was for Nethaniah; he, his sons, and his brethren were twelve.
The sixth lot was for Bukkiah; he, his sons, and his brethren were twelve.
The seventh lot was for Jesharelah; he, his sons, and his brethren were twelve.
The eighth lot was for Jeshaiah; he, his sons, and his brethren were twelve.
The ninth lot was for Mattaniah; he, his sons, and his brethren were twelve.
The tenth lot was for Shimei; he, his sons, and his brethren were twelve.
The eleventh lot was for Azareel; he, his sons, and his brethren were twelve.
The twelfth lot was for Hashabiah; he, his sons, and his brethren were twelve.
The thirteenth lot was for Shubael; he, his sons, and his brethren were twelve.
The fourteenth lot was for Mattithiah; he, his sons, and his brethren were twelve.
The fifteenth lot was for Jeremoth; he, his sons, and his brethren were twelve.
The sixteenth lot was for Hananiah; he, his sons, and his brethren were twelve.
The seventeenth lot was for Joshbekashah; he, his sons, and his brethren were twelve.
The eighteenth lot was for Hanani; he, his sons, and his brethren were twelve.
The nineteenth lot was for Mallothi; he, his sons, and his brethren were twelve.
The twentieth lot was for Eliathah; he, his sons, and his brethren were twelve.
The twenty-first lot was for Hothir; he, his sons, and his brethren were twelve.
The twenty-second lot was for Giddalti; he, his sons, and his brethren were twelve.
The twenty-third lot was for Mahazioth; he, his sons, and his brethren were twelve.
The twenty-fourth lot was for Romamtiezer; he, his sons, and his brethren were twelve.
Concerning the divisions of the porters: Meshelemiah, the son of Kore, was of the Korhites, and he was among the sons of Asaph.
The sons of Meshelemiah included Zechariah the firstborn, Jediael the second, Zebadiah the third, and Jathniel the fourth.
Elam was the fifth, Jehohanan the sixth, and Elioenai the seventh.
The sons of Obededom were Shemaiah the firstborn, Jehozabad the second, Joah the third, Sacar the fourth, and Nethaneel the fifth.
Ammiel was the sixth, Issachar the seventh, and Peulthai the eighth, for God blessed him.
Shemaiah, his son, had sons who ruled in their father's house, for they were mighty men of valor.
The sons of Shemaiah were Othni, Rephael, Obed, and Elzabad, whose brothers were strong men: Elihu and Semachiah.
All these were the sons of Obededom; they, along with their sons and brothers, were capable men, totaling sixty-two of Obededom.
Meshelemiah had sons and brothers who were strong men, numbering eighteen.
Hosah, of the children of Merari, also had sons: Simri the chief (though he was not the firstborn, his father made him chief),
Hilkiah was the second, Tebaliah the third, and Zechariah the fourth; all the sons and brothers of Hosah totaled thirteen.
Among these were the divisions of the porters, including the chief men, who had wards opposite one another to minister in the house of the LORD.
They cast lots, both small and great, according to the houses of their fathers, for every gate.
The lot for the eastward gate fell to Shelemiah. For Zechariah, his wise son, they cast lots, and his lot came out for the northward gate.
Obededom received the southward lot, and to his sons was assigned the house of Asuppim.
The lot for Shuppim and Hosah came forth for the westward gate, with the gate Shallecheth, by the causeway of the ascent, ward against ward.
Eastward, there were six Levites; northward, four each day; southward, four each day; and toward Asuppim, two and two.
At Parbar westward, there were four at the causeway and two at Parbar.
These are the divisions of the porters among the sons of Kore and the sons of Merari.
Of the Levites, Ahijah was in charge of the treasures of the house of God and the treasures of the dedicated things.
Regarding the sons of Laadan, the chief fathers of the Gershonite Laadan were Jehieli.
The sons of Jehieli were Zetham and Joel, his brother, who were in charge of the treasures of the house of the LORD.
Among the Amramites, Izharites, Hebronites, and Uzzielites:
Shebuel, the son of Gershom, the son of Moses, was the ruler of the treasures.
His brothers by Eliezer were Rehabiah, Jeshaiah, Joram, Zichri, and Shelomith.

Shelomith and his brothers were responsible for all the treasures of the dedicated things, which King David, the chief fathers, the captains over thousands and hundreds, and the captains of the host had dedicated.
They dedicated from the spoils won in battles to maintain the house of the LORD.
All that Samuel the seer, Saul the son of Kish, Abner the son of Ner, and Joab the son of Zeruiah had dedicated was under the oversight of Shelomith and his brothers.
Among the Izharites, Chenaniah and his sons were responsible for the outward business over Israel, serving as officers and judges.

Among the Hebronites, Hashabiah and his brothers, valiant men numbering one thousand seven hundred, served as officers among the Israelites on this side of the Jordan, westward, in all matters of the LORD and in the service of the king.

Among the Hebronites, Jerijah was the chief, according to the generations of his fathers. In the fortieth year of King David's reign, they were sought out and found to be mighty men of valor at Jazer of Gilead.

His brothers, valiant men, numbered two thousand seven hundred chief fathers, whom King David appointed as rulers over the Reubenites, the Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh, for all matters pertaining to God and the affairs of the king.

The children of Israel were counted, including the chief fathers, captains of thousands and hundreds, and their officers who served the king in various capacities. Each month, throughout the entire year, there were twenty-four thousand in every course.
In the first month, Jashobeam the son of Zabdiel was over the first course, which also consisted of twenty-four thousand.
The chief of all the captains for the first month was from the children of Perez.
In the second month, Dodai the Ahohite was in charge, with Mikloth as the ruler of his course, which also had twenty-four thousand.
Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, a chief priest, was the third captain for the third month, and his course also included twenty-four thousand.
This Benaiah was renowned among the thirty and even above them, and his son Ammizabad was part of his course.
Asahel, the brother of Joab, was the fourth captain for the fourth month, followed by his son Zebadiah, and their course also had twenty-four thousand.
Shamhuth the Izrahite was the fifth captain for the fifth month, and his course also consisted of twenty-four thousand.
Ira the son of Ikkesh the Tekoite was the sixth captain for the sixth month, and his course also included twenty-four thousand.
Helez the Pelonite, from the children of Ephraim, was the seventh captain for the seventh month, and his course also had twenty-four thousand.
Sibbecai the Hushathite, from the Zarhites, was the eighth captain for the eighth month, and his course also consisted of twenty-four thousand.
Abiezer the Anetothite, from the Benjamites, was the ninth captain for the ninth month, and his course also included twenty-four thousand.
Maharai the Netophathite, from the Zarhites, was the tenth captain for the tenth month, and his course also had twenty-four thousand.
Benaiah the Pirathonite, from the children of Ephraim, was the eleventh captain for the eleventh month, and his course also consisted of twenty-four thousand.
Heldai the Netophathite, from Othniel, was the twelfth captain for the twelfth month, and his course also included twenty-four thousand.
Additionally, the rulers over the tribes of Israel were as follows: Eliezer the son of Zichri for the Reubenites, and Shephatiah the son of Maachah for the Simeonites.
For the Levites, Hashabiah the son of Kemuel was in charge, and for the Aaronites, it was Zadok.
Elihu, a brother of David, was the ruler for Judah, while Omri the son of Michael represented Issachar.
Ishmaiah the son of Obadiah was the ruler for Zebulun, and Jerimoth the son of Azriel for Naphtali.
Hoshea the son of Azaziah was in charge of the children of Ephraim, and Joel the son of Pedaiah represented the half tribe of Manasseh.
Iddo the son of Zechariah was the ruler for the half tribe of Manasseh in Gilead, and Jaasiel the son of Abner for Benjamin.
Azareel the son of Jeroham was the ruler for Dan. These were the princes of the tribes of Israel.
However, David did not count those twenty years old and under, as the LORD had declared He would increase Israel like the stars in the heavens.
Joab the son of Zeruiah began the numbering but did not complete it, as there was wrath against Israel for this; thus, the number was not included in the chronicles of King David.
Azmaveth the son of Adiel was in charge of the king's treasures, while Jehonathan the son of Uzziah oversaw the storehouses in the fields, cities, villages, and castles.
Ezri the son of Chelub was responsible for those working the fields for tillage.
Shimei the Ramathite was in charge of the vineyards, and Zabdi the Shiphmite managed the increase of the vineyards for the wine cellars.
Baalhanan the Gederite oversaw the olive and sycamore trees in the low plains, while Joash was in charge of the oil cellars.
Shitrai the Sharonite managed the herds feeding in Sharon, and Shaphat the son of Adlai oversaw the herds in the valleys.
Obil the Ishmaelite was responsible for the camels, and Jehdeiah the Meronothite managed the donkeys.
Jaziz the Hagerite was in charge of the flocks. All these were the rulers of the resources belonging to King David.
Jonathan, David's uncle, served as a counselor, a wise man, and a scribe, alongside Jehiel the son of Hachmoni, who was with the king's sons.
Ahithophel was the king's counselor, and Hushai the Archite was the king's companion.
Following Ahithophel were Jehoiada the son of Benaiah and Abiathar, while Joab was the general of the king's army.

And David gathered all the leaders of Israel, including the tribal leaders, the captains of the divisions that served the king in rotation, the commanders of thousands, the commanders of hundreds, the stewards of all the king's possessions and those of his sons, along with the officers, the mighty warriors, and all the valiant men, to Jerusalem.

Then King David stood up and addressed his brethren and his people: "Listen to me, my brothers and my people: I had it in my heart to build a resting place for the ark of the covenant of the LORD and for the footstool of our God, and I had made preparations for the construction.
But God said to me, 'You shall not build a house for my name, for you have been a man of war and have shed blood.'

Nevertheless, the LORD God of Israel chose me from all my father's house to be king over Israel forever; for He has chosen Judah to be the ruler, and from the house of Judah, the house of my father; and among my father's sons, He chose me to be king over all Israel.
Of all my sons (for the LORD has given me many), He has chosen my son Solomon to sit on the throne of the kingdom of the LORD over Israel.
He said to me, 'Your son Solomon shall build my house and my courts, for I have chosen him to be my son, and I will be his father.'
Moreover, I will establish his kingdom forever, if he remains steadfast in keeping my commandments and my judgments, as he does today.

Now, therefore, in the sight of all Israel, the congregation of the LORD, and in the presence of our God, keep and seek all the commandments of the LORD your God, so that you may possess this good land and leave it as an inheritance for your children forever.

And you, Solomon my son, know the God of your father and serve Him with a perfect heart and a willing mind; for the LORD searches all hearts and understands all the imaginations of the thoughts. If you seek Him, He will be found by you; but if you forsake Him, He will cast you off forever.
Take heed now, for the LORD has chosen you to build a house for the sanctuary; be strong and do it.
Then David provided Solomon, his son, with the blueprint for the porch, the houses, the treasuries, the upper chambers, the inner rooms, and the place of the mercy seat,

as well as the design of everything he had in mind for the courts of the house of the LORD, and for all the surrounding chambers, the treasuries of the house of God, and the treasuries for the dedicated gifts.
He also provided for the divisions of the priests and the Levites, and for all the work of the service of the house of the LORD, and for all the vessels used in the service of the house of the LORD.
He gave gold by weight for the items made of gold, for all instruments of every kind of service; silver also by weight for all instruments of silver used in service.

He specified the weight for the gold candlesticks and their lamps, by weight for each candlestick and its lamps; and for the silver candlesticks by weight, both for the candlestick and for its lamps, according to the use of each candlestick.
He also provided gold by weight for the tables of showbread, for each table, and likewise silver for the tables of silver.
He provided pure gold for the fleshhooks, the bowls, and the cups; and for the golden basins, he gave gold by weight for each basin, and likewise silver by weight for each silver basin.
He provided refined gold by weight for the altar of incense, and gold for the design of the chariot of the cherubim that spread their wings and covered the ark of the covenant of the LORD.
David said, "All this the LORD made me understand in writing by His hand upon me, even all the works of this pattern."

And David said to Solomon his son, "Be strong and courageous, and do it; do not be afraid or dismayed, for the LORD God, even my God, will be with you; He will not fail you or forsake you until you have finished all the work for the service of the house of the LORD.

And behold, the divisions of the priests and the Levites will be with you for all the service of the house of God; and every skilled man who is willing to work will be at your command, along with the princes and all the people who will be entirely at your disposal."

Furthermore, King David addressed the entire congregation, saying, "Solomon, my son, whom God has chosen, is still young and inexperienced, and the task ahead is significant: for the palace is not for man, but for the LORD God.

I have prepared with all my strength for the house of my God: the gold for items made of gold, the silver for items made of silver, the bronze for items made of bronze, the iron for items made of iron, and the wood for items made of wood; onyx stones, and stones to be set, sparkling stones of various colors, and all kinds of precious stones, along with an abundance of marble.

Moreover, because I have devoted my heart to the house of my God, I have given from my own resources, gold and silver, which I have contributed to the house of my God, in addition to all that I have prepared for the holy house.
This includes three thousand talents of gold from the gold of Ophir, and seven thousand talents of refined silver, to overlay the walls of the buildings.

The gold for items made of gold, and the silver for items made of silver, and for all kinds of work to be done by the hands of craftsmen. So who is willing to dedicate their service today to the LORD?
Then the leaders of the families, the princes of the tribes of Israel, the captains of thousands and hundreds, along with the rulers of the king's work, offered willingly,

And contributed for the service of the house of God: five thousand talents of gold and ten thousand darics, ten thousand talents of silver, eighteen thousand talents of bronze, and one hundred thousand talents of iron.
And those who had precious stones gave them to the treasury of the house of the LORD, through the hand of Jehiel the Gershonite.
Then the people rejoiced, for they had offered willingly, and with a perfect heart they had given to the LORD; and King David also rejoiced greatly.
Therefore, David blessed the LORD in the presence of all the congregation, and he said, "Blessed are you, LORD God of Israel our father, forever and ever.

Yours, O LORD, is the greatness, the power, the glory, the victory, and the majesty; for all that is in heaven and on earth is yours; yours is the kingdom, O LORD, and you are exalted as head over all.
Both riches and honor come from you, and you reign over all; in your hand are power and might; it is in your hand to make great and to give strength to all.
Now, therefore, our God, we thank you and praise your glorious name.
But who am I, and what is my people, that we should be able to offer so willingly in this manner? For all things come from you, and of your own have we given you.
For we are strangers before you, and sojourners, as were all our ancestors; our days on earth are like a shadow, and there is no permanence.
O LORD our God, all this abundance that we have prepared to build you a house for your holy name comes from your hand, and is all your own.

I know also, my God, that you test the heart and take pleasure in uprightness. As for me, in the integrity of my heart I have willingly offered all these things; and now I have seen with joy your people, who are present here, offering willingly to you.
O LORD God of Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, our ancestors, keep this forever in the thoughts and intentions of the hearts of your people, and prepare their hearts toward you.
And give my son Solomon a perfect heart, to keep your commandments, your testimonies, and your statutes, and to do all these things, and to build the palace for which I have made provision.
And David said to all the congregation, "Now bless the LORD your God." And all the congregation blessed the LORD God of their ancestors, and bowed their heads and worshiped the LORD and the king.

And they sacrificed offerings to the LORD, and offered burnt offerings to the LORD the day after that, a thousand bullocks, a thousand rams, and a thousand lambs, with their drink offerings, and sacrifices in abundance for all Israel.
And they ate and drank before the LORD on that day with great joy. And they made Solomon the son of David king a second time, and anointed him to be the chief governor, and Zadok to be priest.
Then Solomon sat on the throne of the LORD as king in place of his father David, and prospered; and all Israel obeyed him.
All the princes, the mighty men, and all the sons of King David likewise submitted themselves to King Solomon.
And the LORD magnified Solomon exceedingly in the sight of all Israel, and bestowed upon him such royal majesty as had not been on any king before him in Israel.
Thus, David the son of Jesse reigned over all Israel.
The duration of his reign over Israel was forty years; he reigned seven years in Hebron, and thirty-three years in Jerusalem.
