He died at a good old age, full of days, riches, and honor; and his son Solomon reigned in his place.
Now the acts of King David, from beginning to end, are written in the book of Samuel the seer, in the book of Nathan the prophet, and in the book of Gad the seer,
With all his reign and his might, and the events that transpired during his time, over Israel, and over all the kingdoms of the countries."
And Solomon, the son of David, was strengthened in his kingdom; the LORD his God was with him and greatly magnified him.
Then Solomon spoke to all Israel, to the captains of thousands and hundreds, to the judges, and to every governor in all Israel, the leaders of the families.

So Solomon, along with the entire congregation, went to the high place at Gibeon, for there was the tabernacle of the congregation of God, which Moses, the servant of the LORD, had made in the wilderness.
However, David had brought the ark of God up from Kirjath-jearim to the place he had prepared for it, having pitched a tent for it in Jerusalem.
Additionally, the bronze altar that Bezaleel, the son of Uri, the son of Hur, had made was placed before the tabernacle of the LORD, and Solomon and the congregation sought guidance from it.
And Solomon went up to the bronze altar before the LORD, which was at the tabernacle of the congregation, and offered a thousand burnt offerings on it.
That night, God appeared to Solomon and said to him, "Ask what I shall give you."
And Solomon replied to God, "You have shown great mercy to David my father and have made me reign in his place."
Now, O LORD God, let your promise to David my father be established, for you have made me king over a people as numerous as the dust of the earth.
Give me wisdom and knowledge now, that I may go out and come in before this people; for who can judge this great people of yours?

And God said to Solomon, "Because this was in your heart, and you have not asked for riches, wealth, or honor, nor for the life of your enemies, nor have you asked for long life, but have asked for wisdom and knowledge for yourself, that you may judge my people over whom I have made you king:
Wisdom and knowledge are granted to you; and I will give you riches, wealth, and honor, such as none of the kings before you have had, nor shall any after you have the like."
Then Solomon returned from his journey to the high place at Gibeon to Jerusalem, from before the tabernacle of the congregation, and reigned over Israel.
And Solomon gathered chariots and horsemen; he had fourteen hundred chariots and twelve thousand horsemen, which he stationed in the chariot cities and with the king in Jerusalem.
The king made silver and gold in Jerusalem as plentiful as stones, and he made cedar trees as abundant as the sycamore trees in the lowland.
And Solomon imported horses from Egypt and linen yarn; the king's merchants received the linen yarn at a price.

They brought up a chariot from Egypt for six hundred shekels of silver and a horse for one hundred and fifty; and they exported horses for all the kings of the Hittites and for the kings of Syria through their agents.
And Solomon resolved to construct a house for the name of the LORD, as well as a palace for his kingdom.
Solomon assigned seventy thousand men to carry burdens, eighty thousand to quarry stone in the mountains, and three thousand six hundred to supervise them.
He sent a message to Huram, the king of Tyre, saying, "Just as you assisted my father David by sending him cedars to build a house for him to dwell in, please do the same for me."

"Behold, I am building a house for the name of the LORD my God, to dedicate it to Him, to burn sweet incense before Him, to provide the continual showbread, and to offer burnt offerings morning and evening, on the sabbaths, on the new moons, and on the solemn feasts of the LORD our God. This is an everlasting ordinance for Israel."
"The house I am building is great, for our God is greater than all gods."

"But who is capable of building Him a house, considering that the heavens and the highest heavens cannot contain Him? Who am I, then, that I should build Him a house, except to offer sacrifices before Him?"

"Therefore, send me a skilled man who can work with gold, silver, brass, iron, purple, crimson, and blue, and who can engrave with the skilled artisans who are with me in Judah and Jerusalem, whom my father David provided."
"Also, send me cedar trees, fir trees, and algum trees from Lebanon, for I know that your servants are skilled in cutting timber in Lebanon; and my servants will work alongside yours."
"This will ensure that I have an abundant supply of timber, for the house I am about to build will be extraordinarily great."

"Furthermore, I will provide your servants, the woodcutters, with twenty thousand measures of beaten wheat, twenty thousand measures of barley, twenty thousand baths of wine, and twenty thousand baths of oil."
Then Huram, the king of Tyre, responded in writing to Solomon, saying, "Because the LORD has loved His people, He has made you king over them."

Huram continued, "Blessed be the LORD God of Israel, who made heaven and earth, and who has given David the king a wise son, endowed with prudence and understanding, to build a house for the LORD and a palace for his kingdom."
"And now I have sent you a skilled man, endowed with understanding, from Huram my father."

"He is the son of a woman from the daughters of Dan, and his father is a man of Tyre, skilled in working with gold, silver, brass, iron, stone, timber, purple, blue, fine linen, and crimson; he is also capable of engraving any design and finding out every device that may be required, along with your skilled artisans and those of my lord David your father."
"Now, concerning the wheat, barley, oil, and wine that my lord has mentioned, let him send them to his servants."
"We will cut wood from Lebanon as much as you need, and we will transport it to you in rafts by sea to Joppa, and you can then carry it up to Jerusalem."
Solomon counted all the foreigners in the land of Israel, following the census that David his father had conducted, and they were found to number one hundred fifty-three thousand six hundred.
He appointed seventy thousand of them as bearers of burdens, eighty thousand as stonecutters in the mountains, and three thousand six hundred overseers to manage the work.

Then Solomon commenced the construction of the house of the LORD in Jerusalem on Mount Moriah, where the Lord had appeared to his father David, at the site that David had prepared on the threshing floor of Ornan the Jebusite.
He began the building on the second day of the second month in the fourth year of his reign.

These are the specifications that Solomon received for the construction of the house of God: the length, measured in cubits according to the first standard, was sixty cubits, and the width was twenty cubits.
The porch at the front of the house was designed to match the width of the house, measuring twenty cubits in length and one hundred and twenty cubits in height; he adorned it inside with pure gold.
The larger room was paneled with fir wood, which he covered with fine gold, and he decorated it with palm trees and chains.
He embellished the house with precious stones for beauty, and the gold used was from Parvaim.
He also covered the house, including the beams, posts, walls, and doors, with gold, and engraved cherubim on the walls.
He constructed the most holy place, which measured twenty cubits in length and twenty cubits in width, and he overlaid it with fine gold, totaling six hundred talents.
The weight of the nails was fifty shekels of gold, and he covered the upper chambers with gold as well.
In the most holy place, he crafted two cherubim from carved work and overlaid them with gold.

The wings of the cherubim were each twenty cubits long: one wing of one cherub measured five cubits, reaching to the wall of the house, and the other wing was also five cubits, extending to the wing of the other cherub.
One wing of the other cherub was five cubits, reaching to the wall of the house, and its other wing was also five cubits, connecting to the wing of the first cherub.
The wings of these cherubim extended outward, measuring twenty cubits, and they stood on their feet, facing inward.
He made the veil of blue, purple, crimson, and fine linen, and embroidered cherubim on it.
Additionally, he constructed two pillars in front of the house, each thirty-five cubits high, with a five-cubit chapiter atop each.
He created chains, similar to those in the oracle, and placed them on the tops of the pillars; he made one hundred pomegranates and attached them to the chains.
He erected the pillars in front of the temple, one on the right and the other on the left, naming the one on the right Jachin and the one on the left Boaz.
Moreover, he constructed an altar of brass, measuring twenty cubits in length, twenty cubits in breadth, and ten cubits in height.
He also created a molten sea, ten cubits from brim to brim, round in circumference, and five cubits in height; a line of thirty cubits encircled it.
Beneath it was the likeness of oxen, which surrounded it: ten in a cubit, encircling the sea. Two rows of oxen were cast during its creation.
It rested upon twelve oxen, three facing north, three facing west, three facing south, and three facing east; the sea was positioned above them, with all their hind parts inward.
Its thickness was a handbreadth, and the brim resembled the work of a cup, adorned with lily flowers; it received and held three thousand baths.

He also made ten lavers, placing five on the right side and five on the left for washing; the offerings for the burnt offering were washed in them, while the sea was designated for the priests to wash in.
He crafted ten candlesticks of gold according to their design and positioned them in the temple, five on the right side and five on the left.
Additionally, he made ten tables and arranged them in the temple, five on the right side and five on the left, and he created one hundred basins of gold.
Furthermore, he constructed the court of the priests, the great court, and doors for the court, overlaying the doors with brass.
He placed the sea on the right side of the east end, opposite the south.
Huram made the pots, shovels, and basins, completing the work he was assigned for King Solomon for the house of God;
Specifically, the two pillars, the pommels, and the chapiters atop the two pillars, along with the two wreaths to cover the pommels of the chapiters on the pillars;
And four hundred pomegranates on the two wreaths, with two rows of pomegranates on each wreath to cover the pommels of the chapiters on the pillars.
He also made bases and lavers upon the bases;
One sea, supported by twelve oxen beneath it.
The pots, shovels, fleshhooks, and all their instruments were crafted by Huram, his father, for King Solomon for the house of the LORD from bright brass.
In the plain of Jordan, the king cast them in the clay ground between Succoth and Zeredathah.
Thus, Solomon made all these vessels in great abundance, as the weight of the brass could not be determined.
Solomon also made all the vessels for the house of God, including the golden altar and the tables for the showbread;
Moreover, the candlesticks with their lamps were made to burn in the manner before the oracle, crafted from pure gold;
He made the flowers, lamps, and tongs of gold, all of perfect quality;
And the snuffers, basins, spoons, and censers were made of pure gold; the entry of the house, the inner doors for the most holy place, and the doors of the temple were also made of gold.

Thus, all the work that Solomon completed for the house of the LORD was finished. Solomon brought in all the items that his father David had dedicated, including the silver, gold, and all the instruments, and placed them among the treasures of the house of God.

Then Solomon gathered the elders of Israel, along with all the heads of the tribes and the leaders of the families of the children of Israel, in Jerusalem to bring up the ark of the covenant of the LORD from the city of David, which is Zion.
Therefore, all the men of Israel assembled before the king for the feast that took place in the seventh month.
All the elders of Israel came, and the Levites carried the ark.
They brought up the ark, the tabernacle of the congregation, and all the holy vessels that were in the tabernacle; these were brought up by the priests and the Levites.
King Solomon, along with the entire congregation of Israel that had gathered before the ark, sacrificed sheep and oxen, which could not be counted or numbered due to their multitude.
The priests brought the ark of the covenant of the LORD to its designated place, to the oracle of the house, in the most holy place, beneath the wings of the cherubim.
The cherubim spread their wings over the place of the ark, covering the ark and its poles from above.
They drew out the poles of the ark so that the ends of the poles were visible from the ark in front of the oracle, but they were not visible outside. And it remains that way to this day.
There was nothing in the ark except for the two tablets that Moses placed inside at Horeb, when the LORD made a covenant with the children of Israel as they came out of Egypt.
When the priests came out of the holy place, (for all the priests present had been sanctified and did not wait by course),

The Levites, who were the singers, all from Asaph, Heman, and Jeduthun, along with their sons and brothers, dressed in white linen and carrying cymbals, psalteries, and harps, stood at the east end of the altar, accompanied by one hundred and twenty priests sounding trumpets.

It came to pass that as the trumpeters and singers united to make one sound in praising and thanking the LORD, and when they lifted their voices with trumpets, cymbals, and musical instruments, praising the LORD and saying, "For He is good; for His mercy endures forever," the house was filled with a cloud, even the house of the LORD.
So much so that the priests could not stand to minister because of the cloud, for the glory of the LORD had filled the house of God.
Then Solomon said, "The LORD has declared that He would dwell in thick darkness.
But I have built a house of habitation for You, and a place for Your dwelling forever.
And the king turned his face and blessed the entire congregation of Israel; all the congregation of Israel stood.
He said, "Blessed be the LORD God of Israel, who has fulfilled with His hands what He spoke with His mouth to my father David, saying,

'Since the day I brought my people out of the land of Egypt, I chose no city among all the tribes of Israel to build a house in, that my name might be there; nor did I choose any man to be a ruler over my people Israel.
But I have chosen Jerusalem, that my name might be there; and I have chosen David to be over my people Israel.'
Now it was in the heart of my father David to build a house for the name of the LORD God of Israel.
But the LORD said to my father David, 'Because it was in your heart to build a house for my name, you did well that it was in your heart.
Nevertheless, you shall not build the house; your son, who shall come from your loins, he shall build the house for my name.'

The LORD has therefore performed His word that He spoke: for I have risen up in the place of my father David and am set on the throne of Israel, as the LORD promised, and have built the house for the name of the LORD God of Israel.
And in it, I have placed the ark, which contains the covenant of the LORD that He made with the children of Israel.
He stood before the altar of the LORD in the presence of all the congregation of Israel and spread forth his hands.

For Solomon had made a bronze scaffold five cubits long, five cubits wide, and three cubits high, and had set it in the midst of the court; upon it, he stood, knelt down before all the congregation of Israel, and spread forth his hands toward heaven.
And he said, 'O LORD God of Israel, there is no God like You in heaven or on earth; You keep covenant and show mercy to Your servants who walk before You with all their hearts.
You who have kept with Your servant David my father what You promised him; You spoke with Your mouth and have fulfilled it with Your hand, as it is this day.

Now therefore, O LORD God of Israel, keep with Your servant David my father what You promised him, saying, 'There shall not fail you a man in my sight to sit upon the throne of Israel; provided that your children take heed to their way to walk in my law, as you have walked before me.'
Now then, O LORD God of Israel, let Your word be confirmed, which You have spoken to Your servant David.
But will God indeed dwell with men on the earth? Behold, heaven and the heaven of heavens cannot contain You; how much less this house which I have built!
Therefore, have respect to the prayer of Your servant and to his supplication, O LORD my God, to listen to the cry and the prayer which Your servant prays before You:
That Your eyes may be open upon this house day and night, upon the place of which You have said that You would put Your name there; to listen to the prayer which Your servant prays toward this place.
Listen therefore to the supplications of Your servant and of Your people Israel, which they shall make toward this place; hear from Your dwelling place, even from heaven; and when You hear, forgive.
If a man sins against his neighbor, and an oath is laid upon him to make him swear, and the oath comes before Your altar in this house;
Then hear from heaven and act, and judge Your servants, by requiting the wicked, by bringing his way upon his own head; and by justifying the righteous, by giving him according to his righteousness.
And if Your people Israel are defeated before the enemy because they have sinned against You; and they return and confess Your name, and pray and make supplication before You in this house;
Then hear from heaven and forgive the sin of Your people Israel, and bring them back to the land which You gave to them and to their fathers.
When heaven is shut up and there is no rain because they have sinned against You; yet if they pray toward this place, and confess Your name, and turn from their sin when You afflict them;

Then hear from heaven and forgive the sin of Your servants and of Your people Israel, when You have taught them the good way in which they should walk; and send rain upon Your land, which You have given to Your people for an inheritance.

If there is famine in the land, if there is pestilence, if there is blight or mildew, locusts, or caterpillars; if their enemies besiege them in the cities of their land; whatever sore or sickness there is:
Then whatever prayer or supplication shall be made by any man, or by all Your people Israel, when everyone knows his own sore and his own grief, and spreads forth his hands in this house:
Then hear from heaven Your dwelling place, and forgive, and render to every man according to all his ways, whose heart You know; (for You alone know the hearts of the children of men:)
That they may fear You, to walk in Your ways, as long as they live in the land which You gave to our fathers.

Moreover, concerning the stranger who is not of Your people Israel, but has come from a far country for Your great name's sake, and Your mighty hand, and Your outstretched arm; if they come and pray in this house;

Then hear from the heavens, even from Your dwelling place, and do according to all that the stranger calls to You for; that all the peoples of the earth may know Your name and fear You, as does Your people Israel, and may know that this house which I have built is called by Your name.
If Your people go out to war against their enemies by the way that You send them, and they pray to You toward this city which You have chosen, and the house which I have built for Your name;
Then hear from the heavens their prayer and their supplication, and maintain their cause.
If they sin against You, (for there is no man who does not sin,) and You become angry with them, and deliver them over to their enemies, and they carry them away captive to a land far off or near;

Yet if they come to themselves in the land where they are carried captive, and turn and pray to You in the land of their captivity, saying, 'We have sinned, we have done wrong, and have acted wickedly;'

If they return to You with all their heart and with all their soul in the land of their captivity, where they have been taken captive, and pray toward their land, which You gave to their fathers, and toward the city which You have chosen, and toward the house which I have built for Your name:
Then hear from the heavens, even from Your dwelling place, their prayer and their supplications, and maintain their cause, and forgive Your people who have sinned against You.
Now, my God, let, I beseech You, Your eyes be open, and let Your ears be attentive to the prayer that is made in this place.
Now therefore arise, O LORD God, into Your resting place, You, and the ark of Your strength; let Your priests, O LORD God, be clothed with salvation, and let Your saints rejoice in goodness.
O LORD God, do not turn away the face of Your anointed; remember the mercies of Your servant David."
Now, when Solomon had finished praying, fire descended from heaven and consumed the burnt offering and the sacrifices; the glory of the LORD filled the house.
The priests could not enter the house of the LORD because the glory of the LORD had filled it.

When all the children of Israel saw the fire come down and the glory of the LORD upon the house, they bowed their faces to the ground on the pavement, worshipped, and praised the LORD, saying, "For He is good; His mercy endures forever."
Then the king and all the people offered sacrifices before the LORD.
King Solomon offered a sacrifice of twenty-two thousand oxen and one hundred twenty thousand sheep; thus, the king and all the people dedicated the house of God.

The priests attended to their duties, and the Levites played musical instruments of the LORD, which King David had made to praise the LORD, for His mercy endures forever, as David praised through their ministry; the priests sounded trumpets before them, and all Israel stood.

Moreover, Solomon consecrated the middle of the court that was before the house of the LORD, where he offered burnt offerings and the fat of the peace offerings, because the bronze altar that Solomon had made could not accommodate the burnt offerings, the grain offerings, and the fat.
At the same time, Solomon celebrated the feast for seven days, and all Israel joined him, a very large congregation, from the entrance of Hamath to the river of Egypt.
On the eighth day, they held a solemn assembly; they kept the dedication of the altar for seven days and the feast for seven days.
On the twenty-third day of the seventh month, he sent the people away to their tents, joyful and glad of heart for the goodness that the LORD had shown to David, to Solomon, and to Israel His people.
Thus, Solomon completed the house of the LORD and the king's palace; everything that came into Solomon's heart to make in the house of the LORD and in his own house, he successfully accomplished.
The LORD appeared to Solomon at night and said to him, "I have heard your prayer and have chosen this place for Myself as a house of sacrifice.
If I shut up heaven so that there is no rain, or if I command locusts to devour the land, or if I send pestilence among My people;
If My people, who are called by My name, will humble themselves, pray, seek My face, and turn from their wicked ways, then I will hear from heaven, forgive their sin, and heal their land.
Now My eyes will be open and My ears attentive to the prayer made in this place.
For I have chosen and sanctified this house, that My name may be there forever; My eyes and My heart will be there perpetually.
As for you, if you walk before Me as your father David walked, and do according to all that I have commanded you, and observe My statutes and My judgments;
Then I will establish the throne of your kingdom, as I covenanted with David your father, saying, "There shall not fail you a man to be ruler in Israel."
But if you turn away and forsake My statutes and My commandments, which I have set before you, and go and serve other gods and worship them;
Then I will uproot them from My land, which I have given them; and this house, which I have sanctified for My name, I will cast out of My sight and make it a proverb and a byword among all nations.
This house, which is high, will be an astonishment to everyone who passes by it; they will say, "Why has the LORD done this to this land and to this house?"

It will be answered, "Because they forsook the LORD God of their fathers, who brought them out of the land of Egypt, and embraced other gods, worshipped them, and served them; therefore, He has brought all this evil upon them."
And it came to pass at the end of twenty years, during which Solomon had built the house of the LORD and his own palace,
That the cities which Huram had restored to Solomon were built by him, and he settled the children of Israel there.
And Solomon went to Hamathzobah and successfully conquered it.
He constructed Tadmor in the wilderness, along with all the store cities he built in Hamath.
Additionally, he built the upper and lower Bethhoron, fortified cities with walls, gates, and bars;

And Baalath, along with all the store cities that belonged to Solomon, as well as the chariot cities and the cities of the horsemen, and all that Solomon wished to build in Jerusalem, Lebanon, and throughout all the land under his rule.
As for all the people who remained from the Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites, who were not of Israel,
The children of Israel did not consume their descendants who remained in the land; instead, Solomon made them pay tribute until this day.
However, Solomon did not make any of the children of Israel his servants for his work; they were men of war, chief captains, and commanders of his chariots and horsemen.
These were the chief officers of King Solomon, numbering two hundred and fifty, who ruled over the people.

Solomon brought the daughter of Pharaoh from the city of David to the house he had built for her, stating, "My wife shall not dwell in the house of David, king of Israel, because the places are holy, where the ark of the LORD has come."
Then Solomon offered burnt offerings to the LORD on the altar he had built before the porch,

Daily offering at a specified rate, according to the commandment of Moses, on the sabbaths, new moons, and solemn feasts, three times a year: during the feast of unleavened bread, the feast of weeks, and the feast of tabernacles.

He appointed, according to the order of his father David, the courses of the priests for their service, and the Levites for their duties, to praise and minister before the priests as required daily; the porters also by their courses at every gate, as commanded by David, the man of God.
They did not depart from the commandment of the king regarding the priests and Levites concerning any matter or the treasures.
Now all the work of Solomon was prepared from the day of the foundation of the house of the LORD until it was completed. Thus, the house of the LORD was perfected.
Then Solomon went to Eziongeber and Eloth, by the seaside in the land of Edom.

Huram sent him ships and skilled sailors by the hands of his servants; they went with Solomon's servants to Ophir, where they took four hundred and fifty talents of gold and brought them to King Solomon.

When the queen of Sheba heard of Solomon's fame, she traveled to Jerusalem to test him with difficult questions, accompanied by a large entourage and camels laden with spices, abundant gold, and precious stones. Upon her arrival, she spoke with Solomon about everything that was on her mind.
Solomon answered all her questions, leaving nothing undisclosed.
After witnessing Solomon's wisdom and the magnificent house he had built,

along with the food on his table, the seating of his servants, the attendance of his ministers, their attire, the apparel of his cupbearers, and the way he ascended to the house of the LORD, she was left breathless.
She said to the king, "The report I heard in my own land about your deeds and wisdom was true.
However, I did not believe their words until I came and saw it with my own eyes. Indeed, the half of your greatness and wisdom was not told to me; you surpass the fame I had heard."
"Blessed are your men, and blessed are these servants of yours who stand continually before you and hear your wisdom.

Praise be to the LORD your God, who delighted in you and set you on His throne as king for the LORD your God. Because your God loved Israel and established them forever, He made you king over them to maintain justice and righteousness."

She presented the king with one hundred and twenty talents of gold, a great abundance of spices, and precious stones; there had never been such spices as those given to King Solomon by the queen of Sheba.
The servants of Huram and Solomon, who brought gold from Ophir, also brought algum trees and precious stones.

The king used the algum trees to make terraces for the house of the LORD and for the king's palace, as well as harps and psalteries for singers; such items had never been seen before in the land of Judah.
King Solomon granted the queen of Sheba all her desires, whatever she asked, in addition to what she had brought to the king. Then she turned and returned to her own land with her servants.
The amount of gold that came to Solomon in one year was six hundred and sixty-six talents of gold,
not including what the merchants and traders brought. All the kings of Arabia and governors of the region brought gold and silver to Solomon.
King Solomon made two hundred gold shields, each shield requiring six hundred shekels of beaten gold.
He also made three hundred gold shields, each shield requiring three hundred shekels of gold, and placed them in the house of the forest of Lebanon.
Additionally, the king constructed a grand throne of ivory and overlaid it with pure gold.
The throne had six steps, with a gold footstool attached, and there were armrests on each side of the seat, with two lions standing beside the armrests.
Twelve lions stood on either side of the six steps; nothing like it had been made in any kingdom.
All the drinking vessels of King Solomon were made of gold, and all the vessels in the house of the forest of Lebanon were pure gold; silver was not valued in the days of Solomon.
The king's ships went to Tarshish with the servants of Huram, and every three years, the ships from Tarshish returned, bringing gold, silver, ivory, apes, and peacocks.
King Solomon surpassed all the kings of the earth in wealth and wisdom.
All the kings of the earth sought the presence of Solomon to hear the wisdom that God had placed in his heart.
They each brought gifts: vessels of silver, vessels of gold, clothing, harnesses, spices, horses, and mules, each year in their appointed season.
Solomon had four thousand stalls for horses and chariots, and twelve thousand horsemen, whom he stationed in the chariot cities and with the king in Jerusalem.
He ruled over all the kings from the river to the land of the Philistines and to the border of Egypt.
The king made silver in Jerusalem as plentiful as stones, and he made cedar trees as abundant as sycamore trees in the lowlands.
They brought horses to Solomon from Egypt and from all other lands.

Now, the rest of Solomon's acts, both the first and the last, are they not recorded in the book of Nathan the prophet, in the prophecy of Ahijah the Shilonite, and in the visions of Iddo the seer concerning Jeroboam son of Nebat?
Solomon reigned in Jerusalem over all Israel for forty years.
Solomon rested with his ancestors and was buried in the city of his father David; his son Rehoboam succeeded him as king.
Rehoboam went to Shechem, for all of Israel had gathered there to make him king.
When Jeroboam, the son of Nebat, who had fled to Egypt to escape King Solomon, heard this, he returned from Egypt.
They sent for him, and Jeroboam along with all of Israel spoke to Rehoboam, saying,
"Your father made our yoke burdensome; now, lighten the harsh servitude your father imposed on us, and we will serve you."
Rehoboam replied, "Come back to me in three days." So the people departed.
King Rehoboam consulted with the elders who had served his father Solomon while he was still alive, asking, "What advice do you give me to respond to this people?"
They advised him, "If you are kind to this people, and speak good words to them, they will be your servants forever."
However, he rejected the advice of the elders and sought counsel from the young men who had grown up with him and were now in his service.
He asked them, "What do you advise that we should say to this people who have requested that I lighten the yoke my father placed on them?"

The young men replied, "This is what you should tell the people who said to you, 'Your father made our yoke heavy, but you should lighten it for us': say to them, 'My little finger is thicker than my father's waist.
Whereas my father laid a heavy yoke on you, I will make it even heavier; my father used whips on you, but I will use scorpions.'"
So Jeroboam and all the people returned to Rehoboam on the third day, as the king had instructed.
The king responded harshly and disregarded the advice of the elders,
answering them according to the counsel of the young men: "My father made your yoke heavy, but I will add to it; my father used whips on you, but I will use scorpions."
The king did not listen to the people, for the situation was from God, so that the LORD could fulfill His word spoken through Ahijah the Shilonite to Jeroboam, son of Nebat.

When all of Israel saw that the king refused to listen to them, they answered the king, saying, "What share do we have in David? We have no inheritance in the son of Jesse. Each of you, to your tents, O Israel! Look after your own house, David." So all of Israel went to their tents.
But the people of Israel who lived in the cities of Judah were ruled by Rehoboam.
Then King Rehoboam sent Hadoram, who was in charge of forced labor, but the Israelites stoned him to death. King Rehoboam quickly mounted his chariot to flee to Jerusalem.
Thus, Israel has rebelled against the house of David to this day.
When Rehoboam arrived in Jerusalem, he gathered 180,000 chosen warriors from the house of Judah and Benjamin to fight against Israel, intending to restore the kingdom to himself.
However, the word of the LORD came to Shemaiah, a man of God, instructing him to say,
"Speak to Rehoboam, son of Solomon, king of Judah, and to all Israel in Judah and Benjamin, saying,

'Thus says the LORD: You shall not go up or fight against your brothers. Let every man return to his home, for this matter is ordained by Me.'" They obeyed the LORD's command and withdrew from confronting Jeroboam.
Rehoboam settled in Jerusalem and fortified cities in Judah.
He built cities such as Bethlehem, Etam, and Tekoa,
as well as Bethzur, Shoco, and Adullam,
Gath, Mareshah, and Ziph,
Adoraim, Lachish, and Azekah,
Zorah, Aijalon, and Hebron, which are fortified cities in Judah and Benjamin.
He strengthened the strongholds, appointed captains, and stored provisions, oil, and wine.
In every city, he placed shields and spears, making them exceedingly strong, with Judah and Benjamin on his side.
The priests and Levites from all Israel gathered to him from their regions.
The Levites abandoned their towns and possessions to come to Judah and Jerusalem, for Jeroboam and his sons had removed them from serving as priests to the LORD.
He appointed priests for the high places, for the idols, and for the calves he had made.
Afterward, those from all the tribes of Israel who were determined to seek the LORD God of Israel came to Jerusalem to offer sacrifices to the LORD God of their ancestors.
Thus, they strengthened the kingdom of Judah and made Rehoboam, son of Solomon, strong for three years, during which they followed the ways of David and Solomon.
Rehoboam married Mahalath, the daughter of Jerimoth, son of David, and Abihail, the daughter of Eliab, son of Jesse;
she bore him children: Jeush, Shamariah, and Zaham.
After her, he took Maachah, the daughter of Absalom, who bore him Abijah, Attai, Ziza, and Shelomith.
Rehoboam loved Maachah, daughter of Absalom, more than all his other wives and concubines; he had eighteen wives and sixty concubines, and he fathered twenty-eight sons and sixty daughters.
Rehoboam made Abijah, son of Maachah, chief among his brothers, intending to make him king.
He acted wisely, distributing his children throughout all the regions of Judah and Benjamin, to every fortified city, providing them with abundant provisions. He also desired many wives.
And it came to pass, when Rehoboam had established the kingdom and strengthened himself, he forsook the law of the LORD, and all Israel followed him.
And it came to pass that in the fifth year of King Rehoboam, Shishak, king of Egypt, came up against Jerusalem because they had transgressed against the LORD.
With twelve hundred chariots and sixty thousand horsemen, and the people who came with him out of Egypt were without number; the Lubims, the Sukkiims, and the Ethiopians.
And he took the fortified cities that belonged to Judah and came to Jerusalem.

Then Shemaiah the prophet came to Rehoboam and to the princes of Judah, who were gathered together in Jerusalem because of Shishak, and said to them, "Thus says the LORD: You have forsaken me, and therefore I have also left you in the hand of Shishak."
Upon hearing this, the princes of Israel and the king humbled themselves, saying, "The LORD is righteous."

And when the LORD saw that they humbled themselves, the word of the LORD came to Shemaiah, saying, "They have humbled themselves; therefore I will not destroy them, but I will grant them some deliverance, and my wrath shall not be poured out upon Jerusalem by the hand of Shishak."
Nevertheless, they shall be his servants, so that they may know my service and the service of the kingdoms of the countries.

So Shishak, king of Egypt, came up against Jerusalem and took away the treasures of the house of the LORD and the treasures of the king's house; he took everything, including the gold shields that Solomon had made.
In their place, King Rehoboam made shields of brass and entrusted them to the chief of the guard, who kept watch at the entrance of the king's house.
And when the king entered the house of the LORD, the guard came and fetched the shields, bringing them back to the guard chamber.
And when he humbled himself, the wrath of the LORD turned from him, so that he would not destroy him completely; and also, things went well in Judah.

So King Rehoboam strengthened himself in Jerusalem and reigned; for Rehoboam was forty-one years old when he began to reign, and he reigned seventeen years in Jerusalem, the city which the LORD had chosen out of all the tribes of Israel to put his name there. His mother's name was Naamah, an Ammonitess.
And he did evil, for he did not prepare his heart to seek the LORD.

Now the acts of Rehoboam, both the first and the last, are they not written in the book of Shemaiah the prophet and of Iddo the seer concerning genealogies? And there were continual wars between Rehoboam and Jeroboam.
And Rehoboam slept with his fathers and was buried in the city of David; and his son Abijah reigned in his stead.
In the eighteenth year of King Jeroboam, Abijah began his reign over Judah.
He ruled for three years in Jerusalem. His mother was Michaiah, the daughter of Uriel from Gibeah. There was conflict between Abijah and Jeroboam.

Abijah arranged his forces with an army of valiant warriors, totaling four hundred thousand chosen men; Jeroboam also organized his troops against him, with eight hundred thousand chosen men, all mighty warriors.
Abijah stood on Mount Zemaraim, located in Mount Ephraim, and proclaimed, "Hear me, Jeroboam, and all Israel;
Should you not know that the LORD God of Israel granted the kingdom of Israel to David forever, to him and his descendants, by a covenant of salt?
Yet Jeroboam, the son of Nebat, a servant of Solomon, the son of David, has risen up and rebelled against his lord.
He has gathered vain men, the children of Belial, and has strengthened himself against Rehoboam, the son of Solomon, when Rehoboam was young and tenderhearted, unable to resist them.
And now you think to oppose the kingdom of the LORD in the hands of the sons of David; you are a great multitude, and you have the golden calves that Jeroboam made for you as gods.

Have you not expelled the priests of the LORD, the sons of Aaron, and the Levites, and appointed priests for yourselves in the manner of the nations of other lands? So that whoever comes to consecrate himself with a young bull and seven rams may become a priest of those who are no gods.
But as for us, the LORD is our God, and we have not forsaken Him; the priests who minister to the LORD are the sons of Aaron, and the Levites are dedicated to their duties.

They offer burnt sacrifices and sweet incense to the LORD every morning and evening; they also arrange the showbread on the pure table and keep the golden lampstand with its lamps burning every evening. We maintain the charge of the LORD our God, but you have forsaken Him.

And behold, God Himself is with us as our captain, and His priests are with sounding trumpets to sound the alarm against you. O children of Israel, do not fight against the LORD God of your fathers, for you will not succeed.
But Jeroboam set an ambush behind them: they were in front of Judah, and the ambush was behind them.
When Judah looked back, they saw the battle was in front and behind them; they cried out to the LORD, and the priests sounded the trumpets.
Then the men of Judah shouted, and as they shouted, God struck Jeroboam and all Israel before Abijah and Judah.
The children of Israel fled before Judah, and God delivered them into their hands.
Abijah and his people struck them down with a great slaughter, and five hundred thousand chosen men of Israel fell slain.
Thus, at that time, the children of Israel were subdued, and the children of Judah prevailed because they relied on the LORD God of their fathers.
Abijah pursued Jeroboam and captured cities from him, including Bethel and its towns, Jeshanah and its towns, and Ephraim and its towns.
Jeroboam did not regain strength during Abijah's reign; the LORD struck him, and he died.
But Abijah grew strong, married fourteen wives, and fathered twenty-two sons and sixteen daughters.
The rest of the acts of Abijah, his ways, and his sayings are recorded in the story of the prophet Iddo.
So Abijah rested with his ancestors, and they buried him in the city of David; Asa, his son, succeeded him as king. During his reign, the land enjoyed peace for ten years.
Asa did what was good and right in the sight of the LORD his God.
He removed the altars of foreign gods and the high places, smashed the sacred stones, and cut down the Asherah poles.
He commanded Judah to seek the LORD, the God of their ancestors, and to observe the law and the commandments.
He also removed the high places and the images from all the cities of Judah, and the kingdom was at peace before him.
He fortified the cities of Judah, for the land was at rest, and he experienced no wars during those years because the LORD had granted him peace.

Therefore, he said to Judah, "Let us build these cities and surround them with walls, towers, gates, and bars, while the land is still available to us; for we have sought the LORD our God, and He has given us peace on every side." So they built and prospered.
Asa had an army of 300,000 men from Judah who carried shields and spears, and 280,000 men from Benjamin who carried shields and drew bows; all these were valiant warriors.
Then Zerah the Ethiopian came out against them with an army of a million men and 300 chariots, and he approached Mareshah.
Asa went out to confront him, and they arranged the battle in the valley of Zephathah at Mareshah.

Asa cried out to the LORD his God, saying, "LORD, there is no one like You to help the powerless against the mighty. Help us, O LORD our God, for we rely on You, and in Your name, we go against this vast army. O LORD, You are our God; let no mortal prevail against You."
So the LORD struck down the Ethiopians before Asa and Judah, and the Ethiopians fled.

Asa and the people with him pursued them as far as Gerar, and the Ethiopians were defeated so badly that they could not recover; they were destroyed before the LORD and His army, and they carried away a great deal of plunder.
They attacked all the cities around Gerar, for the terror of the LORD had fallen upon them, and they plundered all the cities, for there was a great amount of spoil in them.
They also struck down the tents of the livestock, taking a large number of sheep and camels, and returned to Jerusalem.
And the Spirit of God came upon Azariah, the son of Oded.

He went out to meet Asa and said to him, "Listen to me, Asa, and all Judah and Benjamin: The LORD is with you as long as you are with Him; if you seek Him, He will be found by you, but if you forsake Him, He will forsake you."
For a long time, Israel has been without the true God, without a teaching priest, and without the law.
But when they turned to the LORD God of Israel in their trouble and sought Him, He was found by them.
During those times, there was no peace for those who went out or came in, but great distress was upon all the inhabitants of the lands.
Nation was destroyed by nation, and city by city, for God troubled them with all kinds of adversity.
Be strong, therefore, and do not let your hands be weak, for your work will be rewarded.

When Asa heard these words and the prophecy of Oded the prophet, he took courage, removed the abominable idols from all the land of Judah and Benjamin, and from the cities he had captured in Ephraim, and renewed the altar of the LORD that was before the porch of the LORD.
He gathered all Judah and Benjamin, along with the strangers from Ephraim, Manasseh, and Simeon, for they had joined him in abundance when they saw that the LORD his God was with him.
So they assembled in Jerusalem in the third month of the fifteenth year of Asa's reign.
They offered to the LORD at that time from the spoils they had brought, seven hundred oxen and seven thousand sheep.
They entered into a covenant to seek the LORD God of their fathers with all their heart and soul;
That whoever would not seek the LORD God of Israel should be put to death, whether small or great, man or woman.
They swore an oath to the LORD with a loud voice, with shouting, and with trumpets and cornets.
All Judah rejoiced at the oath, for they had sworn with all their heart and sought Him with their whole desire; and He was found by them, and the LORD gave them rest all around.
Regarding Maachah, the mother of Asa the king, he removed her from being queen because she had made an idol in a grove; Asa cut down her idol, crushed it, and burned it at the brook Kidron.
However, the high places were not removed from Israel; nevertheless, Asa's heart was perfect all his days.
He brought into the house of God the things that his father had dedicated, as well as those he himself had dedicated: silver, gold, and vessels.
There was no more war until the thirty-fifth year of Asa's reign.
In the thirty-sixth year of Asa's reign, Baasha, king of Israel, came up against Judah and built Ramah to prevent anyone from going out or coming in to Asa, king of Judah.
Then Asa took silver and gold from the treasures of the house of the LORD and from the king's palace and sent it to Benhadad, king of Syria, who was residing in Damascus, saying,

"There is a treaty between you and me, as there was between my father and your father. Behold, I have sent you silver and gold; go, break your treaty with Baasha, king of Israel, so that he may withdraw from me."
Benhadad listened to king Asa and sent the commanders of his armies against the cities of Israel; they struck Ijon, Dan, Abelmaim, and all the storage cities of Naphtali.
When Baasha heard this, he stopped building Ramah and ceased his work.
Then King Asa gathered all of Judah, and they carried away the stones and timber of Ramah, which Baasha had been using to build, and with them, he built Geba and Mizpah.

At that time, Hanani the seer came to Asa, king of Judah, and said to him, "Because you have relied on the king of Syria and not on the LORD your God, the army of the king of Syria has escaped from your hand.
Were not the Ethiopians and the Lubims a vast army, with many chariots and horsemen? Yet, because you relied on the LORD, He delivered them into your hand.
For the eyes of the LORD range throughout the earth to strengthen those whose hearts are fully committed to Him. You have done a foolish thing, and from now on, you will be at war."
Then Asa was angry with the seer and put him in prison, for he was enraged with him because of this. At the same time, Asa oppressed some of the people.
And behold, the acts of Asa, both the first and the last, are written in the book of the kings of Judah and Israel.
In the thirty-ninth year of his reign, Asa was afflicted with a disease in his feet, and his condition became very severe; yet, in his disease, he did not seek the LORD but turned to physicians.
Asa rested with his ancestors and died in the forty-first year of his reign.

They buried him in his own tombs that he had made for himself in the city of David, and laid him in a bed filled with sweet aromas and various spices prepared by the perfumers' art; and they made a very great fire in his honor.
And Jehoshaphat, his son, reigned in his place and fortified himself against Israel.
He stationed forces in all the fortified cities of Judah and set garrisons in the land of Judah and in the cities of Ephraim that Asa, his father, had captured.
The LORD was with Jehoshaphat because he followed the early ways of his father David and did not seek after Baalim.
Instead, he sought the Lord God of his father, followed His commandments, and did not imitate the practices of Israel.
As a result, the LORD established the kingdom in his hand; all Judah brought gifts to Jehoshaphat, and he amassed great wealth and honor.
His heart was uplifted in the ways of the LORD; furthermore, he removed the high places and groves from Judah.
In the third year of his reign, he sent his officials, including Benhail, Obadiah, Zechariah, Nethaneel, and Michaiah, to teach in the cities of Judah.
Along with them, he sent Levites: Shemaiah, Nethaniah, Zebadiah, Asahel, Shemiramoth, Jehonathan, Adonijah, Tobijah, and Tobadonijah, as well as priests Elishama and Jehoram.
They taught in Judah, carrying the book of the law of the LORD with them, and traveled throughout all the cities of Judah to instruct the people.
The fear of the LORD fell upon all the kingdoms surrounding Judah, so they did not wage war against Jehoshaphat.
Some of the Philistines also brought Jehoshaphat gifts and tribute silver, while the Arabians presented him with flocks: seven thousand seven hundred rams and seven thousand seven hundred he-goats.
Jehoshaphat grew exceedingly powerful and built castles and store cities in Judah.
He had extensive business dealings in the cities of Judah, and the mighty men of valor were in Jerusalem.
These are the numbers of them according to their ancestral houses: from Judah, the captains of thousands: Adnah the chief, accompanied by three hundred thousand mighty men of valor.
Next to him was Jehohanan the captain, with two hundred eighty thousand alongside him.
Next was Amasiah, the son of Zichri, who willingly offered himself to the LORD, accompanied by two hundred thousand mighty men of valor.
From Benjamin, Eliada, a mighty man of valor, led two hundred thousand armed men with bows and shields.
Next to him was Jehozabad, with one hundred eighty thousand ready for battle.
These served the king, in addition to those whom the king assigned to the fortified cities throughout all Judah.
Now Jehoshaphat possessed great wealth and honor, and he formed an alliance with Ahab.

After some years, he traveled to Samaria to visit Ahab. Ahab prepared a feast of sheep and oxen in abundance for him and his entourage, and he urged Jehoshaphat to join him in the campaign against Ramothgilead.
Ahab, the king of Israel, asked Jehoshaphat, "Will you go with me to Ramothgilead?" Jehoshaphat replied, "I am as you are, and my people are as your people; we will fight alongside you."
Jehoshaphat then said to the king of Israel, "Please inquire of the LORD today."

Consequently, the king of Israel summoned four hundred prophets and asked them, "Shall we go to Ramothgilead to battle, or should I refrain?" They answered, "Go up, for God will deliver it into the king's hand."
However, Jehoshaphat asked, "Is there not a prophet of the LORD here that we may inquire of?"

The king of Israel replied to Jehoshaphat, "There is one man through whom we can inquire of the LORD, but I hate him because he never prophesies good about me, only evil. His name is Micaiah, the son of Imla." Jehoshaphat responded, "Let not the king say so."
The king of Israel then called one of his officers and instructed, "Quickly fetch Micaiah, the son of Imla."

The king of Israel and Jehoshaphat, king of Judah, sat on their thrones, dressed in their royal robes, in a vacant area at the entrance of the gate of Samaria, while all the prophets prophesied before them.
Zedekiah, the son of Chenaanah, had made iron horns and declared, "Thus says the LORD: With these, you shall push back Syria until they are destroyed."
All the prophets prophesied similarly, saying, "Go up to Ramothgilead and succeed, for the LORD will deliver it into the king's hand."
The messenger who went to summon Micaiah spoke to him, saying, "Look, the words of the prophets are unanimously favorable to the king; please let your words be like theirs and speak favorably."
Micaiah replied, "As the LORD lives, whatever my God says, that will I speak."

When he arrived before the king, the king asked him, "Micaiah, shall we go to Ramothgilead to battle, or should I refrain?" Micaiah answered, "Go up and prosper, for they will be delivered into your hand."
The king said to him, "How many times must I adjure you to tell me nothing but the truth in the name of the LORD?"
Micaiah then said, "I saw all Israel scattered on the mountains like sheep without a shepherd. The LORD said, 'These have no master; let each return home in peace.'"
The king of Israel turned to Jehoshaphat and said, "Did I not tell you that he would not prophesy good about me, but only evil?"
Micaiah continued, "Therefore, hear the word of the LORD: I saw the LORD sitting on His throne, and all the host of heaven standing on His right and on His left."
The LORD asked, "Who will entice Ahab, king of Israel, to go up and fall at Ramothgilead?" One spirit spoke in this manner, and another in that manner.
Then a spirit came forward and stood before the LORD, saying, "I will entice him." The LORD asked, "How?"
The spirit replied, "I will go out and be a lying spirit in the mouths of all his prophets." The LORD said, "You will entice him and succeed; go out and do it."
Now, therefore, behold, the LORD has put a lying spirit in the mouths of these prophets, and the LORD has spoken evil against you.
Zedekiah, the son of Chenaanah, approached Micaiah and struck him on the cheek, asking, "Which way did the Spirit of the LORD go from me to speak to you?"
Micaiah replied, "You will see on that day when you go into an inner chamber to hide."
The king of Israel then ordered, "Take Micaiah and return him to Amon, the governor of the city, and to Joash, the king's son.
Tell them, 'Thus says the king: Put this man in prison and feed him with the bread of affliction and the water of affliction until I return in peace.'"
Micaiah responded, "If you return in peace, then the LORD has not spoken by me." He added, "Listen, all you people!"
So the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat, king of Judah, went up to Ramothgilead.
The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, "I will disguise myself and go into battle, but you wear your robes." So the king of Israel disguised himself, and they went into battle.
The king of Syria had commanded the captains of his chariots, saying, "Do not fight with small or great, but only with the king of Israel."

When the captains of the chariots saw Jehoshaphat, they said, "Surely this is the king of Israel." They surrounded him to fight, but Jehoshaphat cried out, and the LORD helped him; God caused them to turn away from him.
When the captains of the chariots realized that he was not the king of Israel, they turned back from pursuing him.

A certain man drew his bow at random and struck the king of Israel between the joints of his armor. He then said to his chariot driver, "Turn your hand and carry me out of the battle, for I am wounded."
The battle intensified that day, but the king of Israel propped himself up in his chariot against the Syrians until evening. As the sun was setting, he died.
And Jehoshaphat, the king of Judah, returned to his house in peace in Jerusalem.
Jehu, the son of Hanani the seer, went out to meet him and said to King Jehoshaphat, "Should you help the ungodly and love those who hate the LORD? Therefore, the LORD's wrath is upon you."
Nevertheless, good things have been found in you, for you have removed the groves from the land and prepared your heart to seek God.
Jehoshaphat dwelt in Jerusalem and went out again among the people from Beersheba to Mount Ephraim, bringing them back to the LORD God of their fathers.
He appointed judges in the land throughout all the fortified cities of Judah, city by city.
He said to the judges, "Take heed to what you do, for you do not judge for man, but for the LORD, who is with you in judgment."
Now, let the fear of the LORD be upon you; take heed and act accordingly, for there is no iniquity with the LORD our God, nor favoritism, nor acceptance of bribes.
Furthermore, in Jerusalem, Jehoshaphat appointed Levites, priests, and the heads of the families of Israel for the judgment of the LORD and for controversies when they returned to Jerusalem.
He charged them, saying, "Thus shall you act in the fear of the LORD, faithfully and with a perfect heart."

And whatever case comes to you from your brethren who dwell in your cities, regarding bloodshed, law, commandments, statutes, and judgments, you shall warn them not to trespass against the LORD, so that wrath does not come upon you and your brethren; do this, and you will not trespass.

Behold, Amariah the chief priest is over you in all matters of the LORD, and Zebadiah the son of Ishmael is the ruler of the house of Judah for all the king's matters; the Levites shall also be officers before you. Act courageously, and the LORD will be with the good.
It came to pass after this that the children of Moab, the children of Ammon, and others alongside the Ammonites came against Jehoshaphat for battle.
Then some came to tell Jehoshaphat, saying, "A great multitude is coming against you from beyond the sea on this side of Syria; behold, they are in Hazazontamar, which is Engedi."
And Jehoshaphat was afraid, and he set himself to seek the LORD, proclaiming a fast throughout all Judah.
And Judah gathered together to ask for help from the LORD; they came from all the cities of Judah to seek the LORD.
And Jehoshaphat stood in the assembly of Judah and Jerusalem, in the house of the LORD, before the new court,
And said, "O LORD God of our fathers, are you not God in heaven? Do you not rule over all the kingdoms of the nations? Is there not power and might in your hand, so that none can withstand you?
Are you not our God, who drove out the inhabitants of this land before your people Israel, and gave it to the descendants of Abraham your friend forever?
And they dwelt there, and built you a sanctuary for your name, saying,

'If evil comes upon us, such as the sword, judgment, pestilence, or famine, and we stand before this house and in your presence (for your name is in this house) and cry out to you in our affliction, then you will hear and help.'
And now, behold, the children of Ammon, Moab, and Mount Seir, whom you would not let Israel invade when they came out of the land of Egypt, for they turned away from them and did not destroy them;
Behold, I say, how they reward us, by coming to cast us out of your possession, which you have given us to inherit.
O our God, will you not judge them? For we have no power against this great multitude coming against us; nor do we know what to do, but our eyes are upon you.
And all Judah stood before the LORD, with their little ones, their wives, and their children.
Then the Spirit of the LORD came upon Jahaziel, the son of Zechariah, the son of Benaiah, the son of Jeiel, the son of Mattaniah, a Levite of the sons of Asaph, in the midst of the congregation;

And he said, "Listen, all Judah and you inhabitants of Jerusalem, and you King Jehoshaphat: Thus says the LORD to you, 'Do not be afraid or dismayed because of this great multitude; for the battle is not yours, but God's.
Tomorrow, go down against them: behold, they come up by the cliff of Ziz; and you will find them at the end of the brook, before the wilderness of Jeruel.

You will not need to fight in this battle: position yourselves, stand still, and see the salvation of the LORD with you, O Judah and Jerusalem: do not fear or be dismayed; tomorrow go out against them, for the LORD will be with you.'"
And Jehoshaphat bowed his head with his face to the ground, and all Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem fell before the LORD, worshiping the LORD.
And the Levites, of the children of the Kohathites and the Korhites, stood up to praise the LORD God of Israel with a loud voice on high.

And they rose early in the morning and went forth into the wilderness of Tekoa: and as they went, Jehoshaphat stood and said, "Hear me, O Judah, and you inhabitants of Jerusalem; believe in the LORD your God, and you shall be established; believe his prophets, and you shall prosper."

And when he had consulted with the people, he appointed singers to the LORD, to praise the beauty of holiness as they went out before the army, saying, "Praise the LORD; for his mercy endures forever."
And when they began to sing and to praise, the LORD set ambushes against the children of Ammon, Moab, and Mount Seir, who had come against Judah; and they were struck down.

For the children of Ammon and Moab rose up against the inhabitants of Mount Seir, utterly to slay and destroy them; and when they had finished with the inhabitants of Seir, everyone helped to destroy one another.
And when Judah came toward the watchtower in the wilderness, they looked toward the multitude, and behold, they were dead bodies fallen to the earth, and none escaped.

And when Jehoshaphat and his people came to take away the spoil, they found among them in abundance both riches with the dead bodies and precious jewels, which they stripped off for themselves, more than they could carry away; and they were three days gathering the spoil, it was so much.
And on the fourth day, they assembled in the valley of Berachah; for there they blessed the LORD: therefore, the name of that place was called The Valley of Berachah to this day.
Then they returned, every man of Judah and Jerusalem, and Jehoshaphat at the forefront of them, to go again to Jerusalem with joy; for the LORD had made them rejoice over their enemies.
And they came to Jerusalem with psalteries, harps, and trumpets to the house of the LORD.
And the fear of God was on all the kingdoms of those countries when they heard that the LORD fought against the enemies of Israel.
So the realm of Jehoshaphat was quiet, for his God gave him rest all around.
And Jehoshaphat reigned over Judah; he was thirty-five years old when he began to reign, and he reigned twenty-five years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Azubah, the daughter of Shilhi.
And he walked in the way of Asa his father, and did not turn from it, doing what was right in the sight of the LORD.
However, the high places were not taken away, for the people had not yet prepared their hearts to the God of their fathers.
Now the rest of the acts of Jehoshaphat, first and last, behold, they are written in the book of Jehu, the son of Hanani, which is mentioned in the book of the kings of Israel.
And after this, Jehoshaphat, king of Judah, allied himself with Ahaziah, king of Israel, who acted very wickedly.
And he joined with him to make ships to go to Tarshish; and they made the ships in Eziongaber.

Then Eliezer, the son of Dodavah of Mareshah, prophesied against Jehoshaphat, saying, "Because you have allied yourself with Ahaziah, the LORD has broken your works." And the ships were wrecked, so that they were not able to go to Tarshish.
Now Jehoshaphat rested with his ancestors and was laid to rest alongside them in the city of David. His son Jehoram succeeded him as king.
He had brothers, the sons of Jehoshaphat: Azariah, Jehiel, Zechariah, Azariah, Michael, and Shephatiah; all these were the sons of Jehoshaphat, king of Israel.
Their father bestowed upon them significant gifts of silver, gold, and precious items, along with fortified cities in Judah; however, the kingdom was given to Jehoram, as he was the firstborn.
When Jehoram ascended to the throne of his father, he fortified his position and killed all his brothers with the sword, along with various princes of Israel.
Jehoram was thirty-two years old when he began to reign, and he ruled for eight years in Jerusalem.
He followed the ways of the kings of Israel, just as the house of Ahab did, for he had married Ahab's daughter; he committed evil in the sight of the LORD.
Nevertheless, the LORD would not destroy the house of David because of the covenant He made with David, and as He promised to provide a light for him and his descendants forever.
During his reign, the Edomites revolted against the rule of Judah and established their own king.
Then Jehoram went out with his princes and all his chariots; he rose up at night and struck down the Edomites who surrounded him, along with the captains of the chariots.
Thus, the Edomites revolted from under the authority of Judah to this day. At the same time, Libnah also revolted against him because he had forsaken the LORD God of his ancestors.
Moreover, he built high places in the mountains of Judah and led the inhabitants of Jerusalem into sexual immorality, compelling Judah to do the same.

A letter came to him from Elijah the prophet, stating, "Thus says the LORD God of David your father: Because you have not walked in the ways of your father Jehoshaphat, nor in the ways of Asa king of Judah,

but have walked in the way of the kings of Israel, and have caused Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem to commit acts of harlotry, like the harlotries of the house of Ahab, and have also killed your brothers of your father's house, who were better than you:
Behold, the LORD will strike your people, your children, your wives, and all your possessions with a great plague.
And you will suffer severe illness from a disease of your bowels, until your bowels come out because of the sickness day by day.
Furthermore, the LORD stirred up against Jehoram the spirit of the Philistines and the Arabians, who were near the Ethiopians.

They came up into Judah, broke into it, and carried away all the possessions found in the king's house, including his sons and wives; so that no son remained with him except Jehoahaz, the youngest of his sons.
After all this, the LORD afflicted him in his bowels with an incurable disease.
Eventually, after two years, his bowels fell out due to his sickness, and he died from severe diseases. His people did not burn incense for him, as they had for his ancestors.

He was thirty-two years old when he began to reign, and he ruled in Jerusalem for eight years, departing without being desired. However, they buried him in the city of David, but not in the tombs of the kings.

The inhabitants of Jerusalem made Ahaziah, his youngest son, king in his place, for the group of men who had come with the Arabians to the camp had killed all the older sons. Thus, Ahaziah, the son of Jehoram, king of Judah, began to reign.
Ahaziah was forty-two years old when he ascended to the throne, and he ruled for one year in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Athaliah, the daughter of Omri.
He followed the ways of the house of Ahab, for his mother was his advisor in doing evil.
As a result, he committed wicked acts in the sight of the LORD, similar to the house of Ahab, for they counseled him after his father's death, leading to his downfall.
He also followed their advice and joined Jehoram, the son of Ahab, king of Israel, in battle against Hazael, king of Syria, at Ramoth-gilead, where the Syrians struck Joram.

He returned to Jezreel to recover from the wounds he sustained at Ramah while fighting Hazael, king of Syria. Azariah, the son of Jehoram, king of Judah, went down to visit Jehoram, the son of Ahab, in Jezreel because he was ill.

The downfall of Ahaziah was orchestrated by God when he allied with Joram, for upon his arrival, he went out with Jehoram to confront Jehu, the son of Nimshi, whom the LORD had anointed to eliminate the house of Ahab.
It came to pass that when Jehu was executing judgment upon the house of Ahab, he found the princes of Judah and the brothers of Ahaziah who served him, and he killed them.

He sought out Ahaziah, and they captured him (for he was hiding in Samaria) and brought him to Jehu. After they killed him, they buried him, saying, "He is the son of Jehoshaphat, who sought the LORD with all his heart." Thus, the house of Ahaziah was unable to maintain control of the kingdom.
When Athaliah, the mother of Ahaziah, realized her son was dead, she rose up and exterminated all the royal offspring of the house of Judah.

However, Jehoshabeath, the daughter of the king, took Joash, the son of Ahaziah, and hid him from among the slain king's sons, placing him and his nurse in a secret chamber. Jehoshabeath, the daughter of king Jehoram and wife of Jehoiada the priest (and sister of Ahaziah), concealed him from Athaliah so that she would not kill him.
He remained hidden with them in the house of God for six years, while Athaliah ruled over the land.

In the seventh year, Jehoiada strengthened himself and took the captains of hundreds: Azariah, the son of Jeroham; Ishmael, the son of Jehohanan; Azariah, the son of Obed; Maaseiah, the son of Adaiah; and Elishaphat, the son of Zichri, into a covenant with him.
They traveled throughout Judah, gathering the Levites from all the cities of Judah, along with the leaders of the families of Israel, and they assembled in Jerusalem.
The entire congregation made a covenant with the king in the house of God. He said to them, "Behold, the king's son shall reign, as the LORD has declared concerning the sons of David."
This is what you shall do: A third of you, who enter on the Sabbath, of the priests and Levites, shall be gatekeepers at the doors;
A third shall be at the king's house, and a third at the gate of the foundation. All the people shall be in the courts of the house of the LORD.
But let no one enter the house of the LORD except the priests and those Levites who minister; they may enter, for they are holy. All the people shall keep watch over the LORD.
The Levites shall surround the king, each man with his weapon in hand. Anyone else who enters the house shall be put to death. You are to be with the king when he comes in and when he goes out.
So the Levites and all Judah acted according to everything that Jehoiada the priest commanded, taking each man his assigned duty for the Sabbath, as Jehoiada the priest did not dismiss the divisions.
Moreover, Jehoiada the priest provided the captains of hundreds with spears, bucklers, and shields that had belonged to King David, which were kept in the house of God.
He positioned all the people, each man with his weapon in hand, from the right side of the temple to the left side, alongside the altar and the temple, surrounding the king.
Then they brought out the king's son, placed the crown upon him, gave him the testimony, and made him king. Jehoiada and his sons anointed him, proclaiming, "God save the king!"
When Athaliah heard the noise of the people running and praising the king, she came to the people in the house of the LORD.

She looked, and behold, the king stood at his pillar at the entrance, with the princes and the trumpeters beside him. All the people of the land rejoiced and sounded trumpets, while the singers played instruments of music and taught the people to sing praises. Athaliah then tore her clothes and shouted, "Treason! Treason!"

Jehoiada the priest brought out the captains of hundreds who were in charge of the army and said to them, "Take her outside the ranks, and whoever follows her should be slain with the sword." For the priest commanded, "Do not slay her in the house of the LORD."
So they seized her, and when she reached the entrance of the horse gate by the king's house, they killed her there.
Jehoiada made a covenant between himself, all the people, and the king, that they would be the LORD's people.
Then all the people went to the house of Baal, tore it down, smashed its altars and images to pieces, and killed Mattan, the priest of Baal, before the altars.

Jehoiada also appointed the duties of the house of the LORD through the priests and Levites, whom David had assigned in the house of the LORD, to offer the burnt offerings of the LORD, as prescribed in the law of Moses, with rejoicing and singing, as ordained by David.
He stationed the gatekeepers at the gates of the house of the LORD, so that no one unclean in any way could enter.

He took the captains of hundreds, the nobles, the governors of the people, and all the people of the land, and brought the king down from the house of the LORD. They came through the high gate into the king's house and set the king upon the throne of the kingdom.
All the people of the land rejoiced, and the city was quiet after they had slain Athaliah with the sword.
Joash was seven years old when he began to reign, and he ruled for forty years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Zibiah from Beersheba.
Joash did what was right in the sight of the LORD throughout the days of Jehoiada the priest.
Jehoiada took two wives for him, and he had sons and daughters.
After this, Joash decided to repair the house of the LORD.

He gathered the priests and the Levites and instructed them to go out to the cities of Judah to collect money from all Israel for the repair of the house of your God year after year, urging them to expedite the matter. However, the Levites did not act quickly.

The king summoned Jehoiada the chief and asked him why he had not required the Levites to bring in the collection from Judah and Jerusalem, as commanded by Moses the servant of the LORD and the congregation of Israel for the tabernacle of witness.
The sons of Athaliah, that wicked woman, had broken into the house of God, and they had also given all the dedicated items of the house of the LORD to Baalim.
At the king's command, they made a chest and placed it outside the gate of the house of the LORD.
They proclaimed throughout Judah and Jerusalem to bring in the collection to the LORD that Moses the servant of God had laid upon Israel in the wilderness.
All the princes and the people rejoiced, brought in their contributions, and cast them into the chest until they had finished.

It happened that when the chest was brought to the king's office by the Levites, and they saw that there was much money, the king's scribe and the high priest's officer came, emptied the chest, took it, and returned it to its place. They did this daily, gathering money in abundance.

The king and Jehoiada gave the collected funds to those who were doing the work of the service of the house of the LORD, hiring masons and carpenters to repair the house of the LORD, as well as those who worked with iron and brass to mend it.
The workmen worked diligently, and the project was completed by them; they restored the house of God to its original state and strengthened it.

When they finished, they brought the remaining money before the king and Jehoiada, from which they made vessels for the house of the LORD, including items for ministry, offerings, spoons, and vessels of gold and silver. They offered burnt offerings in the house of the LORD continually throughout the days of Jehoiada.
However, Jehoiada grew old and full of days when he died; he was one hundred and thirty years old at the time of his death.
They buried him in the city of David among the kings because he had done good in Israel, both toward God and toward His house.
After the death of Jehoiada, the princes of Judah came and paid homage to the king. The king listened to them.
They abandoned the house of the LORD God of their fathers and served groves and idols, leading to wrath upon Judah and Jerusalem for this transgression.
Yet he sent prophets to bring them back to the LORD; they testified against them, but they would not listen.

The Spirit of God came upon Zechariah, the son of Jehoiada the priest, who stood above the people and said to them, "Thus says God, Why do you transgress the commandments of the LORD so that you cannot prosper? Because you have forsaken the LORD, He has also forsaken you."
They conspired against him and stoned him with stones at the king's command in the court of the house of the LORD.
Thus, Joash the king did not remember the kindness that Jehoiada his father had shown him, but instead killed his son. As he died, he said, "The LORD look upon it and require it."
At the end of the year, the army of Syria came against him; they invaded Judah and Jerusalem, destroying all the princes of the people and sending all the spoils to the king of Damascus.

The army of the Syrians came with a small number of men, but the LORD delivered a very great host into their hands because they had forsaken the LORD God of their fathers. Thus, they executed judgment against Joash.

When they departed from him (for they left him in great illness), his own servants conspired against him for the blood of the sons of Jehoiada the priest and killed him in his bed. He died and was buried in the city of David, but they did not bury him in the tombs of the kings.
These are the conspirators against him: Zabad the son of Shimeath, an Ammonitess, and Jehozabad the son of Shimrith, a Moabitess.
Now concerning his sons, the burdens laid upon him, and the repair of the house of God, behold, they are written in the story of the book of the kings. Amaziah, his son, reigned in his place.
Amaziah was twenty-five years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for twenty-nine years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Jehoaddan of Jerusalem.
He did what was right in the sight of the LORD, but not with a perfect heart.
When the kingdom was established for him, he killed the servants who had murdered his father, the king.

However, he did not kill their children, following the law written in the book of Moses, where the LORD commanded, "Fathers shall not die for their children, nor shall children die for their fathers; each shall die for their own sin."
