So we fasted and prayed to our God for this, and He was attentive to our plea.
Then I set apart twelve of the chief priests: Sherebiah, Hashabiah, and ten of their brothers with them,
And I weighed out to them the silver, gold, and vessels, the offerings for the house of our God, which the king, his counselors, his lords, and all Israel present had offered:
I weighed into their hands six hundred and fifty talents of silver, one hundred talents of silver vessels, and one hundred talents of gold;
Also twenty gold basins, worth a thousand drams each; and two vessels of fine copper, as precious as gold.
I said to them, "You are holy to the LORD; the vessels are holy as well; and the silver and gold are a freewill offering to the LORD God of your fathers.
Watch and keep them until you weigh them before the chief priests, Levites, and the heads of the families of Israel in Jerusalem, in the chambers of the house of the LORD."
So the priests and Levites took the weight of the silver, gold, and vessels, to bring them to Jerusalem, to the house of our God.

Then we departed from the river of Ahava on the twelfth day of the first month, heading to Jerusalem; the hand of our God was upon us, and He delivered us from the hand of the enemy and from those who lay in wait along the way.
We arrived in Jerusalem and stayed there for three days.

On the fourth day, the silver, gold, and vessels were weighed in the house of our God by Meremoth the son of Uriah the priest; with him was Eleazar the son of Phinehas; and with them were Jozabad the son of Jeshua and Noadiah the son of Binnui, Levites;
They counted and weighed everything, and all the weights were recorded at that time.

The children of those who had been carried away, who had come out of captivity, offered burnt offerings to the God of Israel: twelve bullocks for all Israel, ninety-six rams, seventy-seven lambs, and twelve male goats for a sin offering; all this was a burnt offering to the LORD.
They delivered the king's orders to the king's lieutenants and to the governors on this side of the river, and they supported the people and the house of God.

Now that these matters were addressed, the leaders approached me, saying, "The people of Israel, along with the priests and Levites, have not distanced themselves from the surrounding nations, engaging in their detestable practices, including those of the Canaanites, Hittites, Perizzites, Jebusites, Ammonites, Moabites, Egyptians, and Amorites."

They have taken daughters from these nations for their sons, resulting in the holy lineage being mixed with the peoples of those lands. Indeed, the leaders and rulers have been the primary contributors to this wrongdoing.
Upon hearing this, I tore my garments and mantle, pulled out the hair from my head and beard, and sat down in shock.
Then, all who trembled at the words of the God of Israel gathered around me, due to the transgressions of those who had returned from exile; I remained in shock until the evening sacrifice.
At the evening sacrifice, I rose from my state of despair; having torn my garments and mantle, I knelt down and extended my hands to the LORD my God,
And said, "O my God, I am ashamed and embarrassed to lift my face to You, my God, for our iniquities have multiplied beyond measure, and our transgressions have reached the heavens.

Since the days of our ancestors, we have been in great transgression up to this day; and because of our iniquities, we, our kings, and our priests have been delivered into the hands of the kings of the lands, facing the sword, captivity, plunder, and disgrace, as we experience today.

And now, for a brief moment, grace has been shown to us from the LORD our God, allowing us to escape and providing us a stake in His holy place, so that our God may enlighten our eyes and grant us a little revival in our bondage.

For we were slaves; yet our God has not abandoned us in our bondage but has shown us mercy in the sight of the kings of Persia, to revive us, to rebuild the house of our God, to restore its desolations, and to provide us a wall in Judah and Jerusalem.
And now, O our God, what shall we say after this? For we have forsaken Your commandments,

Which You commanded through Your servants the prophets, saying, "The land you are entering to possess is an unclean land, filled with the filthiness of the peoples of the lands, with their abominations that have polluted it from one end to the other."

Therefore, do not give your daughters to their sons, nor take their daughters for your sons, and do not seek their peace or prosperity forever, so that you may be strong, enjoy the good of the land, and leave it as an inheritance for your children forever.

After all that has come upon us for our evil deeds and great transgressions, considering that You, our God, have punished us less than our iniquities deserve and have granted us such deliverance as this;
Should we again break Your commandments and form alliances with the people committing these abominations? Would You not be angry with us until You had consumed us, leaving no remnant or escape?
O LORD God of Israel, You are righteous; for we remain yet escaped, as it is this day. Behold, we stand before You in our trespasses, for we cannot stand before You because of this.

Now, when Ezra had prayed and confessed, weeping and casting himself down before the house of God, a very large congregation of men, women, and children assembled to him from Israel, for the people wept bitterly.

And Shechaniah, the son of Jehiel, one of the sons of Elam, answered Ezra, saying, "We have sinned against our God and taken foreign wives from the people of the land; yet now there is hope in Israel regarding this matter."

Therefore, let us make a covenant with our God to put away all the wives and those born of them, according to the counsel of my lord and those who fear the commandment of our God; let it be done according to the law.
Arise, for this matter belongs to you; we will also be with you. Be of good courage and act.
Then Ezra arose and made the chief priests, the Levites, and all Israel swear that they would act according to this word. And they swore.

Ezra then rose from before the house of God and went into the chamber of Johanan, the son of Eliashib. When he arrived there, he ate no bread and drank no water, for he mourned because of the transgression of those who had been exiled.
They made a proclamation throughout Judah and Jerusalem to all the children of the captivity, urging them to gather together in Jerusalem.

And whoever did not come within three days, according to the counsel of the princes and elders, would have all his possessions forfeited and be separated from the congregation of those who had been exiled.

Then all the men of Judah and Benjamin gathered together in Jerusalem within three days. It was the ninth month, on the twentieth day of the month, and all the people sat in the street of the house of God, trembling because of this matter and the heavy rain.
Ezra the priest stood up and said to them, "You have transgressed and taken foreign wives, increasing the guilt of Israel."
Now, therefore, confess to the LORD God of your fathers and do His will: separate yourselves from the people of the land and from the foreign wives.
Then all the congregation answered with a loud voice, "As you have said, so must we do."
But the people are many, and it is a time of heavy rain; we cannot stand outside, nor is this a task for one day or two, for we have many who have transgressed in this matter.

Let our rulers of all the congregation stand, and let all those who have taken foreign wives in our cities come at appointed times, along with the elders of every city and their judges, until the fierce wrath of our God regarding this matter is turned away from us.
Only Jonathan, the son of Asahel, and Jahaziah, the son of Tikvah, were assigned to this matter, and Meshullam and Shabbethai the Levite assisted them.

The children of the captivity did so. Ezra the priest, along with certain chiefs of the fathers, after the house of their fathers, and all of them by name, were separated and sat down on the first day of the tenth month to examine the matter.
They completed the examination of all the men who had taken foreign wives by the first day of the first month.
Among the sons of the priests, those found to have taken foreign wives included the sons of Jeshua, the son of Jozadak, and his brothers: Maaseiah, Eliezer, Jarib, and Gedaliah.
They pledged to put away their wives and, being guilty, offered a ram from the flock for their trespass.
Among the sons of Immer were Hanani and Zebadiah.
Among the sons of Harim were Maaseiah, Elijah, Shemaiah, Jehiel, and Uzziah.
Among the sons of Pashur were Elioenai, Maaseiah, Ishmael, Nethaneel, Jozabad, and Elasah.
Also, among the Levites were Jozabad, Shimei, Kelaiah (also known as Kelita), Pethahiah, Judah, and Eliezer.
Among the singers was Eliashib; and among the porters were Shallum, Telem, and Uri.
Moreover, from Israel, among the sons of Parosh were Ramiah, Jeziah, Malchiah, Miamin, Eleazar, Malchijah, and Benaiah.
Among the sons of Elam were Mattaniah, Zechariah, Jehiel, Abdi, Jeremoth, and Eliah.
Among the sons of Zattu were Elioenai, Eliashib, Mattaniah, Jeremoth, Zabad, and Aziza.
Among the sons of Bebai were Jehohanan, Hananiah, Zabbai, and Athlai.
Among the sons of Bani were Meshullam, Malluch, Adaiah, Jashub, Sheal, and Ramoth.
Among the sons of Pahathmoab were Adna, Chelal, Benaiah, Maaseiah, Mattaniah, Bezaleel, Binnui, and Manasseh.
Among the sons of Harim were Eliezer, Ishijah, Malchiah, Shemaiah, and Shimeon.
Among the sons of Benjamin were Malluch and Shemariah.
Among the sons of Hashum were Mattenai, Mattathah, Zabad, Eliphelet, Jeremai, Manasseh, and Shimei.
Among the sons of Bani were Maadai, Amram, and Uel,
Benaiah, Bedeiah, Chelluh,
Vaniah, Meremoth, Eliashib,
Mattaniah, Mattenai, and Jaasau,
And Bani, Binnui, Shimei,
And Shelemiah, Nathan, and Adaiah,
Machnadebai, Shashai, Sharai,
Azareel, Shelemiah, Shemariah,
Shallum, Amariah, and Joseph.
Among the sons of Nebo were Jeiel, Mattithiah, Zabad, Zebina, Jadau, Joel, and Benaiah.
All these had taken foreign wives, and some of them had wives by whom they had children.
The words of Nehemiah, son of Hachaliah. It happened in the month of Chisleu, in the twentieth year, while I was in the palace at Shushan.
Hanani, one of my brothers, arrived with some men from Judah, and I inquired about the Jews who had escaped the captivity and about Jerusalem.
They replied, "The remnant left from the captivity in the province is in great distress and disgrace; the wall of Jerusalem is broken down, and its gates have been burned with fire."
When I heard these words, I sat down, wept, mourned for several days, fasted, and prayed before the God of heaven.
I said, "I beseech you, O LORD God of heaven, the great and awesome God, who keeps covenant and mercy for those who love Him and observe His commandments:

Let your ear now be attentive, and your eyes open, that you may hear the prayer of your servant, which I pray before you day and night for the children of Israel, your servants, and confess the sins of the children of Israel, which we have committed against you; both I and my father's house have sinned.
We have acted very corruptly against you and have not kept the commandments, statutes, or judgments that you commanded your servant Moses.
Remember, I beseech you, the word you commanded your servant Moses, saying, 'If you transgress, I will scatter you among the nations.'

But if you return to me and keep my commandments and do them, even if you were cast out to the farthest part of the heavens, I will gather them from there and bring them to the place I have chosen to set my name.
Now these are your servants and your people, whom you have redeemed by your great power and strong hand.

O LORD, I beseech you, let your ear be attentive to the prayer of your servant and to the prayer of your servants who desire to fear your name; grant success to your servant today and give him favor in the sight of this man. For I was the king's cupbearer.
In the month of Nisan, during the twentieth year of King Artaxerxes, wine was presented before him. I took the wine and gave it to the king, having never before appeared sad in his presence.
The king asked me, "Why is your face sad when you are not ill? This can only be sorrow of the heart." I became very afraid.
I replied to the king, "May the king live forever! Why should my face not be sad when the city, the resting place of my ancestors, lies in ruins and its gates have been burned down?"
The king then asked me, "What is your request?" I prayed to the God of heaven.
I said to the king, "If it pleases you, and if I have found favor in your sight, please send me to Judah, to the city of my ancestors' tombs, so that I may rebuild it."
The king, with the queen sitting beside him, asked, "How long will your journey take, and when will you return?" It pleased the king to send me, and I set a time for my return.
Furthermore, I requested of the king, "If it pleases you, please provide me with letters to the governors beyond the river, so they will grant me safe passage until I reach Judah.

And a letter to Asaph, the keeper of the king's forest, so he will give me timber to make beams for the gates of the palace, the wall of the city, and the house I will enter." The king granted my requests, for the good hand of my God was upon me.
I arrived at the governors beyond the river and delivered the king's letters. The king had also sent captains of the army and horsemen with me.
When Sanballat the Horonite and Tobiah the Ammonite servant heard about it, they were greatly displeased that someone had come to seek the welfare of the children of Israel.
I arrived in Jerusalem and stayed there for three days.
At night, I set out with a few men; I did not tell anyone what God had put in my heart to do in Jerusalem, and I had no animal with me except the one I rode.
I went out at night through the Valley Gate, past the Dragon Well, and to the Dung Gate, inspecting the walls of Jerusalem that had been broken down and the gates that had been burned.
I continued to the Fountain Gate and the King’s Pool, but there was no room for my animal to pass.
So I went up the valley at night and inspected the wall. I returned and entered through the Valley Gate.
The rulers did not know where I had gone or what I was doing; I had not yet shared my plans with the Jews, the priests, the nobles, or the officials, or anyone else involved in the work.
Then I said to them, "You see the trouble we are in: Jerusalem lies in ruins, and its gates have been burned. Come, let us rebuild the wall of Jerusalem, so we will no longer be a disgrace."

I shared with them how the hand of my God had been favorable to me, and the words the king had spoken to me. They responded, "Let us rise up and build!" So they strengthened their hands for the good work.

However, when Sanballat the Horonite, Tobiah the Ammonite servant, and Geshem the Arabian heard about it, they mocked us and despised us, saying, "What is this you are doing? Are you rebelling against the king?"
I replied to them, "The God of heaven will grant us success; we, His servants, will rise and build, but you have no share, right, or memorial in Jerusalem."

Then Eliashib the high priest rose up with his fellow priests, and they built the sheep gate; they consecrated it and set up its doors; as far as the tower of Meah they consecrated it, up to the tower of Hananeel.
Next to him, the men of Jericho built. Next to them, Zaccur the son of Imri built.
The sons of Hassenaah built the fish gate; they also laid its beams and set up its doors, locks, and bars.
Next to them, Meremoth the son of Urijah, the son of Koz, repaired. Next to him, Meshullam the son of Berechiah, the son of Meshezabeel, repaired. Next to him, Zadok the son of Baana repaired.
Next to them, the Tekoites repaired; however, their nobles did not put their shoulders to the work of their LORD.
Moreover, Jehoiada the son of Paseah and Meshullam the son of Besodeiah repaired the old gate; they laid its beams and set up its doors, locks, and bars.
Next to them, Melatiah the Gibeonite and Jadon the Meronothite, men of Gibeon and Mizpah, repaired up to the throne of the governor on this side of the river.
Next to him, Uzziel the son of Harhaiah, of the goldsmiths, repaired. Next to him, Hananiah the son of one of the apothecaries repaired, and they fortified Jerusalem up to the broad wall.
Next to them, Rephaiah the son of Hur, the ruler of half of Jerusalem, repaired.
Next to them, Jedaiah the son of Harumaph repaired, directly opposite his house. Next to him, Hattush the son of Hashabniah repaired.
Malchijah the son of Harim and Hashub the son of Pahathmoab repaired another section, including the tower of the furnaces.
Next to him, Shallum the son of Halohesh, the ruler of half of Jerusalem, repaired, along with his daughters.
The valley gate was repaired by Hanun and the inhabitants of Zanoah; they built it, set up its doors, locks, and bars, and a thousand cubits on the wall up to the dung gate.
Malchiah the son of Rechab, the ruler of part of Bethhaccerem, repaired the dung gate; he built it and set up its doors, locks, and bars.

Shallun the son of Colhozeh, the ruler of part of Mizpah, repaired the fountain gate; he built it, covered it, set up its doors, locks, and bars, and the wall of the pool of Siloah by the king's garden, and to the stairs that go down from the city of David.
After him, Nehemiah the son of Azbuk, the ruler of half of Bethzur, repaired up to the place opposite the sepulchres of David, to the pool that was made, and to the house of the mighty.
After him, the Levites, Rehum the son of Bani, repaired. Next to him, Hashabiah, the ruler of half of Keilah, repaired in his section.
After him, their brethren, Bavai the son of Henadad, the ruler of half of Keilah, repaired.
Next to him, Ezer the son of Jeshua, the ruler of Mizpah, repaired another section opposite the ascent to the armory at the turning of the wall.
After him, Baruch the son of Zabbai earnestly repaired another section, from the turning of the wall to the door of the house of Eliashib the high priest.
After him, Meremoth the son of Urijah, the son of Koz, repaired another section, from the door of the house of Eliashib to the end of his house.
After him, the priests, the men of the plain, repaired.
After him, Benjamin and Hashub repaired opposite their house. After him, Azariah the son of Maaseiah, the son of Ananiah, repaired by his house.
After him, Binnui the son of Henadad repaired another section, from the house of Azariah to the turning of the wall, up to the corner.
Palal the son of Uzai repaired opposite the turning of the wall and the tower that projects from the king's high house, near the court of the prison. After him, Pedaiah the son of Parosh repaired.
Moreover, the Nethinims lived in Ophel, opposite the water gate toward the east, and the tower that projects.
After them, the Tekoites repaired another section, opposite the great tower that projects, up to the wall of Ophel.
From above the horse gate, the priests repaired, each one opposite his house.
After them, Zadok the son of Immer repaired opposite his house. After him, Shemaiah the son of Shechaniah, the keeper of the east gate, repaired.
After him, Hananiah the son of Shelemiah and Hanun the sixth son of Zalaph repaired another section. After him, Meshullam the son of Berechiah repaired opposite his chamber.
After him, Malchiah the son of the goldsmith repaired up to the place of the Nethinims and the merchants, opposite the gate Miphkad, and to the ascent of the corner.
Between the ascent of the corner and the sheep gate, the goldsmiths and merchants repaired.
But it came to pass that when Sanballat heard that we were building the wall, he became furious, took great offense, and mocked the Jews.

He spoke before his brethren and the army of Samaria, saying, "What do these weak Jews think they are doing? Will they fortify themselves? Will they offer sacrifices? Will they complete their work in a day? Will they revive the stones from the heaps of burned rubble?"
Now Tobiah the Ammonite was with him, and he said, "Even what they are building, if a fox were to climb up on it, he would break down their stone wall."
"Hear, O our God, for we are despised; turn their reproach upon their own heads, and give them as prey in the land of captivity.
And do not cover their iniquity; let not their sin be erased from before You, for they have provoked You to anger before the builders."
So we built the wall, and the entire wall was joined together to half its height, for the people had a mind to work.

But it came to pass that when Sanballat, Tobiah, the Arabians, the Ammonites, and the Ashdodites heard that the walls of Jerusalem were being restored and that the breaches were beginning to be closed, they were very angry.
They conspired together to come and fight against Jerusalem and to hinder it.
Nevertheless, we prayed to our God and set a watch against them day and night because of this.
Judah said, "The strength of the bearers of burdens is failing, and there is much rubbish, so we are unable to build the wall."
Our adversaries said, "They will not know or see until we come among them, kill them, and cause the work to cease."
And it came to pass that when the Jews who lived near them came, they said to us ten times, "From all places where you turn, they will be upon you."
Therefore, I stationed people in the lower places behind the wall and on the higher places; I set the people by their families with their swords, spears, and bows.

I looked, rose up, and said to the nobles, the rulers, and the rest of the people, "Do not be afraid of them; remember the LORD, who is great and awesome, and fight for your brethren, your sons, your daughters, your wives, and your homes."
And it came to pass that when our enemies heard that it was known to us and that God had frustrated their plan, we all returned to the wall, each one to his work.
From that time on, half of my servants worked on the project, while the other half held the spears, shields, bows, and armor; and the rulers stood behind all the people of Judah.
Those who built the wall and those who carried burdens, each with one hand worked on the project and with the other hand held a weapon.
For the builders, each had his sword girded at his side as they built. And he who sounded the trumpet was beside me.
I said to the nobles, the rulers, and the rest of the people, "The work is great and extensive, and we are separated on the wall, one far from another.
In whatever place you hear the sound of the trumpet, gather there to us; our God will fight for us."
So we labored in the work, and half of them held the spears from dawn until the stars appeared.
At the same time, I said to the people, "Let every one of you and your servants stay within Jerusalem, so that they may be a guard for us by night and a laborer by day."
So neither I, nor my brethren, nor my servants, nor the men of the guard who followed me, did any of us take off our clothes, except for when each one needed to wash them.
And there was a loud outcry from the people and their wives against their fellow Jews.
For some said, "We, our sons, and our daughters are numerous; therefore, we must obtain grain for them so that we may eat and survive."
Others said, "We have mortgaged our fields, vineyards, and homes to buy grain due to the famine."
There were also those who said, "We have borrowed money for the king's tax, putting our fields and vineyards as collateral."

Yet now our flesh is the same as the flesh of our brothers, our children as their children. Behold, we are forcing our sons and daughters into servitude, and some of our daughters are already in bondage. We cannot redeem them, for others possess our fields and vineyards.
I was very angry when I heard their outcry and these words.
Then I consulted with myself, and I rebuked the nobles and the officials, saying to them, "You are exacting usury from each of your brothers." I gathered a large assembly against them.
I said to them, "We have redeemed our fellow Jews who were sold to the nations, and will you sell your brothers? Or will they be sold to us?" They remained silent and had no response.
I also said, "What you are doing is not right. Should you not walk in the fear of our God to avoid the reproach of the nations, our enemies?"
I, along with my brothers and my servants, could have demanded money and grain from them; I urge you to stop this usury.
I ask you to restore to them today their fields, vineyards, olive groves, and homes, along with the interest on the money, grain, wine, and oil that you have exacted from them.
They replied, "We will restore everything and require nothing from them; we will do as you say." Then I called the priests and made them take an oath to act according to this promise.

I also shook out the folds of my robe and said, "So may God shake out every man from his house and from his labor who does not keep this promise; may he be shaken out and emptied." And all the congregation said, "Amen," and praised the LORD. The people acted according to this promise.

Furthermore, from the time I was appointed as their governor in the land of Judah, from the twentieth year until the thirty-second year of King Artaxerxes, a total of twelve years, neither I nor my brothers consumed the governor's provisions.

But the previous governors who were before me burdened the people, taking bread and wine from them, in addition to forty shekels of silver; even their servants ruled over the people. But I did not do so because of the fear of God.
Indeed, I continued the work on this wall, and we did not buy any land; all my servants were gathered for the work.
Moreover, there were one hundred and fifty Jews and officials at my table, besides those who came to us from the surrounding nations.

Now what was prepared for me daily included one ox and six choice sheep; also, birds were prepared for me, and every ten days an abundance of all kinds of wine. Yet, despite all this, I did not demand the governor's provisions, because the burden was heavy on this people.
Remember me, my God, for good, according to all that I have done for this people.

It came to pass that when Sanballat, Tobiah, Geshem the Arabian, and the rest of our enemies heard that I had built the wall and that there was no breach left in it (though at that time I had not yet set up the doors on the gates),
Sanballat and Geshem sent to me, saying, "Come, let us meet together in one of the villages in the plain of Ono." But they intended to do me harm.
I sent messengers to them, saying, "I am engaged in a great work, and I cannot come down. Why should the work cease while I leave it to come down to you?"
Yet they sent to me four times in this manner, and I answered them the same way each time.
Then Sanballat sent his servant to me a fifth time with an open letter in his hand,

in which it was written, "It is reported among the nations, and Gashmu says it, that you and the Jews intend to rebel. That is why you are building the wall, so that you may become their king, according to these words.

And you have also appointed prophets to proclaim concerning you in Jerusalem, saying, 'There is a king in Judah.' Now this report will be made to the king according to these words. Come now, therefore, and let us confer together."
I replied to him, saying, "There is no truth to the things you are saying; you are inventing them out of your own mind."
For they all sought to intimidate us, saying, "Their hands will be weakened from the work, and it will not be done." Now therefore, O God, strengthen my hands.

Afterward, I went to the house of Shemaiah the son of Delaiah the son of Mehetabeel, who was confined to his home. He said, "Let us meet together in the house of God, within the temple, and let us shut the doors of the temple, for they are coming to kill you; yes, in the night they will come to kill you."
I said, "Should such a man as I flee? And who is there that, being as I am, would go into the temple to save his life? I will not go in."
And behold, I perceived that God had not sent him, but that he pronounced this prophecy against me because Tobiah and Sanballat had hired him.
He was hired to intimidate me, to cause me to be afraid, and to sin, so that they might have grounds for an evil report and reproach me.
My God, remember Tobiah and Sanballat according to their works, and also the prophetess Noadiah and the rest of the prophets who sought to intimidate me.
So the wall was completed on the twenty-fifth day of the month Elul, in fifty-two days.

When all our enemies heard about this, and all the nations around us saw these things, they were greatly disheartened in their own eyes, for they realized that this work had been accomplished with the help of our God.
Moreover, in those days, the nobles of Judah sent many letters to Tobiah, and Tobiah's letters came to them.
For many in Judah were bound by oath to him, since he was the son-in-law of Shechaniah the son of Arah, and his son Johanan had married the daughter of Meshullam the son of Berechiah.
They also reported his good deeds to me and relayed my words to him. And Tobiah sent letters to intimidate me.
Now it came to pass, when the wall was completed, and I had installed the doors, and appointed the porters, singers, and Levites,
That I entrusted my brother Hanani, and Hananiah, the ruler of the palace, with the oversight of Jerusalem, for he was a faithful man who feared God more than many.

And I instructed them, "Do not let the gates of Jerusalem be opened until the sun is hot; while they stand guard, let them shut the doors and bar them. Appoint watches from among the inhabitants of Jerusalem, each in their watch, and each opposite their own house."
Now the city was large and great, but the population was few, and the houses had not yet been built.
And my God put it in my heart to gather the nobles, rulers, and people so that they might be counted by genealogy. I found a register of those who had come up first and found it written therein,
These are the children of the province who returned from captivity, those who had been carried away by Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, and returned to Jerusalem and Judah, each to their own city;
Who came with Zerubbabel, Jeshua, Nehemiah, Azariah, Raamiah, Nahamani, Mordecai, Bilshan, Mispereth, Bigvai, Nehum, and Baanah. The number of the men of the people of Israel was as follows:
The children of Parosh, two thousand one hundred seventy-two.
The children of Shephatiah, three hundred seventy-two.
The children of Arah, six hundred fifty-two.
The children of Pahathmoab, of the children of Jeshua and Joab, two thousand eight hundred eighteen.
The children of Elam, one thousand two hundred fifty-four.
The children of Zattu, eight hundred forty-five.
The children of Zaccai, seven hundred sixty-three.
The children of Binnui, six hundred forty-eight.
The children of Bebai, six hundred twenty-eight.
The children of Azgad, two thousand three hundred twenty-two.
The children of Adonikam, six hundred sixty-seven.
The children of Bigvai, two thousand sixty-seven.
The children of Adin, six hundred fifty-five.
The children of Ater of Hezekiah, ninety-eight.
The children of Hashum, three hundred twenty-eight.
The children of Bezai, three hundred twenty-four.
The children of Hariph, one hundred twelve.
The children of Gibeon, ninety-five.
The men of Bethlehem and Netophah, one hundred eighty-eight.
The men of Anathoth, one hundred twenty-eight.
The men of Bethazmaveth, forty-two.
The men of Kirjathjearim, Chephirah, and Beeroth, seven hundred forty-three.
The men of Ramah and Gaba, six hundred twenty-one.
The men of Michmas, one hundred twenty-two.
The men of Bethel and Ai, one hundred twenty-three.
The men of the other Nebo, fifty-two.
The children of the other Elam, one thousand two hundred fifty-four.
The children of Harim, three hundred twenty.
The children of Jericho, three hundred forty-five.
The children of Lod, Hadid, and Ono, seven hundred twenty-one.
The children of Senaah, three thousand nine hundred thirty.
The priests: the children of Jedaiah, of the house of Jeshua, nine hundred seventy-three.
The children of Immer, one thousand fifty-two.
The children of Pashur, one thousand two hundred forty-seven.
The children of Harim, one thousand seventeen.
The Levites: the children of Jeshua, of Kadmiel, and of the children of Hodevah, seventy-four.
The singers: the children of Asaph, one hundred forty-eight.
The porters: the children of Shallum, the children of Ater, the children of Talmon, the children of Akkub, the children of Hatita, and the children of Shobai, one hundred thirty-eight.
The Nethinims: the children of Ziha, the children of Hashupha, and the children of Tabbaoth,
The children of Keros, the children of Sia, and the children of Padon,
The children of Lebana, the children of Hagaba, and the children of Shalmai,
The children of Hanan, the children of Giddel, and the children of Gahar,
The children of Reaiah, the children of Rezin, and the children of Nekoda,
The children of Gazzam, the children of Uzza, and the children of Phaseah,
The children of Besai, the children of Meunim, and the children of Nephishesim,
The children of Bakbuk, the children of Hakupha, and the children of Harhur,
The children of Bazlith, the children of Mehida, and the children of Harsha,
The children of Barkos, the children of Sisera, and the children of Tamah,
The children of Neziah, and the children of Hatipha.
The children of Solomon's servants: the children of Sotai, the children of Sophereth, and the children of Perida,
The children of Jaala, the children of Darkon, and the children of Giddel,
The children of Shephatiah, the children of Hattil, the children of Pochereth of Zebaim, and the children of Amon.
All the Nethinims and the children of Solomon's servants totaled three hundred ninety-two.
And these were those who also came up from Telmelah, Telharesha, Cherub, Addon, and Immer: but they could not show their father's house, nor their lineage, whether they were of Israel.
The children of Delaiah, the children of Tobiah, and the children of Nekoda, six hundred forty-two.
And of the priests: the children of Habaiah, the children of Koz, and the children of Barzillai, who took one of the daughters of Barzillai the Gileadite as his wife, and was called by their name.
These sought their register among those who were counted by genealogy, but it was not found; therefore, they were considered polluted and excluded from the priesthood.
And the Tirshatha said to them that they should not eat of the most holy things until a priest stood up with Urim and Thummim.
The whole congregation together numbered forty-two thousand three hundred sixty,
Besides their male and female servants, of whom there were seven thousand three hundred thirty-seven; and they had two hundred forty-five singing men and singing women.
Their horses numbered seven hundred thirty-six; their mules, two hundred forty-five;
Their camels, four hundred thirty-five; and their donkeys, six thousand seven hundred twenty.
And some of the chief of the fathers contributed to the work. The Tirshatha gave to the treasury one thousand drams of gold, fifty basins, and five hundred thirty priestly garments.
And some of the chief of the fathers gave to the treasury of the work twenty thousand drams of gold and two thousand two hundred pounds of silver.
And what the rest of the people gave was twenty thousand drams of gold, two thousand pounds of silver, and sixty-seven priestly garments.

So the priests, Levites, porters, singers, and some of the people, along with the Nethinims, and all Israel, dwelt in their cities; and when the seventh month arrived, the children of Israel were in their cities.

And all the people gathered together as one man in the street before the Water Gate; they spoke to Ezra the scribe, asking him to bring the book of the law of Moses, which the LORD had commanded to Israel.
Ezra the priest brought the law before the congregation, including men and women, and all who could understand, on the first day of the seventh month.
He read from the book in front of the Water Gate from morning until midday, before the men, women, and those who could understand; the ears of all the people were attentive to the book of the law.

Ezra the scribe stood on a wooden pulpit made for this purpose; beside him stood Mattithiah, Shema, Anaiah, Urijah, Hilkiah, and Maaseiah on his right, and on his left stood Pedaiah, Mishael, Malchiah, Hashum, Hashbadana, Zechariah, and Meshullam.
Ezra opened the book in the sight of all the people; (for he was above all the people;) and when he opened it, all the people stood up.
Ezra blessed the LORD, the great God, and all the people answered, "Amen, Amen," lifting their hands; they bowed their heads and worshipped the LORD with their faces to the ground.

Jeshua, Bani, Sherebiah, Jamin, Akkub, Shabbethai, Hodijah, Maaseiah, Kelita, Azariah, Jozabad, Hanan, Pelaiah, and the Levites helped the people understand the law, and the people stood in their place.
They read from the book of the law of God distinctly, gave the sense, and helped them understand the reading.

Nehemiah, who is the Tirshatha, Ezra the priest and scribe, and the Levites who taught the people said to all the people, "This day is holy to the LORD your God; do not mourn or weep." For all the people wept when they heard the words of the law.

Then he said to them, "Go your way, eat the fat, drink the sweet, and send portions to those for whom nothing is prepared; for this day is holy to our LORD. Do not be sorrowful, for the joy of the LORD is your strength."
So the Levites quieted all the people, saying, "Be still, for the day is holy; do not be grieved."
And all the people went their way to eat, drink, send portions, and make great joy, because they had understood the words that were declared to them.
On the second day, the chief of the fathers of all the people, the priests, and the Levites gathered together to Ezra the scribe to understand the words of the law.
They found written in the law which the LORD had commanded by Moses that the children of Israel should dwell in booths during the feast of the seventh month.

They were to proclaim in all their cities and in Jerusalem, saying, "Go out to the mountain and bring olive branches, pine branches, myrtle branches, palm branches, and branches of thick trees to make booths, as it is written."

So the people went out, brought them, and made booths for themselves, each on the roof of their house, in their courts, in the courts of the house of God, and in the street of the Water Gate, and in the street of the gate of Ephraim.

All the congregation that had returned from captivity made booths and sat under them; for since the days of Jeshua the son of Nun until that day, the children of Israel had not done so. And there was very great gladness.

Day by day, from the first day to the last day, he read from the book of the law of God. They kept the feast for seven days, and on the eighth day, there was a solemn assembly, according to the custom.
On the twenty-fourth day of this month, the children of Israel gathered together in fasting, wearing sackcloth and dust on their heads.
The descendants of Israel separated themselves from all foreigners, standing and confessing their sins and the iniquities of their ancestors.
They stood in their place and read from the book of the law of the LORD their God for a quarter of the day; for another quarter, they confessed and worshipped the LORD their God.
Then Jeshua, Bani, Kadmiel, Shebaniah, Bunni, Sherebiah, Bani, and Chenani stood on the stairs of the Levites and cried out with a loud voice to the LORD their God.

The Levites—Jeshua, Kadmiel, Bani, Hashabniah, Sherebiah, Hodijah, Shebaniah, and Pethahiah—said, "Stand up and bless the LORD your God forever and ever; blessed be your glorious name, which is exalted above all blessing and praise."

You alone are the LORD; you made the heavens, the highest heavens, with all their host, the earth and everything in it, the seas and all that is in them, and you preserve them all; the host of heaven worships you.
You are the LORD God who chose Abram, brought him out of Ur of the Chaldeans, and gave him the name Abraham;

You found his heart faithful before you and made a covenant with him to give the land of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Jebusites, and Girgashites to his descendants, and you have fulfilled your words; for you are righteous.
You saw the affliction of our ancestors in Egypt and heard their cry by the Red Sea;
You showed signs and wonders against Pharaoh, his servants, and all the people of his land, for you knew they dealt proudly against them. Thus, you made a name for yourself, as it is this day.
You divided the sea before them, so they went through the midst of the sea on dry land; their pursuers you hurled into the depths, like a stone into mighty waters.
Moreover, you led them by a cloudy pillar during the day and by a pillar of fire at night, to give them light on the path they should take.
You came down on Mount Sinai, spoke with them from heaven, and gave them right judgments, true laws, good statutes, and commandments.
You made known to them your holy Sabbath and commanded them precepts, statutes, and laws through your servant Moses.
You provided them bread from heaven for their hunger and brought forth water from the rock for their thirst, and promised them that they would go in to possess the land you had sworn to give them.
But they and our ancestors acted arrogantly, stiffened their necks, and did not listen to your commandments.

They refused to obey, were not mindful of your wonders that you performed among them; they hardened their necks and, in their rebellion, appointed a captain to return to their bondage. Yet you are a God ready to pardon, gracious and merciful, slow to anger, and of great kindness; you did not forsake them.
Even when they made a molten calf and said, "This is your God who brought you up out of Egypt," and committed great provocations,

You, in your manifold mercies, did not forsake them in the wilderness; the pillar of cloud did not depart from them by day to lead them on their way, nor the pillar of fire by night to give them light on the path they should take.
You also gave your good Spirit to instruct them, and did not withhold your manna from their mouths, and provided them water for their thirst.
For forty years you sustained them in the wilderness, so they lacked nothing; their clothes did not wear out, and their feet did not swell.
Moreover, you gave them kingdoms and nations, and divided them into districts; so they possessed the land of Sihon, the land of the king of Heshbon, and the land of Og, king of Bashan.
Their children you multiplied as the stars of heaven and brought them into the land you promised their fathers that they would go in to possess.

So the children went in and possessed the land, and you subdued before them the inhabitants of the land, the Canaanites, and gave them into their hands, along with their kings and the people of the land, that they might do with them as they wished.

They took strong cities and a fertile land, and possessed houses full of all good things, wells dug, vineyards, olive groves, and fruit trees in abundance; so they ate, were filled, became fat, and delighted themselves in your great goodness.

Nevertheless, they were disobedient and rebelled against you, casting your law behind their backs, and killed your prophets who testified against them to turn them back to you; they committed great provocations.

Therefore, you delivered them into the hands of their enemies, who oppressed them; and in the time of their trouble, when they cried out to you, you heard them from heaven; and according to your manifold mercies, you gave them saviors who saved them from the hand of their enemies.

But after they had rest, they did evil again before you; therefore, you left them in the hand of their enemies, who had dominion over them. Yet when they returned and cried out to you, you heard them from heaven; and many times you delivered them according to your mercies.

You testified against them to bring them back to your law; yet they acted arrogantly and did not listen to your commandments, but sinned against your judgments, which if a man does, he shall live in them; they withdrew the shoulder, hardened their neck, and would not listen.
Yet for many years you bore with them and testified against them by your Spirit in your prophets; yet they would not listen; therefore, you gave them into the hands of the peoples of the lands.
Nevertheless, for your great mercies' sake, you did not utterly consume them or forsake them; for you are a gracious and merciful God.

Now therefore, our God, the great, mighty, and terrible God, who keeps covenant and mercy, let not all the trouble that has come upon us, on our kings, princes, priests, prophets, fathers, and all your people, seem little before you, since the time of the kings of Assyria until this day.
However, you are just in all that has come upon us; for you have done right, but we have done wickedly.
Neither have our kings, princes, priests, nor our fathers kept your law, nor listened to your commandments and testimonies, with which you testified against them.

For they have not served you in their kingdom, and in your great goodness that you gave them, and in the large and fertile land which you set before them; neither did they turn from their wicked works.
Behold, we are servants this day, and for the land that you gave to our fathers to eat the fruit and the good of it, behold, we are servants in it.
And it yields much increase to the kings whom you have set over us because of our sins; they also have dominion over our bodies and our cattle at their pleasure, and we are in great distress.
And because of all this, we make a sure covenant and write it; and our princes, Levites, and priests seal it.
Now those who sealed were Nehemiah, the Tirshatha, the son of Hachaliah, and Zidkijah;
Seraiah, Azariah, Jeremiah;
Pashur, Amariah, Malchijah;
Hattush, Shebaniah, Malluch;
Harim, Meremoth, Obadiah;
Daniel, Ginnethon, Baruch;
Meshullam, Abijah, Mijamin;
Maaziah, Bilgai, Shemaiah: these were the priests.
And the Levites: both Jeshua the son of Azaniah, Binnui of the sons of Henadad, Kadmiel;
And their brethren, Shebaniah, Hodijah, Kelita, Pelaiah, Hanan;
Micha, Rehob, Hashabiah;
Zaccur, Sherebiah, Shebaniah;
Hodijah, Bani, Beninu.
The chiefs of the people: Parosh, Pahathmoab, Elam, Zatthu, Bani;
Bunni, Azgad, Bebai;
Adonijah, Bigvai, Adin;
Ater, Hizkijah, Azzur;
Hodijah, Hashum, Bezai;
Hariph, Anathoth, Nebai;
Magpiash, Meshullam, Hezir;
Meshezabeel, Zadok, Jaddua;
Pelatiah, Hanan, Anaiah;
Hoshea, Hananiah, Hashub;
Hallohesh, Pileha, Shobek;
Rehum, Hashabnah, Maaseiah;
And Ahijah, Hanan, Anan;
Malluch, Harim, Baanah.

And the rest of the people, the priests, the Levites, the porters, the singers, the Nethinims, and all who had separated themselves from the people of the lands to the law of God, their wives, their sons, and their daughters, everyone having knowledge and understanding;

They joined with their brethren, their nobles, and entered into a curse and an oath, to walk in God's law, which was given by Moses the servant of God, and to observe and do all the commandments of the LORD our Lord, and His judgments and His statutes;
And that we would not give our daughters to the people of the land, nor take their daughters for our sons;

And if the people of the land bring ware or any victuals on the Sabbath day to sell, we would not buy it from them on the Sabbath or on the holy day; and that we would leave the seventh year and the exaction of every debt.
Also, we made ordinances for ourselves, to charge ourselves yearly with a third part of a shekel for the service of the house of our God;

For the showbread, and for the continual meat offering, and for the continual burnt offering, of the Sabbaths, of the new moons, for the set feasts, and for the holy things, and for the sin offerings to make atonement for Israel, and for all the work of the house of our God.

And we cast lots among the priests, the Levites, and the people for the wood offering, to bring it into the house of our God, after the houses of our fathers, at times appointed year by year, to burn upon the altar of the LORD our God, as it is written in the law;
And to bring the firstfruits of our ground, and the firstfruits of all fruit of all trees, year by year, to the house of the LORD;

Also, the firstborn of our sons and of our cattle, as it is written in the law, and the firstlings of our herds and of our flocks, to bring to the house of our God, to the priests who minister in the house of our God;

And that we should bring the firstfruits of our dough, and our offerings, and the fruit of all manner of trees, of wine and of oil, to the priests, to the chambers of the house of our God; and the tithes of our ground to the Levites, that the same Levites might have the tithes in all the cities of our tillage.

And the priest, the son of Aaron, shall be with the Levites when the Levites take tithes; and the Levites shall bring up the tithe of the tithes to the house of our God, to the chambers, into the treasure house.

For the children of Israel and the children of Levi shall bring the offering of the corn, of the new wine, and the oil, to the chambers, where are the vessels of the sanctuary, and the priests who minister, and the porters, and the singers; and we will not forsake the house of our God.

The rulers of the people resided in Jerusalem, while the remaining populace cast lots to determine that one out of ten would live in Jerusalem, the holy city, and the other nine would inhabit various other cities.
The people expressed their gratitude to all those who willingly chose to reside in Jerusalem.

These are the leaders of the province who lived in Jerusalem; however, in the cities of Judah, each person dwelled in their own property, including the Israelites, priests, Levites, Nethinims, and the descendants of Solomon's servants.

In Jerusalem, certain descendants of Judah and Benjamin resided. Among the children of Judah were Athaiah, the son of Uzziah, who was the son of Zechariah, the son of Amariah, the son of Shephatiah, the son of Mahalaleel, from the lineage of Perez.
Maaseiah, the son of Baruch, was also listed, being the son of Colhozeh, the son of Hazaiah, the son of Adaiah, the son of Joiarib, the son of Zechariah, the son of Shiloni.
All the sons of Perez who lived in Jerusalem numbered four hundred sixty-eight valiant men.
The sons of Benjamin included Sallu, the son of Meshullam, who was the son of Joed, the son of Pedaiah, the son of Kolaiah, the son of Maaseiah, the son of Ithiel, the son of Jesaiah.
Following him were Gabbai and Sallai, totaling nine hundred twenty-eight.
Joel, the son of Zichri, served as their overseer, while Judah, the son of Senuah, was second in command over the city.
Among the priests were Jedaiah, the son of Joiarib, and Jachin.
Seraiah, the son of Hilkiah, who was the son of Meshullam, the son of Zadok, the son of Meraioth, the son of Ahitub, served as the ruler of the house of God.

Their brethren who worked in the house numbered eight hundred twenty-two, including Adaiah, the son of Jeroham, the son of Pelaliah, the son of Amzi, the son of Zechariah, the son of Pashur, the son of Malchiah.
His brethren, the heads of families, numbered two hundred forty-two, including Amashai, the son of Azareel, the son of Ahasai, the son of Meshillemoth, the son of Immer.
Their brethren, who were mighty men of valor, numbered one hundred twenty-eight, with Zabdiel, the son of one of the prominent men, as their overseer.
Among the Levites were Shemaiah, the son of Hashub, the son of Azrikam, the son of Hashabiah, the son of Bunni.
Shabbethai and Jozabad, leaders among the Levites, oversaw the external affairs of the house of God.

Mattaniah, the son of Micha, the son of Zabdi, the son of Asaph, was the principal who initiated the thanksgiving in prayer; Bakbukiah was second among his brethren, and Abda, the son of Shammua, the son of Galal, the son of Jeduthun, was also noted.
The total number of Levites in the holy city was two hundred eighty-four.
Additionally, the porters, Akkub, Talmon, and their brethren who guarded the gates, numbered one hundred seventy-two.
The remaining Israelites, including priests and Levites, lived in all the cities of Judah, each in their own inheritance.
The Nethinims resided in Ophel, with Ziha and Gispa overseeing them.
The overseer of the Levites in Jerusalem was Uzzi, the son of Bani, the son of Hashabiah, the son of Mattaniah, the son of Micha. The sons of Asaph were responsible for the music in the house of God.
The king had commanded that a specific portion be allocated for the singers, to be provided daily.
Pethahiah, the son of Meshezabeel, from the children of Zerah, the son of Judah, was at the king's side regarding all matters concerning the people.
In the villages and their fields, some of the children of Judah lived in Kirjatharba and its surrounding villages, in Dibon and its villages, and in Jekabzeel and its villages.
They also resided in Jeshua, Moladah, and Bethphelet,
as well as in Hazarshual, Beersheba, and its villages,
in Ziklag, Mekonah, and its villages,
and in Enrimmon, Zareah, and Jarmuth,
Zanoah, Adullam, and their villages, Lachish and its fields, Azekah and its villages. They lived from Beersheba to the valley of Hinnom.
The children of Benjamin from Geba lived in Michmash, Aija, Bethel, and their villages.
They also resided in Anathoth, Nob, Ananiah,
Hazor, Ramah, Gittaim,
Hadid, Zeboim, Neballat,
Lod, and Ono, in the valley of craftsmen.
The Levites were organized into divisions in both Judah and Benjamin.
Now these are the priests and the Levites who went up with Zerubbabel the son of Shealtiel and Jeshua: Seraiah, Jeremiah, Ezra,
Amariah, Malluch, Hattush,
Shechaniah, Rehum, Meremoth,
Iddo, Ginnetho, Abijah,
Miamin, Maadiah, Bilgah,
Shemaiah, Joiarib, Jedaiah,
Sallu, Amok, Hilkiah, Jedaiah. These were the leaders of the priests and their brethren in the days of Jeshua.
Moreover, the Levites: Jeshua, Binnui, Kadmiel, Sherebiah, Judah, and Mattaniah, who was in charge of the thanksgiving, he and his brethren.
Also, Bakbukiah and Unni, their brethren, were stationed opposite them in the watches.
And Jeshua fathered Joiakim, Joiakim also fathered Eliashib, and Eliashib fathered Joiada,
And Joiada fathered Jonathan, and Jonathan fathered Jaddua.
And in the days of Joiakim, the priests, the leaders of the families, were: of Seraiah, Meraiah; of Jeremiah, Hananiah;
Of Ezra, Meshullam; of Amariah, Jehohanan;
Of Melicu, Jonathan; of Shebaniah, Joseph;
Of Harim, Adna; of Meraioth, Helkai;
Of Iddo, Zechariah; of Ginnethon, Meshullam;
Of Abijah, Zichri; of Miniamin, of Moadiah, Piltai;
Of Bilgah, Shammua; of Shemaiah, Jehonathan;
And of Joiarib, Mattenai; of Jedaiah, Uzzi;
Of Sallai, Kallai; of Amok, Eber;
Of Hilkiah, Hashabiah; of Jedaiah, Nethaneel.
The Levites in the days of Eliashib, Joiada, Johanan, and Jaddua were recorded as leaders of the families: also the priests, to the reign of Darius the Persian.
The sons of Levi, the leaders of the families, were written in the book of the chronicles, even until the days of Johanan the son of Eliashib.

And the leaders of the Levites: Hashabiah, Sherebiah, and Jeshua the son of Kadmiel, with their brethren opposite them, to praise and give thanks, according to the commandment of David the man of God, ward opposite ward.
Mattaniah, Bakbukiah, Obadiah, Meshullam, Talmon, Akkub, were porters keeping the watch at the thresholds of the gates.
These were in the days of Joiakim the son of Jeshua, the son of Jozadak, and in the days of Nehemiah the governor, and of Ezra the priest, the scribe.

And at the dedication of the wall of Jerusalem, they sought the Levites from all their places, to bring them to Jerusalem, to keep the dedication with gladness, both with thanksgivings and with singing, with cymbals, psalteries, and harps.
And the sons of the singers gathered themselves together, both from the plain country around Jerusalem and from the villages of Netophathi;
Also from the house of Gilgal, and from the fields of Geba and Azmaveth: for the singers had built villages around Jerusalem.
And the priests and the Levites purified themselves, and purified the people, and the gates, and the wall.
Then I brought up the leaders of Judah upon the wall, and appointed two great companies of them that gave thanks, of which one went on the right hand upon the wall toward the dung gate:
And after them went Hoshaiah, and half of the leaders of Judah,
And Azariah, Ezra, and Meshullam,
Judah, Benjamin, Shemaiah, and Jeremiah,
And certain of the priests' sons with trumpets; namely, Zechariah the son of Jonathan, the son of Shemaiah, the son of Mattaniah, the son of Michaiah, the son of Zaccur, the son of Asaph:
And his brethren, Shemaiah, Azarael, Milalai, Gilalai, Maai, Nethaneel, and Judah, Hanani, with the musical instruments of David the man of God, and Ezra the scribe before them.
And at the fountain gate, which was opposite them, they went up by the stairs of the city of David, at the ascent of the wall, above the house of David, even unto the water gate eastward.
And the other company of them that gave thanks went opposite them, and I after them, and half of the people upon the wall, from beyond the tower of the furnaces even unto the broad wall;

And from above the gate of Ephraim, and above the old gate, and above the fish gate, and the tower of Hananeel, and the tower of Meah, even unto the sheep gate: and they stood still in the prison gate.
So stood the two companies of them that gave thanks in the house of God, and I, and half of the rulers with me:
And the priests; Eliakim, Maaseiah, Miniamin, Michaiah, Elioenai, Zechariah, and Hananiah, with trumpets;
And Maaseiah, Shemaiah, Eleazar, Uzzi, Jehohanan, Malchijah, Elam, and Ezer. And the singers sang loudly, with Jezrahiah their overseer.
Also that day they offered great sacrifices and rejoiced: for God had made them rejoice with great joy: the wives also and the children rejoiced: so that the joy of Jerusalem was heard even afar off.

And at that time, some were appointed over the chambers for the treasures, for the offerings, for the firstfruits, and for the tithes, to gather into them out of the fields of the cities the portions of the law for the priests and Levites: for Judah rejoiced for the priests and for the Levites that served.
And both the singers and the porters kept the watch of their God, and the watch of the purification, according to the commandment of David and of Solomon his son.
For in the days of David and Asaph of old, there were leaders of the singers, and songs of praise and thanksgiving unto God.

And all Israel in the days of Zerubbabel and in the days of Nehemiah gave the portions of the singers and the porters, every day his portion: and they sanctified holy things unto the Levites; and the Levites sanctified them unto the children of Aaron.
On that day, they read from the book of Moses in the presence of the people; and it was found written that the Ammonite and the Moabite should not enter the congregation of God forever.
Because they did not meet the children of Israel with bread and water, but hired Balaam against them to curse them; however, our God turned the curse into a blessing.
Now it came to pass that when they heard the law, they separated from Israel all the mixed multitude.
Before this, Eliashib the priest, who oversaw the chamber of the house of our God, was allied with Tobiah.

He had prepared for him a large chamber, where previously they had stored the meat offerings, the frankincense, the vessels, and the tithes of the corn, the new wine, and the oil, which were commanded to be given to the Levites, the singers, and the porters, as well as the offerings for the priests.
But during all this time, I was not in Jerusalem; for in the thirty-second year of Artaxerxes, king of Babylon, I came to the king, and after some days, I obtained leave from the king.
I then came to Jerusalem and learned about the evil that Eliashib had done for Tobiah by preparing a chamber in the courts of the house of God.
This greatly distressed me; therefore, I threw out all the household items of Tobiah from the chamber.
Then I commanded that they cleanse the chambers, and I brought back the vessels of the house of God, along with the meat offerings and the frankincense.
I noticed that the portions for the Levites had not been given to them; for the Levites and the singers who performed the work had fled, each to his own field.
Then I contended with the rulers and said, "Why is the house of God forsaken?" I gathered them together and set them in their places.
Then all of Judah brought the tithe of the corn, the new wine, and the oil to the treasuries.

I appointed treasurers over the treasuries: Shelemiah the priest, Zadok the scribe, and Pedaiah of the Levites; and next to them was Hanan, the son of Zaccur, the son of Mattaniah, for they were considered faithful, and their duty was to distribute to their brethren.
Remember me, O my God, concerning this, and do not erase my good deeds that I have done for the house of my God and for its services.

In those days, I saw Jews treading wine presses on the Sabbath, bringing in sheaves, and loading donkeys; as well as wine, grapes, figs, and all kinds of burdens, which they brought into Jerusalem on the Sabbath day. I testified against them on the day they sold provisions.
There were also men of Tyre living there, who brought fish and all kinds of goods and sold them on the Sabbath to the children of Judah and in Jerusalem.
Then I contended with the nobles of Judah and said to them, "What evil thing is this that you do, profaning the Sabbath day?
Did not your fathers do this, and did not our God bring all this evil upon us and upon this city? Yet you bring more wrath upon Israel by profaning the Sabbath."

And it came to pass that when the gates of Jerusalem began to be dark before the Sabbath, I commanded that the gates should be shut and ordered that they should not be opened until after the Sabbath. Some of my servants were stationed at the gates to ensure that no burden would be brought in on the Sabbath day.
So the merchants and sellers of all kinds of goods camped outside Jerusalem once or twice.
Then I testified against them and said to them, "Why do you camp around the wall? If you do so again, I will lay hands on you." From that time on, they did not come back on the Sabbath.

I commanded the Levites to cleanse themselves and to come and guard the gates, to sanctify the Sabbath day. Remember me, O my God, concerning this also, and spare me according to the greatness of your mercy.
In those days, I also saw Jews who had married women from Ashdod, Ammon, and Moab.
Their children spoke half in the language of Ashdod and could not speak the Jews' language, but only according to the language of each people.

I contended with them, cursed them, struck some of them, and pulled out their hair, and made them swear by God, saying, "You shall not give your daughters to their sons, nor take their daughters for your sons or for yourselves."

Did not Solomon, king of Israel, sin by these things? Yet among many nations, there was no king like him, who was beloved by his God, and God made him king over all Israel; nevertheless, even he was led into sin by foreign women.
Shall we then listen to you to do all this great evil, to transgress against our God by marrying foreign wives?
One of the sons of Joiada, the son of Eliashib the high priest, was a son-in-law to Sanballat the Horonite; therefore, I drove him away from me.
Remember them, O my God, because they have defiled the priesthood and the covenant of the priesthood and of the Levites.
Thus, I cleansed them from all foreigners and appointed the duties of the priests and the Levites, each in his own work.
And for the wood offering, at appointed times, and for the firstfruits. Remember me, O my God, for good.
In the days of Ahasuerus, who reigned from India to Ethiopia over one hundred and twenty-seven provinces, it came to pass:
During this time, when King Ahasuerus sat on the throne of his kingdom in Shushan the palace,
In the third year of his reign, he hosted a feast for all his princes and servants; the power of Persia and Media, along with the nobles and princes of the provinces, were present before him.
He displayed the riches of his glorious kingdom and the honor of his excellent majesty for many days, a total of one hundred and eighty days.
When these days were over, the king held a feast for all the people present in Shushan the palace, both great and small, for seven days in the court of the king's garden.

There were white, green, and blue hangings, fastened with cords of fine linen and purple to silver rings and marble pillars; the beds were made of gold and silver, set upon a pavement of red, blue, white, and black marble.
They served drinks in vessels of gold, each vessel unique, and royal wine in abundance, reflecting the king's grandeur.
The drinking was in accordance with the law; no one was compelled, for the king had instructed all the officers of his house to act according to each person's preference.
Queen Vashti also hosted a feast for the women in the royal house belonging to King Ahasuerus.

On the seventh day, when the king's heart was merry with wine, he commanded Mehuman, Biztha, Harbona, Bigtha, Abagtha, Zethar, and Carcas, the seven chamberlains who served in the presence of King Ahasuerus,
To bring Queen Vashti before the king with the royal crown, to show the people and the princes her beauty, for she was lovely to behold.
However, Queen Vashti refused to come at the king's command through his chamberlains; therefore, the king was very angry, and his fury burned within him.
Then the king asked the wise men who understood the times, for it was the king's custom to consult those knowledgeable in law and judgment.
Next to him was Carshena, Shethar, Admatha, Tarshish, Meres, Marsena, and Memucan, the seven princes of Persia and Media, who had access to the king's presence and sat first in the kingdom.
"What shall we do to Queen Vashti according to the law, since she has not obeyed the command of King Ahasuerus delivered by the chamberlains?"
Memucan answered before the king and the princes, "Vashti the queen has not wronged the king alone, but also all the princes and all the people in every province of King Ahasuerus.

For this act of the queen will become known to all women, leading them to despise their husbands in their eyes when it is reported, 'King Ahasuerus commanded Queen Vashti to be brought before him, but she did not come.'
Likewise, the ladies of Persia and Media will say this day to all the king's princes, who have heard of the queen's deed. This will lead to excessive contempt and anger.

If it pleases the king, let a royal decree be issued, and let it be written among the laws of the Persians and Medes, which cannot be altered, that Vashti shall no longer come before King Ahasuerus; and let the king give her royal position to another who is better than she.
When the king's decree is published throughout his vast empire, all wives will honor their husbands, both great and small.
The proposal pleased the king and the princes, and the king acted according to the word of Memucan:

He sent letters to all the king's provinces, to each province in its own script, and to every people in their own language, instructing that every man should be the ruler in his own house, and that this should be proclaimed in the language of each people.
After these events, when King Ahasuerus's anger subsided, he remembered Vashti, what she had done, and the decree made against her.
Then the king's attendants suggested, "Let fair young virgins be sought for the king."

And let the king appoint officials in all the provinces of his kingdom to gather all the fair young virgins to Shushan the palace, to the house of the women, under the care of Hege, the king's chamberlain, keeper of the women; and let them be provided with their purification items.
And let the maiden who pleases the king be made queen instead of Vashti. This proposal pleased the king, and he agreed to it.
Now in Shushan the palace, there was a certain Jew named Mordecai, the son of Jair, the son of Shimei, the son of Kish, a Benjamite.
He had been taken captive from Jerusalem with those who were exiled with Jeconiah, king of Judah, whom Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, had carried away.

Mordecai raised Hadassah, also known as Esther, his uncle's daughter, for she had no father or mother. The maiden was lovely and beautiful; when her parents died, Mordecai adopted her as his own daughter.

When the king's command and decree were proclaimed, and many maidens were gathered to Shushan the palace under the care of Hegai, Esther was also brought to the king's house, to the custody of Hegai, keeper of the women.

The maiden pleased him, and she found favor in his sight; he quickly provided her with her purification items, along with her personal belongings, and seven maidens suitable to serve her from the king's house. He placed her and her maids in the best quarters of the house of the women.
Esther had not revealed her heritage or her people, for Mordecai had instructed her not to disclose it.
Mordecai walked daily in front of the court of the women's house to learn how Esther was doing and what would become of her.

When it was time for each maiden to go in to King Ahasuerus, after she had completed twelve months of preparation (for this was the time required for their purification, six months with oil of myrrh and six months with sweet perfumes and other preparations for the women),
Each maiden approached the king; whatever she desired was given to her to take from the house of the women to the king's house.

In the evening, she would go in, and in the morning, she would return to the second house of the women, to the custody of Shaashgaz, the king's chamberlain who kept the concubines. She would not go in to the king again unless he delighted in her and called for her by name.

When it was Esther's turn, the daughter of Abihail, Mordecai's uncle who had adopted her, she requested nothing except what Hegai, the king's chamberlain, keeper of the women, advised. Esther found favor in the eyes of all who saw her.
So Esther was taken to King Ahasuerus in his royal palace in the tenth month, which is the month of Tebeth, in the seventh year of his reign.
The king loved Esther more than all the other women, and she found grace and favor in his sight more than all the virgins; so he set the royal crown on her head and made her queen instead of Vashti.
Then the king held a great feast for all his officials and servants, even Esther's feast; he proclaimed a release to the provinces and gave gifts according to the generosity of the king.
When the virgins were gathered a second time, Mordecai was sitting at the king's gate.
Esther had not yet revealed her family background or her people, as Mordecai had instructed her, for she continued to follow Mordecai's command just as she had when she was brought up by him.
In those days, while Mordecai was sitting at the king's gate, two of the king's chamberlains, Bigthan and Teresh, who guarded the door, became angry and sought to assassinate King Ahasuerus.
The matter became known to Mordecai, who informed Esther, the queen; and Esther reported it to the king in Mordecai's name.
When the matter was investigated and found to be true, both men were hanged on a gallows, and it was recorded in the book of the chronicles in the presence of the king.
After these events, King Ahasuerus promoted Haman, the son of Hammedatha the Agagite, elevated him, and placed his position above all the princes who were with him.
All the king's servants at the king's gate bowed and honored Haman, as the king had commanded regarding him. However, Mordecai did not bow or show him respect.
The king's servants at the gate asked Mordecai, "Why do you violate the king's command?"
When they spoke to him daily and he did not listen, they informed Haman to see if Mordecai's actions would hold, as he had told them he was a Jew.
When Haman noticed that Mordecai did not bow or show him respect, he became filled with rage.

He considered it beneath him to lay hands on Mordecai alone; instead, he was informed about Mordecai's people, leading Haman to seek the destruction of all Jews throughout the entire kingdom of Ahasuerus, including Mordecai's people.
In the first month, which is Nisan, during the twelfth year of King Ahasuerus, they cast Pur, or lots, before Haman day by day and month by month, until the twelfth month, which is Adar.

Haman said to King Ahasuerus, "There is a certain people scattered and dispersed among the peoples in all the provinces of your kingdom; their laws are different from those of all other nations, and they do not follow the king's laws. Therefore, it is not in the king's best interest to allow them to remain."
"If it pleases the king, let it be decreed that they be destroyed. I will pay ten thousand talents of silver to those in charge of this matter, to bring it into the king's treasury."
The king took his ring from his hand and gave it to Haman, the son of Hammedatha the Agagite, the enemy of the Jews.
The king said to Haman, "The silver is given to you, and the people as well; do with them as you see fit."

On the thirteenth day of the first month, the king's scribes were summoned, and they wrote according to all that Haman had commanded to the king's lieutenants, governors over each province, and rulers of every people in their respective provinces, in their own languages; it was written in the name of King Ahasuerus and sealed with the king's ring.

The letters were dispatched by messengers to all the king's provinces, ordering the destruction, killing, and annihilation of all Jews, young and old, including little children and women, in a single day, on the thirteenth day of the twelfth month, which is Adar, and to seize their possessions as plunder.
A copy of the decree was issued as a command in every province, making it known to all people, so they would be prepared for that day.
The messengers hurried out, compelled by the king's command, and the decree was issued in the palace of Shushan. The king and Haman then sat down to drink, but the city of Shushan was in turmoil.
When Mordecai saw all that had transpired, he tore his clothes, donned sackcloth and ashes, and went out into the heart of the city, crying out with a loud and bitter lament.
He even approached the king's gate, for no one was permitted to enter the king's gate dressed in sackcloth.
In every province, wherever the king's command and decree reached, there was great mourning among the Jews, along with fasting, weeping, and wailing; many lay in sackcloth and ashes.

Esther's maids and her attendants came and informed her of this. The queen was deeply distressed; she sent garments to clothe Mordecai and to remove his sackcloth from him, but he refused to accept them.
Esther then summoned Hatach, one of the king's chamberlains whom he had appointed to serve her, and instructed him to go to Mordecai to find out what was happening and why.
Hatach went out to Mordecai in the city square, which was in front of the king's gate.
Mordecai explained everything that had happened to him, including the amount of money that Haman had promised to pay into the king's treasuries to annihilate the Jews.
He also provided Hatach with a copy of the decree issued in Shushan to destroy the Jews, to show it to Esther, to inform her, and to urge her to approach the king to plead for her people.
Hatach returned and relayed Mordecai's words to Esther.
Once again, Esther spoke to Hatach and instructed him to convey a message to Mordecai:

"All the king's servants and the people of the king's provinces know that if any man or woman approaches the king in the inner court without being summoned, there is but one law: they shall be put to death, unless the king extends the golden scepter to them, allowing them to live. But I have not been called to approach the king for the past thirty days."
They reported Esther's words back to Mordecai.
Then Mordecai instructed them to reply to Esther, "Do not think that you will escape in the king's palace any more than all the other Jews.

For if you remain silent at this time, relief and deliverance for the Jews will arise from another place, but you and your father's family will perish. And who knows but that you have come to your royal position for such a time as this?"
Esther then sent this response to Mordecai:

"Go, gather all the Jews who are in Shushan and fast for me. Do not eat or drink for three days, night or day. I and my maids will fast as you do. When this is done, I will go to the king, even though it is against the law; and if I perish, I perish."
So Mordecai went away and did everything Esther had instructed him to do.

Now it came to pass on the third day that Esther donned her royal attire and stood in the inner court of the king's palace, opposite the king's house: and the king sat upon his royal throne in the royal palace, facing the gate of the house.

And it was so, when the king saw Esther the queen standing in the court, that she found favor in his sight: and the king extended to Esther the golden scepter that was in his hand. So Esther approached and touched the tip of the scepter.
Then the king said to her, "What is it, queen Esther? What is your request? It shall be granted to you, even to half of the kingdom."
And Esther replied, "If it pleases the king, let the king and Haman come this day to the banquet that I have prepared for him."
Then the king said, "Hasten Haman, so that he may do as Esther has said." So the king and Haman went to the banquet that Esther had prepared.
And the king said to Esther at the wine banquet, "What is your petition? It shall be granted to you: and what is your request? Even to half of the kingdom it shall be fulfilled."
Then Esther answered and said, "My petition and my request is this:

If I have found favor in the sight of the king, and if it pleases the king to grant my petition and fulfill my request, let the king and Haman come to the banquet that I will prepare for them, and I will do tomorrow as the king has said."
Then Haman went out that day joyful and with a glad heart: but when Haman saw Mordecai in the king's gate, that he did not rise or move for him, he was filled with rage against Mordecai.
Nevertheless, Haman restrained himself: and when he came home, he sent for his friends and Zeresh his wife.

And Haman told them of the splendor of his riches, the multitude of his children, and all the ways in which the king had honored him, and how he had been elevated above the princes and servants of the king.
Haman added, "Indeed, Esther the queen did not allow anyone to come in with the king to the banquet she had prepared except me; and tomorrow I am also invited to her with the king."
Yet all this means nothing to me as long as I see Mordecai the Jew sitting at the king's gate.
