He also exalts the horn of His people, the praise of all His saints, even of the children of Israel, a people near to Him. Praise the LORD!
Praise the LORD! Sing to the LORD a new song, and offer His praise in the assembly of the faithful.
Let Israel rejoice in their Creator; let the children of Zion be glad in their King.
Let them praise His name with dance; let them sing praises to Him with tambourine and harp.
For the LORD delights in His people; He will adorn the humble with salvation.
Let the saints rejoice in glory; let them sing joyfully upon their beds.
Let the high praises of God be in their mouths, and a two-edged sword in their hands;
To carry out vengeance upon the nations, and punishments upon the peoples;
To bind their kings with chains, and their nobles with shackles of iron;
To carry out the judgment that is written: this honor belongs to all His saints. Praise the LORD!
Praise the LORD! Praise God in His sanctuary; praise Him in the expanse of His power.
Praise Him for His mighty deeds; praise Him for His excellent greatness.
Praise Him with the sound of the trumpet; praise Him with the lute and harp.
Praise Him with the tambourine and dance; praise Him with stringed instruments and flutes.
Praise Him with loud cymbals; praise Him with clashing cymbals.
Let everything that has breath praise the LORD! Praise the LORD!
The proverbs of Solomon, son of David, king of Israel;
To gain wisdom and instruction; to understand the words of insight;
To accept the guidance of wisdom, justice, judgment, and fairness;
To provide insight to the naive, and knowledge and discretion to the young.
A wise person will listen and increase their learning; a person of understanding will attain wise counsel:
To comprehend a proverb and its interpretation; the words of the wise and their enigmatic sayings.
The fear of the LORD is the beginning of knowledge; fools, however, despise wisdom and instruction.
My child, listen to your father's instruction and do not forsake your mother's teaching:
For they will be a garland of grace for your head and chains around your neck.
My child, if sinners entice you, do not consent.
If they say, "Come with us, let us lie in wait for blood, let us ambush the innocent without cause:
Let us swallow them alive like the grave, and whole, like those who go down to the pit:
We will find all precious goods; we will fill our houses with plunder:
Cast your lot in with us; let us all share one purse:"
My child, do not walk in their way; keep your foot from their path:
For their feet run to evil and they hurry to shed blood.
Surely, it is in vain that a net is spread in the sight of any bird.
And they lie in wait for their own blood; they lurk secretly for their own lives.
Such are the ways of everyone who is greedy for gain; it takes away the life of its owners.
Wisdom calls out in the streets; she raises her voice in the public squares:
She cries out at the busiest corners, at the entrance of the city, she speaks her words, saying,
"How long, you simple ones, will you love simplicity? How long will scoffers delight in their scoffing, and fools hate knowledge?
Turn at my rebuke; behold, I will pour out my spirit on you, I will make my words known to you.
Because I have called and you refused; I have stretched out my hand and no one paid attention;
But you have ignored all my counsel and would not accept my rebuke:
I will also laugh at your calamity; I will mock when your fear comes;
When your fear comes like desolation and your destruction comes like a whirlwind; when distress and anguish come upon you.
Then they will call upon me, but I will not answer; they will seek me diligently, but they will not find me:
Because they hated knowledge and did not choose the fear of the LORD:
They rejected my counsel and despised all my rebuke.
Therefore, they shall eat the fruit of their own way and be filled with their own devices.
For the turning away of the simple will slay them, and the complacency of fools will destroy them.
But whoever listens to me will dwell safely and will be at ease from the fear of evil.
My son, if you will accept my words and treasure my commandments within you;
So that you may turn your ear to wisdom and apply your heart to understanding;
Indeed, if you cry out for knowledge and raise your voice for understanding;
If you seek her as silver and search for her as for hidden treasures;
Then you will understand the fear of the LORD and find the knowledge of God.
For the LORD gives wisdom; from His mouth come knowledge and understanding.
He stores up sound wisdom for the righteous; He is a shield to those who walk uprightly.
He guards the paths of justice and preserves the way of His saints.
Then you will understand righteousness, justice, and equity; indeed, every good path.
When wisdom enters your heart and knowledge is pleasant to your soul;
Discretion will protect you, and understanding will keep you safe:
To deliver you from the way of the wicked, from the person who speaks perverse things;
Who forsakes the paths of uprightness to walk in the ways of darkness;
Who rejoice in doing evil and delight in the perversity of the wicked;
Whose paths are crooked, and who are devious in their ways:
To deliver you from the strange woman, from the foreigner who flatters with her words;
Who forsakes the companion of her youth and forgets the covenant of her God.
For her house leads down to death, and her paths to the dead.
None who go to her return, nor do they regain the paths of life.
So that you may walk in the way of good people and keep to the paths of the righteous.
For the upright will dwell in the land, and the blameless will remain in it.
But the wicked will be cut off from the earth, and the treacherous will be rooted out of it.
My son, do not forget my teachings; let your heart hold fast to my commandments.
For they will add length of days, a long life, and peace to you.
Do not let mercy and truth leave you; tie them around your neck; inscribe them on the tablet of your heart.
Then you will find favor and good understanding in the sight of God and man.
Trust in the LORD with all your heart; do not rely on your own understanding.
In all your ways acknowledge Him, and He will make your paths straight.
Do not be wise in your own eyes; fear the LORD and turn away from evil.
This will bring health to your body and nourishment to your bones.
Honor the LORD with your wealth and with the firstfruits of all your crops.
Then your barns will be filled to overflowing, and your vats will brim over with new wine.
My son, do not despise the LORD's discipline, and do not resent His rebuke.
For the LORD disciplines those He loves, as a father the son he delights in.
Blessed is the man who finds wisdom, the man who gains understanding.
For she is more profitable than silver and yields better returns than gold.
She is more precious than rubies; nothing you desire can compare with her.
Long life is in her right hand; in her left hand are riches and honor.
Her paths are pleasant paths, and all her ways are peace.
She is a tree of life to those who embrace her; happy are those who hold her fast.
The LORD founded the earth by wisdom and established the heavens by understanding.
By His knowledge, the watery depths were divided, and the clouds let drop the dew.
My son, do not let wisdom and discretion out of your sight; preserve sound judgment and discernment.
They will be life for you, an ornament to grace your neck.
Then you will go on your way in safety, and your foot will not stumble.
When you lie down, you will not be afraid; when you lie down, your sleep will be sweet.
Do not fear sudden danger or the ruin that overtakes the wicked, when it comes.
For the LORD will be your confidence and will keep your foot from being snared.
Do not withhold good from those to whom it is due, when it is in your power to act.
Do not say to your neighbor, "Come back later; I'll give it tomorrow," when you now have it with you.
Do not plot harm against your neighbor, who lives trustfully near you.
Do not accuse a man for no reason, when he has done you no harm.
Do not envy a violent man or choose any of his ways.
For the LORD detests the perverse but takes the upright into His confidence.
The LORD's curse is on the house of the wicked, but He blesses the home of the righteous.
He mocks proud mockers but shows favor to the humble and oppressed.
The wise inherit honor, but fools get only shame.
Listen, children, to the guidance of a father, and pay attention to gain understanding.
For I provide you with sound teaching; do not abandon my instructions.
I was my father's cherished son, tender and beloved in my mother's eyes.
He also taught me, saying, "Let your heart hold onto my words: keep my commandments and live."
Acquire wisdom, acquire understanding: do not forget it; do not stray from the words I speak.
Do not forsake her, and she will protect you; love her, and she will keep you safe.
Wisdom is the most important thing; therefore, seek wisdom: and in all your pursuits, seek understanding.
Honor her, and she will elevate you; she will bring you respect when you embrace her.
She will grant you a crown of grace upon your head: a glorious crown she will bestow upon you.
Listen, my son, and accept my teachings; and your years will be many.
I have instructed you in the way of wisdom; I have guided you along the right paths.
When you walk, your steps will not be hindered; and when you run, you will not stumble.
Hold tightly to instruction; do not let her go: keep her, for she is your life.
Do not enter the path of the wicked, and do not follow the way of evil people.
Avoid it, do not pass by it, turn away from it, and move on.
For they do not sleep unless they have done something wrong; their sleep is taken away unless they cause someone to fall.
For they consume the bread of wickedness and drink the wine of violence.
But the path of the righteous is like the shining light, which shines brighter and brighter until the perfect day.
The way of the wicked is like darkness: they do not know what they stumble over.
My son, pay attention to my words; incline your ear to my sayings.
Do not let them depart from your sight; keep them in the center of your heart.
For they are life to those who find them, and health to all their flesh.
Guard your heart with all diligence; for from it flow the springs of life.
Remove from you a deceitful mouth, and keep perverse lips far from you.
Let your eyes look straight ahead, and let your eyelids gaze directly before you.
Consider the path of your feet, and let all your ways be established.
Do not turn to the right or to the left; keep your foot from evil.
My son, listen to my wisdom, and pay attention to my understanding:
So that you may value discretion, and your lips may preserve knowledge.
For the words of an unfaithful woman are as sweet as honey, and her speech is smoother than oil:
But her end is as bitter as wormwood, sharp as a double-edged sword.
Her feet lead down to death; her steps take hold of the grave.
Do not ponder the path of life, for her ways are unpredictable, and you cannot know them.
Listen to me now, O children, and do not stray from the words of my mouth.
Keep your distance from her, and do not approach the door of her house:
Lest you give your honor to others, and your years to the cruel:
Lest strangers consume your wealth; and your hard work be in the house of a foreigner;
And you regret it in the end, when your body and flesh are consumed,
And say, How I have hated instruction, and my heart has despised correction;
And have not listened to the voice of my teachers, nor inclined my ear to those who guided me!
I was almost caught in all evil in the midst of the congregation and assembly.
Drink water from your own cistern, and flowing water from your own well.
Let your fountains be dispersed abroad, and streams of water in the streets.
Let them be exclusively yours, and not shared with strangers.
Let your fountain be blessed: and rejoice with the wife of your youth.
Let her be as a loving doe and a graceful deer; let her breasts satisfy you at all times; and may you always be captivated by her love.
And why, my son, would you be captivated by an unfaithful woman, and embrace the bosom of a stranger?
For the ways of man are before the eyes of the LORD, and He examines all his paths.
His own iniquities will trap the wicked, and he will be held fast by the cords of his sins.
He will die without instruction; and in the folly of his arrogance, he will go astray.
My son, if you become surety for your friend, if you have struck your hand with a stranger,
You are ensnared by the words of your mouth; you are taken by the words of your mouth.
Do this now, my son, and free yourself; when you have come into the power of your friend, go, humble yourself, and ensure your friend.
Do not give sleep to your eyes, nor slumber to your eyelids.
Free yourself like a deer from the hand of the hunter, and like a bird from the hand of the fowler.
Go to the ant, you sluggard; consider her ways and be wise:
Though she has no guide, overseer, or ruler,
She provides her food in the summer and gathers her sustenance in the harvest.
How long will you sleep, O sluggard? When will you arise from your sleep?
A little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the hands to rest:
So shall your poverty come as a traveler, and your need like an armed man.
A wicked person, a deceitful man, walks with a perverse mouth.
He winks with his eyes, speaks with his feet, and teaches with his fingers;
Perversity is in his heart; he devises mischief continually and sows discord.
Therefore, his calamity will come suddenly; he will be broken without remedy.
These six things the LORD hates; yes, seven are an abomination to Him:
A proud look, a lying tongue, and hands that shed innocent blood,
A heart that devises wicked imaginations, feet that are swift in running to mischief,
A false witness who speaks lies, and one who sows discord among brethren.
My son, keep your father's commandment and do not forsake the law of your mother:
Bind them continually upon your heart and tie them around your neck.
When you go, they will lead you; when you sleep, they will keep you; and when you awake, they will speak with you.
For the commandment is a lamp, and the law is light; and reproofs of instruction are the way of life:
To keep you from the evil woman, from the flattering tongue of a strange woman.
Do not lust after her beauty in your heart; neither let her captivate you with her eyelids.
For by means of a promiscuous woman, a man is brought to a piece of bread; and the adulteress hunts for the precious life.
Can a man take fire in his bosom and his clothes not be burned?
Can one walk on hot coals and his feet not be scorched?
So he who goes in to his neighbor's wife; whoever touches her will not be innocent.
Men do not despise a thief if he steals to satisfy his soul when he is hungry;
But if he is found, he shall restore sevenfold; he shall give all the substance of his house.
But whoever commits adultery with a woman lacks understanding; he who does it destroys his own soul.
A wound and dishonor he will receive, and his reproach will not be wiped away.
For jealousy is the rage of a man; therefore, he will not spare in the day of vengeance.
He will not accept any ransom, nor will he be content, though you give many gifts.
My son, cherish my words and treasure my commandments within you.
Obey my commandments and you will live; regard my law as the most precious thing in your sight.
Bind them to your fingers; inscribe them on the tablet of your heart.
Embrace wisdom as your sister and call understanding your closest relative.
These will protect you from the seductive woman, from the stranger who entices with her words.
From the window of my house, I looked through the lattice,
And I observed among the naive, I discerned among the young men, a youth lacking sense,
As he passed through the street near her corner, heading toward her house,
In the twilight, in the evening, in the dark of night.
And behold, a woman approached him, dressed like a harlot, with a cunning heart.
(She is loud and defiant; her feet do not stay at home.
Now she is outside, now in the streets, lurking at every corner.)
So she seized him, kissed him, and with a bold face said to him,
"I have peace offerings with me; today I fulfilled my vows.
Therefore, I came out to meet you, eagerly seeking your presence, and I have found you.
I have adorned my bed with coverings of tapestry, with intricate designs, with fine linen from Egypt.
I have scented my bed with myrrh, aloes, and cinnamon.
Come, let us indulge in love until morning; let us delight ourselves with affection.
For my husband is not at home; he has gone on a long journey.
He has taken a bag of money with him and will return on the appointed day.
With her persuasive words, she led him astray; with the flattery of her lips, she compelled him.
He follows her immediately, like an ox going to the slaughter, or like a fool heading for correction.
Until a dart pierces his liver; like a bird rushing into a trap, unaware that it is for its life.
Listen to me now, therefore, O children, and pay attention to the words of my mouth.
Do not let your heart stray toward her ways; do not wander into her paths.
For she has caused many to fall; indeed, many strong men have been slain by her.
Her house is the path to destruction, leading down to the chambers of death.
Does not wisdom cry out? And understanding raise her voice?
She stands at the top of high places, along the way, at the crossroads.
She cries out at the gates, at the entrance of the city, at the coming in of the doors.
To you, O men, I call; and my voice is directed to the sons of mankind.
O you simple ones, understand wisdom; and you fools, gain an understanding heart.
Listen; for I will speak of excellent things, and the opening of my lips will reveal right things.
For my mouth will speak truth; wickedness is an abomination to my lips.
All the words of my mouth are in righteousness; there is nothing crooked or perverse in them.
They are all plain to those who understand, and right to those who find knowledge.
Receive my instruction, and not silver; and knowledge rather than choice gold.
For wisdom is better than rubies; and all that may be desired cannot be compared to it.
I, wisdom, dwell with prudence, and I discover knowledge of witty inventions.
The fear of the LORD is to hate evil: pride, arrogance, the evil way, and the perverse mouth, I hate.
Counsel is mine, and sound wisdom; I am understanding; I have strength.
By me, kings reign, and princes decree justice.
By me, princes rule, and nobles, even all the judges of the earth.
I love those who love me; and those who seek me early will find me.
Riches and honor are with me; yes, enduring riches and righteousness.
My fruit is better than gold, yes, than fine gold; and my revenue is better than choice silver.
I lead in the way of righteousness, in the midst of the paths of judgment:
That I may cause those who love me to inherit substance; and I will fill their treasures.
The LORD possessed me at the beginning of His way, before His works of old.
I was established from everlasting, from the beginning, before the earth existed.
When there were no depths, I was brought forth; when there were no fountains abounding with water.
Before the mountains were settled, before the hills, I was brought forth:
While He had not yet made the earth, nor the fields, nor the highest part of the dust of the world.
When He prepared the heavens, I was there; when He set a compass upon the face of the deep:
When He established the clouds above; when He strengthened the fountains of the deep:
When He gave to the sea His decree, that the waters should not pass His commandment; when He appointed the foundations of the earth:
Then I was beside Him, as one brought up with Him; and I was daily His delight, rejoicing always before Him;
Rejoicing in the habitable part of His earth; and my delights were with the sons of men.
Now therefore, listen to me, O children; for blessed are those who keep my ways.
Hear instruction, and be wise, and do not refuse it.
Blessed is the man who hears me, watching daily at my gates, waiting at the posts of my doors.
For whoever finds me finds life, and shall obtain favor from the LORD.
But he who sins against me wrongs his own soul; all those who hate me love death.
Wisdom has built her house; she has hewn out her seven pillars.
She has prepared her feast; she has mixed her wine and set her table.
She has sent out her maidens; she calls from the highest places in the city,
"Whoever is simple, let him come in here!" To him who lacks understanding, she says,
"Come, eat of my bread and drink of the wine I have mixed."
Forsake foolishness and live; walk in the way of understanding.
He who corrects a scoffer brings shame upon himself; he who rebukes a wicked man earns a stain.
Do not reprove a scoffer, lest he hate you; rebuke a wise man, and he will love you.
Instruct a wise man, and he will become wiser; teach a righteous man, and he will increase in learning.
The fear of the LORD is the beginning of wisdom, and knowledge of the Holy One is understanding.
For through me, your days will be multiplied, and the years of your life will be increased.
If you are wise, you will benefit yourself; but if you scoff, you alone will bear the consequences.
A foolish woman is loud; she is naive and knows nothing.
For she sits at the door of her house, on a seat in the high places of the city,
To call out to those passing by, who go straight on their way:
"Whoever is simple, let him come in here!" And to him who lacks understanding, she says,
"Stolen waters are sweet, and bread eaten in secret is pleasant."
But he does not know that the dead are there, and that her guests are in the depths of Sheol.
The proverbs of Solomon: A wise son brings joy to his father, but a foolish son brings grief to his mother.
Wealth gained through wickedness is of no benefit, but righteousness saves from death.
The LORD will not allow the righteous to go hungry, but He will reject the possessions of the wicked.
Those who are lazy will become poor, but the diligent will prosper.
A wise son gathers during the summer, while one who sleeps during harvest brings shame.
Blessings rest on the head of the righteous, but violence conceals the words of the wicked.
The memory of the righteous is cherished, but the name of the wicked will decay.
The wise in heart accept instruction, but a talkative fool will stumble.
Those who walk with integrity walk securely, but those who twist their paths will be exposed.
Winking with the eye brings sorrow, but a talkative fool will stumble.
The words of a righteous person are a source of life, but violence conceals the words of the wicked.
Hatred stirs up conflict, but love covers all offenses.
Wisdom is found in the lips of the understanding, but a fool deserves punishment.
Wise individuals store up knowledge, but the words of the foolish lead to destruction.
The wealth of the rich is like a fortified city, while the poverty of the poor leads to their downfall.
The work of the righteous leads to life, while the actions of the wicked lead to sin.
Those who heed instruction are on the path of life, but those who reject correction go astray.
He who conceals hatred with deceitful words and spreads slander is a fool.
In a multitude of words, sin is inevitable, but the wise person restrains their speech.
The tongue of the righteous is like precious silver, while the heart of the wicked is of little value.
The lips of the righteous nourish many, but fools perish for lack of wisdom.
The blessing of the LORD brings wealth without adding sorrow.
To a fool, mischief is like a game, but a wise person possesses understanding.
The fear of the wicked will come upon them, but the desires of the righteous will be fulfilled.
As the whirlwind passes, the wicked are no more, but the righteous stand firm forever.
As vinegar is to the teeth and smoke is to the eyes, so is the sluggard to those who send him.
The fear of the LORD extends life, but the years of the wicked are cut short.
The hope of the righteous brings joy, but the expectation of the wicked will be dashed.
The way of the LORD is a source of strength for the upright, but destruction awaits those who practice iniquity.
The righteous will never be uprooted, but the wicked will not dwell in the land.
The mouth of the righteous brings forth wisdom, but the perverse tongue will be silenced.
The lips of the righteous know what is appropriate, but the mouth of the wicked speaks perversity.
A false balance is an abomination to the LORD, but a just weight is His delight.
When pride comes, then shame follows; but with the lowly is wisdom.
The integrity of the upright shall guide them, but the perverseness of transgressors shall destroy them.
Riches do not profit in the day of wrath, but righteousness delivers from death.
The righteousness of the perfect shall direct his way, but the wicked shall fall by his own wickedness.
The righteousness of the upright shall deliver them, but transgressors shall be caught in their own naughtiness.
When a wicked man dies, his expectation shall perish, and the hope of unjust men perishes.
The righteous are delivered out of trouble, and the wicked come in their stead.
A hypocrite with his mouth destroys his neighbor, but through knowledge, the just are delivered.
When it goes well with the righteous, the city rejoices; and when the wicked perish, there is shouting.
By the blessing of the upright, the city is exalted, but it is overthrown by the mouth of the wicked.
He who is void of wisdom despises his neighbor, but a man of understanding holds his peace.
A talebearer reveals secrets, but he who is of a faithful spirit conceals the matter.
Where there is no counsel, the people fall; but in the multitude of counselors, there is safety.
He who is surety for a stranger shall suffer for it, and he who hates suretyship is secure.
A gracious woman retains honor, and strong men retain riches.
The merciful man does good to his own soul, but he who is cruel troubles his own flesh.
The wicked work a deceitful work, but to him who sows righteousness shall be a sure reward.
As righteousness tends to life, so he who pursues evil pursues it to his own death.
Those with a froward heart are an abomination to the LORD, but those who are upright in their way are His delight.
Though hand join in hand, the wicked shall not go unpunished, but the seed of the righteous shall be delivered.
As a jewel of gold in a swine's snout, so is a fair woman who lacks discretion.
The desire of the righteous is only good, but the expectation of the wicked is wrath.
There are those who scatter, yet increase; and there are those who withhold more than is right, but it leads to poverty.
The liberal soul shall be made fat, and he who waters shall also be watered himself.
He who withholds corn, the people shall curse him, but blessing shall be upon the head of him who sells it.
He who diligently seeks good procures favor, but he who seeks mischief, it shall come upon him.
He who trusts in his riches shall fall, but the righteous shall flourish like a branch.
He who troubles his own house shall inherit the wind, and the fool shall be servant to the wise of heart.
The fruit of the righteous is a tree of life, and he who wins souls is wise.
Behold, the righteous shall be recompensed on the earth; much more the wicked and the sinner.
Whosoever loves instruction loves knowledge; but he who hates reproof is foolish.
A good man obtains favor from the LORD, but a man with wicked schemes will be condemned.
A man will not be established by wickedness, but the root of the righteous will not be shaken.
A virtuous woman is a crown to her husband, but one who brings shame is like rottenness in his bones.
The thoughts of the righteous are just, but the plans of the wicked are deceitful.
The words of the wicked lie in wait for blood, but the mouth of the upright will rescue them.
The wicked are overthrown and are no more, but the house of the righteous will stand firm.
A man is commended according to his wisdom, but one with a perverse heart will be despised.
He who is despised and has a servant is better than he who honors himself but lacks bread.
A righteous man cares for the life of his animal, but the tender mercies of the wicked are cruel.
He who cultivates his land will be satisfied with bread, but he who follows worthless pursuits lacks understanding.
The wicked desire the net of evil men, but the root of the righteous yields fruit.
The wicked is ensnared by the transgression of his lips, but the just will escape trouble.
A man will be satisfied with good by the fruit of his mouth, and the recompense of a man's hands will be rendered to him.
The way of a fool seems right in his own eyes, but he who listens to counsel is wise.
A fool's anger is quickly known, but a prudent man covers shame.
He who speaks the truth shows forth righteousness, but a false witness spreads deceit.
There are those who speak like the piercings of a sword, but the tongue of the wise brings healing.
The lip of truth will be established forever, but a lying tongue lasts only for a moment.
Deceit is in the heart of those who devise evil, but joy belongs to the counselors of peace.
No evil will befall the just, but the wicked will be filled with trouble.
Lying lips are an abomination to the LORD, but those who deal truthfully are His delight.
A prudent man conceals knowledge, but the heart of fools proclaims foolishness.
The hand of the diligent will rule, but the lazy will be put to forced labor.
Heaviness in the heart of a man makes it stoop, but a good word makes it glad.
The righteous is more excellent than his neighbor, but the way of the wicked leads them astray.
The slothful man does not roast what he took in hunting, but the possessions of a diligent man are valuable.
In the way of righteousness is life, and in its pathway, there is no death.
A wise son listens to his father's instruction, but a scorner ignores rebuke.
A man enjoys good from the fruit of his words, but the soul of the transgressors feeds on violence.
He who guards his mouth preserves his life, but he who speaks recklessly will face destruction.
The soul of the sluggard craves and gets nothing, but the soul of the diligent is richly satisfied.
A righteous man detests lying, but a wicked man is repulsive and will face shame.
Righteousness protects those who are upright in their path, but wickedness leads sinners to ruin.
There are those who make themselves rich yet have nothing, and those who make themselves poor yet possess great wealth.
The ransom for a man's life is his riches, but the poor do not heed rebuke.
The light of the righteous brings joy, but the lamp of the wicked will be extinguished.
Only pride leads to conflict, but wisdom is found with the well-advised.
Wealth gained through vanity will diminish, but he who gathers through hard work will increase.
Hope deferred makes the heart sick, but when desire is fulfilled, it is a tree of life.
Whoever despises the word will face destruction, but he who fears the commandment will be rewarded.
The law of the wise is a fountain of life, guiding one away from the snares of death.
Good understanding brings favor, but the path of transgressors is difficult.
Every prudent man acts with knowledge, but a fool exposes his folly.
A wicked messenger falls into trouble, but a faithful ambassador brings health.
Poverty and shame come to those who refuse instruction, but he who heeds reproof will be honored.
The desire fulfilled is sweet to the soul, but it is an abomination for fools to turn away from evil.
He who walks with wise men will be wise, but a companion of fools will suffer destruction.
Evil pursues sinners, but good will be repaid to the righteous.
A good man leaves an inheritance for his grandchildren, but the wealth of the sinner is stored up for the just.
There is much food in the tillage of the poor, but some are destroyed for lack of judgment.
He who spares his rod hates his son, but he who loves him disciplines him early.
The righteous eat to the satisfaction of their souls, but the belly of the wicked will go hungry.
Every wise woman builds her house, but the foolish tears it down with her own hands.
He who walks in his integrity fears the LORD, but he who is perverse in his ways despises Him.
In the mouth of the foolish is a rod of pride, but the lips of the wise preserve them.
Where there are no oxen, the manger is clean, but much increase comes from the strength of the ox.
A faithful witness does not lie, but a false witness speaks lies.
A scoffer seeks wisdom and finds it not, but knowledge is easy for him who understands.
Avoid the presence of a foolish man when you do not perceive in him the lips of knowledge.
The wisdom of the prudent is to understand his way, but the folly of fools is deceit.
Fools mock at sin, but among the righteous there is favor.
The heart knows its own bitterness, and a stranger does not intermeddle with its joy.
The house of the wicked will be overthrown, but the dwelling of the upright will flourish.
There is a way that seems right to a man, but its end is the way of death.
Even in laughter, the heart is sorrowful, and the end of that mirth is heaviness.
The backslider in heart will be filled with his own ways, but a good man will be satisfied with himself.
The simple believe every word, but the prudent man carefully considers his steps.
A wise man fears and departs from evil, but the fool rages and is confident.
He who is quick to anger acts foolishly, and a man of wicked schemes is hated.
The simple inherit folly, but the prudent are crowned with knowledge.
The evil bow before the good, and the wicked stand at the gates of the righteous.
The poor is despised even by his own neighbor, but the rich has many friends.
He who despises his neighbor sins, but he who shows mercy to the poor is happy.
Do they not err who devise evil? But mercy and truth will be to those who devise good.
In all labor there is profit, but mere talk leads only to poverty.
The crown of the wise is their riches, but the foolishness of fools is folly.
A true witness saves lives, but a deceitful witness speaks lies.
In the fear of the LORD is strong confidence, and His children will have a place of refuge.
The fear of the LORD is a fountain of life, turning one away from the snares of death.
In the multitude of people is the king's honor, but in the lack of people is the destruction of the prince.
He who is slow to anger has great understanding, but he who is quick-tempered exalts folly.
A sound heart is the life of the flesh, but envy rots the bones.
He who oppresses the poor insults his Maker, but he who honors Him has mercy on the poor.
The wicked are driven away in their wickedness, but the righteous have hope in their death.
Wisdom rests in the heart of him who has understanding, but what is in the midst of fools is made known.
Righteousness exalts a nation, but sin is a reproach to any people.
The king's favor is toward a wise servant, but his wrath is against him who causes shame.
A gentle response can defuse anger, but harsh words provoke it.
The wise use knowledge wisely, while fools spew foolishness.
The LORD observes all places, watching both the wicked and the good.
A healthy tongue is like a tree of life, but perverse speech breaks the spirit.
A fool disregards his father's guidance, but one who accepts correction is wise.
In the home of the righteous, there is great wealth, but the gains of the wicked bring trouble.
The wise share knowledge, while the foolish keep their hearts closed.
The offerings of the wicked are detestable to the LORD, but the prayers of the upright bring Him joy.
The path of the wicked is detestable to the LORD, but He loves those who pursue righteousness.
Correction is painful for those who abandon the right path; those who hate reproof will face consequences.
Destruction lies before the LORD; how much more so the hearts of mankind?
A scoffer does not appreciate correction and will not seek wisdom.
A joyful heart brightens the face, but sorrow can crush the spirit.
The heart of the understanding seeks knowledge, while fools indulge in foolishness.
All the days of the afflicted are filled with trouble, but a joyful heart enjoys a constant feast.
Better to have little with reverence for the LORD than great wealth accompanied by strife.
A meal of vegetables shared in love is better than a feast of beef served with hatred.
A hot-tempered person stirs up conflict, but the patient calm disputes.
The path of the lazy is like a thorny hedge, while the way of the righteous is clear.
A wise son brings joy to his father, but a foolish child disrespects his mother.
Folly is a delight to those lacking wisdom, but a wise person walks with integrity.
Without guidance, plans fail, but with many advisors, they succeed.
A man finds joy in the response of his lips; a timely word is truly good.
The path of life leads the wise upward, away from destruction below.
The LORD will bring down the proud's house, but He will secure the widow's estate.
The thoughts of the wicked are detestable to the LORD, but the words of the pure are pleasing.
A greedy person brings trouble to their own home, but one who despises bribes will thrive.
The righteous carefully consider their responses, while the wicked speak evil without thought.
The LORD is distant from the wicked, but He hears the prayers of the righteous.
The light in the eyes brings joy to the heart, and a good report nourishes the spirit.
The ear that listens to life’s correction remains among the wise.
One who rejects instruction harms their own soul, but one who accepts reproof gains understanding.
The fear of the LORD is the foundation of wisdom, and humility precedes honor.
The preparations of the heart in a person, and the response of the tongue, come from the LORD.
All a person's ways seem pure in their own eyes; but the LORD weighs the spirit.
Commit your actions to the LORD, and your plans will be established.
The LORD has made everything for His purpose: even the wicked for the day of judgment.
Everyone who is proud in heart is detestable to the LORD; though they join forces, they will not go unpunished.
By mercy and truth, iniquity is atoned for; and by the fear of the LORD, people turn away from evil.
When a person's ways please the LORD, He makes even their enemies be at peace with them.
Better is a little with righteousness than great profits without justice.
A person's heart plans their way, but the LORD directs their steps.
A divine decree is on the lips of the king; his mouth does not transgress in judgment.
A just weight and balance are the LORD's; all the weights in the bag are His work.
It is detestable for kings to commit wickedness, for the throne is established by righteousness.
Righteous lips are the delight of kings, and they love those who speak what is right.
The wrath of a king is like messengers of death; but a wise person will appease it.
In the light of the king's countenance is life; and his favor is like a cloud of the latter rain.
How much better it is to gain wisdom than gold! and to gain understanding is to be chosen over silver!
The path of the upright is to turn away from evil; whoever guards their way preserves their soul.
Pride goes before destruction, and a haughty spirit before a fall.
It is better to be of a humble spirit with the lowly than to share the spoils with the proud.
Whoever handles a matter wisely will find good; and whoever trusts in the LORD is happy.
The wise in heart will be called discerning, and sweetness of speech increases learning.
Understanding is a fountain of life to those who have it; but the instruction of fools is folly.
The heart of the wise instructs their mouth and adds learning to their lips.
Pleasant words are like a honeycomb, sweet to the soul and health to the bones.
There is a way that seems right to a person, but its end is the way of death.
Whoever labors labors for themselves; for their mouth craves it of them.
An ungodly person digs up evil, and their lips are like a burning fire.
A perverse person sows strife, and a whisperer separates close friends.
A violent person entices their neighbor and leads them down a path that is not good.
They shut their eyes to devise perverse things; moving their lips, they bring evil to pass.
The gray head is a crown of glory if it is found in the way of righteousness.
Whoever is slow to anger is better than the mighty; and whoever rules their spirit is better than one who takes a city.
The lot is cast into the lap, but the whole disposing of it is from the LORD.
Better is a dry morsel accompanied by peace than a house full of sacrifices accompanied by strife.
A wise servant will rule over a son who brings shame and will share in the inheritance among the brothers.
The refining pot is for silver, and the furnace is for gold, but the LORD tests the hearts.
A wicked person pays attention to false lips, and a liar listens to a deceitful tongue.
Whoever mocks the poor insults their Maker, and those who rejoice in calamities will not go unpunished.
Grandchildren are the crown of the elderly, and the glory of children is their fathers.
Excellent speech is not fitting for a fool; much less are lying lips suitable for a prince.
A gift is like a precious stone in the eyes of the one who possesses it; wherever it goes, it brings prosperity.
He who covers a transgression seeks love, but he who repeats a matter separates close friends.
A reproof penetrates deeper into a wise man than a hundred stripes into a fool.
An evil person seeks only rebellion; therefore, a cruel messenger will be sent against him.
It is better for a man to encounter a bear robbed of her cubs than to meet a fool in his folly.
Whoever rewards evil for good will have evil never depart from his house.
The beginning of strife is like releasing water; therefore, stop contention before it escalates.
He who justifies the wicked and condemns the just are both an abomination to the LORD.
Why is there a price in the hand of a fool to acquire wisdom, seeing he has no heart for it?
A friend loves at all times, and a brother is born for times of adversity.
A man lacking understanding strikes hands and becomes surety in the presence of his friend.
He who loves transgression loves strife, and he who exalts his gate seeks destruction.
He who has a perverse heart finds no good, and he who has a deceitful tongue falls into mischief.
He who begets a fool does so to his sorrow, and the father of a fool has no joy.
A merry heart is like medicine, but a broken spirit dries the bones.
A wicked man takes a gift from his bosom to pervert the ways of justice.
Wisdom is before the one who has understanding, but the eyes of a fool wander to the ends of the earth.
A foolish son brings grief to his father and bitterness to his mother.
It is not good to punish the just, nor is it right to strike princes for their integrity.
He who has knowledge spares his words, and a man of understanding has an excellent spirit.
Even a fool, when he remains silent, is considered wise, and he who shuts his lips is regarded as a man of understanding.
Through desire, a man separates himself and seeks to intermeddle with all wisdom.
A fool takes no pleasure in understanding, but only in revealing his own heart.
When the wicked arrive, contempt follows, accompanied by reproach and disgrace.
The words of a man's mouth are like deep waters, and the wellspring of wisdom is like a flowing brook.
It is unwise to favor the wicked and to undermine the righteous in judgment.
A fool's lips lead to conflict, and his mouth invites punishment.
A fool's mouth leads to his own destruction, and his lips ensnare his soul.
The words of a gossip are like wounds, penetrating deep into the innermost parts of the belly.
He who is lazy in his work is a brother to the one who is a great waste.
The name of the LORD is a strong tower; the righteous run to it and find safety.
The wealth of the rich man is like a fortified city, and he sees it as a high wall in his own mind.
Before destruction, a man's heart is proud, but humility comes before honor.
He who answers a matter before hearing it is foolish and brings shame upon himself.
The spirit of a man can sustain him in sickness, but who can bear a wounded spirit?
The heart of the prudent seeks knowledge, and the ear of the wise craves understanding.
A man's gift opens doors for him and brings him before great individuals.
The one who is first to present his case seems right, but his neighbor comes and examines him.
Casting lots puts an end to disputes and separates the mighty.
An offended brother is harder to win than a strong city, and their conflicts are like the bars of a fortress.
A man's stomach is filled with the fruit of his words; with the increase of his lips, he is satisfied.
Death and life are in the power of the tongue, and those who love it will reap its rewards.
Whoever finds a wife finds a good thing and receives favor from the LORD.
The poor plead for help, but the rich respond harshly.
A man who has friends must show himself friendly, and there is a friend who sticks closer than a brother.
Better is a poor person who walks in integrity than one who is perverse in speech and a fool.
Moreover, it is not good for the soul to lack knowledge; he who rushes with his feet sins.
The foolishness of a person distorts their path, and their heart frets against the LORD.
Wealth attracts many friends, but the poor is isolated from their neighbor.
A false witness will not go unpunished, and one who speaks lies will not escape.
Many will seek the favor of a ruler, and everyone is a friend to those who give gifts.
All the relatives of the poor despise him; how much more do his friends distance themselves? He pursues them with words, yet they are absent.
He who gains wisdom loves his own soul; he who holds onto understanding will find good.
A false witness will not go unpunished, and one who speaks lies will perish.
Delight is not fitting for a fool; much less is it appropriate for a servant to rule over princes.
A man's discretion delays his anger; it is his glory to overlook an offense.
The king's wrath is like the roaring of a lion, but his favor is like dew on the grass.
A foolish son brings calamity to his father, and a contentious wife is like a constant dripping.
A house and wealth are an inheritance from fathers, but a prudent wife is a gift from the LORD.
Laziness leads to deep sleep, and an idle soul will suffer hunger.
He who keeps the commandment preserves his own soul; but he who despises his ways will die.
He who shows compassion to the poor lends to the LORD, and what he has given will be repaid.
Discipline your son while there is hope, and do not be unwilling to correct him for his crying.
A man of great anger will face punishment; if you rescue him, you will have to do it again.
Listen to counsel and accept instruction, so that you may be wise in your later years.
There are many plans in a person's heart, but the counsel of the LORD will stand.
A person's desire is their kindness, and a poor person is better than a liar.
The fear of the LORD leads to life; he who has it will be satisfied and will not encounter evil.
A lazy person hides their hand in their bosom and will not even bring it to their mouth.
Strike a scoffer, and the simple will take warning; reprove one who has understanding, and they will gain knowledge.
He who wastes his father and drives away his mother is a son who brings shame and disgrace.
My son, stop listening to instruction that leads you away from the words of knowledge.
An ungodly witness mocks justice, and the mouth of the wicked consumes iniquity.
Judgments are prepared for scoffers, and stripes are for the backs of fools.
Wine is a mocker, and strong drink causes rage; whoever is deceived by them is unwise.
The fear of a king is like the roar of a lion; whoever provokes him to anger sins against their own soul.
It is an honor for a man to refrain from strife, but every fool will meddle.
The sluggard will not plow because of the cold; therefore, he will beg during harvest and have nothing.
Counsel in a man's heart is like deep water, but a man of understanding will draw it out.
Most men will proclaim their own goodness, but who can find a faithful man?
The just man walks in his integrity; his children are blessed after him.
A king who sits on the throne of judgment dispels all evil with his gaze.
Who can say, "I have made my heart clean; I am pure from my sin"?
Diverse weights and measures are both an abomination to the LORD.
Even a child is known by his actions, whether his work is pure and right.
The hearing ear and the seeing eye, the LORD has made both.
Do not love sleep, lest you come to poverty; open your eyes, and you will be satisfied with bread.
"It is nothing, it is nothing," says the buyer; but when he has gone his way, he boasts.
There is gold and a multitude of rubies, but the lips of knowledge are a precious jewel.
Take the garment of one who is surety for a stranger, and take a pledge from him for a strange woman.
Bread gained by deceit is sweet to a man, but afterward, his mouth will be filled with gravel.
Every purpose is established by counsel; with good advice, make war.
He who goes about as a talebearer reveals secrets; therefore, do not associate with him who flatters with his lips.
Whoever curses his father or mother, his lamp will be put out in obscure darkness.
An inheritance may be gained hastily at the beginning, but its end will not be blessed.
Do not say, "I will repay evil"; wait on the LORD, and He will save you.
Diverse weights are an abomination to the LORD, and a false balance is not good.
A man's steps are directed by the LORD; how then can a man understand his own way?
It is a snare for a man to devour what is holy and then to make inquiry after vows.
A wise king scatters the wicked and brings the wheel over them.
The spirit of man is the candle of the LORD, searching all the inward parts of the belly.
Mercy and truth preserve the king, and his throne is upheld by mercy.
The glory of young men is their strength, and the beauty of old men is the gray head.
The blueness of a wound cleanses away evil; so do stripes cleanse the inward parts of the belly.
The king's heart is in the hand of the LORD, like rivers of water; He directs it wherever He wishes.
Every man believes his own way is right, but the LORD weighs the hearts.
To execute justice and judgment is more pleasing to the LORD than sacrifice.
A haughty look, a proud heart, and the actions of the wicked are all sin.
The thoughts of the diligent lead only to abundance, but those who act hastily will find only lack.
Acquiring treasures through deceit is vanity, tossed about by those who seek death.
The wrongdoing of the wicked will lead to their destruction, for they refuse to uphold justice.
The path of man is perverse and strange, but the work of the pure is right.
It is better to live in a corner of the rooftop than to share a house with a quarrelsome woman.
The soul of the wicked craves evil; his neighbor finds no favor in his sight.
When the scorner is punished, the simple gain wisdom; when the wise are instructed, they receive knowledge.
The righteous man wisely observes the house of the wicked, but God will overthrow the wicked for their evil deeds.
Whoever shuts his ears to the cry of the poor will also cry out but will not be heard.
A secret gift calms anger, and a reward given in private pacifies strong wrath.
It brings joy to the just to execute judgment, but destruction awaits those who practice iniquity.
The man who strays from the path of understanding will remain among the dead.
He who loves pleasure will become poor; he who loves wine and oil will not be rich.
The wicked will serve as a ransom for the righteous, and the transgressor for the upright.
It is better to live in the wilderness than with a quarrelsome and angry woman.
There is treasure and oil to be desired in the dwelling of the wise, but a foolish man squanders it.
He who pursues righteousness and mercy finds life, righteousness, and honor.
A wise man scales the city of the mighty and brings down the stronghold of its confidence.
Whoever guards his mouth and tongue keeps his soul from troubles.
The proud and haughty scorner is his name, who acts in proud wrath.
The desire of the lazy kills him, for his hands refuse to work.
He covets greedily all day long, but the righteous give and do not hold back.
The sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination; how much more so when he brings it with a wicked intent?
A false witness will perish, but the man who listens speaks with integrity.
A wicked man hardens his face, but the upright directs his path.
There is no wisdom, understanding, or counsel against the LORD.
The horse is prepared for the day of battle, but safety comes from the LORD.
A good name is to be chosen over great riches, and loving favor is better than silver and gold.
The rich and the poor come together; the LORD is the creator of them all.
A wise person foresees danger and takes refuge, but the naive continue on and suffer the consequences.
Through humility and the fear of the LORD come riches, honor, and life.
Thorns and snares lie in the path of the perverse; whoever guards their soul stays far from them.
Train a child in the way they should go, and when they are old, they will not depart from it.
The rich rule over the poor, and the borrower is a servant to the lender.
Whoever sows iniquity will reap vanity; the rod of their anger will fail.
The one with a generous eye will be blessed, for they share their bread with the poor.
Cast out the scoffer, and strife will cease; contention and reproach will vanish.
Whoever loves a pure heart and gracious speech will have the king as their friend.
The eyes of the LORD preserve knowledge, but He overthrows the words of the transgressor.
The slothful person says, "There is a lion outside; I will be killed in the streets."
The words of an immoral woman are a deep pit; whoever is detested by the LORD will fall into it.
Foolishness is bound in the heart of a child, but the rod of correction will drive it far from them.
Whoever oppresses the poor to increase their wealth, and gives to the rich, will surely come to want.
Listen closely and hear the words of the wise; apply your heart to my knowledge.
For it is pleasant if you keep them within you; they will be fitting on your lips.
So that your trust may be in the LORD, I have made known to you today, even to you.
Have I not written to you excellent things in counsel and knowledge,
To make you know the certainty of the words of truth, so you may give a true answer to those who send you?
Do not rob the poor because they are poor, nor oppress the afflicted at the gate;
For the LORD will plead their cause and will take the life of those who rob them.
Do not make friends with a hot-tempered person, and do not associate with one easily angered;
Lest you learn their ways and get ensnared in your soul.
Do not be one of those who strike hands or pledge for debts.
If you have nothing to pay, why should they take your bed from under you?
Do not remove the ancient landmark that your ancestors have set.
Do you see a man diligent in his work? He will stand before kings; he will not stand before obscure men.
When you sit down to eat with a ruler, carefully consider what is before you.
And if you are someone who craves indulgence, put a knife to your throat.
Do not desire his delicacies, for they are deceptive food.
Do not strive to be rich; refrain from relying on your own understanding.
Will you set your eyes on what is not? For wealth can easily take flight; it soars away like an eagle in the sky.
Do not eat the bread of one with an evil eye, nor crave his fine foods.
For as he thinks in his heart, so is he: "Eat and drink," he says to you, but his heart is not with you.
The morsel you have eaten will be regurgitated, and you will lose your pleasant words.
Do not speak in the ears of a fool, for he will scorn the wisdom of your words.
Do not remove the ancient boundary stones, and do not encroach on the fields of the fatherless.
For their Redeemer is strong; He will defend their cause against you.
Direct your heart toward instruction, and your ears toward knowledge.
Do not withhold discipline from a child; if you strike him with a rod, he will not die.
You shall strike him with the rod and save his soul from destruction.
My son, if your heart is wise, my heart will rejoice, even mine.
Yes, my innermost being will rejoice when your lips speak what is right.
Do not let your heart envy sinners; instead, remain in the fear of the LORD all day long.
For surely there is a future, and your hope will not be cut off.
Listen, my son, and be wise; direct your heart in the right way.
Do not associate with heavy drinkers or gluttonous eaters of meat.
For the drunkard and the glutton will come to poverty, and drowsiness will clothe a man in rags.
Listen to your father who gave you life, and do not despise your mother when she is old.
Buy the truth and do not sell it; also acquire wisdom, instruction, and understanding.
The father of the righteous will greatly rejoice, and he who begets a wise child will find joy in him.
Your father and mother will be glad, and she who bore you will rejoice.
My son, give me your heart, and let your eyes observe my ways.
For an immoral woman is a deep pit, and a strange woman is a narrow well.
She lies in wait like a thief, and increases the unfaithful among men.
Who has woe? Who has sorrow? Who has strife? Who has complaints? Who has unnecessary wounds? Who has red eyes?
Those who linger long over wine, those who go to taste mixed wine.
Do not look at the wine when it is red, when it sparkles in the cup, when it goes down smoothly.
In the end, it bites like a serpent and stings like a viper.
Your eyes will see strange sights, and your heart will utter perverse things.
Yes, you will be like one who lies down in the midst of the sea, or like one who lies on the top of a mast.
You will say, "They struck me, but I was not hurt; they beat me, but I did not feel it. When will I wake up? I will seek it again."
Do not be envious of evil people, nor desire to associate with them.
For their hearts plot destruction, and their words are filled with mischief.
Through wisdom, a house is built; and by understanding, it is established.
By knowledge, the chambers are filled with all precious and delightful riches.
A wise person is strong; indeed, a person of knowledge increases strength.
For with wise counsel, you will wage your war; in a multitude of counselors, there is safety.
Wisdom is too high for a fool; he does not open his mouth in the assembly.
He who plans to do evil will be called a troublemaker.
The thought of foolishness is sin; and the scoffer is an abomination to others.
If you faint in the day of adversity, your strength is small.
If you refrain from delivering those drawn to death, and those ready to be slain;
If you say, "Behold, we did not know it," does not He who weighs the heart consider it? And He who keeps your soul, does He not know it? And will He not repay every person according to their deeds?
My child, eat honey, for it is good; and the honeycomb, which is sweet to your taste.
So shall the knowledge of wisdom be to your soul: when you find it, there will be a reward, and your hope will not be cut off.
Do not lie in wait, O wicked person, against the dwelling of the righteous; do not spoil his resting place.
For a just person may fall seven times and rise again; but the wicked will fall into mischief.
Do not rejoice when your enemy falls, and do not let your heart be glad when he stumbles.
Lest the LORD see it and be displeased, and turn away His wrath from him.
Do not fret because of evil people, nor be envious of the wicked.
For there will be no reward for the evil person; the lamp of the wicked will be extinguished.
My child, fear the LORD and the king; do not associate with those who are given to change.
For their calamity will rise suddenly; and who knows the ruin that will come upon them both?
These things also belong to the wise: it is not good to show partiality in judgment.
He who says to the wicked, "You are righteous," will be cursed by the people; nations will abhor him.
But those who rebuke him will find delight, and a good blessing will come upon them.
Every person will kiss the lips of one who gives a right answer.
Prepare your work outside, and make it ready for yourself in the field; and afterward, build your house.
Do not be a witness against your neighbor without cause; do not deceive with your lips.
Do not say, "I will do to him as he has done to me; I will repay the man according to his deeds."
I passed by the field of the slothful, and by the vineyard of the man lacking understanding;
And behold, it was all overgrown with thorns, and nettles had covered its surface, and its stone wall was broken down.
Then I saw and considered it carefully; I looked upon it and received instruction.
A little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the hands to rest:
So shall your poverty come like a traveler, and your need like an armed man.
These are also proverbs of Solomon, which the men of Hezekiah, king of Judah, transcribed.
It is the glory of God to conceal a matter, but the honor of kings is to investigate it.
The heavens are high, the earth is deep, and the hearts of kings are unsearchable.
Remove the impurities from silver, and a refined vessel will emerge.
Remove the wicked from the king's presence, and his throne will be established in righteousness.
Do not present yourself in the presence of the king, and do not take a place among great men.
For it is better to be invited to come up here than to be humiliated in the presence of a prince you have seen.
Do not rush to argue, lest you find yourself unsure of what to do in the end when your neighbor puts you to shame.
Discuss your case with your neighbor directly, and do not reveal a secret to another.
Lest the one who hears it shames you, and your disgrace does not depart.
A well-timed word is like apples of gold in settings of silver.
Like a gold earring and a fine gold ornament, so is a wise reprover to an attentive ear.
As cold snow in harvest time, so is a faithful messenger to those who send him; he refreshes the soul of his masters.
Whoever boasts of a false gift is like clouds and wind without rain.
A prince is persuaded by long patience, and a gentle tongue can break a bone.
Have you found honey? Eat only what is sufficient for you, lest you become full and vomit it.
Withdraw your foot from your neighbor's house, lest he grow weary of you and come to hate you.
A man who bears false witness against his neighbor is like a hammer, a sword, and a sharp arrow.
Trusting in an unfaithful person in times of trouble is like having a broken tooth or a dislocated foot.
As one who takes away a garment in cold weather, and as vinegar on soda, so is he who sings songs to a heavy heart.
If your enemy is hungry, give him bread to eat; and if he is thirsty, give him water to drink.
For you will heap burning coals on his head, and the LORD will reward you.
The north wind drives away rain; so does an angry countenance a backbiting tongue.
It is better to dwell in the corner of a rooftop than to share a house with a quarrelsome woman.
As cold water to a thirsty soul, so is good news from a distant land.
A righteous man who falls before the wicked is like a troubled fountain and a corrupt spring.
It is not good to eat too much honey; so it is not glory for men to seek their own honor.
He who has no control over his own spirit is like a city broken down, without walls.
As snow in summer, and as rain in harvest, so honor is not fitting for a fool.
As the bird wanders, as the swallow flies, so the curse without cause shall not come.
A whip for the horse, a bridle for the donkey, and a rod for the fool's back.
Do not answer a fool according to his folly, lest you also become like him.
Answer a fool according to his folly, lest he become wise in his own eyes.
He who sends a message by the hand of a fool cuts off his own feet and drinks damage.
The legs of the lame are not equal; so is a parable in the mouth of fools.
As he who binds a stone in a sling, so is he who gives honor to a fool.
As a thorn goes into the hand of a drunkard, so is a parable in the mouths of fools.
The great God who formed all things rewards both the fool and the transgressors.
As a dog returns to his vomit, so a fool returns to his folly.
Do you see a man wise in his own eyes? There is more hope for a fool than for him.
The slothful man says, "There is a lion in the way; a lion is in the streets."
As the door turns on its hinges, so does the slothful man turn on his bed.
The slothful hides his hand in his bosom; it grieves him to bring it back to his mouth.
The sluggard is wiser in his own eyes than seven men who can give a reason.
He who passes by and meddles in a strife not belonging to him is like one who takes a dog by the ears.
As a madman who casts firebrands, arrows, and death,
So is the man who deceives his neighbor and says, "Am I not in sport?"
Where there is no wood, the fire goes out; so where there is no talebearer, strife ceases.
As coals are to burning coals, and wood to fire, so is a contentious man to kindle strife.
The words of a talebearer are like wounds, and they go down into the innermost parts of the belly.
Burning lips and a wicked heart are like a potsherd covered with silver dross.
He who hates disguises his hatred with his lips and lays up deceit within him;
When he speaks kindly, do not believe him, for there are seven abominations in his heart.
Whose hatred is covered by deceit, his wickedness shall be revealed before the whole congregation.
Whoever digs a pit will fall into it; and he who rolls a stone, it will return upon him.
A lying tongue hates those it wounds, and a flattering mouth works ruin.
Do not boast about tomorrow; for you do not know what a day may bring.
Let someone else praise you, and not your own mouth; a stranger, and not your own lips.
A stone is heavy, and sand is weighty; but a fool's anger is heavier than both.
Wrath is cruel, and anger is outrageous; but who can stand before envy?
Open rebuke is better than hidden love.
Faithful are the wounds of a friend; but the kisses of an enemy are deceitful.
The full soul loathes honeycomb; but to the hungry soul, every bitter thing is sweet.
Like a bird that wanders from her nest, so is a man who strays from his place.
Ointment and perfume bring joy to the heart; so does the sweetness of a friend’s hearty counsel.
Do not forsake your own friend or your father's friend; nor go to your brother's house in the day of your calamity: for better is a neighbor who is near than a brother far away.
My son, be wise, and make my heart glad, so that I may respond to him who reproaches me.
A prudent man foresees danger and hides himself; but the simple pass on and suffer the consequences.
Take his garment who is surety for a stranger, and take a pledge from him for a strange woman.
He who blesses his friend with a loud voice, rising early in the morning, will be counted as cursing.
A continual dripping on a very rainy day and a contentious woman are alike.
Whoever hides her hides the wind, and the ointment of his right hand reveals itself.
Iron sharpens iron; so a man sharpens the countenance of his friend.
Whoever tends the fig tree will eat its fruit; so he who waits on his master will be honored.
As in water, face answers to face, so the heart of man reflects man.
Hell and destruction are never full; so the eyes of man are never satisfied.
As the refining pot is for silver, and the furnace for gold; so is a man to his praise.
Though you grind a fool in a mortar with wheat using a pestle, his foolishness will not depart from him.
Be diligent to know the state of your flocks, and pay close attention to your herds.
For riches are not forever; and does the crown endure to every generation?
The hay appears, and the tender grass shows itself, and the herbs of the mountains are gathered.
The lambs are for your clothing, and the goats are the price of the field.
And you will have enough goats' milk for your food, for the food of your household, and for the sustenance of your maidens.
The wicked flee when no one pursues them, but the righteous are as bold as lions.
For the transgression of a land, there are many princes; but a man of understanding and knowledge will prolong its state.
A poor man who oppresses the poor is like a sweeping rain that leaves no food.
Those who forsake the law praise the wicked, but those who keep the law contend with them.
Evil men do not understand judgment, but those who seek the LORD understand all things.
Better is a poor man who walks in his uprightness than a rich man who is perverse in his ways.
Whoever keeps the law is a wise son, but a companion of riotous men brings shame to his father.
He who increases his wealth through usury and unjust gain will gather it for someone who will pity the poor.
He who turns away his ear from hearing the law, even his prayer will be an abomination.
Whoever causes the righteous to go astray in an evil way will fall into his own pit, but the upright will possess good things.
The rich man is wise in his own eyes, but the poor man with understanding searches him out.
When righteous men rejoice, there is great glory; but when the wicked rise, a man hides himself.
He who covers his sins will not prosper, but whoever confesses and forsakes them will find mercy.
Happy is the man who fears always, but he who hardens his heart will fall into mischief.
Like a roaring lion and a ranging bear, so is a wicked ruler over poor people.
The prince who lacks understanding is a great oppressor, but he who hates covetousness will prolong his days.
A man who commits violence against any person will flee to the pit; let no one stop him.
Whoever walks uprightly will be saved, but the perverse in their ways will fall suddenly.
He who tills his land will have plenty of bread, but he who follows after vain persons will experience poverty.
A faithful man will abound with blessings, but he who hastens to be rich will not go unpunished.
To show partiality is not good; for a piece of bread, a man will transgress.
He who hastens to be rich has an evil eye and does not consider that poverty will come upon him.
He who rebukes a man will find more favor than he who flatters with the tongue.
Whoever robs his father or mother and says, "It is no transgression," is the companion of a destroyer.
He who has a proud heart stirs up strife, but he who trusts in the LORD will be enriched.
He who trusts in his own heart is a fool, but whoever walks wisely will be delivered.
He who gives to the poor will not lack, but he who hides his eyes will receive many curses.
When the wicked rise, men hide themselves, but when they perish, the righteous increase.
He who is often reproved and hardens his neck will be suddenly destroyed, and that without remedy.
When the righteous are in authority, the people rejoice; but when the wicked rule, the people mourn.
Whoever loves wisdom brings joy to his father; but he who associates with harlots wastes his substance.
The king establishes the land through judgment; but he who accepts bribes overthrows it.
A man who flatters his neighbor sets a trap for his feet.
In the transgression of an evil man, there is a snare; but the righteous sing and rejoice.
The righteous consider the cause of the poor; but the wicked do not care to know it.
Scornful men bring a city into a snare; but wise men turn away wrath.
If a wise man contends with a foolish man, whether he rages or laughs, there is no rest.
The bloodthirsty hate the upright; but the just seek his soul.
A fool expresses all his thoughts; but a wise man keeps them to himself until later.
If a ruler listens to lies, all his servants are wicked.
The poor and the deceitful man meet together; the LORD enlightens both their eyes.
The king who judges the poor with faithfulness will have his throne established forever.
The rod and reproof give wisdom; but a child left to himself brings shame to his mother.
When the wicked are multiplied, transgression increases; but the righteous will see their downfall.
Correct your son, and he will give you rest; yes, he will bring delight to your soul.
Where there is no vision, the people perish; but he who keeps the law is happy.
A servant will not be corrected by mere words; for though he understands, he will not respond.
Do you see a man who is hasty in his words? There is more hope for a fool than for him.
He who delicately raises his servant from childhood will eventually have him as a son.
An angry man stirs up strife, and a furious man abounds in transgression.
A man's pride will bring him low; but honor will uphold the humble in spirit.
Whoever partners with a thief hates his own soul; he hears cursing but does not disclose it.
The fear of man brings a snare; but whoever puts his trust in the LORD will be safe.
Many seek the ruler's favor; but every man's judgment comes from the LORD.
An unjust man is an abomination to the just; and he who is upright in his way is an abomination to the wicked.
The words of Agur, son of Jakeh, the prophecy: the man spoke to Ithiel, to Ithiel and Ucal.
Surely, I am more foolish than any man and lack the understanding of a human.
I have neither learned wisdom nor possess the knowledge of the holy.

Who has ascended to heaven or descended? Who has gathered the wind in his fists? Who has wrapped the waters in a garment? Who has established all the ends of the earth? What is his name, and what is his son's name, if you can tell?
Every word of God is flawless; he is a shield to those who take refuge in him.
Do not add to his words, or he will rebuke you, and you will be found a liar.
Two things I ask of you; do not deny me them before I die:
Remove far from me falsehood and lies; give me neither poverty nor riches; feed me with the food that is my portion:
Lest I be full and deny you, and say, "Who is the LORD?" or lest I be poor and steal, and profane the name of my God.
Do not accuse a servant before his master, or he will curse you, and you will be found guilty.
There is a generation that curses their father and does not bless their mother.
There is a generation that is pure in their own eyes, yet is not cleansed from their filth.
There is a generation, oh, how lofty are their eyes! Their eyelids are lifted high.
There is a generation whose teeth are like swords, and their jaw teeth like knives, to devour the poor from the earth and the needy from among men.
The leech has two daughters, crying, "Give, give." There are three things that are never satisfied; yes, four things that do not say, "It is enough":
The grave, the barren womb, the earth that is not filled with water, and the fire that says, "It is enough."
The eye that mocks his father and despises to obey his mother, the ravens of the valley shall pick it out, and the young eagles shall eat it.
There are three things that are too wonderful for me; yes, four that I do not understand:
The way of an eagle in the air, the way of a serpent on a rock, the way of a ship in the midst of the sea, and the way of a man with a maiden.
Such is the way of an adulterous woman; she eats and wipes her mouth and says, "I have done no wrong."
For three things the earth is disquieted, and for four it cannot bear:
For a servant when he reigns, and a fool when he is full of food;
For an odious woman when she is married, and a handmaid who inherits from her mistress.
There are four things that are small on the earth, but they are exceedingly wise:
The ants are a people not strong, yet they prepare their food in the summer;
The conies are but a feeble folk, yet they make their homes in the rocks;
The locusts have no king, yet they all go out in bands;
The spider takes hold with her hands and is in kings' palaces.
There are three things that go well; yes, four are lovely in their going:
A lion, which is strongest among beasts and does not turn away from any;
A greyhound, a male goat, and a king against whom there is no rising up.
If you have acted foolishly in exalting yourself, or if you have thought evil, lay your hand upon your mouth.
Surely, the churning of milk produces butter, and the wringing of the nose produces blood; so the forcing of wrath produces strife.
The words of King Lemuel, the prophecy that his mother imparted to him.
What, my son? And what, the son of my womb? And what, the son of my vows?
Do not give your strength to women, nor your ways to that which destroys kings.
It is not for kings, O Lemuel; it is not for kings to drink wine, nor for princes strong drink.
Lest they drink and forget the law, and pervert the judgment of any of the afflicted.
Give strong drink to him who is ready to perish, and wine to those who are of heavy hearts.
Let him drink and forget his poverty, and remember his misery no more.
Open your mouth for the mute, in the cause of all who are appointed to destruction.
Open your mouth, judge righteously, and plead the cause of the poor and needy.
Who can find a virtuous woman? For her worth is far above rubies.
The heart of her husband safely trusts in her, so that he will have no need of spoil.
She will do him good and not evil all the days of her life.
She seeks wool and flax, and works willingly with her hands.
She is like the merchant ships; she brings her food from afar.
She rises while it is yet night, and provides food for her household, and a portion for her maidens.
She considers a field and buys it; with the fruit of her hands, she plants a vineyard.
She girds her loins with strength and strengthens her arms.
She perceives that her merchandise is good; her candle does not go out by night.
She lays her hands on the spindle, and her hands hold the distaff.
She stretches out her hand to the poor; yes, she reaches forth her hands to the needy.
She is not afraid of the snow for her household, for all her household are clothed in scarlet.
She makes herself coverings of tapestry; her clothing is silk and purple.
Her husband is known at the gates when he sits among the elders of the land.
She makes fine linen and sells it; she delivers sashes to the merchant.
Strength and honor are her clothing, and she shall rejoice in the time to come.
She opens her mouth with wisdom, and the law of kindness is on her tongue.
She looks well to the ways of her household and does not eat the bread of idleness.
Her children rise up and call her blessed; her husband also, and he praises her.
Many daughters have done well, but you excel them all.
Charm is deceptive, and beauty is fleeting; but a woman who fears the LORD, she shall be praised.
Give her the fruit of her hands, and let her own works praise her at the gates.
The words of the Preacher, the son of David, who reigned as king in Jerusalem.
Vanity of vanities, declares the Preacher; vanity of vanities, all is vanity.
What benefit does a man gain from all his labor under the sun?
One generation passes away, and another generation comes; yet the earth remains forever.
The sun rises and sets, hurrying back to the place where it rises.
The wind blows toward the south, then turns to the north; it swirls around continually, returning to its circuits.
All the rivers flow into the sea, yet the sea is never full; to the place where the rivers flow, there they return again.
All things are full of labor; man cannot express it: the eye is never satisfied with seeing, nor the ear filled with hearing.
