What has been will be again; what has been done will be done again; there is nothing new under the sun.
Is there anything of which one might say, "Look, this is new"? It has already been here long ago, before our time.
There is no remembrance of past things; nor will there be any remembrance of things yet to come by those who will come after.
I, the Preacher, was king over Israel in Jerusalem.
And I devoted my heart to seek and explore by wisdom all that is done under heaven; this heavy burden God has given to the sons of man to occupy themselves with.
I have seen all the works that are done under the sun, and behold, all is vanity and a striving after wind.
What is crooked cannot be made straight, and what is lacking cannot be counted.
I said to my heart, "Look, I have attained great wisdom, surpassing all who were before me in Jerusalem; my heart has had great experience of wisdom and knowledge."
And I applied my heart to know wisdom, and to know madness and folly; I perceived that this too is a striving after wind.
For with much wisdom comes much grief, and he who increases knowledge increases sorrow.
I said to myself, "Come now, I will test you with joy; therefore, indulge in pleasure." But behold, this too is meaningless.
I spoke of laughter, "It is madness," and of joy, "What does it accomplish?"

I sought in my heart to give myself to wine, while also seeking wisdom; and to grasp folly, so that I might understand what is good for the children of men to do under heaven during the days of their lives.
I undertook great projects; I built houses for myself; I planted vineyards for myself.
I made gardens and parks, and planted all kinds of fruit trees in them.
I created reservoirs of water to irrigate the trees that produce fruit.
I acquired servants and maidens, and had servants born in my household; I also amassed great possessions of livestock, both large and small, more than anyone in Jerusalem before me.
I gathered silver and gold, along with the treasures of kings and provinces; I acquired male and female singers, and the pleasures of men, including musical instruments of all kinds.
So I became great and surpassed all who were before me in Jerusalem; my wisdom remained with me.
And whatever my eyes desired, I did not withhold from them; I did not deny my heart any joy, for my heart found joy in all my labor, and this was my reward for all my toil.
Then I looked at all the works my hands had done and the labor I had expended to achieve them; and behold, all was meaningless and a chasing after the wind, and there was no profit under the sun.
I turned to consider wisdom, madness, and folly; for what can a man do who comes after the king? Only what has already been done.
Then I realized that wisdom is better than folly, just as light is better than darkness.
The wise man's eyes are in his head, but the fool walks in darkness; and I also perceived that the same fate befalls them both.
Then I said to myself, "As it happens to the fool, so it happens to me; and why then have I been more wise?" I concluded that this too is meaningless.
For there is no lasting remembrance of the wise more than of the fool forever; since in the days to come, all will be forgotten. And how does the wise man die? Just like the fool.
Therefore, I hated life, because the work done under the sun was burdensome to me; for all is meaningless and a chasing after the wind.
Indeed, I hated all my labor that I had performed under the sun, because I must leave it to the man who comes after me.
And who knows whether he will be a wise man or a fool? Yet he will have control over all my labor in which I toiled and in which I showed my wisdom under the sun. This too is meaningless.
So I decided to give my heart to despair over all the labor I had undertaken under the sun.
For there is a man whose labor is in wisdom, knowledge, and equity; yet to a man who has not worked for it, he will leave it as his portion. This too is meaningless and a great evil.
For what does a man gain from all his labor and the anxiety of his heart, which he toils at under the sun?
For all his days are filled with sorrow, and his work is a burden; even at night, his heart finds no rest. This too is meaningless.
There is nothing better for a man than to eat and drink, and to find enjoyment in his labor. This too, I saw, is from the hand of God.
For who can eat or find enjoyment more than I?

For God gives wisdom, knowledge, and joy to a man who is good in His sight; but to the sinner, He gives the task of gathering and heaping up, only to give to the one who is good before God. This too is meaningless and a chasing after the wind.
To everything, there is a season, and a time for every purpose under heaven:
A time to be born and a time to die; a time to plant and a time to harvest what is planted;
A time to kill and a time to heal; a time to tear down and a time to build up;
A time to weep and a time to laugh; a time to mourn and a time to dance;
A time to throw away stones and a time to gather stones together; a time to embrace and a time to refrain from embracing;
A time to gain and a time to lose; a time to keep and a time to discard;
A time to tear and a time to sew; a time to be silent and a time to speak;
A time to love and a time to hate; a time for war and a time for peace.
What benefit does one have from their labor?
I have observed the toil that God has given to humanity to engage in.
He has made everything beautiful in its time; He has also placed eternity in their hearts, so that no one can fathom the work of God from beginning to end.
I know that there is no good in them, except for a person to find joy and do good in their life.
And also that everyone should eat and drink and enjoy the fruits of their labor; this is a gift from God.
I know that whatever God does will last forever; nothing can be added to it, nor taken from it; and God does this so that people may fear Him.
What has been will be; and what is to come has already been; and God requires what is past.
Furthermore, I observed under the sun the place of judgment, where wickedness was present; and the place of righteousness, where iniquity was found.
I said in my heart, God will judge the righteous and the wicked, for there is a time for every purpose and every work.
I reflected in my heart about the condition of humanity, that God might reveal them, and that they might see that they are like animals.

For what happens to humanity also happens to animals; the same fate awaits them: as one dies, so dies the other; indeed, they all share the same breath; so a person has no advantage over an animal; all is vanity.
All go to one place; all are from the dust, and all return to dust.
Who knows the spirit of man that rises upward, and the spirit of the animal that descends to the earth?
Therefore, I conclude that there is nothing better than for a person to find joy in their own work; for that is their lot: who can bring them to see what will come after them?

I returned and reflected on all the oppressions occurring under the sun. I noticed the tears of the oppressed, who had no comforter; meanwhile, their oppressors held power, yet they too had no comforter.
Therefore, I praised the dead who have already passed away more than the living who are still alive.
Indeed, better is he who has not yet been born, who has not witnessed the evil deeds done under the sun.
Once more, I contemplated all the toil and every righteous deed, and I saw that for this, a man is envied by his neighbor. This too is vanity and a vexation of spirit.
The fool folds his hands and consumes his own flesh.
Better is a handful of tranquility than two hands full of toil and vexation of spirit.
Then I returned and observed vanity under the sun.

There is one who is alone, with no second; he has neither child nor brother. Yet, there is no end to all his labor; his eyes are never satisfied with riches, and he does not ask, "For whom do I labor and deprive my soul of good?" This is also vanity; indeed, it is a grievous toil.
Two are better than one because they have a good reward for their labor.
If one falls, the other will lift him up; but woe to him who is alone when he falls, for he has no one to help him up.
Again, if two lie together, they have warmth; but how can one be warm alone?
And if one can overpower him, two can withstand him; a threefold cord is not easily broken.
Better is a poor but wise child than an old and foolish king who can no longer be admonished.
For out of prison, he comes to reign; while he who is born into his kingdom becomes poor.
I considered all the living who walk under the sun, along with the second child who will take his place.
There is no end to all the people, even those who have come before them; those who come after will not rejoice in him. Surely, this too is vanity and a vexation of spirit.
Keep your foot when you go to the house of God, and be more ready to listen than to offer the sacrifice of fools, for they do not realize they are doing wrong.
Do not be quick with your mouth, and let not your heart be hasty to speak anything before God, for God is in heaven, and you are on earth; therefore, let your words be few.
For a dream comes through the abundance of business, and a fool's voice is recognized by the multitude of words.
When you make a vow to God, do not delay in fulfilling it, for He takes no pleasure in fools; pay what you have vowed.
It is better not to vow than to vow and not fulfill it.
Do not let your mouth lead you into sin, and do not say before the angel that it was a mistake; why should God be angry at your voice and destroy the work of your hands?
For in the multitude of dreams and many words, there are also various vanities; but fear God.

If you see the oppression of the poor and the violent perversion of justice in a province, do not be amazed at the matter, for there is one higher than the highest who observes, and there are others higher than they.
Moreover, the profit of the earth is for all; even the king is served by the field.
He who loves silver will not be satisfied with silver, nor he who loves abundance with increase; this is also vanity.
When goods increase, those who consume them increase as well; and what benefit is there to the owners, except to gaze upon them?
The sleep of a laboring man is sweet, whether he eats little or much, but the abundance of the rich will not allow him to sleep.
There is a grievous evil that I have seen under the sun: riches kept for the owners to their detriment.
But those riches perish through misfortune, and if he begets a son, there is nothing in his hand.
As he came from his mother's womb, he shall return as he came, taking nothing of his labor that he may carry away in his hand.
And this is also a grievous evil: that in all respects, as he came, so shall he go; and what profit does he have who has labored for the wind?
All his days he eats in darkness, and he has much sorrow and anger with his sickness.
Behold what I have seen: it is good and fitting for one to eat and drink and enjoy the good of all his labor under the sun during the days of his life, which God gives him, for it is his portion.
To every man to whom God has given riches and wealth, and has granted him the power to enjoy them, to take his portion, and to rejoice in his labor; this is the gift of God.
For he will not often remember the days of his life, because God keeps him occupied with the joy of his heart.
There is a troubling reality I have observed under the sun, and it is prevalent among humanity:

A man to whom God has granted riches, wealth, and honor, so that he lacks nothing for his soul of all that he desires, yet God does not give him the ability to enjoy it; instead, a stranger consumes it: this is futility, and it is a grievous affliction.

If a man fathers a hundred children and lives many years, so that the days of his life are numerous, yet his soul is not satisfied with good, and he has no burial; I say, that a stillborn child is better off than he.
For he comes into the world in vain and departs in darkness, and his name will be enveloped in obscurity.
Moreover, he has not seen the sun, nor experienced anything: this one finds more rest than the other.
Indeed, even if he lives a thousand years twice over, yet he has not witnessed any good: do not all end up in the same place?
All the toil of man is for his mouth, yet his appetite is never satisfied.
For what advantage does the wise have over the fool? What does the poor man possess, who knows how to walk among the living?
Better is the sight of the eyes than the wandering of desire: this too is futility and a vexation of spirit.
That which has been is already named, and it is known that it is humanity: nor can he contend with one who is stronger than he.
Given that there are many things that amplify futility, what benefit is there for man?
For who knows what is good for man in this life, all the days of his fleeting existence which he spends like a shadow? For who can tell a man what will come after him under the sun?
A good name is more valuable than precious ointment; and the day of death is better than the day of one's birth.
It is better to visit the house of mourning than to attend the house of feasting, for that is the fate of all people; and the living should take it to heart.
Sorrow is more beneficial than laughter, for the sadness of the countenance improves the heart.
The heart of the wise is in the house of mourning, while the heart of fools is in the house of merriment.
It is better to heed the rebuke of the wise than to listen to the song of fools.
Just as the crackling of thorns under a pot, so is the laughter of a fool; this too is vanity.
Surely oppression drives a wise man to madness, and a gift corrupts the heart.
Better is the end of a matter than its beginning; and the patient in spirit is better than the proud in spirit.
Do not be quick to anger in your spirit, for anger rests in the bosom of fools.
Do not say, "Why were the former days better than these?" for you do not inquire wisely about this.
Wisdom is valuable alongside an inheritance, and it brings profit to those who see the light of day.
For wisdom is a defense, and money is a defense; but the excellence of knowledge is that wisdom gives life to those who possess it.
Consider the work of God, for who can make straight what He has made crooked?
In the day of prosperity, be joyful, but in the day of adversity, reflect: God has set one against the other so that man may find nothing after him.
I have seen all things in the days of my vanity: there is a just man who perishes in his righteousness, and there is a wicked man who prolongs his life in his wickedness.
Do not be overly righteous, nor make yourself excessively wise; why should you destroy yourself?
Do not be excessively wicked, nor be foolish; why should you die before your time?
It is good to hold on to this; yes, do not let go of it: for he who fears God will escape from them all.
Wisdom strengthens the wise more than ten mighty men in a city.
For there is no just man on earth who does good and does not sin.
Also, do not pay attention to all the words that are spoken, lest you hear your servant curse you;
For often your own heart knows that you yourself have also cursed others.
All this I have tested by wisdom: I said, "I will be wise," but it was far from me.
What is far off and exceedingly deep? Who can find it out?
I applied my heart to know, to search, and to seek out wisdom, the reason for things, and to understand the wickedness of folly, even of foolishness and madness.
And I find more bitter than death the woman whose heart is full of snares and nets, and whose hands are like chains: whoever pleases God will escape from her, but the sinner will be caught by her.
Behold, this I have found, says the preacher, counting one by one to find the account:
Yet my soul seeks but does not find: one man among a thousand I have found, but a woman among all these I have not found.
Lo, this only have I discovered: that God made man upright, but they have sought out many inventions.
Who is the wise man, and who knows the interpretation of a matter? A man's wisdom makes his face shine, and the boldness of his face will change.
I advise you to keep the king's command, and to respect the oath made to God.
Do not be quick to leave his presence; do not stand in an evil matter, for he does whatever pleases him.
Where the word of a king is, there is power; and who can say to him, "What are you doing?"
Whoever keeps the commandment will experience no evil; a wise man's heart discerns both time and judgment.
For every purpose, there is a time and judgment; therefore, the misery of man is great upon him.
For he does not know what will happen; who can tell him when it will occur?
No man has power over the spirit to retain it; nor does he have power on the day of death. There is no escape in that war, nor will wickedness save those who are devoted to it.
I have seen all this and applied my heart to every work done under the sun: there is a time when one man rules over another to his own detriment.
I also observed the wicked being buried, who had come and gone from the place of the holy; they were forgotten in the city where they had acted: this is also vanity.
Because the sentence against an evil deed is not executed quickly, the hearts of the sons of men are fully set to do evil.
Though a sinner commits evil a hundred times and his days are prolonged, I know that it will be well with those who fear God, who stand in awe before Him.
But it will not be well with the wicked, nor will he prolong his days, which are like a shadow, because he does not fear God.
There is a vanity that occurs on the earth: just men suffer as if they were wicked, while wicked men are treated as if they were righteous; I said that this too is vanity.

Then I commended joy, for there is nothing better for a man under the sun than to eat, drink, and be merry; for this will remain with him from his labor throughout the days of his life, which God gives him under the sun.
When I set my heart to know wisdom and to observe the business that is done on the earth (for there is one who neither day nor night sees sleep with his eyes),

I then considered all the work of God, that a man cannot discover the work done under the sun; for even if a man labors to seek it out, he will not find it; yes, further, even if a wise man thinks he knows it, he will not be able to find it.
I contemplated all of this in my heart, deciding to express it: the righteous, the wise, and their deeds are in the hands of God. No one knows love or hatred based on what lies before them.

All things happen to everyone alike: there is one fate for the righteous and the wicked, for the good and the clean, as well as for the unclean; for those who sacrifice and those who do not. Just as the good is, so is the sinner; and he who swears is like he who fears an oath.

This is a troubling reality among all that occurs under the sun: there is one fate for all. Indeed, the hearts of humanity are filled with evil, and madness resides in their hearts while they live, and afterward, they go to the dead.
For those who are joined to all the living, there is hope: a living dog is better than a dead lion.
The living know that they will die, but the dead know nothing; they have no reward, for their memory is forgotten.
Their love, hatred, and envy have now perished; they no longer have a share in anything that is done under the sun.
Go your way, enjoy your bread with joy, and drink your wine with a cheerful heart, for God now accepts your works.
Let your garments always be white, and let your head lack no ointment.
Live joyfully with the wife you love all the days of your fleeting life, which He has given you under the sun, for that is your portion in this life and in your labor under the sun.
Whatever your hand finds to do, do it with all your might; for there is no work, device, knowledge, or wisdom in the grave, where you are going.

I returned and observed under the sun that the race is not always to the swift, nor the battle to the strong, nor bread to the wise, nor riches to those of understanding, nor favor to skilled individuals; rather, time and chance happen to them all.
For man does not know his time: like fish caught in an evil net and birds trapped in a snare, so are the sons of men ensnared in an evil time that suddenly befalls them.
This wisdom I have also observed under the sun, and it seemed significant to me:
There was a small city with few men in it; a great king came against it, besieged it, and built strong fortifications against it.
In that city, a poor wise man was found, and through his wisdom, he saved the city; yet no one remembered that same poor man.
Then I said, "Wisdom is better than strength; however, the wisdom of the poor man is despised, and his words are not heard."
The words of wise individuals are heard in quiet more than the shouts of a ruler among fools.
Wisdom is better than weapons of war, but one sinner can destroy much good.
Dead flies cause the apothecary's ointment to emit a foul odor; likewise, a small folly can tarnish the reputation of one esteemed for wisdom and honor.
A wise man's heart is positioned at his right hand, while a fool's heart is found at his left.
Indeed, when a fool walks along the way, his lack of wisdom becomes evident, and he proclaims to everyone that he is a fool.
If the spirit of the ruler rises against you, do not abandon your position; for yielding can quell significant offenses.
I have observed an injustice under the sun, an error that arises from the ruler:
Folly is exalted, while the wealthy occupy lowly positions.
I have seen servants riding on horses, while princes walk as servants upon the earth.
Whoever digs a pit will fall into it; and whoever breaks through a hedge will be bitten by a serpent.
Whoever removes stones will be harmed by them; and he who splits wood will be endangered by it.
If the iron is dull and he does not sharpen its edge, he must exert more strength; but wisdom is valuable for guidance.
Surely, the serpent will strike without enchantment; and a babbler is no better.
The words from a wise man's mouth are gracious; but the lips of a fool will ultimately lead to his own downfall.
The beginning of his words is foolishness, and the conclusion of his speech is mischievous madness.
A fool is also full of words: a man cannot predict what will be; and who can tell what will come after him?
The toil of the foolish exhausts everyone, for he does not know how to navigate to the city.
Woe to you, O land, when your king is a child, and your princes feast in the morning!
Blessed are you, O land, when your king is the son of nobles, and your princes eat at the proper time, for strength, and not for drunkenness!
Through excessive laziness, the structure decays; and due to the idleness of hands, the house collapses.
A feast is made for laughter, and wine brings joy; but money answers all things.
Do not curse the king, not even in your thoughts; and do not curse the rich in your private chamber: for a bird of the air will carry your voice, and that which has wings will reveal the matter.
Cast your bread upon the waters, for you will find it after many days.
Give a portion to seven, and also to eight; for you do not know what misfortune may come upon the earth.
If the clouds are full of rain, they will pour themselves out upon the earth; and if a tree falls to the south or to the north, in the place where the tree falls, there it will remain.
He who observes the wind will not sow, and he who regards the clouds will not reap.
Just as you do not know the way of the spirit, nor how the bones grow in the womb of a pregnant woman, so you do not know the works of God who creates all.
In the morning, sow your seed, and in the evening, do not withhold your hand; for you do not know which will prosper, this or that, or whether both will be equally good.
Truly, the light is sweet, and it is a pleasant thing for the eyes to behold the sun.
But if a man lives many years and enjoys them all, let him remember the days of darkness, for they will be many. All that comes is vanity.

Rejoice, O young man, in your youth; let your heart cheer you in the days of your youth, and walk in the ways of your heart and in the sight of your eyes; but know that for all these things, God will bring you into judgment.
Therefore, remove sorrow from your heart and put away evil from your flesh, for childhood and youth are vanity.
Remember your Creator in the days of your youth, before the difficult days come, and the years approach when you will say, "I find no pleasure in them."
Before the sun, the light, the moon, and the stars grow dim, and the clouds return after the rain:
On the day when the keepers of the house tremble, and the strong men bow down, when the grinders cease because they are few, and those who look out the windows are darkened,
And the doors are shut in the streets, when the sound of grinding is low, and one rises at the voice of a bird, and all the daughters of music are brought low;

Also, when they are afraid of heights, and dangers are in the way, when the almond tree blossoms, and the grasshopper becomes a burden, and desire fails: for man goes to his eternal home, and mourners walk in the streets:
Before the silver cord is loosed, or the golden bowl is broken, or the pitcher shatters at the fountain, or the wheel is broken at the cistern.
Then the dust returns to the earth as it was, and the spirit returns to God who gave it.
Vanity of vanities, says the preacher; all is vanity.
Moreover, because the preacher was wise, he taught the people knowledge; he carefully considered and arranged many proverbs.
The preacher sought to find acceptable words, and what was written was upright, even words of truth.
The words of the wise are like goads, and like nails firmly fixed by the masters of assemblies, given by one shepherd.
And further, my son, be warned: there is no end to the making of many books, and much study is a weariness to the flesh.
Let us hear the conclusion of the whole matter: Fear God and keep His commandments, for this is the whole duty of man.
For God will bring every deed into judgment, including every hidden thing, whether it is good or evil.
The Song of Songs, attributed to Solomon.
Let him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth, for your love is better than wine.
Because of the fragrance of your good ointments, your name is like ointment poured forth; therefore, the virgins love you.
Draw me in; we will run after you. The king has brought me into his chambers; we will be glad and rejoice in you; we will remember your love more than wine; the upright love you.
I am dark but lovely, O daughters of Jerusalem, like the tents of Kedar, like the curtains of Solomon.
Do not look upon me because I am dark, for the sun has gazed upon me. My mother's children were angry with me; they made me the keeper of the vineyards, but my own vineyard I have not kept.
Tell me, O you whom my soul loves, where you feed your flock, where you make it rest at noon; for why should I be like one who turns aside by the flocks of your companions?
If you do not know, O fairest among women, go your way following the footsteps of the flock, and feed your young goats beside the shepherds' tents.
I have compared you, O my love, to a company of horses in Pharaoh's chariots.
Your cheeks are lovely with rows of jewels; your neck is adorned with chains of gold.
We will make you borders of gold with studs of silver.
While the king sits at his table, my spikenard sends forth its fragrance.
A bundle of myrrh is my beloved to me; he shall lie all night between my breasts.
My beloved is to me like a cluster of henna in the vineyards of Engedi.
Behold, you are fair, my love; behold, you are fair; you have dove's eyes.
Behold, you are fair, my beloved; yes, pleasant; also, our bed is green.
The beams of our house are cedar, and our rafters are fir.
I am the rose of Sharon and the lily of the valleys.
As the lily among thorns, so is my love among the daughters.
As the apple tree among the trees of the wood, so is my beloved among the sons. I sat down under his shadow with great delight, and his fruit was sweet to my taste.
He brought me to the banqueting house, and his banner over me was love.
Sustain me with flagons, comfort me with apples, for I am lovesick.
His left hand is under my head, and his right hand embraces me.
I charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem, by the roes and by the hinds of the field, that you do not stir up nor awaken my love until he pleases.
The voice of my beloved! Behold, he comes leaping upon the mountains, skipping upon the hills.
My beloved is like a roe or a young hart; behold, he stands behind our wall, looking forth at the windows, showing himself through the lattice.
My beloved spoke and said to me, "Rise up, my love, my fair one, and come away."
For behold, the winter is past, the rain is over and gone;
The flowers appear on the earth; the time of the singing of birds has come, and the voice of the turtle is heard in our land;
The fig tree puts forth her green figs, and the vines with tender grapes give a good smell. Arise, my love, my fair one, and come away.
O my dove, that art in the clefts of the rock, in the secret places of the stairs, let me see your countenance, let me hear your voice; for sweet is your voice, and your countenance is lovely.
Take us the foxes, the little foxes that spoil the vines, for our vines have tender grapes.
My beloved is mine, and I am his; he feeds among the lilies.
Until the day breaks and the shadows flee away, turn, my beloved, and be like a roe or a young hart upon the mountains of Bether.
By night, on my bed, I sought the one whom my soul loves; I searched for him, but I did not find him.
I will rise now and wander through the city, in the streets and in the broad ways; I will seek the one whom my soul loves; I searched for him, but I did not find him.
The watchmen who patrol the city found me; to them, I said, "Have you seen the one whom my soul loves?"

I had only passed a little way from them when I found the one whom my soul loves; I held him and would not let him go until I brought him into my mother's house, into the chamber of her who conceived me.
I charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem, by the gazelles and by the does of the field, that you do not stir up or awaken my love until he pleases.
Who is this that comes out of the wilderness like pillars of smoke, perfumed with myrrh and frankincense, with all the fragrant powders of the merchant?
Behold his bed, which is Solomon's; sixty valiant men surround it, from the valiant of Israel.
All of them hold swords, skilled in battle; each man has his sword at his side because of fear in the night.
King Solomon made himself a chariot from the wood of Lebanon.
He made its pillars of silver, its base of gold, its covering of purple, and its interior paved with love for the daughters of Jerusalem.
Go forth, O daughters of Zion, and behold King Solomon with the crown with which his mother crowned him on the day of his wedding, and on the day of the joy of his heart.
Behold, you are beautiful, my love; behold, you are beautiful; you have doves' eyes within your hair: your hair is like a flock of goats that appear from Mount Gilead.
Your teeth are like a flock of sheep that have been freshly shorn, which have come up from the washing; each one bears twins, and none is barren among them.
Your lips are like a thread of scarlet, and your speech is lovely: your temples are like a piece of pomegranate within your hair.
Your neck is like the tower of David built for an armory, upon which hang a thousand bucklers, all shields of mighty men.
Your two breasts are like two young deer that are twins, which feed among the lilies.
Until the day breaks and the shadows flee away, I will go to the mountain of myrrh and to the hill of frankincense.
You are all beautiful, my love; there is no flaw in you.
Come with me from Lebanon, my bride; come with me from Lebanon: look from the top of Amana, from the top of Shenir and Hermon, from the dens of lions, from the mountains of leopards.
You have captivated my heart, my sister, my bride; you have captivated my heart with one of your eyes, with one chain of your neck.
How beautiful is your love, my sister, my bride! How much better is your love than wine! And the fragrance of your ointments is better than all spices!
Your lips, O my bride, drip like the honeycomb: honey and milk are under your tongue; and the fragrance of your garments is like the fragrance of Lebanon.
A garden enclosed is my sister, my bride; a spring shut up, a fountain sealed.
Your plants are an orchard of pomegranates, with delightful fruits; henna with spikenard,
Spikenard and saffron; calamus and cinnamon, with all trees of frankincense; myrrh and aloes, with all the finest spices:
A fountain of gardens, a well of living waters, and streams flowing from Lebanon.
Awake, O north wind; and come, O south wind; blow upon my garden, that its spices may flow out. Let my beloved come into his garden and eat its pleasant fruits.

I have come into my garden, my sister, my spouse: I have gathered my myrrh along with my spice; I have eaten my honeycomb and my honey; I have drunk my wine and my milk: eat, O friends; drink, yes, drink abundantly, O beloved.

I sleep, but my heart is awake: it is the voice of my beloved that knocks, saying, Open to me, my sister, my love, my dove, my undefiled: for my head is drenched with dew, and my locks with the drops of the night.
I have put off my coat; how can I put it on again? I have washed my feet; how can I defile them?
My beloved put his hand through the hole of the door, and my heart was stirred for him.
I rose up to open to my beloved; my hands dripped with myrrh, and my fingers with sweet-smelling myrrh, upon the handles of the lock.
I opened to my beloved; but my beloved had withdrawn himself and was gone: my soul failed when he spoke: I sought him, but I could not find him; I called him, but he gave me no answer.
The watchmen who went about the city found me; they struck me, they wounded me; the keepers of the walls took away my veil from me.
I charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem, if you find my beloved, that you tell him that I am sick with love.
What is your beloved more than another beloved, O you fairest among women? What is your beloved more than another beloved, that you so charge us?
My beloved is white and ruddy, the chiefest among ten thousand.
His head is like the finest gold, his locks are bushy and black as a raven.
His eyes are like the eyes of doves by the rivers of waters, washed with milk, and fitly set.
His cheeks are like a bed of spices, like sweet flowers: his lips are like lilies, dropping sweet-smelling myrrh.
His hands are like gold rings set with beryl: his belly is like bright ivory overlaid with sapphires.
His legs are like pillars of marble, set upon sockets of fine gold: his countenance is like Lebanon, excellent as the cedars.
His mouth is most sweet: yes, he is altogether lovely. This is my beloved, and this is my friend, O daughters of Jerusalem.
Where has your beloved gone, O fairest among women? Where has your beloved turned aside? Let us seek him with you.
My beloved has gone down into his garden, to the beds of spices, to feed in the gardens and gather lilies.
I am my beloved's, and my beloved is mine; he grazes among the lilies.
You are beautiful, O my love, as Tirzah, lovely as Jerusalem, fearsome as an army with banners.
Turn your eyes away from me, for they have captivated me; your hair is like a flock of goats descending from Gilead.
Your teeth are like a flock of sheep that have come up from the washing, each one bearing twins, and not one is barren among them.
Like a piece of pomegranate are your temples within your locks.
There are sixty queens, eighty concubines, and countless virgins.
My dove, my undefiled, is but one; she is the only one of her mother, the chosen one of her who bore her. The daughters saw her and blessed her; indeed, the queens and concubines praised her.
Who is she that appears like the dawn, beautiful as the moon, bright as the sun, and fearsome as an army with banners?
I went down into the garden of nuts to see the fruits of the valley, to see if the vine had blossomed and the pomegranates had budded.
Before I was aware, my soul set me among the chariots of Amminadib.
Return, return, O Shulamite; return, return, that we may gaze upon you. What will you see in the Shulamite? As if it were the company of two armies.
How lovely are your feet in shoes, O daughter of the prince! The curves of your thighs are like precious jewels, crafted by the hands of a skilled artisan.
Your navel is like a round goblet, never lacking in wine; your belly resembles a mound of wheat surrounded by lilies.
Your two breasts are like two young twin deer.
Your neck is like a tower of ivory; your eyes are like the fish pools in Heshbon, near the gate of Bathrabbim; your nose is like the tower of Lebanon that looks toward Damascus.
Your head is like Mount Carmel, and your hair is like royal purple; the king is captivated by your beauty.
How lovely and delightful you are, O love!
Your stature resembles a palm tree, and your breasts are like clusters of grapes.
I said, I will climb the palm tree and take hold of its branches; your breasts will be like clusters of the vine, and the fragrance of your breath like apples.
And the roof of your mouth is like the finest wine for my beloved, flowing smoothly and awakening the lips of those who are asleep.
I belong to my beloved, and his desire is for me.
Come, my beloved, let us go out to the fields; let us rest in the villages.
Let us rise early to the vineyards; let us see if the vines are in bloom, if the tender grapes have appeared, and if the pomegranates are blossoming; there I will give you my love.
The mandrakes emit a sweet fragrance, and at our gates are all kinds of delightful fruits, both new and old, which I have stored up for you, O my beloved.
O, that you were like my brother, who nursed at my mother's breast! When I find you outside, I would kiss you; indeed, I would not be scorned.
I would lead you and bring you into my mother's house, where she would teach me: I would offer you spiced wine and the juice of my pomegranate.
His left hand would be under my head, and his right hand would embrace me.
I urge you, O daughters of Jerusalem, do not stir up or awaken my love until he desires it.
Who is this coming up from the wilderness, leaning on her beloved? I raised you under the apple tree; there your mother gave you birth; there she bore you.
Set me as a seal upon your heart, as a seal upon your arm: for love is as strong as death; jealousy is as fierce as the grave: its flames are fiery, a most intense blaze.
Many waters cannot quench love, nor can floods drown it: if a man were to give all the substance of his house for love, it would be utterly despised.
We have a little sister, and she has no breasts: what shall we do for our sister on the day she is spoken for?
If she is a wall, we will build upon her a palace of silver; and if she is a door, we will enclose her with boards of cedar.
I am a wall, and my breasts are like towers: in his eyes, I was as one who found favor.
Solomon had a vineyard at Baalhamon; he leased the vineyard to caretakers; each was to bring a thousand pieces of silver for its fruit.
My vineyard, which is mine, is before me: you, O Solomon, must have a thousand, and those who tend the fruit, two hundred.
You who dwell in the gardens, your companions listen for your voice: let me hear it.
Make haste, my beloved, and be like a gazelle or a young stag on the mountains of spices.
The vision of Isaiah, son of Amoz, which he received regarding Judah and Jerusalem during the reigns of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, kings of Judah.
Listen, O heavens, and pay attention, O earth: for the LORD has spoken. I have nurtured and raised children, but they have rebelled against me.
The ox knows its owner, and the donkey its master's feeding trough; but Israel does not know, my people do not understand.

Ah, sinful nation, a people burdened with iniquity, a brood of evildoers, children who are corruptors: they have forsaken the LORD, they have provoked the Holy One of Israel to anger, they have turned away backward.
Why should you be struck anymore? You will only continue to rebel: the whole head is sick, and the whole heart is faint.
From the sole of the foot to the head, there is no soundness in it; only wounds, bruises, and festering sores: they have not been treated, nor bound up, nor soothed with ointment.
Your country is desolate, your cities are burned with fire: your land is devoured by strangers in your presence, and it is desolate, like a city overthrown by invaders.
And the daughter of Zion is left like a hut in a vineyard, like a lodge in a cucumber garden, like a besieged city.
Unless the LORD of hosts had left us a very small remnant, we would have been like Sodom, and we would have been like Gomorrah.
Hear the word of the LORD, you rulers of Sodom; give ear to the law of our God, you people of Gomorrah.

What is the purpose of the multitude of your sacrifices to me? says the LORD: I am full of the burnt offerings of rams, and the fat of well-fed beasts; I do not delight in the blood of bulls, or of lambs, or of goats.
When you come to appear before me, who has required this from your hand, to trample my courts?
Bring no more worthless offerings; incense is an abomination to me; your new moons and sabbaths, the calling of assemblies, I cannot endure; it is iniquity, even the solemn meeting.
Your new moons and your appointed feasts my soul hates: they are a burden to me; I am weary of bearing them.
And when you spread out your hands, I will hide my eyes from you: yes, when you make many prayers, I will not listen: your hands are full of blood.
Wash yourselves, make yourselves clean; remove the evil of your deeds from before my eyes; cease to do evil;
Learn to do good; seek justice, relieve the oppressed, defend the fatherless, plead for the widow.
Come now, and let us reason together, says the LORD: though your sins are like scarlet, they shall be as white as snow; though they are red like crimson, they shall be like wool.
If you are willing and obedient, you shall eat the good of the land;
But if you refuse and rebel, you shall be devoured by the sword: for the mouth of the LORD has spoken.
How has the faithful city become a harlot! It was full of justice; righteousness dwelt in it; but now murderers.
Your silver has become dross, your wine is mixed with water.
Your princes are rebellious, and companions of thieves: everyone loves gifts and follows after rewards: they do not judge the fatherless, nor does the cause of the widow come before them.
Therefore says the LORD, the LORD of hosts, the Mighty One of Israel, Ah, I will rid myself of my adversaries, and avenge myself on my enemies:
And I will turn my hand against you, and thoroughly purge away your dross, and remove all your impurities:
And I will restore your judges as at the first, and your counselors as at the beginning: afterward you shall be called, The city of righteousness, the faithful city.
Zion shall be redeemed with justice, and her converts with righteousness.
And the destruction of the transgressors and of the sinners shall be together, and those who forsake the LORD shall be consumed.
For they shall be ashamed of the oaks which you have desired, and you shall be confounded for the gardens that you have chosen.
For you shall be like an oak whose leaf withers, and like a garden that has no water.
And the strong shall be like tow, and the maker of it like a spark, and they shall both burn together, and none shall quench them.
The vision that Isaiah, son of Amoz, received regarding Judah and Jerusalem.
In the last days, the mountain of the LORD's house will be established at the highest point of the mountains and exalted above the hills; all nations will stream to it.

Many people will come and say, "Come, let us go up to the mountain of the LORD, to the house of the God of Jacob; He will teach us His ways, and we will walk in His paths, for the law will go forth from Zion, and the word of the LORD from Jerusalem."

He will judge among the nations and rebuke many people; they will turn their swords into plowshares and their spears into pruning hooks. Nation will not take up sword against nation, nor will they learn war anymore.
O house of Jacob, come, let us walk in the light of the LORD.
You have forsaken your people, the house of Jacob, because they are filled with influences from the east, are soothsayers like the Philistines, and delight in the children of strangers.
Their land is full of silver and gold, and there is no end to their treasures; their land is also filled with horses, and there is no end to their chariots.
Their land is filled with idols; they worship the work of their own hands, what their own fingers have made.
The common man bows down, and the great man humbles himself; therefore, do not forgive them.
Enter into the rocks and hide in the dust, in fear of the LORD and for the glory of His majesty.
The proud looks of man will be humbled, and the arrogance of men will be brought low; the LORD alone will be exalted in that day.
For the day of the LORD of hosts will be upon everyone who is proud and lofty, and upon everyone who is lifted up; they will be brought low.
It will be upon all the cedars of Lebanon, which are high and lifted up, and upon all the oaks of Bashan,
And upon all the high mountains and upon all the hills that are lifted up,
And upon every high tower and every fortified wall,
And upon all the ships of Tarshish and all the beautiful vessels.
The pride of man will be humbled, and the arrogance of men will be brought low; the LORD alone will be exalted in that day.
He will completely abolish the idols.
They will go into the holes of the rocks and into the caves of the earth, in fear of the LORD and for the glory of His majesty, when He arises to shake the earth terribly.
In that day, a man will throw away his silver idols and his gold idols, which he made for himself to worship, to the moles and to the bats;
To enter the clefts of the rocks and the tops of the rugged cliffs, in fear of the LORD and for the glory of His majesty, when He arises to shake the earth terribly.
Stop trusting in man, whose breath is in his nostrils; for what is he to be valued?
For behold, the Lord, the LORD of hosts, removes from Jerusalem and Judah the support and the sustenance, the complete supply of bread, and the entire supply of water.
The valiant man, the warrior, the judge, the prophet, the wise, and the elder,
The captain of fifty, the respected man, the counselor, the skilled craftsman, and the articulate speaker.
And I will appoint children to be their leaders, and infants shall govern them.
And the people shall be oppressed, each by another, and each by his neighbor: the child shall act arrogantly against the elder, and the lowly against the esteemed.
When a man shall grasp his brother from his father's house, saying, "You have clothing; be our leader, and let this disaster be under your authority."
In that day, he shall swear, saying, "I will not be a healer; for in my house is neither bread nor clothing: do not make me a ruler of the people."
For Jerusalem is devastated, and Judah has fallen: because their speech and their actions are against the LORD, provoking the gaze of His glory.
The appearance of their faces testifies against them; they openly declare their sin like Sodom, they do not hide it. Woe to their souls! for they have brought evil upon themselves.
Tell the righteous that it shall be well with them: for they shall enjoy the fruit of their deeds.
Woe to the wicked! it shall be ill with him: for the consequences of his actions shall be given to him.
As for my people, children are their oppressors, and women rule over them. O my people, those who lead you cause you to stray and destroy the path you should follow.
The LORD stands up to plead, and stands to judge the people.
The LORD will enter into judgment with the elders of His people and their leaders: for you have consumed the vineyard; the plunder of the poor is in your homes.
What do you mean by crushing my people and grinding the faces of the poor? says the Lord GOD of hosts.
Moreover, the LORD says, Because the daughters of Zion are proud, and walk with outstretched necks and seductive eyes, strutting and swaying as they go, and making a tinkling sound with their feet:
Therefore, the LORD will strike with a scab the crown of the heads of the daughters of Zion, and the LORD will expose their secret parts.
In that day, the Lord will remove the finery of their tinkling ornaments around their feet, and their headbands, and their crescent-shaped ornaments,
The chains, and the bracelets, and the veils,
The bonnets, and the leg ornaments, and the headbands, and the tablets, and the earrings,
The rings, and the nose jewels,
The changeable garments, and the mantles, and the shawls, and the curling pins,
The mirrors, and the fine linen, and the hoods, and the veils.

And it shall come to pass that instead of a sweet fragrance, there shall be a stench; and instead of a sash, a rope; and instead of well-styled hair, baldness; and instead of a rich robe, a garment of sackcloth; and branding instead of beauty.
Your men shall fall by the sword, and your mighty in battle.
And her gates shall lament and mourn; and she, being desolate, shall sit upon the ground.
And in that day, seven women will cling to one man, saying, "We will provide our own food and wear our own clothes; just let us be called by your name to remove our disgrace."
In that day, the branch of the LORD will be beautiful and glorious, and the produce of the earth will be excellent and appealing for those who have survived in Israel.
It will come to pass that those who are left in Zion and those who remain in Jerusalem will be called holy, every one whose name is written among the living in Jerusalem.
When the Lord has cleansed the impurities of the daughters of Zion and has removed the bloodshed from Jerusalem by the spirit of judgment and the spirit of purification.

And the LORD will create over every dwelling place on Mount Zion and over her gatherings, a cloud and smoke by day, and the radiance of a flaming fire by night; for the glory will serve as a protective covering.
There will be a shelter to provide shade during the day from the heat, and a place of refuge, as well as a cover from storms and rain.
Now I will sing to my beloved a song about his vineyard. My beloved has a vineyard on a very fruitful hill:
He fenced it, removed the stones, planted it with the finest vines, built a tower in the middle, and made a winepress there. He expected it to produce grapes, but it yielded wild grapes.
And now, O inhabitants of Jerusalem and men of Judah, I ask you to judge between me and my vineyard.
What more could have been done for my vineyard that I have not done? Why, when I expected it to produce grapes, did it yield wild grapes?
Now, I will tell you what I will do to my vineyard: I will remove its hedge, and it will be devoured; I will break down its wall, and it will be trampled.
I will make it a wasteland; it will not be pruned or cultivated, and briers and thorns will grow up. I will also command the clouds not to rain upon it.
For the vineyard of the LORD of hosts is the house of Israel, and the men of Judah are his cherished plants. He looked for justice, but behold, oppression; for righteousness, but behold, a cry.
Woe to those who join house to house, who add field to field, until there is no room, and they are left alone in the midst of the earth!
In my ears, the LORD of hosts said, "Truly, many houses will be desolate, even great and beautiful ones, without inhabitants."
Indeed, ten acres of vineyard will yield only one bath, and a homer of seed will produce only an ephah.
Woe to those who rise early in the morning to pursue strong drink, who continue until night, until wine inflames them!
The harp, the lyre, the tambourine, and the flute, along with wine, are in their feasts; but they do not regard the work of the LORD, nor consider the operation of his hands.
Therefore, my people go into captivity for lack of knowledge; their honorable men are famished, and their multitude is parched with thirst.
Therefore, hell has enlarged itself and opened its mouth without measure; their glory, their multitude, their pomp, and he who rejoices shall descend into it.
The common man will be brought down, and the mighty man will be humbled; the eyes of the proud will be humbled.
But the LORD of hosts will be exalted in judgment, and the Holy God will be sanctified in righteousness.
Then the lambs will graze as they wish, and strangers will eat in the desolate places of the fat ones.
Woe to those who draw iniquity with cords of vanity and sin as if with a cart rope!
Who say, "Let him hurry, and let his work come quickly, that we may see it; and let the counsel of the Holy One of Israel draw near and come, that we may know it!"
Woe to those who call evil good and good evil; who put darkness for light and light for darkness; who put bitter for sweet and sweet for bitter!
Woe to those who are wise in their own eyes and prudent in their own sight!
Woe to those who are mighty to drink wine and valiant men to mix strong drink,
Who justify the wicked for a bribe and take away the righteousness of the righteous from him!

Therefore, as the fire devours the stubble and the flame consumes the chaff, so their root will be as rottenness, and their blossom will go up like dust; because they have rejected the law of the LORD of hosts and despised the word of the Holy One of Israel.

Therefore, the anger of the LORD is kindled against his people; he has stretched out his hand against them and struck them. The hills trembled, and their corpses were torn in the streets. For all this, his anger is not turned away, but his hand is still stretched out.
He will lift up a banner for the nations from afar and will whistle for them from the ends of the earth; behold, they will come swiftly.
None will be weary or stumble among them; none will slumber or sleep; neither will the belt of their waist be loosed nor the strap of their sandals be broken.
Their arrows are sharp, and all their bows are bent; their horses' hooves will be like flint, and their wheels like a whirlwind.
Their roaring will be like a lion; they will roar like young lions. Yes, they will roar and seize their prey, and carry it away safely, and none will rescue it.
And in that day, they will roar against them like the roaring of the sea; and if one looks to the land, behold, darkness and sorrow, and the light will be darkened in the heavens.
In the year that King Uzziah died, I also saw the LORD sitting upon a throne, high and lifted up, and His train filled the temple.
Above it stood the seraphim; each one had six wings: with two he covered his face, with two he covered his feet, and with two he flew.
And one cried to another, saying, "Holy, holy, holy is the LORD of hosts; the whole earth is full of His glory."
And the posts of the door shook at the voice of him who cried, and the house was filled with smoke.
Then I said, "Woe is me! For I am undone; because I am a man of unclean lips, and I dwell in the midst of a people of unclean lips; for my eyes have seen the King, the LORD of hosts."
Then one of the seraphim flew to me, having a live coal in his hand, which he had taken with tongs from the altar.
And he laid it upon my mouth and said, "Lo, this has touched your lips; your iniquity is taken away, and your sin purged."
Also, I heard the voice of the Lord saying, "Whom shall I send, and who will go for us?" Then I said, "Here am I; send me."
And He said, "Go, and tell this people, 'Hear indeed, but understand not; and see indeed, but perceive not.'"

"Make the heart of this people fat, and make their ears heavy, and shut their eyes; lest they see with their eyes, and hear with their ears, and understand with their heart, and convert, and be healed."
Then I said, "Lord, how long?" And He answered, "Until the cities are wasted without inhabitant, and the houses without man, and the land is utterly desolate."
And the LORD has removed men far away, and there is a great forsaking in the midst of the land.

But yet in it shall be a tenth, and it shall return and be eaten; as a terebinth tree and as an oak, whose substance is in them when they cast their leaves; so the holy seed shall be the substance thereof.

In the days of Ahaz, son of Jotham, son of Uzziah, king of Judah, it happened that Rezin, king of Syria, and Pekah, son of Remaliah, king of Israel, marched against Jerusalem to wage war, but they could not succeed.
The house of David was informed, saying, "Syria has allied with Ephraim." This news troubled Ahaz and his people, as the trees of the forest tremble in the wind.
Then the LORD spoke to Isaiah, saying, "Go now to meet Ahaz, you and your son Shearjashub, at the end of the conduit of the upper pool on the highway to the fuller's field.
Tell him, 'Take heed and remain calm; do not fear, nor let your heart be faint because of the two smoldering firebrands—the fierce anger of Rezin and Syria, and the son of Remaliah.'
For Syria, Ephraim, and the son of Remaliah have plotted evil against you, saying,
'Let us go up against Judah and trouble it, and let us set up a king in the midst of it, even the son of Tabeal.'
Thus says the Lord GOD: 'It shall not stand, nor shall it come to pass.'
For the head of Syria is Damascus, and the head of Damascus is Rezin; within sixty-five years, Ephraim will be shattered so that it will no longer be a people.
The head of Ephraim is Samaria, and the head of Samaria is Remaliah's son. If you do not believe, you will not be established.'
Moreover, the LORD spoke again to Ahaz, saying,
'Ask for a sign from the LORD your God; ask it either in the depths or in the heights above.'
But Ahaz replied, 'I will not ask, nor will I test the LORD.'
Then he said, 'Hear now, O house of David; is it a trivial thing for you to weary men, but will you weary my God also?
Therefore, the Lord himself will give you a sign: Behold, a virgin shall conceive and bear a son, and shall call his name Immanuel.
He will eat butter and honey, so that he may know to refuse the evil and choose the good.
For before the child knows to refuse the evil and choose the good, the land that you dread will be forsaken by both of its kings.
The LORD will bring upon you, your people, and your father's house days that have not come since the day Ephraim departed from Judah, even the king of Assyria.
And it shall come to pass in that day that the LORD will whistle for the fly that is in the farthest part of the rivers of Egypt, and for the bee that is in the land of Assyria.
They will come and rest in the desolate valleys, in the holes of the rocks, and upon all thorns and bushes.
In that day, the Lord will shave with a hired razor, namely, with those beyond the river, with the king of Assyria, the head and the hair of the feet; it will also consume the beard.
It shall come to pass in that day that a man will rear a young cow and two sheep;
And it shall come to pass that, because of the abundance of milk they give, he will eat butter; for butter and honey will everyone eat who is left in the land.
In that day, every place where there were a thousand vines worth a thousand silver shekels will become briers and thorns.
Men will come there with bows and arrows, for all the land will become briers and thorns.
And on all the hills that are dug with a mattock, there will be no fear of briers and thorns; it will be for the sending forth of oxen and for the treading of lesser cattle.
Moreover, the LORD said to me, "Take a large scroll and write on it with a man's pen concerning Mahershalalhashbaz."
I appointed faithful witnesses to record this: Uriah the priest and Zechariah, the son of Jeberechiah.
I went to the prophetess, and she conceived and bore a son. Then the LORD said to me, "Name him Mahershalalhashbaz."
Before the child knows how to say, "My father" and "My mother," the riches of Damascus and the spoils of Samaria will be taken away before the king of Assyria.
The LORD spoke to me again, saying,
"Since this people refuses the gentle waters of Shiloah and rejoices in Rezin and Remaliah's son,

now behold, the Lord will bring upon them the mighty waters of the river, strong and numerous, even the king of Assyria and all his glory. He will rise over all his channels and overflow all his banks.
He will sweep through Judah; he will overflow and go over, reaching even to the neck; and the outstretching of his wings will fill the breadth of your land, O Immanuel.
Associate yourselves, O you people, and you will be shattered; give ear, all you from distant lands: gird yourselves, and you will be shattered; gird yourselves, and you will be shattered.
Take counsel together, but it will come to nothing; speak the word, but it will not stand, for God is with us.
For the LORD spoke to me with a strong hand and instructed me not to walk in the way of this people, saying,
"Do not say, 'A confederacy,' to all those to whom this people says, 'A confederacy'; do not fear what they fear, nor be afraid."
Sanctify the LORD of hosts Himself; let Him be your fear, and let Him be your dread.
He will be a sanctuary; but for both houses of Israel, He will be a stone of stumbling and a rock of offense, a trap and a snare to the inhabitants of Jerusalem.
Many among them will stumble, fall, be broken, be snared, and be taken.
Bind up the testimony; seal the law among my disciples.
I will wait for the LORD, who hides His face from the house of Jacob, and I will look for Him.
Behold, I and the children whom the LORD has given me are for signs and wonders in Israel from the LORD of hosts, who dwells in Mount Zion.
When they say to you, "Seek those who have familiar spirits and wizards who chirp and mutter," should not a people seek their God? Should they seek the living on behalf of the dead?
To the law and to the testimony: if they do not speak according to this word, it is because there is no light in them.
They will pass through it, hard-pressed and hungry; and it will come to pass that when they are hungry, they will be enraged and curse their king and their God, and look upward.
They will look to the earth and see trouble and darkness, gloom and anguish; and they will be driven into darkness.

Nevertheless, the dimness shall not be as it was in her vexation when he first lightly afflicted the land of Zebulun and the land of Naphtali; afterward, he did more grievously afflict her by the way of the sea, beyond Jordan, in Galilee of the nations.
The people who walked in darkness have seen a great light; those who dwell in the land of the shadow of death, upon them has the light shined.
You have multiplied the nation, yet not increased the joy; they rejoice before you as in the joy of harvest, and as men rejoice when they divide the spoil.
For you have broken the yoke of his burden, and the staff from his shoulder, the rod of his oppressor, as in the day of Midian.
For every battle of the warrior is with confused noise and garments rolled in blood; but this shall be with burning and fuel of fire.

For unto us a child is born, unto us a son is given; and the government shall be upon his shoulder, and his name shall be called Wonderful, Counselor, The Mighty God, The Everlasting Father, The Prince of Peace.

Of the increase of his government and peace, there shall be no end, upon the throne of David and upon his kingdom, to order it and to establish it with judgment and justice from henceforth even forever. The zeal of the LORD of hosts will perform this.
The Lord sent a word into Jacob, and it has lighted upon Israel.
And all the people shall know, even Ephraim and the inhabitants of Samaria, who say in the pride and stoutness of heart,
"The bricks have fallen down, but we will build with hewn stones; the sycamores are cut down, but we will change them into cedars."
Therefore, the LORD shall set up the adversaries of Rezin against him and join his enemies together;
The Syrians before and the Philistines behind; and they shall devour Israel with open mouth. For all this, his anger is not turned away, but his hand is stretched out still.
For the people do not turn to him who smites them, nor do they seek the LORD of hosts.
Therefore, the LORD will cut off from Israel head and tail, branch and rush, in one day.
The ancient and honorable, he is the head; and the prophet who teaches lies, he is the tail.
For the leaders of this people cause them to err, and those who are led by them are destroyed.

Therefore, the LORD shall have no joy in their young men, nor shall he have mercy on their fatherless and widows; for everyone is a hypocrite and an evildoer, and every mouth speaks folly. For all this, his anger is not turned away, but his hand is stretched out still.
For wickedness burns like fire; it shall devour the briers and thorns, and shall kindle in the thickets of the forest, and they shall mount up like the lifting of smoke.
Through the wrath of the LORD of hosts, the land is darkened, and the people shall be as fuel for the fire; no man shall spare his brother.
And he shall snatch on the right hand and be hungry; and he shall eat on the left hand and not be satisfied; they shall eat every man the flesh of his own arm:
Manasseh, Ephraim; and Ephraim, Manasseh; and they together shall be against Judah. For all this, his anger is not turned away, but his hand is stretched out still.
Woe to those who enact unjust laws and write oppressive decrees;
To divert the needy from justice and deny the rights of the poor among my people, so that widows become their prey and they rob the fatherless!
And what will you do on the day of reckoning, and in the devastation that will come from afar? To whom will you turn for help? Where will you leave your glory?
Without me, they will bow down among the captives and fall among the slain. Yet, despite all this, his anger is not turned away, and his hand is still stretched out.
O Assyrian, the rod of my anger, and the staff in their hand is my indignation.
I will send him against a hypocritical nation, and I will give him a charge against the people of my wrath, to plunder and take the spoil, and to trample them down like the mire of the streets.
However, he does not intend this, nor does his heart think so; rather, it is in his heart to destroy and cut off many nations.
For he says, "Are not my princes all kings?"
Is not Calno like Carchemish? Is not Hamath like Arpad? Is not Samaria like Damascus?
As my hand has found the kingdoms of idols, and their graven images surpassed those of Jerusalem and Samaria;
Shall I not, as I have done to Samaria and her idols, do the same to Jerusalem and her idols?
Therefore, it will come to pass that when the Lord has completed his work on Mount Zion and Jerusalem, I will punish the proud heart of the king of Assyria and the glory of his lofty looks.

For he says, "By the strength of my hand I have accomplished this, and by my wisdom; for I am clever: I have removed the boundaries of the people, plundered their treasures, and brought down the inhabitants like a mighty warrior."
And my hand has found the riches of the people like a nest; as one gathers abandoned eggs, I have gathered all the earth, and there was none that flapped a wing, or opened a mouth, or chirped.

Shall the axe boast against the one who wields it? Or shall the saw exalt itself against the one who uses it? As if the rod should shake itself against those who lift it, or as if the staff should lift itself, as if it were not wood.
Therefore, the Lord, the Lord of hosts, will send leanness among his fat ones; and under his glory, he will kindle a fire like the burning of a flame.
And the light of Israel will be for a fire, and his Holy One for a flame: it will burn and consume his thorns and briers in a single day;
And it will consume the glory of his forest and his fruitful field, both soul and body: and they will be as when a standard-bearer faints.
And the remaining trees of his forest will be few, so that a child may write them down.

And it will come to pass in that day, that the remnant of Israel, and those who have escaped from the house of Jacob, will no longer rely on him who struck them; but they will trust in the LORD, the Holy One of Israel, in truth.
The remnant will return, even the remnant of Jacob, to the mighty God.
For though your people Israel be as the sand of the sea, yet a remnant of them will return: the decree of destruction will overflow with righteousness.
For the Lord GOD of hosts will carry out a decree, determined in the midst of all the land.
Therefore, thus says the Lord GOD of hosts, O my people dwelling in Zion, do not be afraid of the Assyrian: he will strike you with a rod and lift up his staff against you, as in the manner of Egypt.
For yet a little while, and the indignation will cease, and my anger will be directed at their destruction.
And the LORD of hosts will raise up a scourge against him, like the slaughter of Midian at the rock of Oreb: and as his rod was upon the sea, so will he lift it up in the manner of Egypt.
And it will come to pass in that day, that his burden will be removed from your shoulder, and his yoke from your neck, and the yoke will be destroyed because of the anointing.
He has come to Aiath, he has passed to Migron; at Michmash, he has laid up his supplies:
They have crossed over the passage; they have taken up their lodging at Geba; Ramah is afraid; Gibeah of Saul has fled.
Lift up your voice, O daughter of Gallim: let it be heard to Laish, O poor Anathoth.
Madmenah is removed; the inhabitants of Gebim gather to flee.
Yet he will remain at Nob that day: he will shake his hand against the mount of the daughter of Zion, the hill of Jerusalem.
Behold, the Lord, the LORD of hosts, will cut down the bough with terror: and the tall ones will be hewn down, and the proud will be humbled.
And he will cut down the thickets of the forest with iron, and Lebanon will fall by a mighty one.
A rod shall emerge from the lineage of Jesse, and a Branch will sprout from his roots.
The spirit of the LORD will rest upon him, embodying wisdom and understanding, counsel and strength, knowledge, and reverence for the LORD.
He will possess quick understanding in the fear of the LORD; he will not judge by mere appearances or make decisions based on hearsay.

Instead, he will judge the poor with righteousness and defend the meek of the earth with fairness; he will strike the earth with the words of his mouth and slay the wicked with the breath of his lips.
Righteousness will be his belt, and faithfulness will be his sash.
The wolf will live alongside the lamb, and the leopard will lie down with the young goat; the calf, the young lion, and the fattened calf will be together, and a little child will lead them.
The cow and the bear will graze together; their young will lie down side by side, and the lion will eat straw like the ox.
A nursing child will play near the den of the asp, and a weaned child will put his hand on the viper's lair.
They will not harm or destroy in all my holy mountain, for the earth will be filled with the knowledge of the LORD as the waters cover the sea.
On that day, a root of Jesse will stand as a banner for the people; the nations will seek him, and his resting place will be glorious.

It will come to pass on that day that the LORD will once again extend his hand a second time to reclaim the remnant of his people from Assyria, Egypt, Pathros, Cush, Elam, Shinar, Hamath, and the islands of the sea.
He will raise a banner for the nations and gather the outcasts of Israel, bringing together the dispersed of Judah from the four corners of the earth.
The jealousy of Ephraim will vanish, and the enemies of Judah will be cut off; Ephraim will no longer be jealous of Judah, and Judah will not harass Ephraim.
They will soar on the shoulders of the Philistines to the west; they will plunder the eastern peoples, laying their hands on Edom and Moab, and the children of Ammon will obey them.
The LORD will completely destroy the tongue of the Egyptian sea; with his mighty wind, he will wave his hand over the river, striking it into seven streams, allowing people to cross on dry ground.
A highway will be there for the remnant of his people who remain from Assyria, just as it was for Israel when they came up from the land of Egypt.
And on that day, you shall say, O LORD, I will praise you: though you were angry with me, your anger has turned away, and you have comforted me.
Behold, God is my salvation; I will trust and not be afraid: for the LORD JEHOVAH is my strength and my song; he has also become my salvation.
Therefore, with joy, you shall draw water from the wells of salvation.
And on that day, you shall say, Praise the LORD, call upon his name, declare his deeds among the people, and mention that his name is exalted.
Sing to the LORD; for he has done excellent things: this is known throughout all the earth.
Cry out and shout, you inhabitants of Zion: for great is the Holy One of Israel in your midst.
The burden of Babylon, which Isaiah, the son of Amoz, saw.
Lift up a banner on the high mountain, exalt your voice to them, and wave your hand so they may enter the gates of the nobles.
I have commanded my sanctified ones; I have also called my mighty ones for my anger, even those who rejoice in my majesty.
The noise of a multitude in the mountains, like that of a great people; a tumultuous noise of the kingdoms of nations gathered together: the LORD of hosts is mustering the army for battle.
They come from a distant country, from the ends of heaven, even the LORD, and the weapons of His indignation, to destroy the whole land.
Howl, for the day of the LORD is near; it will come as a destruction from the Almighty.
Therefore, all hands will grow weak, and every man's heart will melt.
They will be terrified; anguish and sorrow will seize them; they will be in pain like a woman in labor; they will be astonished at one another; their faces will burn like flames.
Behold, the day of the LORD comes, cruel, with wrath and fierce anger, to make the land desolate; and He will destroy the sinners from it.
For the stars of heaven and their constellations will not give their light; the sun will be darkened at its rising, and the moon will not shine.
And I will punish the world for its evil, and the wicked for their iniquity; I will put an end to the arrogance of the proud and will humble the haughtiness of the ruthless.
I will make a man more precious than fine gold; even a man more than the golden wedge of Ophir.
Therefore, I will shake the heavens, and the earth will be removed from its place, in the wrath of the LORD of hosts, and in the day of His fierce anger.
And it will be like a hunted gazelle, and like sheep with no one to gather them: each will turn to his own people, and everyone will flee to his own land.
Everyone who is found will be thrust through; and everyone who is joined to them will fall by the sword.
Their children will be dashed to pieces before their eyes; their houses will be plundered, and their wives will be ravished.
Behold, I will stir up the Medes against them, who will not value silver; and as for gold, they will not delight in it.
Their bows will also dash the young men to pieces; they will have no pity on the fruit of the womb; their eyes will not spare children.
And Babylon, the glory of kingdoms, the splendor of the Chaldeans, will be like when God overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah.
It will never be inhabited, nor will it be dwelt in from generation to generation; neither will the Arabian pitch his tent there, nor will shepherds make their folds there.
But wild beasts of the desert will lie there, and their houses will be filled with howling creatures; owls will dwell there, and satyrs will dance there.
And the wild beasts of the islands will cry in their desolate houses, and dragons in their pleasant palaces; her time is near to come, and her days will not be prolonged.
For the LORD will show mercy to Jacob, and will once again choose Israel, and place them in their own land: and the foreigners shall join with them, and they shall cling to the house of Jacob.

And the people shall take them and bring them to their place: and the house of Israel shall possess them in the land of the LORD as servants and handmaids: and they shall take captives of those who had taken them captive; and they shall rule over their oppressors.
And it shall come to pass on the day that the LORD gives you rest from your sorrow, and from your fear, and from the hard bondage in which you were made to serve,
That you shall take up this proverb against the king of Babylon, and say, "How the oppressor has ceased! The golden city has come to an end!"
The LORD has broken the staff of the wicked, and the scepter of the rulers.
He who struck the people in wrath with a continuous blow, he who ruled the nations in anger, is persecuted, and no one hinders.
The whole earth is at rest and quiet: they break forth into singing.
Indeed, the fir trees rejoice at your downfall, and the cedars of Lebanon, saying, "Since you have fallen, no lumberjack has come up against us."
Hell from beneath is stirred up to meet you at your coming: it stirs up the dead for you, even all the chief ones of the earth; it has raised up from their thrones all the kings of the nations.
All of them shall speak and say to you, "Are you also become weak like us? Are you become like us?"
Your pomp is brought down to the grave, and the sound of your harps: the worm is spread under you, and the worms cover you.
How you have fallen from heaven, O Lucifer, son of the morning! How you are cut down to the ground, you who weakened the nations!
For you have said in your heart, "I will ascend into heaven, I will exalt my throne above the stars of God: I will also sit upon the mount of the congregation, on the sides of the north:
I will ascend above the heights of the clouds; I will be like the Most High."
Yet you shall be brought down to hell, to the sides of the pit.
Those who see you shall narrowly look upon you, and consider you, saying, "Is this the man who made the earth tremble, who shook kingdoms;
Who made the world like a wilderness, and destroyed its cities; who did not open the house of his prisoners?"
All the kings of the nations, even all of them, lie in glory, every one in his own house.

But you are cast out of your grave like an abominable branch, and like the clothing of those who are slain, thrust through with a sword, who go down to the stones of the pit; like a carcass trampled underfoot.
You shall not be joined with them in burial, because you have destroyed your land, and slain your people: the seed of evildoers shall never be renowned.
Prepare slaughter for his children for the iniquity of their fathers; that they do not rise, nor possess the land, nor fill the face of the world with cities.
For I will rise up against them, says the LORD of hosts, and cut off from Babylon the name, and remnant, and son, and nephew, says the LORD.
I will also make it a possession for the bittern, and pools of water: and I will sweep it with the broom of destruction, says the LORD of hosts.
The LORD of hosts has sworn, saying, "Surely as I have thought, so shall it come to pass; and as I have purposed, so shall it stand:
